DOC.HEAD: Stormie Upgraded to Serious Condition
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 4 grafs to UPDATE with girl upgraded to serious condition. Picks up 5th graf pvs, `She had...'
DOC.TEXT: Stormie Jones, the world's first heart-liver transplant patient, was upgraded to serious condition Monday as she continued to recover from her second liver transplant. Stormie, 12, of White Settlement, Texas, was moved from the intensive care unit of Children's Hospital of Pittsburgh to a regular hospital room. ``She's doing well. She regaining her strength quickly,'' said hospital spokeswoman Lynn McMahon. Stormie was listed as critical Sunday afternoon, but was upgraded to critical but stable after she was taken off a respirator about 7 p.m. and was breathing on her own, Ms. McMahon said. She had been placed back on a respirator Friday after fluid began collecting in her lungs. Stormie received her second liver transplant a week ago Tuesday. She returned to the operating room the next day, when doctors operated to halt internal bleeding. Her first transplant, in 1984, was needed to control effects of a rare disease that left her cholesterol levels 10 times greater than normal. The second operation resulted from permanent liver damage caused by hepatitis. Her donor heart has remained healthy, doctors said.

DOC.HEAD: Writer Henry Fairlie Dies
DOC.TEXT: Henry Fairlie, a writer and contributing editor for the New Republic, is dead of a heart attack and stroke. He was 66. Fairlie worked as a feature writer for the Observer newspaper in his native London and later was an editorial writer for the Times of London. He had been a free lance since 1954, writing for The New York Times, Harper's, the Atlantic, The Washington Post and other publications. He also was the author of books on political affairs, including ``The Spoiled Child of the Western World,'' ``The Kennedy Promise,'' and ``The Seven Deadly Sins Today.'' Fairlie considered the political reputation of Sen. Edward M. Kennedy, D-Mass., greater than the senator deserved, and his writing on that subject prompted outraged letters to the New Republic. Fairlie devoted his last published column to the discovery of contamination in Perrier water. He urged his readers to drink Scotch whisky, ``made from nutritious whole grains,'' and pronounced: ``No scotch has ever been found to be contaminated.'' He died Sunday at George Washington University Hospital. He is survived by his wife, three children and five grandchildren.

DOC.HEAD: Witness to Drug Killing Slain Before Trial
DOC.TEXT: A man who saw his companion die in a hail of bullets allegedly fired by a drug gang was himself slain earlier this month, apparently to make sure he did not testify against those accused in the woman's murder, according to a published report. John Shelton, 43, was gunned down Feb. 7 by a rifle-bearing ski-masked killer who police believe was a hired hit man, The New York Times reported in Tuesday editions, quoting unidentified investigators. Shelton had witnessed the death of Maxine Peterson, who was hit by gunfire nearly two years ago as she stood holding her baby in the kitchen of her home in the New York City borough of Queens. Shelton had been living with Ms. Peterson at the time. He was to testify in the trial of Ms. Peterson's accused murderers, which began Monday in state Supreme Court in Queens. The prosecution and the defense presented opening statements without mentioning Shelton. Michael Bethea, 18, was indicted in Shelton's murder. On trial in Ms. Peterson's murder are Gary Steadman, 24, Kevin Gaines, 27, Raymond Blair, 21, and Keenan Wynn, 21. Shelton's murder is apparently the latest case of a witness being murdered or menaced in Queens. Mildred Greene, 61, a dispatcher for a car service, was shot to death in 1987 after testifying before a grand jury about a gun battle that took place outside the car service office. In another case, the home of a Guyanese immigrant was firebombed twice after he complained about drug dealers. A police officer, Edward Byrne, was later murdered while he guarded the house.

DOC.HEAD: Youth Judged Nation's `Safest Teenage Driver' Killed in Accident
DOC.TEXT: A youth driving a car he won for being named the nation's safest teen-age driver may have fallen asleep at the wheel before he and another driver were killed in a two-car accident, police said. A car driven by Michael Doucette, 17, of Concord, drifted over the center line and slammed into one being driven by Sharon Ann Link, 19, of Lebanon, according to police reports. Both were pronounced dead at the scene Friday evening. Police said it appeared Link may have tried to swerve out of the way before the collision in the extreme right side of her lane. ``Preliminary investigation shows (Doucette) may have fallen asleep at the wheel,'' the police report said. A passenger in the Link vehicle was in stable condition Sunday at Concord Hospital. Last July, Doucette won the safe driving title in a contest called ``Operation Driver Excellence,'' sponsored by Dodge and AMVETS, a veterans' group. He won a $5,000 scholarship, a trophy and the use for a year of an 1989 Dodge _ the car he was driving Friday. Doucette, driving the winning car, was one of the attractions in a New Year's Eve parade down Concord's Main Street. Concord High School Principal Charles Foley was shaken by the news. ``He was just a fine kid from a good family,'' Foley said. ``It's heartbreaking.'' After winning the competition last year, Doucette said the contest was ``like a driver's test, only a lot harder.''

Portrait of Beardless Abraham Lincoln Discovered
LaserPhoto NY36
DOC.TEXT: A portrait of a beardless Abraham Lincoln _ the first portrait ever painted of him _ has been discovered by a collector of Lincoln memorabilia, American Heritage magazine reported. The portrait appears in the magazine's March issue. It was painted from life in 1856 by Dr. Philip O. Jenkins, a physician and amateur artist, before Lincoln was nationally known, collectors James L. Swanson and Lloyd Ostendorf said. Lincoln became president in 1861. Swanson tracked down the portrait in the Illinois home of an 86-year-old distant relative of the artist. ``There, at the end of the parlor, was Abraham Lincoln, sixteenth president of the United States,'' he writes. ``But this was not bearded Father Abraham, the Great Emancipator and Civil War president,'' Swanson said. ``It was the image of another man, Abe Lincoln of Illinois, prominent lawyer and ambitious politician. ``The canvas captured Lincoln as he would have looked in his office, in court, or at a political event on any day in the 1850s _ clean-shaven, wearing a dark frock coat, white shirt and tie.'' The article describes the processes Swanson went through to verify his finding.

DOC.HEAD: ASNE Names Five National Journalism Winners
DOC.TEXT: The American Society of Newspaper Editors has announced five winners of its 1989 Distinguished Writing Awards. The journalists, selected from among 500 applicants, will receive cash awards of $2,500 each during the ASNE's annual convention, April 3-6. The winners, announced Sunday, are: _ Terrie Claflin, staff writer for the Medford (Ore.) Mail Tribune for non-deadline writing. Claflin wrote four stories that chronicled the short life of a brain-damaged foster child whose biological mother is a drug addict. _ Diana Griego Erwin, columnist for the Orange County Register, Santa Ana, Calif., for commentary and column writing. Her columns included one about a Hispanic laborer who had difficulty getting a driver's license because of his poor English. _ Samuel Francis, The Washington Times, for editorial writing. Some of the editorials written by Francis, who won the award for the second straight year, focused on conservative themes such as support for legislation establishing a review process for the National Endowment for the Arts. _ Linnet Myers, reporter for the Chicago Tribune, state and local government reporting. Myers wrote a three-part series reviewing the parade of people through Chicago's criminal court system. _ David Von Drehle, reporter for the Miami Herald, deadline writing. Von Drehle was cited for his first-person account of Hurricane Hugo's assault on Charleston, S.C.

DOC.HEAD: Political Groups Splintered Before March Elections
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Inside the former local Communist Party headquarters, 17 opposition groups work under the same roof but with different visions of how to rebuild East Germany after the nation's first free elections next month. Environmentalists, feminists, the well-known New Forum and even a lone conservative group all rent office space from the Communists in the neo-Gothic building, renamed Democracy House after the Communists moved out in January. ``It's a little chaotic here,'' campaign worker Jana Reuter of New Forum said Friday. ``It's taking a while to get the hang of things.'' Others praise the camaraderie and conveniences of similar groups working under one roof. ``For groups that work together, being in one building has big advantages,'' said Thomas Voit of the leftist-oriented party Democracy Now. ``It's easy to meet quickly and exchange ideas or discuss campaign details.'' With less than three weeks to go before the March 18 elections, Democracy House's winding halls are buzzing with commotion. On the third floor Friday night, the conservative party Democratic Awakening was having an organizational meeting. One floor higher, leaders of the East German Greens gathered. It sometimes seems there's a party or group for everyone. The Social Democrats want to follow in the footsteps of their Western counterparts, led by Willy Brandt. They are leading in the polls. There are Christian Democrats, Free Democrats and the Communists, although the latter have changed their name to the pleasant-sounding Party of Democratic Socialism as they seek to break from their Stalinist past. But there are others as well, including the United Leftists, the Independent Women's Association and the Initiative for Peace and Human Rights. Under present laws in East Germany, a political organization does not have to be a party to run for or hold office. Some have warned that the splintering could lead to an inability to govern. West German Interior Minister Wolfgang Schaeuble has cautioned the United States that difficulties are expected in forming an East German government. ``It is conceivable that there will be no more (East German) government after March 18,'' the Bonn daily newspaper Die Welt on Friday quoted Schaeuble as saying. Some groups in Democracy House say they are aware of the confusion but don't know how else to manage, given the brief time until the elections _ and the pressing problems East Germany must begin solving. Throughout East Germany, groups and organizations have been running campaigns from makeshift offices, many of them lacking essentials like typewriters, to say nothing of photocopying machines. ``We're not pleased to have to work under so much pressure with so little time,'' said Pastor Rainer Eppelmann, himself one of the founding members of the pro-democracy movement and a minister in the current caretaker government. His Democratic Awakening party has helped lessen the splintering somewhat by forming an election alliance with two other conservative parties. The alliance is supported by West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl's Christian Democratic Union. The alliance favors establishing a market-oriented economy, monetary union and unification with West Germany as soon as possible. ``Socialism Never Again!'' is one of its slogans. Three leftist-oriented groups in Democracy House also have formed an alliance. New Forum and the Initiative for Peace and Human Rights have teamed up with Democracy Now to form Buendnis 90 (Alliance '90). ``A market-oriented economy, yes _ but not as a dismantling of social security. Unification, yes _ but not as annexation,'' Alliance '90 says in a campaign paper. The heady rush toward democracy in East Germany has forced the emerging political groups to learn about democracy on the run. ``From the point of view of party organization, it would have been better to hold the elections later,'' Eppelmann said with a sigh. ``But considering the dynamic rate of developments here, the March 18 date is a good thing.''

DOC.HEAD: Second Bomb Goes Off Outside Military Recruiting Office
DOC.TEXT: A bomb exploded at an army recruiting office in this town northwest of London five days after a similar attack in central England for which the IRA claimed responsibility, police said today. Police in West Yorkshire, about 200 miles northwest of London, said the recruiting office was empty at the time of the blast Sunday night. They said the blast damaged the front door and a window but injured no one. No one claimed responsibility for that attack. On Tuesday, a bomb injured two people in the central England town of Leicester when it went off under an army vehicle which had just driven away from a recruiting office. The outlawed Irish Republican Army later said it planted the Leicester bomb. After that explosion, Commander George Churchill-Coleman, head of Scotland Yard's anti-terrorist squad, warned military personnel and people in public life to beware of bombings in mainland Britain by the IRA, which is fighting to end British rule in Northern Ireland. In September, an IRA bomb killed 10 members of a band at the Marine barracks in Deal in southeast England.

DOC.HEAD: Seven Killed at Wake In Apparent Gang Violence
DOC.TEXT: Gunmen armed with automatic rifles burst into a wake and shot to death seven men, including a brother of the man being mourned, police said. The police said they believed Sunday's attack in the Seaview section of Kingston stemmed from a feud between rival youth gangs. They said the gunmen were armed with M-16 assault rifles and other semi-automatic weapons. The attackers raided the wake before dawn Sunday, forcing seven of the 50 people present to lie on the floor and shooting them in the head, police said. The national security minister, Keith D. Knight, said the police had launched a manhunt for the killers. Prime Minister Michael Manley, in a statement issued Sunday night, condemned the killings as ``senseless and heinous.''

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: Spike Lee says sex, not race, will generate a lot of heat in his new film, ``Mo' Better Blues.'' ``The audience may squirm,'' Lee said in the March 5 issue of People magazine. The $10 million film starring Denzel Washington is about a trumpet player torn between his love of music and his desire for two women, a singer played by Cynda Williams and a Harlem schoolteacher played by Lee's sister, Joie. Joie Lee said she had no problem working with her brother in scenes that called for nudity. ``When he said, `Okay, take off your top,' I just did it. It's not perverse,'' she said. Williams said the love scenes are tasteful, ``but when I think of going to see the movie with my parents and grandparents, it freaks me out.'' Lee's last film, ``Do the Right Thing,'' examined racism with a tragic confrontation at a pizza parlor.

Former Olympic skier Suzy Chaffee has been touring the country speaking out against animal-rights activists who would ban the sale of fur coats. For the past three years, Chaffee, 43, has helped design and promote a collection of fur-lined skiwear called Suzy Chaffee Sport Furs. She spoke in Aspen, Colo., before the recent defeat of a proposed ordinance that would have banned the sale of furs in the resort community, and has been appearing on talk shows. ``My credibility is very important to me, and I feel I am really being responsible to the animals and to nature and to the environment because trapping them is better than letting them die the disease-and-starvation route,'' she said. Chaffee, better known to the public as ``Suzy Chapstick'' because of her television commercial for lip balm, skied in the 1968 Winter Olympics and was a three-time world freestyle champion.

So what should Marla Maples, the alleged ``other woman'' in billionaire Donald Trump's marital mess, expect from her involvement in the scuffle? Not much, said some other ``other'' women interviewed by People magazine in its March 5 issue. After word of her sexual liaison with television evangelist Jim Bakker, Jessica Hahn posed for Playboy for $1 million, was host of a mud-wrestling contest and now receives at least $2,000 for personal appearances. But Hahn told Maples, ``Unless he's prepared to marry you, and I don't think he is, you're better off just keeping your feet on the ground and pursuing your career.'' ``Nothing can beat paying your own bills,'' Hahn said. Lobbyist Paula Parkinson, whose alleged relationship with Delaware Rep. Thomas Evans cost him his congressional seat, also posed for Playboy but rejected a television movie offer. Her advice to Maples? ``If you are having an affair, it's going to end, darling. It doesn't turn into love and marriage.''

Andrew Young, who is trying to become Georgia's first black governor, took to the pulpit at a rural Baptist church where the whites were the Sunday regulars and the blacks were the guests. The service at the First Baptist Church was a twist on the decades of white politicians' preaching at black churches, with white visitors sitting in the pews. Young, a former ambassador to the United Nations and a former Atlanta mayor, is a Congregationalist minister. He took his text from Paul's letter to the Ephesians: ``For he is our peace, who has made us both one, and has broken down the dividing wall of hostility.'' During the sermon, Young spoke of a ``transformation of our politics'' that has worn out the metaphor of America as a melting pot. ``We're all in the same pot, but it is not so much like a least common denominator soup. It is more like a stew _ our differences only enhance and enrich,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Romania Violent Revolution Most Chaotic in East Bloc
AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: The Romanian revolution has been the bloodiest and most chaotic of the upheavals in the Soviet bloc. Some of the turmoil seems to stem from the nation's history of brutal authoritarianism, but government critics say mistakes by Romania's new leaders have also played a role. Two months after its anti-Communist uprising, Romania's fragile governing coalition is struggling to keep the peace. Several violent demonstrations saw hundreds of people storm government headquarters. On Wednesday, a National Peasants Party official said two party activists had been killed in recent weeks, apparently for political reasons. In May elections, that traditionally anti-Communist party will likely prove the strongest challenger to the National Salvation Front. The front took power after the overthrow and execution of President Nicolae Ceausescu and has since added other parties to its provisional government. None of the other five rapidly democratizing countries in the East bloc have seen the violence Romania has. Hundreds, perhaps thousands, are thought to have died in revolutionary battles pitting revolutionaries against Ceausescu. No other country, however, had a Ceausescu. Under a quarter-century of his rule, Romania's 23 million people slid deep into economic misery and suffered political repression unmatched elsewhere in the bloc. Before Ceausescu, Romania was under the control of one dictator or another for most of its 2,000-year history, save for 60 years of political pluralism at the turn of the century. The effect of the long period of despotism was to rob Romanians of even the slim experience with democracy that many other Eastern European countries had. After World War II, under Ceausescu, the Communist dictator's repression of government opponents wiped out any major opposition leaders who could fill the power vacuum after his downfall Dec. 22. Other Eastern European nations had at least some strong dissidents who survived their Communist regimes. ``Ceausescu's disastrous political legacy is still haunting us,'' Octavian Paler, a leading writer and editor of the newspaper Romania Libera, said in a recent editorial. ``We must pay a high price for the lack of a non-Communist opposition: suspicion, fear and little democratic tradition historically.'' After the revolution, rivalries broke out between supporters of the National Salvation Front and its opponents. A loose grouping of ex-Communists, technocrats and former dissidents, the front ran the country alone for a few weeks. But its initial reluctance to share power enraged major opposition parties and wide sectors of the population, who feared the relatively high proportion of Communists in its ranks made it a possible vehicle for a new totalitarian takeover. The front was eventually forced to share power with nearly 40 new political parties. Suspicion of front motives increased after interim president and front leader Ion Iliescu said the group _ which most people viewed as only an interim government _ would take part in the May 20 elections. Initially, it had said it had no plans to do so. Following a violent pro-front demonstration Jan. 29, several opposition parties accused the front of Communist tactics, such as busing in truckloads of supporters, blaming the other parties for violence and buying support with money and whiskey. The front moved to redress many grievances during its six-week tenure as the country's sole government. It replaced Ceausescu's most hated laws, opened the borders for Romanians to travel, allowed protest demonstrations, lifted censorship and released political and ordinary prisoners. But even those moves drew criticism. ``They let free the thieves and ordinary criminals and now it's dangerous to move around freely after sunset,'' said Marin Stelian, a Bucharest typographer. Adding to the distrust is fear that vestiges of the horrible past continue to exist. A group of 46 intellectuals expressed worry in early February that Securitate secret policemen who terrorized the country under Ceausescu still wield secret power. In an open letter to the new Council of National Unity, which is to act as a parliament until the elections, the intellectuals said nobody can talk about the victory of the revolution ``when fear, physical and psychological threats go on.'' The depth of concern about the future was evident in remarks made by Iliescu in the wake of the Feb. 18 demonstration, in which some soldiers attempting to keep the mob away from government headquarters were injured. ``If the army and police don't have the legal ability to maintain order, people will feel it necessary to defend themselves _ we could become like Lebanon, and anarchy could lead us to total chaos,'' he said in a public address. Romania's only previous brush with democracy occurred in a 60-year span that began in the 1880s. Political parties were allowed to operate under a constitutional monarchy, but even then the king remained the main figure in decision-making until the Nazi takeover in 1940 and full totalitarianism.
Viorel Urma, now based in Vienna, worked for 14 years for The Associated Press in Bucharest.

DOC.HEAD: State Suffers Public Relations Fiasco in Medfly Spraying Program
DOC.TEXT: B.T. Collins says he's living proof that malathion poses no health risks to Southern Californians, whose neighborhoods are being sprayed with the pesticide to wipe out the crop-destroying Medfly. As head of the California Conservation Corps during a 1981 Medfly infestation, Collins was so sure malathion was safe that he drank a diluted glass of it in front of corps members wary about picking malathion-sprayed fruit. ``I offered to do it again,'' said Collins, now an alive-and-well state chief deputy treasurer. ``I don't think the citizens in Los Angeles have a clue as to how disastrous it could be if that fly gets to Bakersfield,'' at the foot of the agriculturally-rich Central Valley. Perhaps the state should consider taking him up on his offer. Little else has persuaded Southern Californians that aerial malathion spraying should continue to protect agricultural areas from the Mediterranean fruit fly. As one city after another joined the revolt last week against the aerial spraying, state officials were faced with a severe credibility gap and no apparent sign of converting the dubious. Critics and supporters of the spraying say the public relations effort has suffered from a late start, some bad press, a media-savvy opposition and mixed and muddled messages from officials. ``I'll tell you, they lost an enormous amount of credibility in Pasadena,'' said city director Rick Cole, who complained the state broke its promise to finish spraying before commuters leave in the morning for work. The Department of Food and Agriculture ordered the spraying of 400 square miles following the discovery of Mediterranean fruit flies last August. Officials say the eradication program is needed to protect California's $16.5 billion agricultural business. They also say the sticky mixture of malathion and corn syrup bait poses no health risk in small, heavily diluted doses. A third of an ounce of the mixture is dropped over an entire city block. ``It's safe. It's safe. It's safe. We've been saying it over and over again,'' said Gera Curry, a Food and Agriculture Department spokeswoman. But Southern Californians aren't buying the message. A recent Los Angeles Times poll found that 57 percent of Los Angeles and Orange County residents want the spraying stopped, and only one in seven strongly support it. Part of the problem, critics said, is that the state failed to spend enough time explaining its position on health risks and did not listen to concerns before the spraying began. State officials said they had to move quickly because any delay in spraying _ even under court order _ could prove fatal for farming. ``The Medfly won't wait for a temporary restraining order,'' said Dr. Peter Kurtz, a senior medical coordinator with the Food and Agriculture Department. While the state hurried to spray, opponents built momentum. They were aided by media reports damaging the state's position, including charges by the coauthor of a state study who said it was edited to understate the health risks. The report was often cited to support claims that malathion is safe. In recent weeks, a grass-roots effort led mainly by concerned homeowners has grabbed attention by recruiting famous faces, such as most of the cast of television's ``Cheers.'' Politicians responded by holding public hearings on malathion spraying, and scientists countered the official line that malathion is absolutely safe. ``I think that aerial spraying in densely populated areas is absolutely ridiculous,'' said Dr. Donald Dahlsten, a University of California-Berkeley entomologist in testimony before the Los Angeles City Council. The state also has used scientists as spokespeople, but that has posed its own problems: Scientists are reluctant to speak outside of their area of expertise or to give the kind of absolute assurances nervous people want. ``If you're a scientist you don't use the word `safe,''' said Ms. Curry, the agriculture department spokeswoman. ``The word `safe' is not in a scientist's vocabulary.''

DOC.HEAD: Hundreds of Thousands Rally Across Soviet Union Despite Intimidation Tactics
LaserPhotos NY5,6
DOC.TEXT: Despite ominous government warnings and a high police profile, pro-democracy activists marched by the hundreds of thousands in more than 30 Soviet cities to demand an end to one-party Communist rule. The rallies Sunday, unprecedented in scope in the Communists' 72-year rule, came a day after voters in the independence-minded republic of Lithuania apparently stripped the Communists of their parliamentary majority. The day also saw republic-wide elections in another restive republic _ Moldavia. A series of official warnings last week that extremists would provoke violence kept the turnout low in some cities Sunday and prevented some protests altogether. Riot police dragged away people who tried to hold an unsanctioned demonstration in Leningrad, but there were no reports of major unrest. ``We heard about tanks, about police waiting with gas and shovels,'' said a middle-aged woman who was not deterred from demonstrating Sunday in Moscow along with more than 100,000 people. Thousands of uniformed police and internal security troops guarded the authorized march route in Moscow. Sand-filled dump trucks, water trucks and snowplows blocked all approaches to the Kremlin. About 17,000 police and Interior Ministry troops stood by with nightsticks and water cannons, eventually relaxing and stashing their riot gear. ``All was against us,'' Gavril Popov, a member of the Congress of People's Deputies, told the crowd in Moscow's Zubovsky Square. He accused the Communist Party and state apparatus of engineering a campaign of fear not seen since Stalin in an attempt to thwart the outpouring of popular sentiment for a swift change to democracy. Demonstrators demanded democratic reforms ranging from direct popular election of the president to the establishment of private property and creation of a multiparty system. One demonstrator charged that the Sunday morning broadcast of a Polish science-fiction film called ``The Sex Mission'' _ with nudity rare on Soviet TV _ was a deliberate attempt to entice people to stay home. The protests were planned after a successful Feb. 4 pro-democracy rally in Moscow in which about 200,000 people demanded the Communist Party give up its monopoly on power. Party leaders voted to do so shortly afterward, but the day when the Communists must compete with other parties for the right to run the country appears far off to many Soviets. The Communists, with their long-established omnipresent patronage system, still firmly control the government and economy nearly everywhere. Reports from police, local activists interviewed by telephone and state-run media indicated as many as 276,000 people took part in protest rallies in 32 cities outside Moscow, from Petropavlovsk-Kamchatky in the Soviet Far East to Leningrad on the Baltic Sea coast. In Moscow, red, blue and white flags of czarist Russia fluttered along with red and black flags of anarchists and the sky-blue cross on a white background of the Memorial Society, which is dedicated to remembering Stalin's victims. ``General, are you with the people?'' shouted a woman in the crowd to a stocky Interior Ministry officer directing crowd control at Gorky Park, one of the gathering points for the march. ``Sure, I am!'' replied Maj. Gen. Georgy Postoyuk. Contrary to widespread rumors that authorities planned to provoke violence to justify a crackdown, he said officials worked closely with rally organizers and the result was ``a very good, orderly meeting.'' Speakers urged demonstrators to endorse progressive candidates running in March 4 parliamentary elections in the Russian federation and demanded the ouster of members of the ruling Politburo and Council of Ministers, as well as KGB chief Vladimir A. Kryuchkov. With a show of hands, the crowd voted in support of a platform presented by historian and parliament deputy Yuri Afanasyev that proposed a direct presidential election, the establishment of private property and turning over state media from party control to editorial collectives. ``We're fed up with how we live,'' said one demonstrator, Celestine Langovaya, a music teacher in her 50s. ``When (Mikhail S.) Gorbachev first came to power, I believed in him, but things have gotten worse for millions of people.'' The Novosti Press Agency said 100,000 people gathered in Minsk, the Byelorussian capital, for the largest turnout reported outside the Soviet capital. Only about 8,000 demonstrators showed up at the officially authorized rally site in Leningrad, the nation's second-largest city. Leaders of the pro-independence People's Front movement there had urged followers to boycott the event because authorities would not grant permission to demonstrate on a downtown street. Riot police far outnumbered a small group that did try to demonstrate in downtown Leningrad without official permission. Officers broke up the attempted protest and dragged demonstrators aboard waiting buses. Authorities in the southern Russian city of Rostov-on-Don refused to allow rallies, and about 100 dismayed activists gathered near the local Communist headquarters to hand out leaflets, the official Tass news agency said. Military authorities in Azerbaijan banned all demonstrations, fearing a renewal of the nationalist violence that led to ethnic warfare between Armenians and Azerbaijanis in January. About 2,000 were said to have gathered in the central Siberian city of Krasnoyarsk, but activists there said many people went to the wrong places because state-controlled media had refused to report plans for the rally. Elsewhere, local activists said 50,000 people rallied in Georgia's capital of Tbilisi and 12,000 in the large Siberian city of Novosibirsk. Another 18,000 people attended two rallies in the Urals city of Sverdlovsk, they said. Demonstrators in Tbilisi tore down street signs of a street named after Lenin and renamed it for a Georgian dissident killed in a car crash last year, a political activist said. About 50,000 Ukrainians gathered in Kiev, said Victor Linchevsky, a spokesman for the grass-roots organization Rukh. On Saturday, Lithuanian voters appeared to have chosen the country's first legislature not dominated by Communists. Unofficial returns showed that of the 90 races decided, candidates endorsed by the Sajudis reform movement took 72 seats and non-Sajudis candidates took 18, said Rita Dapkus, head of the Sajudis information agency. Moldavians voted Sunday in their first free elections under Soviet rule and expressed hopes their new Parliament would be able to win greater sovereignty from Moscow.

DOC.HEAD: State Suffers Public Relations Fiasco in Medfly Spraying Program
DOC.TEXT: B.T. Collins says he's living proof that malathion poses no health risks to Southern Californians, whose neighborhoods are being sprayed with the pesticide to wipe out the crop-destroying Medfly. As head of the California Conservation Corps during a 1981 Medfly infestation, Collins was so sure malathion was safe that he drank a diluted glass of it in front of corps members wary about picking malathion-sprayed fruit. ``I offered to do it again,'' said Collins, now an alive-and-well state chief deputy treasurer. ``I don't think the citizens in Los Angeles have a clue as to how disastrous it could be if that fly gets to Bakersfield,'' at the foot of the agriculturally-rich Central Valley. Perhaps the state should consider taking him up on his offer. Little else has persuaded Southern Californians that aerial malathion spraying should continue to protect agricultural areas from the Mediterranean fruit fly. As one city after another joined the revolt last week against the aerial spraying, state officials were faced with a severe credibility gap and no apparent sign of converting the dubious. Critics and supporters of the spraying say the public relations effort has suffered from a late start, some bad press, a media-savvy opposition and mixed and muddled messages from officials. ``I'll tell you, they lost an enormous amount of credibility in Pasadena,'' said city director Rick Cole, who complained the state broke its promise to finish spraying before commuters leave in the morning for work. The Department of Food and Agriculture ordered the spraying of 400 square miles following the discovery of Mediterranean fruit flies last August. Officials say the eradication program is needed to protect California's $16.5 billion agricultural business. They also say the sticky mixture of malathion and corn syrup bait poses no health risk in small, heavily diluted doses. A third of an ounce of the mixture is dropped over an entire city block. ``It's safe. It's safe. It's safe. We've been saying it over and over again,'' said Gera Curry, a Food and Agriculture Department spokeswoman. But Southern Californians aren't buying the message. A recent Los Angeles Times poll found that 57 percent of Los Angeles and Orange County residents want the spraying stopped, and only one in seven strongly support it. Part of the problem, critics said, is that the state failed to spend enough time explaining its position on health risks and did not listen to concerns before the spraying began. State officials said they had to move quickly because any delay in spraying _ even under court order _ could prove fatal for farming. ``The Medfly won't wait for a temporary restraining order,'' said Dr. Peter Kurtz, a senior medical coordinator with the Food and Agriculture Department. While the state hurried to spray, opponents built momentum. They were aided by media reports damaging the state's position, including charges by the coauthor of a state study who said it was edited to understate the health risks. The report was often cited to support claims that malathion is safe. In recent weeks, a grass-roots effort led mainly by concerned homeowners has grabbed attention by recruiting famous faces, such as most of the cast of television's ``Cheers.'' Politicians responded by holding public hearings on malathion spraying, and scientists countered the official line that malathion is absolutely safe. ``I think that aerial spraying in densely populated areas is absolutely ridiculous,'' said Dr. Donald Dahlsten, a University of California-Berkeley entomologist in testimony before the Los Angeles City Council. The state also has used scientists as spokespeople, but that has posed its own problems: Scientists are reluctant to speak outside of their area of expertise or to give the kind of absolute assurances nervous people want. ``If you're a scientist you don't use the word `safe,''' said Ms. Curry, the agriculture department spokeswoman. ``The word `safe' is not in a scientist's vocabulary.''

DOC.HEAD: Nikkei Takes Second-Largest Tumble Ever
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 3 grafs to UPDATE with market close; picks up 4th pvs, `The market's ...'
DOC.TEXT: The key index on the Tokyo Stock Exchange took its second-largest tumble ever Monday, representing to many dealers the beginning of an anticipated collapse of artificially high stock values here. The 225-share Nikkei Stock Average shed 1,569.10 points, or 4.5 percent, to fall to 33,321.87 at the close of the trading day. This was the index's second largest decline in points and the lowest it has fallen since July 5, 1989, when it closed at 33,309.71 points. Volume was light at 400 million shares on the first section. The market's main index dropped 2,569.35 points, or 6.86 percent, last week, and 4,024.9 points, or 10.34 percent, since the beginning of the year until Monday. In Washington, a U.S. official said Sunday night that the Treasury Department and Federal Reserve were monitoring the situation on the Tokyo stock exchange but that no special actions had been taken by U.S. authorities. Kazuhiro Nomura of New Japan Securities Co. said the stock market's plunge in the last week showed that ``the bubble phenomenon had finally burst.'' Stock purchasing by investors on borrowed cash at low interest rates had inflated share values, he said. But a sharp rise in interest rates last year spelled an end to obtaining easy cash. The Bank of Japan, the nation's central bank, raised the key discount rate three times last year, and it now stands at 4.25 percent. Ken Schoenholtz, an economist for Solomon Brothers Asia Ltd., said share prices have been out of line with the higher interest rates instituted by the Bank of Japan last year. The decline in the Nikkei shows ``the market getting adjusted to high yields that are likely to stay,'' Schoenholtz said. The benchmark 10-year Japanese government bond was at 7 percent at midday, up slightly from its 6.98 percent opening. ``With the dollar trading at 148.45 yen, we expect a further decline in bond prices, especially with an auction coming up tomorrow,'' said Doug Schumway, a trader at Jardine Fleming Securities in Tokyo. Trading was light. The possibility of a substantial decline, Schumway said, would depend on the volatility of the foreign exchange market. Dealers have also attributed the continuing fall in the Nikkei to fears of an additional interest rate hike by Japan's central bank and a wave of computer-aided selling by arbitrageurs. They said an increase in the Bank of Japan's discount rate is expected shortly because of higher inflation in recent months and rapid growth in the money supply. Japanese market participants have also singled out the growing usage of program arbitrage trading by foreign securities companies as contributing to increased market volatility. In arbitrage trading, dealers profit from differences in prices for the same security in different markets, for instance, the spot and future markets. Some dealers have even singled the two U.S. securities firms Solomon Brothers and Morgan Stanley as the principal users of arbitrage trading in Japan. But Solomon's Schoenholtz disagreed that program selling was responsible for the fall in the Nikkei. ``I doubt that you'd see such extreme market movements that weren't related to the fundamentals,'' he said. Schoenholtz said the decline represented that compression of the earnings yield gap between the equity and bond markets. As of the middle of last week, he said, the yield on stock issues averaged 1.5 percent, whereas the yield on bonds was as high as 7 percent. ``Three percent gaps in yield have been sustained for a considerable amount of time, but 5 percent have not,'' he added. On the foreign exchange market, the dollar was quoted at 148.50 yen, up 2.03 yen, at 12:29 p.m. After opening at 147.50 yen, the currency moved between 147.72 yen and 148.70 yen. ``Participants have no confidence in buying the yen because of negative factors involving the currency,'' said Junichi Kodama, a trader with Chemical Bank in Tokyo. Political uncertainties and the Tokyo Stock Exchange's crash of last week are the major reasons that many investors are staying away from the Japanese currency, he added. The Bank of Japan bank was seen Monday morning making a dollar-selling intervention in the Sydney market before the Tokyo market opened, in an attempt to support the declining yen. The amount of selling was not clear because the bank does not comment officially on its monetary activities.

DOC.HEAD: Bush, Kohl Say United Germany Would Remain in NATO
DOC.TEXT: President Bush and West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl, following ``extraordinarily frank'' talks at Camp David, say the world has nothing to fear from a united Germany and promise it will stay tethered to the Western military alliance. Emerging Sunday from two days of talks at the presidential retreat, Bush and Kohl sought to allay fears from Moscow to Warsaw to London that the two Germanys are marching to the altar too rapidly. Bush said they shared ``a common belief that a unified Germany should remain a full member of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, including participation in its military structure,'' but with ``a special military status'' for the territory of what is now East Germany. Kohl, without mentioning NATO by name, said, ``The alliance of free democracies in Europe and North America ... are of fundamental importance for peace and security. This is true now. This will be true in the future.'' Kohl also ruled out a Warsaw Pact connection for the new Germany, saying, ``A united Germany cannot belong to two different pact systems.'' He added, ``We will have transition situations'' which will have to be negotiated. The Soviets now have 380,000 troops stationed in East Germany, which holds parliamentary elections March 18 that are expected to speed the union of East and West Germany. Kohl reiterated that a neutral Germany is out of the question. ``Neutralism would be a very false solution,'' said Kohl, adding that his country learned that lesson the hard way after World War I. The isolation of the Weimar Republic was followed by the terror and militarism of Hitler's Third Reich. Poland, decimated by the Nazis in World War II, has expressed fear a united Germany might demand old lands back. On that score, Bush said the United States regards the current European borders, including Germany's long border with Poland, as inviolable. Kohl said the border question ``will be settled definitely by a free elected all-German government and a freely elected all-German parliament.'' He said he cannot speak now for what the German state will decide. But Kohl emphasized, ``nobody has any intention of linking the question of national unity with changes in existing borders.'' Bush said the U.S. position ``is not to be afraid of German reunification,'' but to understand the longing of the German people to end the artificial division imposed after World War II. ``We've already crossed that bridge. We welcome reunification. But it's not for the United States to set a timetable. It's not for us to say how fast,'' said Bush, who acknowledged that events ``are moving faster than we expected.'' He called the talks with Kohl ``extraordinarily frank.'' Both leaders said they saw no need to add Poland to the group of four nations that will discuss reunification with the two German states. Poland, like East Germany, has abandoned its communist monopoly government. The allies which defeated Germany in World War II _ The United States, Soviet Union, Great Britain and France _ have agreed to convene meetings that are likely to lead to a unified Germany, perhaps as soon as this year. Bush and Kohl fielded questions from reporters for nearly an hour in a recreation hall at Camp Greentop, just down the road from Camp David atop the Catoctin Mountains of Maryland. Kohl said West Germany had proven its commitment to democracy in the last 40 years as ``a loyal and reliable partner in human rights and the defense of freedom.'' He said he had put his own political existence on the line in supporting the deployment of U.S. Pershing missiles in West Germany in 1983. Kohl also noted that he favors ``the political union of Europe'' and ceding more authority to the European parliament. ``In other words, we want this united Germany to be ever more embedded in an integration process with its neighbors. So nobody needs to be afraid,'' said Kohl. Bush, asked what he would do if Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev refused to allow a united Germany in NATO, said, ``We will do what Lyndon Johnson did: We will reason together. And it will all work out.'' The White House also announced over the weekend that Bush will meet with Japanese Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu on Friday and Saturday in Palm Springs, Calif. Kaifu's Liberal Democratic party won a vote of confidence from the Japanese people in last week's parliamentary elections. ``It's very important now that he's solidified his position'' to hold such talks, Bush told reporters Sunday night at a dinner for governors.

DOC.HEAD: Airlines to Require Safety Seats for Infants
DOC.TEXT: Erin Donnell has flown on airliners four times in six months and she's never had to buy a ticket. She's also never had a seat of her own during takeoff or landing. She's 6 months old. But if airlines have their way, Erin won't be allowed to fly in her mother's arms between Washington and Rochester, N.Y. The airline industry's Air Transport Association last week joined calls from members of Congress, consumer safety groups and flight attendants for a rule requiring safety seats for all passengers under 2 years old. If safety seats are made mandatory, Erin's mother, Judy Donnell of Alexandria, Va., might have to buy a $130 ticket for a seat where she could strap in the child restraint. Some travel agents say many travelers can't afford the extra expense, and a Federal Aviation Administration official said the proposal likely would do little to improve infant air travelers' safety. The proposal would affect the 5,000 to 10,000 babies who fly each day. In most cases, the same safety seats that states now require for infants riding in cars can be used in a jetliner. The FAA proposes only to require that airlines offer use of safety seats as an option to travelers _ as most airlines do now _ but the agency is seeking public comment on the tougher proposal. Mrs. Donnell said she would be willing to pay the extra cost, but she has never considered buying a ticket to guarantee her baby a seat. ``It's really mind-boggling that they think a baby is going to be safe not secured,'' she said, adding that she sometimes straps Erin into an extra seat during flight but holds her unsecured during takeoff and landing. Other passengers apparently are not so content with the prospect of having to carry a safety seat and buy a ticket for a child under 2. ``People are mostly concerned about having to pay,'' said Doris Davidoff, a Bowie, Md., travel agent whose firm books 10,000 tickets a year. ``They'd like to have a choice and don't want it to be mandatory.'' ``I really don't think it would be fair, given the really low percentages of injuries or deaths involved, to force the many, many parents traveling with infants to pay these fares,'' said Mrs. Davidoff. A passenger flying roundtrip between Baltimore and Los Angeles at full fare could have to pay up to $1,246 on a heavily booked flight to guarantee a seat for an infant. If the ticket were bought far enough in advance at a discount, the cost still would be at least $406, unless special child's fares were in effect. The FAA also is concerned about the burden such a rule would put on travelers. ``The number of accidents is statistically low to begin with, and there has been no indication that a great many children have been killed,'' said FAA spokesman Fred Farrar. ``We don't think there is any safety justification for either requiring the airlines to give up a seat for free or for requiring a parent to purchase a seat if they don't want to,'' Farrar said. The problem is that in an air crash, ``A baby becomes a ballistic,'' said Sen. Christopher Bond, R-Mo., cosponsor with Rep. Jim Lightfoot, R-Iowa, of legislation to force the FAA to require safety seats. Much of the new concern was prompted by the death of 23-month-old Evan Tsao in the July 19 crash of United Flight 232 in an Iowa cornfield. The boy's mother, Sylvia Tsao, survived the crash, while the toddler died of smoke inhalation. Proponents of the seat rule say he might have lived if he'd been strapped in next to his mother. A Harvard Medical School study in the early 1980s estimated that three infants might be saved over five years if all children used safety seats on airliners. No group has come up with statistics on injuries to unsecured infants. Airline representatives say mandatory seats wouldn't necessarily mean the end of free flights for babies and it could lead to more family discount packages. Last summer, several airlines offered free seats for up to two children under age 18 traveling with an adult. ``Each airline will handle it differently, but I'd be amazed if anybody gives away those seats,'' said David Brown, spokesman for Southwest Airlines.

DOC.HEAD: Attorney to Seek Return of Morgan's Passport
DOC.TEXT: Dr. Elizabeth Morgan, embroiled in a child custody battle that now spans two continents, wants a judge to return her passport so she can travel to New Zealand where her ex-husband arrived today for family court hearings. Morgan's attorney, Stephen Sachs, said he would file court papers today asking D.C. Superior Court Judge Herbert Dixon to return the passport. It was Dixon who ordered Morgan, a 42-year-old plastic surgeon, jailed for 25 months for civil contempt of court for failing to obey his order to reveal the whereabouts of Hilary Foretich, now 7. Hilary, who became the focus of an intensive 2{-year search by her father, Eric Foretich, was found living with her maternal grandparents in Christchurch, New Zealand, this weekend. The child was sent underground amid allegations by Morgan that Foretich sexually abused their daughter. He has adamantly denied the allegations and no court has sustained Morgan's assertions. Sachs said he questions whether Morgan's passport was legally seized in 1986 and said it should be returned. ``It (the passport) should have been returned,'' said Sachs. ``There was no lawful basis to keep it even before the child was discovered in New Zealand.'' Elaine Mittleman, Foretich's attorney, said Sunday she would oppose the motion to return Morgan's passport. ``Why should she have her passport returned when she's still in contempt of court in the District of Columbia?'' said Mittleman. Meanwhile, Foretich arrived in New Zealand from Washington today and was traveling to Christchurch for a court hearing. ``Certainly, we're going to do what we need to do to rescue my daughter,'' the New Zealand Press Association quoted him as saying. Morgan filed a civil suit in federal court in August 1986 against Foretich and his parents, claiming that the grandparents also had abused the child. The grandparents filed a counterclaim for defamation. After a lengthy trial, the jury ruled against each side's claim. Later that month, Judge Dixon conducted a hearing on continued allegations of abuse. He then ordered Morgan to jail for refusing to allow Foretich to visit their daughter. Morgan was released after three days by the D.C. Court of Appeals, which required that she surrender the deed to her home as bond and turn over her passport. From February 1987 to August 1987, Morgan complied with the court order and allowed her husband a series of supervised visits with Hilary, Sachs said. ``She did comply with the then-existing order for supervised visitation,'' Sachs said. ``She purged herself of that (1986) contempt (claim). For several years, there's been no lawful basis to hold her passport.'' The Court of Appeals first asked that Judge Dixon consider the passport issue in the summer of 1987, he said. ``But by that time, she was jailed for the contempt again, and our job was to get her out of jail,'' Sachs added. Sachs said since Morgan was released from jail in September 1989, he has sent two letters to Dixon requesting the passport be returned, but the requests had gone unanswered.

DOC.HEAD: Sheriff Who Seized Armory Unlikely Rebel
DOC.TEXT: Hampden County Sheriff Michael J. Ashe had been known best for innovative programs like a jail garden teaming inmates and senior citizens. Then came the day he seized a National Guard armory to house inmates from his overflowing jail. The move by the mild-mannered, soft-spoken lawman with a master's degree in social work has been applauded by guards, judges, and even prisoners. He's become a hero on radio talk shows. And he's been catapulted into a confrontation with state officials. But Ashe, who never misses a wake or a wedding and once sneaked off to a McDonald's to fill up after a dinner at the White House, says he has never fancied himself a rebel. ``I've always been a team player,'' he said. ``For the past 15 years I've been here we've worked very, very hard in a professional way to try to manage the severe overcrowding.'' ``We've looked in closets, in the garage and under the stairs. And we've had prisoners in all those places. But there comes a point where you run out of a `little magic.' And you just have to go into the ring,'' he said. Ashe reached the end of his patience after he had jammed 726 men into space built for 279 inmates following more than a year of turning loose hundreds of prisoners to try to meet a 500-inmate limit established by a federal judge. ``It came down to a moral and ethical thing,'' Ashe said. He said he could no longer live with the fear of having one of the prisoners he released kill or maim. ``The system had collapsed. And someone had to do something.'' He acknowledged the timing of his move on the armory _ the day before the three-day Presidents Day weekend began _ was calculated. He installed 15 prisoners in the armory and had public opinion solidly in his corner before stunned state officials could respond. State officials said late last week they would not challenge his occupation of the armory for at least two weeks while they look for other housing. For more than a decade, Ashe's knack of mixing toughness and progressive social programs has kept a lid on the century-old lockup. ``He believes inhumanity and coddling arrive at the same point,'' jail spokesman Richard McCarthy said. ``In no way is he going to allow anyone to lay in a cell all day.'' ``Whatever they decide on, in consultation with their social worker, whether it is one of the vocational programs or working in the kitchen, the men have to answer the bell every morning just like John Q. on the street and just like they will have to do when they get out,'' McCarthy said. One of Ashe's first efforts on taking over the jail in 1975 was to turn his jail quarters into a 60-bed pre-release center where inmates with only six months to serve get extensive vocational, substance-abuse and other counseling. In 1986, he added a day reporting center, one of the first of its kind in the country, where inmates with four months left to serve can be released on a electronic monitoring program that lets them live at home as long as they report in several times a day. More than 1,500 inmates who have passed through his jail have earned high school equivalency diplomas. He also started one of the few job programs to operate in a county jail. Last year office furniture manufacturing returned $200,000 in profits to the county, McCarthy said. Before he became sheriff, Ashe and his wife, Barbara, a high school sweetheart, were the first in a program started by the Catholic Church to help homeless children. They have five sons and one daughter.

DOC.HEAD: 1989 Posts Second-Best Farm Export Record
DOC.TEXT: Frigid weather chilled December shipments a little, but 1989 still was the second-hottest farm export year on record, thus adding further stature to trade policy debate on Capitol Hill. Overall, the Agriculture Department tallied farm export values at just under $40 billion, up 7.7 percent from 1988. That was the best dollar performance since 1981 when export values were a record $43.3 billion. Exports in December remained strong but did drop $94 million from the November level. ``Unusually cold weather contributed to the decline,'' the USDA reported. ``Decreases in corn, soybeans, meat, rice, fruits, nuts and tobacco more than offset increases in wheat, animal feeds, soybean meal, cotton, vegetable oils, barley and cattle hides.'' Although the tabulation was for the calendar year, the department bases its annual forecasts and most analysis on figures for the fiscal year, which runs from Oct. 1 through the next Sept. 30. In the last fiscal year, for example, farm export values totaled about $39.7 billion, also the most since 1981. The forecast for the 1989-90 fiscal year is for exports to decline to around $38 billion. The report last week by the department's Economic Research Service did not include a forecast for calendar 1990. But in reviewing what happened in 1989, the agency noted that last year's commodity export value represented ``the third consecutive year-to-year increase since exports bottomed out at $26.2 billion in 1986, the low point for the 1980s.'' Exports have been recognized for many years as vital to American farmers and are a central issue in the Bush administration's strategy for 1990 farm legislation. Ongoing multilateral Uruguay Round negotiations under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade are aimed at reducing barriers that impede exports and imports. Meanwhile, several USDA programs, notably the Export Enhancement Program, or EEP, have been used to boost U.S. shipments into selected countries where foreign competitors _ mainly the European Economic Community _ have been selling products at subsidized prices. Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter told the House Agriculture Committee last week that the 1990 farm bill should extend export programs that have helped boost U.S. exports since the current farm law was approved in 1985. But Yeutter added that ``after completion of the Uruguay Round all programs will be reassessed.'' Yeutter said the administration wants to continue EEP, which offers designated U.S. commodities to selected target countries at subsidized prices. But he said the program should be reauthorized without mandated levels or programming requirements. ``We want our competitors, especially in the European Community, to know that we stand ready to use this program to the maximum extent,'' he said. ``We want them to phase out their export subsidy practices which have severely distorted world markets for many years.''

Americans are smoking fewer cigarettes, but an Agriculture Department economist says demand continues to grow in the rest of the world. Last year, the per capita use of cigarettes in the United States was estimated at 2,936 ``pieces'' or fewer than 149 packs of 20 cigarettes each, down about 5 percent from the 1988 rate. The per capita use has declined for 16 straight years, said Verner Grise of the department's Economic Research Service. At its peak in 1963, use averaged 4,345 cigarettes, or more than 217 packs. Per capita consumption is based on all persons 18 or older, smokers and non-smokers alike. It does not indicate actual smoking habits and is used by the agency for year-to-year comparisons. But world cigarette trade increased about 12 percent, Grise said in the March issue of Farmline magazine. ``Shipments from the United States, West Germany, the Netherlands, Hong Kong (which is also an importer) and the United Kingdom were up, while those from Bulgaria and Belgium-Luxembourg were down,'' he said. ``Together, these seven countries account for about 84 percent of total world exports.'' Among the cigarette importing countries, the most important markets are the Soviet Union, France, Japan, Italy, Hong Kong and Turkey. During the first nine months of 1989, U.S. cigarette exports were up 16 percent from a year earlier, with all the major markets buying more, Grise said. In the ``relatively small markets,'' sales also rose in South America but declined in Australia-Oceania and Canada.

Australia, one of the world's biggest meat producers, is consuming less of its beef and lamb, according to an Agriculture Department dispatch from Canberra. ``They are eating more breakfast cereals, desserts, fruits and vegetables, but less meat, bakery products and canned vegetables, according to a recent survey,'' the report said. As reported in Retail World, an Australian publication, the value of retail purchases of meat and deli items dropped 33 percent from 1988 to 1989, while bakery products and canned vegetables each declined 14 percent. But purchases of breakfast cereals rose 25 percent; desserts, 20 percent; and fruits and vegetables, 22 percent. The item was reported in AgExporter magazine by the department's Foreign Agricultural Service.

DOC.HEAD: Police Break Up One Rally, Allow Another in `Cradle of Revolution'
With PM-Soviet-Politics, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: In this city where the Communists seized power seven decades ago, about 8,000 people ignored rumors of impending violence and rallied to demand that the people be allowed to choose their leaders. At a second rally on Sunday, riot police dragged away several pro-democracy protesters who tried to gather in the city's center without official permission. The authorized demonstration was part of nationwide protests demanding radical political and economic reforms. A resolution passed by a show of demonstrators' hands and a resounding ``Da!'' said the president should be chosen by the people, not the party apparatus, and urged voters in Russian parliamentary elections next Sunday to vote in pro-democracy candidates and ``tear power from the apparatus.'' ``In February 1917, we started on the road to democracy. In October, we got dictatorship. Now there is a similar situation,'' Ilya Konstantinov, a candidate for parliament, told the crowd outside the Lenin Sports-Concert Complex. Leningrad, the site of three uprisings while it was capital of the Russian Empire, has been dubbed the ``cradle of revolution.'' In 1905, czarist forces fired on demonstrators demanding democratic reforms in a clash known as ``Bloody Sunday.'' Sunday was the anniversary of another uprising, the 1917 February Revolution, in which bourgeois-democratic forces seized power and forced Czar Nicholas II to abdicate. The Bolshevik Communists, led by Vladimir I. Lenin, took over eight months later. An hour before the rally at the sports complex, about a dozen activists in the Democratic Union, a radical group fighting to end the Communist Party's hold on power, gathered on a square. As about 100 police surrounded the crowd and KGB plainclothes agents stood by, an officer shouted through a megaphone that no demonstration was authorized. A dozen riot police wearing white helmets and green bulletproof vests then dragged away several of the activists, who had no protest posters and had not made any public statements. The activists were loaded onto buses for detention. A parliamentary candidate and Associated Press photographer Dominique Mollard also were taken away but later released after their identification documents were checked. One activist climbed atop a yellow construction crane and unfurled a cloth banner that referred to next Sunday's elections. ``Boycott _ It's your First Step to Freedom!'' it read. Five riot police mounted the crane and dragged down the protester. Leaders of The People's Front, Leningrad's biggest pro-democracy group, decided to boycott the authorized rally because they feared retaliation from either the government or right-wing groups. But dissenting People's Front members showed up and harshly condemned their leaders' decision. Writer Mikhail Chulaky, a People's Front member, told the crowd that the Communist Party's decision earlier this month to end its monopoly on power was overdue and added: ``The party of genocide must be disbanded, like (Germany's Nazi party) was disbanded by Nuremberg.'' Under Stalin, thousands of political opponents were murdered. Several speakers attacked President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's proposal to strengthen his powers as president. ``Again they are wrapping a dictator around our necks,'' said Nikolai Ivanov, a parliamentarian from Leningrad whose crusade against official corruption has made him popular. A protest banner equated the presidency with fascism, a powerful comparison in a city where 600,000 people were killed by the Nazis in World War II. Police and plainclothes KGB agents did not interfere in the second rally.

DOC.HEAD: Polling Expert Says Mrs. Chamorro May Pull Upset
With AM-Nicaragua, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Violeta Barrios de Chamorro, the underdog in Sunday's election, was showing surprising strength and could upset President Daniel Ortega, according to a polling expert for the Los Angeles Times. The Times was conducting a ``quick count'' of a representative sample of precincts nationwide for the presidential race. ``She's showing surprising strength and there exists the possibility of an upset,''said I.A. Lewis, the Times polling expert. Lewis refused to release any details or figures of the poll. He spoke as concern rose about the extremely slow reporting of election figures by the nation's Supreme Electoral Tribunal. Mrs. Chamorro, candidate for the U.S.-backed opposition coalition, trailed Ortega of the leftist Sandinista party in polls conducted before the election. But those polls were not considered a sure indicator of victory because Nicaragua is a rural country where polling is difficult. Nicaraguans are reluctant to tell strangers what they think after 45 years under the Somoza family dictatorship and 10 years under the highly disciplined Sandinistas. The Los Angeles Times conducted a ``quick count'' by selecting a representative sample of precincts and having results from those precincts telephoned to a central office in Managua. ``The precinct sample indicates the possibility of a dramatic upset,'' said Lewis.

DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON TODAY: Civil Rights Debate Deepens
DOC.TEXT: Getting agreement in Washington on the need for a civil rights bill is proving almost ridiculously easy. But it's a little tougher to find an accord on what the measure should say. ``I don't believe we have to overhaul the American legal system to ensure equality,'' says Sen. Orrin Hatch, R-Utah. He and other conservatives say the sweeping proposal backed by the civil rights community to remedy workplace bias against minorities and women goes too far and needs to be limited in scope. And yet, civil rights supporters say the Supreme Court itself overhauled much of the U.S. civil rights law last year in a series of rulings on job bias cases. Civil rights forces say those decisions _ from a Supreme Court whose conservatism deepened considerably in the Reagan era _ represent the most severe setback in years for civil rights in the workplace. They say the bill they support would merely restore the previous legal standards. The Supreme Court rulings came at a time when opinion polls show an easing of worry about civil rights among white Americans. And that may in part explain the bill's popularity on Capitol Hill. It has gained broad sponsorship in both the House and Senate, including more than a smattering of Republicans. Critics contend the measure is guaranteed to usher in racial hiring quotas, an idea that would be much harder to sell in Congress. But sponsors declare that nothing in the bill's language requires hiring quotas. Almost everyone agrees change is needed. ``I have no doubt that more needs to be done to combat the evil of discrimination in our society,'' says Hatch. As a senior member of the Senate Labor and Judiciary Committees, he could play a pivotal role in any eventual negotiations on the issue. The Bush administration already is recommending a bill that would overturn two of last year's decisions. But that does not satisfy Sen. Edward M. Kennedy, D-Mass., and other bill sponsors. ``The administration cannot stop there or its response will be inadequate,'' says Kennedy. The administration and the bill sponsors agree that something must be done about the Supreme Court's decision in the so-called Patterson case. The case concerns Brenda Patterson, a former credit union filing clerk from Winston-Salem, N.C. She said her bosses harassed her and discriminated against her for a decade because she was black. ``I was actually told to dust and sweep the office, even though we had a janitor every day and no white employees were ever told to do this,'' she said. The court ruled that the alleged harassment and discrimination was not against the law and that a Civil War-era statute, under which she had brought suit, did not apply in the case. The reaction against the decision has been so overwhelming that it appears all but certain the law will be changed. But other cases are more complex. The Lorance case involves discrimination in company seniority plans. The Martin vs. Wilks decision focuses on court-approved fair-hiring agreements. Civil rights forces and conservatives may be most at odds over whether changes are needed as a result of the Wards Cove case, which involved alleged hiring bias at an Alaska salmon cannery. Before the Supreme Court's decision, employers defending themselves in hiring discrimination cases had to be able to prove they based their actions on business necessity. Now, however, those who file such lawsuits must prove that the employer did not act out of business necessity. ``By shifting the burden, the Supreme Court has made it far more difficult and expensive for victims of discrimination to challenge the barriers they face,'' declares Kennedy. Harvard law Professor Charles Fried, however, says Kennedy's proposed remedy is itself flawed. First, an individual filing such a suit would not be required to pinpoint which of the employer's hiring practices was the source of the discrimination. Fried says that would encourage lawyers representing alleged bias victims to unfurl a long list of practices and thus force the employer to defend all of them. Also, he adds, the bill would require the employer to prove that each practice was essential for staying in business. That could prove too difficult, says Fried. ``I'm afraid they're going to say, `Gee, we don't want to fuss with this. We'll just hire by quota,''' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Governors Oppose Giving Federal Anti-Drug Funds Directly to Cities
DOC.TEXT: City officials have a tough sell when they try to convince governors to loosen their grip on federal funds for combating drugs. ``I strongly support the idea that some of the federal dollars go directly to some of our larger cities,'' Mayor Richard L. Berkley of Kansas City, Mo., told governors Sunday. In his appearance at the annual midwinter meeting of the National Governors' Association, Berkley was careful to emphasize he was talking about only ``some'' dollars and ``some'' cities. But an Associated Press survey of governors found them almost unanimous in their opposition to relinquishing their hold on the flow of federal funds to their states. They were equally united in praise of President Bush's effort to help them combat drugs, particularly his willingness to sharply increase his budget request for the effort. ``President Bush's drug program is a bold attempt to deal with this menace in a comprehensive way,'' said Republican Gov. James Martin of North Carolina. Gov. Robert Casey of Pennsylvania, a Democrat, said the president's program ``is beginning to provide states with the help they need.'' One of the few dissenters was Democratic Gov. Neil Goldschmidt of Oregon who said the president's program ``supplies the guns we need in the war on drugs but not enough bullets for them. Not enough resources are being dedicated to any one of the areas.'' ``I would oppose sending federal money directly to local governments,'' said Gov. William Donald Schaefer of Maryland, a former mayor of Baltimore. ``The problem is not confined just to our larger cities.'' Gov. Tommy Thompson of Wisconsin said that while some cities might benefit from direct funds ``more cities would benefit from having the states administer grant awards.'' ``The state's direct involvement in the allocation of dollars promotes coordination and avoids duplication of efforts,'' said Gov. James Thompson of Illinois. Appearing with Berkley were Mayors Wilson Goode of Philadelphia, Sue Myrick of Charlotte, N.C., and Maureen O'Connor of San Diego. Goode said cities often must wait months from the time federal funds are allocated for drug programs to the time when they actually receive the money. ``Get those federal dollars where they're needed most,'' he said. ``We mayors want direct funding for cities because it doesn't always get down to us,'' said Myrick. O'Connor put the waiting period at anywhere from 12 to 18 months. Gov. Carroll Campbell of South Carolina said cities were ``out of line'' in assuming they have a far greater need for drug funds than rural areas. ``We have a terrible problem outside the cities,'' Campbell said. Gov. Buddy Roemer of Louisiana was a little more sympathetic to the mayors. ``That is a valid complaint if state government is going to ignore the cities, ignore their wishes and not work with them hand in glove,'' he said. However, he added that ``It's invalid in the sense that the drug problem is nationwide, statewide and not just citywide and there needs to be some coordination.'' Gov. Evan Bayh of Indiana said direct funding to the cities ``makes it difficult to coordinate either the state or local effort.'' Virginia Gov. L. Douglas Wilder rejected sending money directly to cities because the problem is ``so pervasive that the state has a responsibility.''

DOC.HEAD: Defense Spending Neutral to U.S. Economy, Report Says
DOC.TEXT: Reducing U.S. defense spending will have no more impact on the economy than cutting money for education, health and other programs, says a report issued today. Using previously published data, economist David Gold concludes that on average over the past four decades, ``defense spending has been a relatively neutral feature of the American economic landscape.'' Gold's findings differ from the accepted belief that reducing the defense budget, which in the latest Bush administration proposal totals $292 billion for fiscal 1991, will generate revenue for other programs and trigger economic growth. ``Cutting the defense budget will have no more of an impact on U.S. investment, research and development, innovation, productivity, international competitiveness and economic growth than will cutting other forms of spending, both public and private,'' Gold said in the report. The economist, who works for the United Nations Centre on Transnational Corp., conducted the study while serving as consultant for the Defense Budget Project. The non-profit think tank released Gold's report. ``The report challenges the conventional wisdom on both sides regarding the impact of defense spending,'' said Gordon Adams, director of the Defense Budget Project. The report said cuts in defense spending may provide funds for other programs, and if properly handled, the economy could benefit. However, ld questioned the argument that the defense budget should be cut to promote economic growth. the defense budget may lie elsewhere, in such problems as wastsmanagement, and in the debate over the actual requirements for military forces in a rapidly changing world,'' Gold said. Gold also disputed the claim that defense requirements for research and development talent have weakened productivity in the private sector. According to the report, the number of scientists and engineers who have left civilian work for the military sector has declined in recent years despite the defense buildup of the 1980s.
