DOC.HEAD: Reagan Says He Did Not Think Letters to Congress on Contras Were False
DOC.TEXT: Former President Reagan, supporting former aides John Poindexter and Robert McFarlane in videotaped testimony, says he didn't think letters they sent to Congress about U.S. aid to the Contras were false. In his testimony for Poindexter's upcoming trial, the former president said he instructed that ``whatever we did'' to maintain the Nicaraguan Contras ``should be done within the law.'' But Reagan said he was unaware his own Tower Commission concluded three years ago that Oliver North was giving military assistance to the Contras. And, Reagan said he did not know that McFarlane had pleaded guilty to withholding information from Congress for denying North's role. ``I have a great deal of confidence in the man who was quoted as sending these letters, McFarlane,'' Reagan testified. ``I have never caught him or seen him doing anything that was in any way out of line or dishonest.'' ``Do you remember that Mr. McFarlane ... has pled guilty in open court to withholding information from Congress in connection with'' his written denials to Congress? asked Iran-Contra prosecutor Dan Webb. ``No, I was not aware of that,'' replied Reagan. ``Mr. President ... did the Tower Commission not tell you'' that ``Oliver North and your National Security Council were involved in 1985 and 1986 in assisting the Contras militarily?'' asked Webb. ``I don't recall that,'' said Reagan. Poindexter, facing trial March 5 on charges of conspiracy, obstructing Congress and making false statements, sent responses to Congress in 1986 that embraced McFarlane's letters of the previous year. In his videotaped deposition, released last Thursday, Reagan asserted that he didn't think Poindexter had obstructed Congress. ``Did you ever ... give authority to John Poindexter to make any false statements to any congressional committee? asked Webb. ``No,'' replied Reagan. ``And I don't think any false statements were made.'' Reagan's comments on behalf of Poindexter were blunted in part by the written answers he gave two years ago to Iran-Contra investigators. The responses, provided to a federal grand jury conducting a criminal investigation of the affair, depicted a president who had been misled by subordinates. In those answers, Reagan said he had heard allegations in the press that North was assisting the Contras militarily during a congressional ban on U.S. military aid, but that he understood the allegations were incorrect. ``Who told you that the allegations in the press about North being involved in assisting the Contras was false or incorrect?'' Webb asked Reagan during the videotaped deposition, referring back to Reagan's written answers. ``It could have been ... the late Bill Casey from CIA,'' said Reagan. ``It could have been Admiral Poindexter. It could have been some people from the Defense Department, or all of the people that were involved in some way'' in seeking support from Congress for the Contras. The former president supported the McFarlane letters on six different occasions in his videotaped testimony. ``I understand exactly what he (McFarlane) is saying here,'' said the former president, ``and I think it is in agreement with'' what Reagan said were his repeated admonitions to his aides _ that they comply with the law. One of the McFarlane letters stated that ``none of us'' at the NSC ``facilitated contacts with prospective donors, or otherwise organized or coordinated the military or paramilitary efforts of the resistance.'' After Reagan repeatedly appeared unable to understand that McFarlane's letters were false, U.S. District Court Judge Harold Greene interrupted Webb and tried to explain the matter to the ex-president himself. McFarlane's letter ``could be interpreted that other way'' as being false, Reagan finally conceded. But the former president added that he had not interpreted it as being false. Poindexter is accused of lying to Congress on Nov. 21, 1986, by saying that no one in the U.S. government knew that a November 1985 shipment to Iran contained Hawk missiles until after the weapons were delivered. However, documents at North's trial last year showed that North helped arrange the shipment and kept Poindexter informed of its progress. Reagan announced on Nov. 19, 1986, that ``all information will be provided to the appropriate members of Congress'' about the Iran initiative. ``You agree with that statement?'' Webb asked Reagan. ``Yes,'' replied Reagan. ``Except that I cannot ... recall whether there were things that then came up that made us have to hold our revelations'' to protect the lives of U.S. hostages held in Lebanon and Iranians with whom the U.S. government was dealing. ``There were times and experience that told us that Congress was not in many instances capable of the kind of security that we required,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: On the Light Side
DOC.TEXT: A program to raise youngsters' interest in history by querying Abraham Lincoln prompted one to ask, ``What was it like being on a penny?'' Officials for the letter-writing program enlisted Jeannine Perez, a teacher at the Illinois State University child-care center, to play Lincoln's ghostwriter and answer the queries from students in kindergarten through second grade. Ms. Perez had little trouble addressing some of the more popular questions, such as ``How does it feel to live in a log house?'' But when one youngster asked, ``Did you have electricity, or radios, or Nintendo or computers?'' Ms. Perez' Lincoln had to ask them questions about Nintendo and computers. Another youngster asked Lincoln, ``Were you friends with Martin Luther King Jr.?'' Ms. Perez' Lincoln replied, ``I didn't ever meet Martin Luther King, but I would imagine that we would have a lot to talk about.'' A first-grader asked, ``Were you afraid when you started first grade?'' Ms. Perez told the student about Lincoln's school, which had schoolmasters who snapped a switch if the students misbehaved. Ms. Perez said she would not classify herself as a Lincoln scholar but as a person interested in history. After consulting several Lincoln books, she has yet to complete all her responses. The program was sponsored by the McLean County Historical Society.

Everybody's heard of the country doctor being paid with chickens, but how about the lawyer who's paid with goat meat? While many attorneys are wary of accepting merchandise for their services, some say they sometimes find themselves stuck between accepting items other than cash _ or getting nothing at all. Helena attorney Nick Jacques said he has received a few haircuts, and once ``a guy gave me some goat meat.'' While hesitant to try the meat, Jacques said it turned out to be a tasty payment once barbequed on his grill. Lawyer Mark Staples said, ``I was paid with a motorcycle for a divorce I handled and rode it around for nearly six months before I realized you needed a special permit. Now, it sits in a storage area.'' And attorney Mayo Ashley said he has accepted paintings, wall hangings and books, among other items. ``One person offered me a car to take his criminal case,'' said Ashley, who declined. ``But I've gotten several golf balls and golf clubs.'' ``You can always turn away a person who doesn't have money, but I guess I'm too soft-hearted,'' Ashley said. ``I've probably lost a lot of money that way.'' And then there's the case of Helena artist Bruce Donald Bunger, who was unable to pay a $500 fine for growing marijuana. His attorney and prosecutors struck a deal last October in which Bunger would satisfy the fine by donating a sculpture of a buffalo head and eagle called ``The Emergence.'' Ironically, the sculpture will sit in front of the old jail, which is being renovated to house an arts center.

DOC.HEAD: Thousands Toss Flowers, Chant For Duarte As Former President Buried
DOC.TEXT: Carrying photos of Jose Napoleon Duarte and tossing flowers at his flag-draped coffin, thousands of mourners paid final respects to the former president eulogized as ``the father of Central American democracy.'' Vice President Dan Quayle, Presidents Oscar Arias of Costa Rica and Vinicio Cerezo of Guatemala and former President Jose Azcona Hoyos of Honduras attended the funeral Mass for Duarte, who died Friday of cancer at age 64. President Alfredo Cristiani did not attend the services Sunday because he was in Taiwan on a state visit. Leaders of Duarte's centrist Christian Democratic Party criticized Cristiani's rightist government for not declaring a national day of mourning. At least 100,000 people paid their last respects to the former president, party leaders said. Duarte's followers, many carrying photographs of the former president and cheering, ``Duarte! Duarte!'' tossed flowers at his flag-draped coffin as it was carried from the Roman Catholic church to a 21-gun military salute. Arias and Cerezo were among the pallbearers at his burial. Arias, remembering Duarte's key role in regional peace talks, called him ``the father of Central American democracy.'' ``Napoleon was a visionary pioneer and an untiring fighter for democracy,'' Arias said at the Mass. Cerezo referred to criticisms of Duarte's 1984-1989 term as president but said, ``I think the magnitude and value of his work still has not been fully appreciated.'' He ``gave his life for the cause of all democrats of Latin America,'' Cerezo said. Duarte, who tried but failed to end a civil war and ease El Salvador's searing class division, died at his San Salvador home after fighting stomach and liver cancer for almost two years. Fidel Chavez Mena, who succeeds Duarte as the Christian Democratic leader, criticized the government as ``niggardly'' for not declaring a day of mourning but added: ``the people were in mourning, anyway, which is the important thing.'' Cristiani, who represents the oligarchy that Duarte has fought for decades, took over as president in June after his conservative Nationalist Republic Alliance, or Arena, defeated the Christian Democrats. Armando Calderon Sol, mayor of San Salvador and Arena president, said: ``Duarte was an expression of democratic will. He made great contributions toward the democratization of the country.'' ``We have been strong adversaries,'' Calderon said. But, he added, ``It would be unjust not to recognize President Duarte's palpable efforts for human rights (and) struggle for freedom of expression.'' After founding the Christian Democratic Party, Duarte was tortured and exiled for seven years. He returned in 1980 and headed a civilian junta until he was chosen president in 1984 in the country's first elections in 50 years.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Fifth Attempt to Launch Shuttle Is Scrubbed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Combines urgent series. CORRECTS lead to say Monday, sted Sunday. Picks up 11th graf, a0449, `Contributing to...'
DOC.TEXT: High winds and clouds forced NASA to abandon its fifth attempt to launch the shuttle Atlantis on a secret military mission Monday morning, the most postponements since the ill-fated Challenger mission. ``Launch director Bob Sieck informed the launch team that we are scrubbing for the day,'' Lisa Malone, launch control center commentator, said at 2:31 a.m. ``There is no hope that the weather will clear in time to support a launch today.'' Before the mission was scrubbed, forecasters had said there was only a 40 percent chance the shuttle could be launched early Monday. The mission was postponed until at least Wednesday morning because the numerous delays had left both the crew and the launch team fatigued, NASA said. As launch time approached, wind gusts up to 31 mph buffeted the launch pad, about 1 mph above the usual allowable limits. Winds that were too high might have blown the shuttle into the launch tower, destroying the spacecraft. At about 12:40 a.m., Sieck called for an extended hold, hoping that the winds would subside before the available launch period of about 90 minutes expired. While that determination was made, clouds moved over the runway where Atlantis' crew would attempt an emergency landing in case of a problem shortly after liftoff. Mission Control said the clouds were unacceptable for launch. The all-military astronaut crew arrived at the launch pad shortly after 10 p.m., just as they did before Saturday night's mission was scrubbed. The launch already had been delayed four times by a combination of bad weather, a cold that felled Atlantis commander, Navy Capt. John O. Creighton, and a faulty computer that halted the count just 31 seconds before liftoff on Sunday. The five delays were the most in a shuttle launch since the Challenger, which was postponed seven times and launched on the eighth try to explode shortly after lift-off Jan. 28, 1986, killing all seven astronauts. Despite the gloomy forecast, shuttle managers in midafternoon had given the go-ahead for the launch team to pump 528,000 gallons of liquid hydrogen and liquid oxygen into Atlantis' cavernous fuel tank for another try. Contributing to the decision to load fuel was the fact that Monday offered the best weather odds of the next three days. The odds drop to just 20 percent on Tuesday and Wednesday, forecasters said. Clouds could block a spectacular view of the liftoff for residents on the East Coast as far north as New Jersey; in clear weather, they could see the shuttle's fiery exhaust climbing on a course a few hundred miles off the coast. Bad weather and the illness of Atlantis' commander resulted in postponements Thursday, Friday and Saturday. The weather was perfect early Sunday before liftoff was halted by the computer problem with 31 seconds to go. The computer is one of two used by the Air Force to provide information on the shuttle's course after liftoff. If the vehicle strayed off track and threatened a populated area, a range safety officer would send a radio signal to blow it up so pieces would fall harmlessly into the Atlantic. Mission rules require that both computers be operating for a launch, with the one that failed serving as a backup. Capt. Ken Warren, an Air Force spokesman, reported Sunday that the trouble had been traced to bad software. ``The computer is up and we're ready to support a launch,'' Warren said. The astronauts, who spent three hours in the spacecraft before Sunday's scrub, went to bed about noon. The commander is Navy Capt. John O. Creighton, who was felled two days last week by a sore throat and nasal congestion. His all-military crew is Air Force Col. John H. Casper, the pilot, and mission specialists Marine Lt. Col. David C. Hilmers, Air Force Col. Richard Mullane and Navy Lt. Cmdr. Pierre J. Thuot. Because the mission is classified, neither NASA nor the Pentagon will identify its purpose. But sources who spoke on condition of anonymity reported that the astronauts were to deploy on the second day a 37,300-pound, $500 million satellite capable of taking super-sharp photos and listening in on military and diplomatic communications around the world. In covering most of the Soviet Union, the satellite would be important in verifying Soviet compliance with current and future arms agreements. NASA and the Pentagon planned to maintain a news blackout throughout the flight, unless there was a major problem. Two announcements were planned, one about three hours after liftoff to report that orbit had begun and another 30 hours into the flight with the date and time of landing. The flight was expected to last four days, with landing at Edwards Air Force Base, Calif.

DOC.HEAD: Last of Seven Victims Pulled from Icy Lake
DOC.TEXT: Aided by a sophisticated underwater video camera, divers spotted and retrieved the body of the last of seven victims who died after plunging into an icy lake. The body of Dave ``Grandpa'' Meyers, one of four would-be rescuers who perished trying to save three teen-agers who fell through thin ice on Lake Convict on Feb. 19, was recovered Sunday. Divers recovered the other six bodies last week. Meyers, 53, of Bishop, was a counselor at Camp O'Neal, where the three teen-agers were residents. Also killed were another counselor, a volunteer firefighter and a forest ranger. Camp O'Neal, near the lake in the Sierra Nevada 250 miles north of Los Angeles, is a home for youngsters placed by county social-service agencies as well as youths who have committed minor crimes and are on probation. Meyers' body was spotted by a sophisticated underwater video camera lowered into the lake on Wednesday, but the water clouded over before divers could go down to recover it. The camera was lowered into the lake again Saturday, but only clothing and eyeglasses were spotted.

DOC.HEAD: Candidates in 1990 Senate Races Already Have Raised $62 Million
DOC.TEXT: Four Senate incumbents raised more than $3 million each last year in preparation for this year's elections, according to federal statistics that show total fund-raising of $62 million by all candidates. Republican Sen. Phil Gramm of Texas topped the list with nearly $6 million in contributions, according to the analysis released Sunday by the Federal Election Commission. Others in the top four were Sens. Bill Bradley, D-N.J., with $4.7 million; Rudy Boschwitz, R-Minn., with $3.6 million; and Paul Simon, D-Ill., with $3.3 million. Twenty-two candidates reported contributions of more than $1 million, all of them incumbents except for three Republican House members and Texas Democrat Hugh Parmer, a state senator taking on Gramm. Rep. Lynn Martin, R-Ill., reported raising $1.5 million for her challenge to Simon. The FEC said GOP Reps. Hank Brown of Colorado, running for an open seat, and Tom Tauke of Iowa, contesting incumbent Democrat Tom Harkin, also raised more than $1 million apiece last year. The FEC report covered 31 incumbents and 29 challengers, plus 10 candidates in three open-seat races in Colorado, Idaho and New Hampshire. The agency said the candidates reported raising $62 million and spending $28 million during 1989. By comparison, candidates in 33 Senate races in 1984 had spent a little more than $35 million in 1983.
DOC.HEAD: Juries Tougher Than Judges On Convicted Felons, Report Says
DOC.TEXT: More people convicted of felonies by state court juries wind up in prison and stay there longer than those found guilty by judges, according to a new report. The Justice Department analysis issued Sunday also found that 89 percent of convicted felons plead guilty and that they spend less time in prison than those who go to trial and are convicted by a judge or jury. The penalties of life in prison or death are meted out to 47 percent of those convicted by juries of murder or non-negligent manslaughter. Meanwhile, only 15 percent of those who pleaded guilty to such charges and 12 percent of those found guilty by a judge received those penalties, said the report by the department's Bureau of Justice Statistics. It is unclear why defendants convicted by juries were more severely punished, the study said. But it noted that ``a higher percentage of the convictions by juries were for violent offenses.'' It said defendants in serious cases, violent and nonviolent, may have been less willing to plead guilty because they expected severe penalties. ``In addition, prosecutors may have recommended and judges may have imposed shorter sentences for those who pled compared to those found guilty by trial,'' it said. The study _ based on information from 100 counties in 37 states regarding all convicted felons sentenced in 1986 _ cautioned that the findings should be considered preliminary because of the limited sample size. The next survey is to cover 300 jurisdictions. Of the estimated 583,000 people convicted of a felony in state courts in 1986, 89 percent pleaded guilty, 8 percent were convicted by a jury and 3 percent were found guilty by a judge, the report says. But many of the guilty pleas were for lesser offenses, with 92 percent of the larceny convictions and 90 percent of the burglary convictions based on guilty pleas, but only 58 percent of the murder convictions and 68 percent of the rape convictions based on such pleas. Felons convicted by a jury were sentenced to an average of 159 months in prison, compared with 103 months when felons were convicted by a judge and 72 months for those who pleaded guilty.
DOC.HEAD: 1990s Said Crucial Decade for Population
DOC.TEXT: The number of people on Earth will double in 39 years unless birth control becomes available to everybody by the end of the decade, according to a new study. ``This is a preventable disaster,'' said Sharon L. Camp, vice president of the private Population Crisis Committee, a Washington-based advocacy group that released the report Sunday. ``We have what it would take _ the financial resources and the know how _ to solve the problem, and to do so in our children's lifetime. But we have to act immediately. We cannot dither away another decade.'' There are about 5.3 billion people in the world, a figure that the United Nations says could rise to 14 billion before stabilizing in the next century. The committee said today's population could double in 39 years and reach 27 billion by the end of the 21st century if present birth and death rates continued unchanged. Stopping population growth at about 9 billion to 10 billion people would require use of contraceptives by some 75 percent of couples, the study estimates. But to accomplish that the products would have to be available to everyone by the end of this century so the average family size could fall to about two children per couple early in the 21st century. The report goes on to estimate the cost of such an effort _ $10.5 billion per year by the year 2000. Currently $3.2 billion is spent on family planning in developing countries, where most population growth is taking place. ``Universal family planning is a bargain compared to the costs of delaying world population stabilization,'' Camp said.

DOC.HEAD: New Cambodian Peace Talks Come After Guerrilla Losses
DOC.TEXT: Cambodia's warring factions gathered today for talks on ending their 11-year-old conflict, the Vietnamese-installed government bolstered by battlefield victories against non-Communist guerrillas. The three days of talks were expected to focus on a possible role for the United Nations in reaching a settlement. With little else on the negotiating table, Asian diplomatic sources said the meeting would be a success only if the U.N. role were approved at least in principle. A ceremonial opening was planned in the evening after the arrival of Foreign Minister Roland Dumas of France, a co-host with Foreign Minister Ali Alatas of Indonesia. A 19-nation peace conference in Paris last summer opened with high hopes only to deadlock, largely on the question of how power would be shared by the Hanoi-backed government of Premier Hun Sen and the three-member guerrilla coalition. Hun Sen has said he would allow the United Nations to organize elections but not administer the country until polling takes place. His government has opposed U.N. participation in peace efforts in the past because the world body recognizes the guerrilla coalition as the legitimate government of Cambodia. Vietnam invaded Cambodia in late 1978, ending nearly four years of rule by the Khmer Rouge, which killed hundreds of thousands of peopl as it tried to turn the former French colony into a radical agrarian commune. The Vietnamese claim to have pulled all their troops out of Cambodia in September. The Khmer Rouge is the strongest member of the guerrilla coalition and there are fears of a recurrence of brutal rule if its fighters were to topple the Hun Sen government. Representing the guerrilla coalition at this week's talks are: Prince Norodom Ranariddh, on behalf of the faction of his father, former head of state Prince Norodom Sihanouk; Khmer Rouge Vice President Khieu Samphan; and former Premier Son Sann, head of the Khmer People's National Liberation Front. Also on hand are Hun Sen, Vietnamese Foreign Minister Nguyen Co Thach and representatives from Laos and the Association of Southeast Asian Nations: Brunei, Indonesia, Malaysia, the Philippines, Singapore and Thailand. As the participants gathered, news reports quoted non-Communist guerrilla commanders as saying they suffered major battlefield losses at the hands of the Phnom Penh army. They blamed a halt in arms supplies from China for their predicament. China has been the main supplier of arms to the three guerrilla factions. It was unclear whether the interruption, confirmed by Western diplomats in Bangkok, was due to logistics or a policy decision. The guerrilla commanders said that, because of their inability to stop a government counteroffensive in northwestern Cambodia, thousands of civilians under their control were moving closer to the Thai border. The Soviet Union has been the main supplier of weapons to Vietnam and the Cambodian government. Khieu Samphan said in a statement Sunday that more than 20,000 Vietnamese troops had been sent back into Cambodia since Hanoi announced that all of its troops were withdrawn in September. The Vietnamese troops wore the uniforms of Hun Sen's army, he said. Khieu Samphan repeated a previous demand for a complete withdrawal to prepare for a comprehensive solution. Asked if he thought the talks might be successful, he said ``it would depend on Vietnam.'' Vietnam's government radio today quoted Dumas as saying France is significantly expanding economic relations with Vietnam, largely isolated for a decade because of its invasion of Cambodia. Dumas, who was in Vietnam over the weekend, said in a joint communique that France will give $8 million to Vietnam, up from $870,000 last year.

DOC.HEAD: Creators of ``Greater Tuna'' Perform at White House
DOC.TEXT: It was, in President Bush's words, ``a very special Tuna evening at the White House.'' Tuna, Texas, that is _ as performed by actors and quick-change artists Joe Sears and Jayston Williams, creators of two satirical plays about life in the third smallest town in Texas. Sears and Williams provided the entertainment Sunday night at Bush's state dinner for the governors. The duo performed four scenes and six characters, including three from their ``Greater Tuna'' and ``A Christmas Tuna'' plays and one skit ordered up for the occasion: a phone-call to the White House from Tuna Tastee Kreme waitress Helen Bedd. The governors and their spouses and Bush and his wife Barbara laughed riotously at the Tuna reprise in the East Room. Sears and Williams, famed for jumping in and out of dresses, wigs and a myriad of characters, caught the president's fancy Jan. 6 when the Bushes saw ``A Christmas Tuna'' at the Kennedy Center on their 45th wedding anniversary. A laughing Bush told the audience afterwards, ``Some of you all may have seen these two artists ... in the greatest sense of the word over at the Kennedy Center. ``Barbara and I went a while back, had our kids with us, and I don't think we ever enjoyed an evening more,'' said the president. He thanked the pair ``for this very special Tuna evening at the White House.'' Afterwards, the actors had one more quick change to perform: out of their Christmas red-and-green satin Tuna robes and into tuxedos to join the Bushes and the governors for champagne and music on the State Floor.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Opposition Claims Victory In Stunning Upset
DOC.TEXT: Violeta Barrios de Chamorro, the steel-haired symbol of democracy, claimed victory Monday over President Daniel Ortega and the leftist Sandinista party that has ruled Nicaragua for 10{ years. ``This is the first time the opposition has ever won (in Nicaragua),'' said Mrs. Chamorro in a speech to supporters. At 3 a.m, nine hours after the polls closed, the Supreme Electoral Council announced that Mrs. Chamorro had 202,417 votes, or 54 percent, to Ortega's 159,100, or 42.5 percent, with 30.6 percent of precincts reporting. ``I am very happy,'' said Mrs. Chamorro as she left her house to go to campaign headquarters and speak to her supporters. ``The people wanted a change,'' she said when asked how she won. Asked if she thought a transfer of power would be smooth, she said, ``That's the commitment. We want peace and reconciliation.'' Celebrations began breaking out in various neighborhoods of Managua, with people burning many of the thousands of Sandinista banners that had been draped across Managua's streets. However, the celebrations appeared to die down quickly, and only a few fires were set.

DOC.HEAD: Pa., N.J. Bicker Over Interstate Bridges
DOC.TEXT: Not since George Washington led a surprise attack on the Hessians in 1776 has there been such a stir over crossing the Delaware River. Pennsylvania and New Jersey are bickering over control of two toll bridges linking the states. The dispute, Pennsylvania officials argue, is about independence and sovereignty and taxation without representation and other principles associated with the Revolutionary War. Officials with the Burlington County Bridge Commission in New Jersey say it's all much simpler than that: federal law gives them jurisdiction over the bridges, the commission needs more money to repair or replace them and it's fairest to get the money from the travelers who use them. So at the start of the year the commission doubled the tolls, to 50 cents, on the Tacony-Palmyra and Burlington-Bristol bridges spanning the Delaware River. The commission also moved ahead with plans to replace the 59-year-old Burlington-Bristol span. The moves drew the ire of lawmakers across the river. U.S. Sen. John Heinz, R-Pa., said the dispute may not ``dissolve our union,'' but he warned the commission had better consult Pennsylvania citizens if it plans on replacing the Burlington-Bristol Bridge. ``We are a nation of many sovereign states,'' Heinz said in a recent speech on the Senate floor. ``Although we like to think of ourselves as a perfect union, there are times when the sovereignty leads to fragmentation, divisiveness and threats upon the very notion of federalism.'' The senator also said that raising the tolls amounted to ``taxation without representation.'' Heinz this month introduced a bill in the Senate that would require cooperation between both states on any bridge project over the Delaware River. The Senate has taken no action on it. J. Garfield DeMarco, chairman of the bridge commission, did not return a reporter's telephone calls. But Stephanie Miller, a public relations consultant for the bridge commission, said Pennsylvanians have been consulted about the bridges _ and should have nothing to complain about anyway. Even at 50 cents, Miller said the bridges were ``a bargain'' compared with the two other major Delaware River spans, where tolls are 90 cents. Miller said the commission is using the extra money for desperately needed bridge maintenance. She said a new bridge, if finally approved by various state agencies, would likely be financed by a bond that could be repaid by another toll increase. But she said that is at least several years away. While it may be unusual for a single-state commission to have such authority over interstate bridges, Miller said the federal General Bridge Act of 1946 left little doubt about the commission's right to replace the Burlington-Bristol span. With two lanes and no median strip, the bridge is ``a real pain for commuters,'' Miller said. ``You drive by a truck and you feel you're going to get blown over. It's very rickety.''

DOC.HEAD: Deep Freeze Grips East, South
DOC.TEXT: Temperatures fell below zero in upstate New York and Michigan early today as an arctic blast ended weeks of unseasonably mild weather in the Northeast. Freezing temperatures extended into the South, while snow fell in Montana. Three days after highs reached the mid-60s in New York City, temperatures early today dropped to 10 degrees. Readings fell into the single digits in Boston and Portland, Maine. Wind chills were expected to drop to 20 to 50 below in eastern New York, Vermont and inland southern New England. Temperatures were at or near freezing in Alabama and Georgia during the night. Most of the nation enjoyed fair weather early today, but snow fell in central Montana. A winter storm Sunday produced up to 10 inches of snow around Narragansett, R.I., Martha's Vineyard, Mass., and parts of northwestern Connecticut. Elsewhere Sunday, snow fell over central Missouri, west-central Minnesota and eastern North Dakota. Scattered snow fell over northern upper Michigan, northeast Ohio, northwest Pennsylvania and western and central New York. The high temperature for the Lower 48 states Sunday was 87 degrees at Borrego Springs, Calif. DOC.HEAD: Observers Shuttle Between Ortega and Chamorro After Proclaiming Vote Clean
DOC.TEXT: The Big Three international observers dashed around in motorcades through the predawn hours today, racing from the president to a challenger who suddenly looked like an upset winner. The men one Sandinista adviser once called ``the holy trinity'' were reluctant to comment on the delicate situation. ``I really don't want to characterize it at all,'' said former U.S. Attorney General Elliot Richardson, head of the 240-member U.N. observer mission. Early returns suggested publisher Violeta Barrios de Chamorro could score a stunning upset and the question of the hour was how President Daniel Ortega and the Sandinistas might take defeat after more than a decade in power. ``You'll have to ask him,'' said former President Jimmy Carter. The meeting between Ortega and the umpires he'd invited anticipating victory ended abruptly, said a witness. ``Let's just wait for the rest of the results,'' Ortega said, turning his back on the distinguished guests. Carter, Richardson and Organization of American States Secretary General Joao Baena Soares then sped off, each in his own motorcycle-led motorcade, to Mrs. Chamorro's house. ``Carter is telling her that she had won,'' one of Mrs. Chamorro's closest advisers, Emilio Montalban Alvarez, told The Associated Press. Baena Soares also asked Mrs. Chamorro not to claim victory until all the returns were in, according to a high-ranking source inside her fragile coalition, the United National Opposition. (Mrs. Chamorro apparently ignored the request, claiming victory with 30.6 percent of the vote counted.) Lights flashing and tires squealing, the three umpires returned to Election Central. Throughout the bitter campaign, opposition vice presidential candidate Virgilio Godoy had said the Sandinistas would cheat rather than lose. But Baena Soares said the count, one of the most closely monitored in history, appeared clean so far. ``No problems,'' he said as he hustled into the counting center. ``No problems.'' The ballots were being counted twice, once at each polling place and again at regional election centers. The results were being telegraphed to the capital and compiled by the Supreme Electoral Council. International observers, more than 3,000 of them, were present at hundreds of local polling places as the ballots were tallied and in all nine regional centers. More than 1.75 million people had registered to vote in the nation's 4,394 polling places and the turnout appeared high. Key observers said the voting had been clean and peaceful. Richardson said none of the UN observers had reported any irregularities in the voting: ``It was essential here to convince skeptics that the vote could be conducted without fraud.'' The Sandinistas had been counting on an internationally endorsed victory to pave the way for improved relations with the United States. They were not prepared for defeat. Nicaragua was the first nation ever to invite the United Nations to monitor its election. The leftist Sandinista government had also invited the Organization of American States (OAS), former President Carter and hundreds of smaller groups. Observers from smaller missions also said they were impressed with how the vote was carried out. ``People were very serious about it,'' said Erin Saberi of the Southwest Voter Registration Project. She and other observers said they were warmly treated by voters and election officials alike. The only observers other than party poll watchers allowed to watch the actual counting were from the United Nations, the OAS and the Carter group. The U.N. and the OAS, which deployed 430 observers, have been in Nicaragua since August, monitoring virtually every step of the electoral process from voter registration to campaign rallies. While none called the campaign perfect, all agreed a free and fair election was possible. Both teams included everything from political analysts to statisticians to communications technicians drawn from their staffs and from member nations. Both teams were doing their own partial counts, a statistical sampling of returns aimed at detecting any fraud. Neither planned to release the results. The Supreme Electoral Council said it had issued credentials for more than 3,000 international observers from hundreds of groups, which meant one official watcher for every 550 or so voters _ or about the same number of observers as Contra rebel fighters believed to be in the country. ``The OAS was everywhere,'' Guatemalan lawmaker Edmond Mullet said after a day-long tour of the provinces Sunday. Mullet was one of 20 observers from the Washington-based Center for Democracy, which monitored the 1986 elections in the Philippines and the 1989 elections in Panama for the U.S. Senate. Carter played a key role in Panama, denouncing fraud while the votes were being counted. The discredited election in that country was part of the Bush administration's explanation for the December invasion that ousted strongman Manuel Antonio Noriega. Carter's observer mission is also considered crucial because it includes a dozen senators and congressmen, many of them members of key committees such as intelligence and foreign relations. Carter, Richardson and OAS Secretary General Joao Baena Soares had praised the the anti-fraud safeguards in place for the voting, many of which were adopted with input from the big observer missions.

DOC.HEAD: Education Groups and Liberals Take Aim at Juvenile Justice Nominee
DOC.TEXT: Groups representing teachers, probation officers and Washington-based liberals are joining in a campaign to derail the Bush administration's nominee as head of $81 million in juvenile justice programs. ``We vehemently oppose his appointment,'' says Kenneth F. Melley, the National Education Association's director of governmental relations. The dispute centers on the nomination of Robert Sweet, a Senate Republican Policy Committee staff aide, to be administrator of the Justice Department's office of juvenile justice and delinquency prevention. Conservatives praise his record and say he has become the victim of an unreasonable attack on the part of liberals. The agency funnels millions of dollars in federal grants designed to assist state and local government's in their fight against delinquency. Senate confirmation is required and that in turn has awakened memories of infighting between moderate Republicans and ``movement conservatives'' at the Education Department in the Reagan era. Among groups opposed besides the National Education Association are the American Probation and Parole Association, the Commonwealth of Virginia Juvenile Justice and Delinquency Prevention and Advisory Committee, the American Psychological Association and the National PTA. Some complain about his role in political turmoil at the Education Department seven years ago. All say he lacks experience specified by law for confirmation as head of the juvenile justice agency. Perhaps the most active critic, however, has been People for the American Way, the Washington-based liberal group that was prominent in the successful fight to block Robert Bork's confirmation to the Supreme Court and skirmishes against an array of other conservative nominees. That alone irks Sweet's chief defender, Sen. Gordon Humphrey, R-N.H. ``I think clearly some of these left-wing groups are trying to ignite a bonfire, but I don't see that it's having any effect,'' says Humphrey. ``I regarded their activities as an accolade in Bob's favor.'' Sweet and his supporters say he received strong commendation for his work at the department and has experience in the education field _ if not directly in juvenile justice _ that meets the requirements of the law. Sweet, 52, was involved in a painful episode in 1983 when he was executive director of the National Council for Educational Research. Sweet sought to enlarge his power considerably by asserting control over the National Institute of Education, the government's main educational research arm. He based his claim on an interpretation of the law sharply rejected by Terrel H. Bell, who was secretary of education at the time. In his memoirs, ``The Thirteenth Man,'' Bell said that Washington observers found Sweet's move ``uproariously funny.'' ``I should have laughed, too, but I was too angry to do anything but alternately scream and smolder,'' Bell said. He calls the affair an effort by ``movement conservatives'' to undermine his moderate rule at the department. Bell said he responded by demanding Sweet's removal. ``The effort yielded quick results. Sweet was offered a job in the White House.'' Sweet nonetheless says he can prove that he was well regarded by Bell when at the department. ``Secretary Bell actually sent a personal note to me, which I've kept, complimenting me on how well I'd run the agency,'' he said. ``I really don't want to comment on Secretary Bell, but I got along with him quite well him my tenure there,'' he added. Sweet and Humphrey scoff at the notion that he lacks requisite juvenile justice experience. He says his background in education meets the requirements. ``Hogwash,'' snorts Melanne Verveer, executive vice president of People for the American Way. ``He was a biology teacher. That's hardly a qualification for a job like this.'' She says more expertise is needed at a time when young people are confronted by drugs and an array of complex other social problems. Some of the questions may be resolved March 1, when the Senate Judiciary Committee is set to hold a hearing on Sweet's nomination. Members of the panel have said little about the matter thus far but lobbying is in full swing. Sen. John Kerry, D-Mass., who is not a member of the panel, wrote to Chairman Joseph R. Biden, D-Del., more than eight weeks ago to report that a number of individuals in the juvenile justice field ``have come to me to express a constellation of concerns about the merits of this nomination.''

DOC.HEAD: Czechoslovak President in Moscow for Meeting with Gorbachev
DOC.TEXT: President Vaclav Havel of Czechoslovakia arrived today for an official two-day visit that was to include talks with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, Radio Moscow said. The arrival of Havel coincided with the first day of the scheduled withdrawal of Soviet troops from Czechoslovakia. Havel was accompanied by Foreign Minister Jiri Dienstbier, Deputy Prime Minister Vladimir Dlougi, Interior Minister Richard Sacher and Defense Minister Miroslav Vacek, the official Tass news agency said. The Soviet Union and Czechoslovakia initialed an agreement on Feb. 22 calling for the total withdrawal of 73,500 Soviet troops from Czechoslokia in three stages, with the first stage beginning Monday. Gorbachev and Havel were expected to sign the agreement during the Czechoslovak president's stay. Soviet troops have been in Czechoslovakia since the Red Army-led Warsaw Pact invasion of 1968 suppressed attempts at political reform. On Friday, Havel returned from a visit to the United States, where he met with President Bush.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Slightly Higher, Gold Falls
DOC.TEXT: The dollar was slightly higher in moderate trading late this morning in Europe, helped by weakness in the Japanese yen and West German mark. Gold prices fell. The dollar was benefiting from a drop in the yen as traders sought refuge in the U.S. currency after the Tokyo stock market fell sharply early today, dealers said. The West German mark, meanwhile, was lower due to concerns about its possible exchange rate with the East German mark under German unification, dealers said. But traders said the dollar's outlook still was bearish. ``While the dollar has clearly taken the high road, it has lost some momentum,'' one Milan trader said. He added that ``the fundamentals of the U.S. economy aren't all that rosy.'' In Tokyo, where trading ends as Europe's business day begins, the dollar rose 2.18 yen to a closing 148.65 yen. Later, in London, it was quoted at a higher rate of 148.70 yen. Other dollar rates at midmorning compared with late Friday: _ 1.6874 West German marks, up from 1.6779 _ 1.4825 Swiss francs, up from 1.4770 _ 5.7115 French francs, up from 5.6715 _ 1.8980 Dutch guilders, up from 1.8890 _ 1,246.50 Italian lire, up from 1,240.75 _ 1.1982 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1965 In London, the dollar rose against the British pound, and was quoted at $1.6973, compared with $1.7090 late Friday. Gold opened in London at a bid price of $413.00 a troy ounce, down from 416.50 bid late Friday. At midmorning, the city's major bullion dealers fixed a recommended price of $412.75. In Zurich, the bid price was $412.75, down from $415.50 late Friday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold fell $2.47 to close at a bid $412.15. Silver fell in London to a bid price of $5.23 a troy ounce from Friday's $5.27.

DOC.HEAD: Astronaut's Widow Criticizes TV Docudrama `Challenger'
DOC.TEXT: The widow of an astronaut killed in the 1986 explosion of space shuttle Challenger lambasted the television docudrama ``Challenger,'' saying it devastated her children. ``How many kinds of death must Ellison Onizuka die? How many deaths of him do my children have to overcome?'' Lorna Onizuka told ABC affiliate KITV in an interview broadcast Sunday night, the night ABC aired the docudrama. ``My youngest daughter said, `First they killed him and now they're killing what I thought he was like.' She said, `How many times are they going to kill him?''' Mrs. Onizuka said in the telephone interview from her home near Houston. ``This production makes a mockery of my husband's life, the man he truly was and the ultimate sacrifice he made for a country he believed in,'' Mrs. Onizuka said. Ellison Onizuka of Hawaii and six other crew members died in the explosion shortly after liftoff from Cape Canaveral, Fla., on Jan. 28, 1986. Onizuka's brother, Claude, also objected to the movie. ``I think it made him seem like he was an arrogant person, which he wasn't,'' Claude Onizuka said. ``I think he was very humble. He remembered his roots and how he got there.'' Claude Onizuka was particularly upset with one scene that depicted the astronaut saying at a news conference that he would not mind a malfunction in space so he could put his emergency training to use. ``He would have never said something like that,'' Claude Onizuka said. George Englund Sr., the movie's executive producer and writer, defended the scene, telling KITV it was taken verbatim from a news conference. The docudrama also has been criticized by Grace Corrigan, the mother of Christa McAuliffe, the New Hampshire schoolteacher killed in the Challenger disaster. ``It started to upset me, then I said, `No, I'm not going to let it because it is only a video,'' she said last week. Englund said he knew there would be mixed reactions to the film, but defended it as ``sensitive in almost every aspect.''

DOC.HEAD: BULLETIN
Sandinistas Beaten In Stunning Upset
DOC.TEXT: Violeta Barrios de Chamorro defeated President Daniel Ortega in closely monitored elections and voting results showed a stunning rebuke to the Sandinistas who ruled Nicaragua after winning a revolution 10{ years ago.

DOC.HEAD: Smokers Try to Cope With Ban on Airline Smoking
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 12th graf, `Passengers were ...', to CORRECT to airplane bathrooms sted airport bathrooms.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY9
DOC.TEXT: Smokers puffed away in airport terminals as they tried to figure out how to cope with a new ban on smoking on virtually all domestic airline flights. Non-smokers breathed a bit easier. Dave Noeth, a traveler at La Guardia Airport in New York City, said under certain circumstances he was prepared to violate the ban that took effect Sunday. ``If the plane starts to go down, I'm lighting one up,'' he said. USAir flight attendant Kelly Brown in Atlanta said a colleague told her ``she had one man nearly miss his plane because he was just standing by the gate trying to finish his cigarette.'' In Seattle, Leo Haag complained that the new law is not fair. ``It doesn't bother me, two or three hours flying without a cigarette, but I don't think it's treating everybody equally,'' he said, puffing on a cigarette in an airport terminal. But non-smoking travelers said air quality on Sunday's flights had improved, and they were relieved not to breathe the smoke or have it foul their clothes. ``It's great,'' said Ron Upham in Newark. He said he and his wife used to try to get seats far away from the smoking section, but sometimes smelled smokers' air anyway. ``I feel like they're inflicting something on me,'' Upham said. The federal ban, in force since 1988 on flights of less than two hours, now applies to 99.8 percent of domestic flights. Only flights to Alaska and Hawaii of more than six hours are excepted. Overseas fights are not affected. Under the new law, smoking is allowed on only 28 of the nation's regularly scheduled 17,000 flights every day, said Jeff Boyer of the Coalition on Smoking or Health in Seattle. Passengers were told not to try smoking in airplane bathrooms. Tampering with smoke detectors in the plane's restrooms is a federal offense punishable with a $2,000 fine. Some smokers didn't resent the ban. ``It's probably going to add more years to my life,'' said David R. Merkel as he waited for a flight at Raleigh-Durham (N.C.) International Airport. ``But given my druthers, I'd rather have a cigarette.'' Other smokers were unequivocal. `I'm going to go nuts,'' said Joseph Golad of Chicago, resigning himself to a smokeless 2{-hour flight to Dallas from O'Hare International Airport. To help passengers like Golad, the Chicago Lung Association distributed ``Smoker Survival Kits,'' which contained sugarless chewing gum, breath mints and tips on how to cope. The association recommended passengers doodle to keep hands busy, stay away from the common cigarette companions of coffee and alcohol, and take a walk around the plane or go to sleep. In Seattle, the Coalition on Smoking or Health offered their own tips, and gave away candy and pins that read: ``I'm kissable, I don't smoke.'' A co-author of the ban, Democratic Sen. Frank Lautenberg of New Jersey, a former 20-year smoker, said the measure was the most popular he had ever worked on. ``It's the most positive thing in terms of response that I've ever done,'' he said. Lautenberg and Rep. Richard Durbin, D-Ill., said they hope the law will be extended soon to airport terminals and train travel. Lautenberg was mugging for cameras in Newark, N.J., as Joan Dahmer arrived on a bumpy flight from Dallas. ``I don't think it's right that we can't have a cigarette to calm us down,'' Dahmer complained. But in Denver, Frank Mills, an addictions therapist, took the occasion to puff on what he said he hoped would be the last cigarette of an 18-year habit. ``I think it's great,'' Mills said. ``I'm ready to quit.''

DOC.HEAD: Police Fire Tear Gas, Stun Grenades, at Protesting Students
DOC.TEXT: Riot police fired tear gas and a stun grenade today at student protesters who were demanding the release of detained friends and talks with President Felix Houphouet-Boigny about social injustices. Police also attacked peaceful protesters at the main campus and outside a suburban university residence, and beat up students and school pupils who blockaded a marketplace, witnesses said. Police appeared to be reacting with increasing violence as student protests entered their eighth day, defying a Sunday night appeal by Houphouet-Boigny for an end to the unrest. This usually peaceful West African nation is being undermined by growing discontent over austerity measures imposed to counter a 10-year-old recession. ``Free our comrades!'' a group of about 200 students yelled as they ran through the central Boulevard de la Republique, before fleeing riot police who fired tear gas and a stun grenade. They told reporters they want direct talks with Houphouet-Boigny, the 84-year-old president who has ruled the Ivory Coast as a one-party state since its independence from France in 1960. Militant students are demanding he step down and give way to a multiparty democracy. In Yopougon, a working class suburb where the unrest began Feb. 19, witnesses said police fired tear gas and stun grenades at a small group of students who refused to get on to two buses police said would take them from their dormitories to the main campus in Cocody suburb, three miles away. At the campus, students said riot police wielding truncheons set upon peaceful protesters and spectators who got in the way. A reporter at the scene said he watched three policemen repeatedly beat a student who stumbled and fell in the stampede to get away from the attackers. A taxi driver said he watched police beat students and school pupils who set up a blockade in the marketplace of Adjame, a residential suburb for working class and middle class Ivorians. The students and pupils fled, he said. Militant students tried to congregate in the city center to protest outside the presidential offices, where Houphouet-Boigny was meeting with representatives of businesses, trade unions and professional organizations. Sources said he is trying to win their support for additional austerity measures expected to be announced at a bigger meeting to include legislators on Tuesday. Employees at government-owned companies had their salaries cut 30 percent this month, and the students want Cabinet ministers' pay also reduced by that amount. Other civil servants have had their salary levels frozen for eight years.

DOC.HEAD: Widow Of Newspaper Publisher Leads Opposition To Victory
DOC.NOTE: Eds: RETRANSMITTING to fix paragraph spacing
DOC.TEXT: Violeta Barrios de Chamorro, publisher of the nation's opposition newspaper, led a 14-party coalition to victory over Sandinista rule despite political inexperience and a broken knee. ``The Nicaraguan people have shown that they want to live in democracy, in peace and in freedom,'' Mrs. Chamorro told more than 1,000 cheering supporters at her election headquarters today. ``I am very happy,'' she said. ``The people wanted a change.'' As a girl, Violeta Barrios wanted to learn to type and be a secretary when she grew up. Instead, she married a man who became one of Nicaragua's revolutionary heroes and was assassinated in 1978. As a gray-haired widow of 60, Mrs. Chamorro found herself the political symbol at the center of an electoral storm. Mrs. Chamorro ran for president with gusto and a common touch. Dona Violeta, as she is called even by President Daniel Ortega, said in in an earlier interview, ``I am nothing.'' ``But in this life, you can learn anything,'' she added. An elegant woman with graceful manners, Mrs. Chamorro's two main strengths are her martyred husband and her lack of alignment with any one political party. That was enough to qualify her as a candidate for the disparate and fractious United National Opposition, a coalition of 14 parties known as UNO. The memory of Pedro Joaquin Chamorro has been used by all sides, even by Mrs. Chamorro's four children, two of whom support Ortega. ``My father's enemies are within UNO,'' wrote Mrs. Chamorro's eldest daughter, Claudia. The phrase was used in Sandinista campaign graffiti throughout Nicaragua. Mrs. Chamorro's late husband, whose father started what is today Nicaragua's sole opposition newspaper, La Prensa, was shot down by assassins in January 1978. The slaying, believed to have been ordered by dictator Anastasio Somoza, ignited the popular revolt that brought the Sandinistas to power in July 1979. Mrs. Chamorro, who still publishes La Prensa, became a member of the junta that took over from Somoza but quit after nine months. She has bitter memories of what she considers the Sandinistas' betrayal of her husband's democratic goals and her own faith in the revolution. ``I'm not praising Somoza's government; it was horrible, but the threats that I've had from the Sandinistas _ I never thought they would repay me in that way,'' she said. Her pain as a widow, strong religous convictions and loyalty to Chamorro's memory _ she pays weekly visits to his grave to leave fresh flowers _ made her a symbol of dissatisfaction with the Sandinistas. But there have been many drawbacks. Even after months of campaigning, she stumbled over speeches and made baffling blunders. Last year, during a trip to Europe, she was asked about UNO's government program. ``It's a secret,'' she replied. The Sandinistas have tried to paint Mrs. Chamorro as empty-headed. A pro-government newspaper runs a daily column where nearly every joke portrays her as slow-witted. Perhaps responding to this, Mrs. Chamorro told a rally early in the campaign, ``I am not a dummy.'' One of her top advisers is her eldest son, Pedro Joaquin Chamorro, who returned from exile in Miami, where he had been a director of the U.S.-backed Contra rebels who tried to topple Ortega's government by force. The son feared his mother would be manipulated by vice presidential candidate Virgilio Godoy and top aide Alfredo Cesar, two strong-willed politicians. Mrs.Chamorro, the eldest daughter of a landowning family, was sent to U.S. finishing schools to learn English. With her father's death in 1948, she returned to the family home in the southern town of Rivas and married Chamorro. Her political awakening came after years of being a housewife and mother. On one of the various occasions Chamorro was imprisoned by Somoza, Mrs. Chamorro blew up at being kept in the dark. ``There had been something political and they threw him in jail,'' Mrs. Chamorro said. ``I asked Pedro what was going on. Then I told him, `Look, let's make a deal. From today on, you're going to tell me all that's happening, so I won't be caught unaware.' '' She has played the role of presidential candidate with gusto. She broke her right knee in a fall Dec. 31. and was hampered during the campaign by a cast. She campaigned from a wheelchair under a sun tent set up in the back of a pickup truck. Beaming smiles at peasants, Dona Violeta was familiar and neighborly, calling people ``papito'' and ``mamita.'' ``I try to help, to do good things for the country,'' Mrs. Chamorro said. ``I am what I am.''

DOC.HEAD: Moldavians Hope for Greater Sovereignty After Sunday Vote
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf to DELETE extraneous words ``50 percent''; SUBS 19th graf, ``Reform Communists ...'' to DELETE reference to Brazauskas as Lithuanian president.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Soviet-Politics, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A day after voters in Lithuania apparently voted the Communists out of power, Moldavia's restive citizenry cast ballots in their first free elections under Soviet rule. Like the Lithuanians to the north, many ethnic Moldavians are seeking sovereignty and hoped Sunday's balloting would bring victory to pro-independence forces. The weekend elections came amid nationwide pro-democracy rallies that demanded a swift end to the Communist Party's monopoly on power. In Sunday's vote in Moldavia, a republic bordering Romania, the pro-autonomy Moldavian Popular Front hoped to win at least half of the 380 seats in Parliament from the Communists. ``We think part of the other deputies will come around to our side,'' said Yuri Roshka, a Popular Front leader and candidate. One Popular Front voter, 26-year-old Anatoly Zhdanov, said after voting: ``We are learning democracy and we want to use the Parliament as a peaceful way to gain our sovereignty.'' Others in a park in Kishinev, the republic's capital, agreed. ``We want to be an independent republic _ not with the Russians, and not with the Romanians. And above all we want our sovereignty,'' said Anatoly Goncharov, listening to results of the Lithuanian election on a radio. The head of Lithuania's Sajudis Popular Front said Sunday that independence from Moscow might be attainable within months. On Saturday, the republic's voters appeared to choose the country's first legislature not dominated by Communists. Unofficial returns showed that of the 90 races decided, candidates endorsed by Sajudis took 72 seats and non-Sajudis candidates took 18, said Rita Dapkus, head of the Sajudis information agency. There are 141 seats, and the rest were to be decided in runoffs March 10. ``If that is not a landslide, then what is?'' Algimantas Cekuolis, a Sajudis officer, told a news conference Sunday in the republic's capital, Vilnius. ``It is a very clear indication of what the people of Lithuania think.'' Sajudis gathered the election results by calling local election commissions, and the tallies were believed to be reliable. Official results in Lithuania were expected today, as were unofficial returns from Moldavia. Turnout among the 2.56 million eligible Lithuanians was about 75 percent, officials said. ``We have a common and very clear goal. Our clear goal is statehood and the independence of Lithuania,'' said Vytautus Landsbergis, Sajudis chairman. ``This goal is achievable this year.'' Sajudis wants talks with Moscow to prepare for an orderly secession, which would break a 50-year-old tie that began with Lithuania's occupation by the Red Army in 1940 and its forcible annexation later that year. The movement supports a neutral, sovereign Lithuania characterized by a market economy and guarantees for human and cultural rights. The Soviet Communist Party recently pledged to support legislation establishing a procedure by which republics could legally secede from the union. Although Sajudis dominated Saturday's voting, Landsbergis did not rule out a strong role for reformed Communists in a coalition government selected by the new Parliament. He stressed the close ties between Sajudis and reform-minded Communist Party members. Reform Communists won 22 seats on Saturday, 13 in districts where they were backed by Sajudis. The Communist winners included the party's first secretary, Algirdas Brazauskas, who in December defied Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev and led his party to split with Moscow. While Lithuania enjoyed two decades of independence between the world wars, Moldavia, a republic of 4 million people in the southwest corner of the Soviet Union, has not known independence this century. Until the czarist empire fell apart in 1917, Moldavia was the Russian province of Bessarabia. After World War I it was ceded to Romania, with which it shares a nearly identical language and many historical and cultural heroes. Moldavia's common heritage with Romania was suppressed when Stalin annexed it to the Soviet Union in 1940. But a half-century of Soviet domination failed to diminish the desire of many of the estimated 3 million ethnic Moldavians to reunite with their neighbor. Demands for unity surged in Moldavia when Romania's December revolution toppled Communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu. But the Popular Front says reunification should be put on hold for the moment in favor of rebuilding the republic's economy and restoring Moldavian culture, stunted by decades of Russification. The Popular Front said it would press for the right to engage in direct economic relations with other countries, a multiparty political system, private property and a market economy. Parliamentary elections were also held Sunday in the Central Asian republic of Tadzhikistan, recently rocked by ethnic unrest in which at least 22 people died. Reports from the capital of Dushanbe, monitored in London, said voting was orderly. Official radio put the voter turnout at 64 percent and attributed the low turnout to the 6 p.m. curfew that has been in effect since Feb. 12 to prevent more unrest. A parliamentary vote also took place Sunday in neighboring Kirghizia, a mountainous republic on the border with China. The official Tass news agency said official results in both elections were expected to be announced Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Prosecutors Checking Whether Underaged Immigrant Was Right Defendant
DOC.TEXT: As prosecutors try to prove an inmate was not wrongly tried as an adult in an armed robbery, a published report raised questions about whether he even committed the crime. Luan Van Hoang was 13 but claimed to be 17 and gave a fictitious name when he was charged in 1986, documents show. The Vietnamese refugee was convicted and sentenced to 38 years and since has been in a maximum-security prison. Last week, District Judge Jack Hampton ordered Hoang returned to Dallas for a hearing to determine his actual age. He is believed to be 17. Luan's age, however, no longer remains the only question about his conviction, The Dallas Morning News reported Sunday. A transcript of testimony in his trial raises the issue of whether officials prosecuted the right person, the paper said. Luan said he told authorities his name was Michael Nguyen and that he was 17 to avoid being returned to a youth detention center in California where he had spent eight months of a nine-month term for joyriding and auto theft. The boy said he believed Vietnamese friends who told him that lying about his age would result in probation. Dallas County authorities accepted Luan's story and tried him as an adult. In 1986, police portrayed Luan as the ``ringleader'' of a youth gang that committed a series of armed robberies in Dallas County. Luan was identified during his trial as a gun-wielding robber. But Luan, who did not testify in his trial and appeared with an interpreter, said he waited outside the home of a Vietnamese couple in Carrollton, a Dallas suburb, while they were robbed by four of his companions. He said he did not enter the home, use a gun or receive any of the proceeds from the robbery. Testimony in Luan's trial reveals several inconsistencies. Luan, abandoned by his companions after the robbery, was arrested less than an hour later at a car wash, where police found a broken watch worth $50 and a costume jewelry pin worth $5, taken during the robbery. A $1,500 gold chain and $2,000 in cash were among other items stolen in the robbery. Not explained in the trial, the Morning News said, is why the alleged gun-toting gang leader would be stranded by his subordinates and left with the least valuable items taken in the heist. Testimony showed that police were unable to find Luan's fingerprints at the robbery site. The state's case against Luan hinged on the testimony of a victim who, according to the police report, was blindfolded during much of the robbery, the newspaper reported. Prosecutors, however, have requested information from California authorities that they hope will challenge the growing number of records _ some of them sworn statements _ that show Luan would have been 13 at the time of his trial. Luan was returned to Dallas from the Texas Department of Corrections last week after the newspaper reported that immigration and school records show he was born Oct. 10, 1972. The newspaper since has obtained two sworn court documents from California prosecutors and one from another immigrant who escaped with Luan from Vietnam in 1980, showing that Luan would have been 13 at the time of his conviction in Dallas.

DOC.HEAD: Skirmishing in East Beirut
DOC.TEXT: Rival Christian forces skirmished in east Beirut today while a mediation committee said it was determined to maintain its effort to stabilize a cease-fire despite persistent violations. Police said two people were killed and six wounded by sniper fire in various districts of embattled east Beirut controlled by Samir Geagea's Lebanese Forces militia and renegade Gen. Michel Aoun's troops. By police count, the showdown for dominance of the 310-square-mile Christian enclave has killed 693 people and wounded 1,921 since it broke out Jan. 30. Father Boulos Naaman, a member of the three-man Christian mediation committee, said in an interview on Geagea's Lebanese Broadcasting Corp. television that his panel ``will not get fed up, despite the difficulties we are facing.'' The two sides began observing a cease-fire Feb. 17 after fighting each other to a standstill. However, they have been reinforcing their forces in east Beirut and other districts of the Christian enclave in apparent preparation for more clashes. The mediation committee, which called the cease-fire, has been trying for three days to reopen roads linking areas controlled by the 6,000-member militia and Aoun's 19,000-strong army, in an effort to buttress the truce and ease the plight of the population. But a three-hour shelling duel Sunday prevented the committee from reopening a major road junction in east Beirut. In a related development, the leftist newspaper As-Safir said an unnamed representative of Syrian-backed President Elias Hrawi met Geagea in east Beirut and obtained from him a ``written pledge to accept bringing east Beirut under government control'' if Hrawi's government intervened to stop the intra-Christian showdown. The report could not be immediately verified with the Lebanese Forces command. Hrawi was elected Nov. 24 in line with an Arab-brokered peace accord to end Lebanon's nearly 15 years of civil war. Aoun has rejected Hrawi's election along with the peace plan which was worked out by Lebanese legislators at the Saudi town of Taif last October. He objects to the pact because it does not provide an explicit timetable for a full withdrawal of Syria's 40,000 troops from Lebanon. They have been in the country since 1976 under an Arab League peace-keeping mandate. Aoun, Geagea and Hrawi are Maronite Catholics, the Christian sect that has dominated political institutions in Lebanon since independence from France in 1943. Also today, two leading newspapers published letters addressed to American journalist Terry Anderson from his sister expressing hope that he and the other foreign hostages held in Lebanon will be released soon. ``You are all sent strength and love and hope. Do not despair for some day _soon, please God _ we will all be reunited,'' Peggy Say said in her letter to her brother and all other hostages held in Lebanon. An Arabic translation of the letter was published on the front page of the independent An-Nahar and on an inside page in the leftist As-Safir. A second message was signed by Bill Foley, a friend of Anderson's, in the name of the Journalists Committee to Free Terry Anderson. Anderson, 42, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press, was kidnapped March 16, 1985, in Moslem west Beirut. He is the longest held of the 18 Western captives in Lebanon.

DOC.HEAD: Unrest Flares in Gaza, 20 Reported Wounded, Three Homes Wrecked
DOC.TEXT: Dozens of Palestinian youths stoned soldiers trying to impose a curfew today in the occupied Gaza Strip and the army responded with tear gas and gunfire, shooting and wounding 22 people, Arab reports said. Army helicopters dropped tear gas into the southern town of Rafah after the clash erupted outside the home of a Palestinian youth who died a day earlier after a confrontation with soldiers, Palestinian witnesses said. U.N. relief officials said 38 other people suffered minor injuries from rubber bullets and 100 people were treated for tear gas inhalation at a local clinic near the site of the riots in Brazil refugee camp in Rafah. The army confirmed there were clashes in Rafah and that eight people were hospitalized for gunshot wounds. Rafah also was declared a closed military zone, the army said, effectively barring entry and exit to the area's 50,000 residents. Soldiers also destroyed the homes of three Palestinians accused of killing an alleged collaborator, the army said. It said a fourth home was sealed because one of its residents was suspected of fire bomb attacks. The military, meanwhile, planned to begin a phased reopening of colleges and universities that have been shut throughout the 26-month rebellion against Israeli occupation, the Jerusalem Post daily reported. Army officials refused to comment on the report, which said 16 vocational schools would be opened in the first stage. But the military announced plans for a news conference later today on the subject. In Israel, tens of thousands of Israeli Arabs staged a general strike to protest inadequate funding for municipal governments in Arab areas and the central government's failure to make good on a promise to write off $50 million in debts. The violence in Gaza came the morning after Vahel Jamil El Hams, 20, died at Tel Hashomer Hospital near Tel Aviv of wounds sustained in a clash with soldiers in the Brazil camp. El Hams' death raised to 659 the number of Palestinians killed by Israelis since the start of the uprising in December 1987. An additional 189 Palestinians have been slain by fellow Arabs as suspected collaborators, and 43 Israelis also have been killed. Dozens gathered outside El Hams' home and threw stones as troops who arrived at the scene in 23 jeeps tried to impose a curfew, Arab witnesses said. Soldiers reportedly responded by opening fire and were joined by troops who shot tear-gas from helicopters. At least 22 people wounded with bullets were treated at Nasser Hospital in nearby Khan Yunis, among them two 12-year-old boys, hospital reports said.

DOC.HEAD: Pittsburgh Ponders Taxing College Research Grants
DOC.TEXT: A city proposal to tax research grants has angered college officials, who say it would be unprecedented and could undermine the region's economic development. ``I've never heard such a thing in Pittsburgh, the state or the country,'' said Louis Popper, chief general counsel at the University of Pittsburgh. ``Frankly, I'd be surprised if anybody ever has.'' Under the city's proposal, research grants would be subject to a six mill business privilege tax. A mill is a tenth of a cent. If such a tax had been in effect last year, it would have generated as much as $1.6 million. The city's finance director, Ben Hayllar, said there are no immediate plans to impose such a tax. But, he said, ``We've talked about it and will look at it.'' That's enough to worry officials at both Pitt and Carnegie Mellon University, which both receive millions in research grants, especially in medicine and computer science. ``We are legally tax exempt and I would vigorously oppose any effort to cheat on that,'' said Carnegie Mellon University President Richard M. Cyert. ``This kind of research is the key to economic development, not only here but nationally.'' The idea is taking a back seat to an effort to remove university-owned buildings from the city's list of tax-exempt real estate. But the taxing of grants could come up for serious discussion later in the year, officials said. Pitt received about $143 million in grants in fiscal 1989, $113 million from federal, state or local governments. If all that were subject to tax, the college would owe $859,200. If only the private contributions were taxed, the amount would be $111,600. Carnegie Mellon received a total of nearly $121 million in research grants during the same period, including $19 million in private contributions. Its tax would be $724,200 on everything; $113,400 on private contributions alone.

DOC.HEAD: Prime Minister Carlsson Returned To Office In Parliament Vote
DOC.TEXT: Parliament confirmed Ingvar Carlsson as prime minister of a new Social Democratic government today, 12 days after he resigned when his economic austerity policy was defeated. The vote of 175-101, with 59 abstentions, came after Carlsson revamped his proposals to rescue Sweden from inflation climbing toward 9 percent, amid stagnant growth. Fourteen legislators were absent from the 349-member Riksdag. The new Cabinet will be presented and installed on Tuesday. The vote ended the worst political crisis for the Social Democrats since they returned to power in 1982 after a six-year hiatus, the only time they had sat in opposition since 1932. Carlsson's Cabinet resigned Feb. 14 when the legislature rejected his emergency economic program. He was asked to form a new government Thursday after the centrist opposition parties failed to unite on a common policy. The Social Democrats, who control 156 seats, won support from the 21-member Communist Party when Carlsson dropped a proposal to impose a two-year freeze on wages and prices and to ban strikes. The new 17-point package would bnring in foreign workers from the Soviet Baltic states to alleviate an inflation-boosting labor shortage, and increase taxes on alcohol and tobacco. Two center-right opposition parties condemned what they called Carlsson's sham resignation and said they favored immediate elections, 18 months ahead of schedule. ``The government crisis looks like a piece of absurd theater, in which many have been forced to play along,'' said Bengt Westerberg, leader of the Liberal Party. Carl Bildt, head of the conservative Moderate Party said, ``We say `no' to the prime minister being allowed to return as if nothing had happened.'' The opposition was given a chance last week to assemble a ruling coalition. But the three non-socialist parties failed to patch differences on economic and energy policy or overcome the socialist majority held by the Social Democrats and Communists.

DOC.HEAD: East Chilled By Coldest Weather of Year; 19 Dead in Accidents
DOC.TEXT: The coldest weather since December slid further down the East Coast today after a snowy weekend in which at least 19 people died in weather-related accidents in five states. ``This will be the coldest weather of 1990,'' said Mel Goldstein, director of the Weather Center at Western Connecticut State University in Danbury. ``We didn't get January in January, so we're getting it in late February.'' The balmy breezes that brought a hint of spring to the Northeast last week were quickly replaced by below-zero wind chills and blowing snow. Records were set this morning in Newark, N.J., where the temperature at the airport was 8 degrees; in Pomona, N.J., where it was 9 degrees; in Windsor Locks, Conn., where it was 3 below zero; and in Syracuse, N.Y., where it was minus 8. At 5 a.m., it was 20 below zero at Saranac Lake in New York's Adirondacks. Walter Zamorski, a National Weather Service meteorologist in Newark, said the weather front was known as the ``Alberta Low,'' after the Canadian province that's getting blamed for launching it southward. Up to a foot of snow fell over a wide area on Saturday and Sunday, causing numerous traffic pileups. The worst of the crashes occurred Saturday evening in western Ohio on Interstate 75 near Tipp City, where 30 cars and two tractor-trailer rigs were involved in a fiery chain-reaction crash in which nine people died and 55 were injured. Still larger pileups north of the Tipp City crash effectively closed I-75. Three separate crashes within three miles of Findlay involved a total of 99 cars. The highway reopened Sunday. ``In my 18 years, this is by far the worst I've ever seen,'' patrol Lt. Dan Dickerson said of the Tipp City pileup. Leaking gas tanks caused a fire that spread through the wreckage, hampering rescue efforts. In all, 13 people died in weather-related accidents in Ohio. Another three died in Illinois, and one each in Michigan, Indiana and Kentucky. The snow caused a 30-car fender-bender Sunday on Interstate 91 near Holyoke, Mass., but state police reported only minor damage and no injuries.
