Blowing snow was blamed for a massive chain-reaction pileup on Interstate 87 near Saratoga Springs, N.Y. Fifteen people suffered minor injuries. A person at the scene said a whiteout from the blowing snow blinded several drivers, who began sliding sideways and banging into each other. As far south as North Carolina, winds reached up to 50 mph, blowing trees and limbs onto utility lines and causing at least 3,500 people to lose power over the weekend, authorities said. In Georgia, farmers fretted about what a freeze would do to their peaches. At 9 a.m. today, it was 31 degrees in Atlanta. ``Depending upon how cold it gets, the peach crop could be wiped out,'' state Agriculture Commissioner Tommy Irvin said Sunday. ``You could also have damage to the apple trees, the ornamentals on certain trees and the wheat crop.'' Al Pearson, chairman of the Georgia Agriculture Commodity Commission for Peaches, said it would be at least Wednesday before officials could assess the damage.

DOC.HEAD: Newspapers Publish Letters to Anderson
DOC.TEXT: Two leading newspapers today published letters addressed to American journalist Terry Anderson from his sister, expressing hope he and the other foreign hostages held in Lebanon will be released soon. ``You are all sent strength and love and hope. Do not despair for some day _soon, please God _ we will all be reunited,'' Peggy Say said in her letter to her brother and all other hostages held in Lebanon. An Arabic translation of the letter was published on the front page of the independent An-Nahar and on an inside page in the leftist As-Safir. A second message was signed by Bill Foley, a friend of Anderson's, in the name of the Journalists Committee to Free Terry Anderson. ``Countless people around the word remember all of you and work to end your suffering,'' the message said. Anderson, 42, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press, was kidnapped March 16, 1985, in Moslem west Beirut. He is the longest held of the 18 Western captives in Lebanon. Mrs. Say is on a tour with an Associated Press delegation to seek the release of Anderson and the others. She has met with U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar, Pope John Paul II and Yasser Arafat, chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization. ``Pope Paul gave me a rosary for you, to replace the one you have made in captivity,'' Mrs. Say said. The papers published their own Arabic translation of the letters. The English text was not published, casting doubt on whether Anderson and other hostages will be able to understand what was addressed to them. Anderson and the 17 other captives did not know Arabic at the time they were kidnapped. Most of the hostages are believed held by pro-Iranian Shiite Moslem extremist factions. They are eight Americans, four Britons, two Swiss, two West Germans, an Irishman and an Italian.

DOC.HEAD: East Germany Accepts Applications for Unemployment Benefits
DOC.TEXT: East Germany today began accepting applications for unemployment benefits for the first time in the Communist nation's 40-year history. Also today, an opposition party leveled new accusations of fraud against the Communist leadership. Unofficial estimates contend that 70,000 East Germans are unemployed, but Labor Ministry spokesman Joachim Guenter said the number of applicants was far lower than had been expected. Authorities speculated about 4,000 people would seek the new insurance. While the number of unemployed is relatively low among East Germany's 9 million workers, the figure is expected to shoot up to as much as 15 percent after competitive Western practices are introduced. West Germany has offered an economic bailout of East Germany in return for a wholesale conversion to capitalism and eventual unity. In the latest accusations against the embattled Communists, a little-known political group, the Independent People's Party, filed a complaint in the nation's high court alleging Communist Party leader Gregor Gysi manipulated financial records for 1989, East Germany's ADN news agency reported. The Communists previously controlled most of the nation's wealth, and numerous accusations have been made against the former party leadership for allegedly skimming funds for personal use or misstating the party's wealth to avoid having to turn over assets. Gysi took over the party leadership in December and declared it a reformed organization free of corruption. The complaint seeks to have Gysi jailed pending investigation. No immediate action was taken by judicial authorities on the People's Party appeal. There also was no immediate reaction from the Communist Party. On Sunday, East German Premier Hans Modrow gave the Communists a last chance for political survival by agreeing to lead his party in March 18 elections. The reformist premier made the announcement at a political rally. Although Modrow remains the most popular politician in East Germany, the Communists are expected to poorly in the balloting because their forerunners are blamed for leading the nation to the brink of collapse. Modrow's decision to stand by the party could draw enough voter support for a parliamentary presence.

DOC.HEAD: New Absentee Voting Rules Change Campaigning
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with three grafs to CLARIFY that only a few polling places are open for absentee balloting. Picks up 4th graf, `In the...'.
DOC.TEXT: The Texas primary isn't until March 13, but balloting has begun under the state's new ``no excuse'' absentee voting system, which politicians say has made big changes in the way they campaign. This is the first governor's race under the 1987 extended voting law, which lets Texans cast ballots during a period that began Wednesday and ends March 9. Before 1987, absentee voting was allowed for about 10 days, and voters needed a valid excuse to cast an absentee ballot _ a trip out of their home county, for instance. Now, voters just have to show up at select polling places, such as county courthouses, and cast their ballots. In the 1988 presidential primaries, ballots cast before election day more than doubled compared with the 1984 primary, results showed. George Bayoud, Texas secretary of state, said the new law gives voters no excuse not to vote in the primary. ``Those old excuses about being turned off by having to stand in long lines or having to take off work on a weekday are no longer valid,'' he said. Bayoud planned to vote absentee and make several public appearances to tout the new law. His spokesman Mark Toohey said, ``This will be a bellwether. This will be a good test to see how many people this attracts to the polls.'' The relaxed requirements pose new challenges for candidates, said Diane Sheridan, president of the League of Women Voters. ``The extended absentee voting creates a need for extended information,'' Ms. Sheridan said. Ed Martin, executive director of the Texas Democratic Party, agreed, saying candidates must have television ads going and mailouts arriving each day of the absentee voting period or they stand to lose a certain number of voters. Most of the gubernatorial candidates have developed strategies aimed at absentee voters. Republican rancher and oil man Clayton Williams notified 100,000 potential supporters of absentee voting locations and times. ``It will be too little too late,'' for candidates who don't have successful absentee voting programs, said Williams' state co-chairman, Roy Barrera Jr. The new law means more campaign spending in a state with 17 million people and 21 television markets. The seven major GOP and Democratic candidates already have spent $20 million, and analysts say the final tab could reach $50 million. ``It forces the candidates to stretch out their media dollars and not just concentrate at the end of the campaign,'' said political consultant George Christian of Austin. Christian said probably 40 percent of the primary voters will cast absentee ballots. There are approximately 8.2 million voters registered for the primary election. Democratic and Republican party officials say they will lead absentee voting drives during the November general election campaign, but are letting the candidates handle the effort for the primaries. Although absentee voting was not reported separately until last year, election officials have tracked absentee voting patterns in major cities and believe the extended, no-excuse law has boosted voter turnout in other races. For example, in San Antonio, 8,218 walk-in absentee ballots were cast in the 1984 presidential primary. After the new law was implemented, 41,262 people voted absentee in the 1988 presidential primary. In Houston, absentee votes increased from 4,683 in the 1984 presidential primary to 7,082 in 1988. Absentee voting also jumped in Dallas, from 1,492 to 9,571 in the two presidential primaries, and in Fort Worth, from 3,099 to 8,822. But Christian said there is no proof the law has increased overall turnout, just that a larger portion of the voters have cast early ballots.

DOC.HEAD: 1,000-Car Caravan Protests Controllers Treatment of Avianca Flight
DOC.TEXT: A Colombian-American group organized a 1,000-car caravan that rolled through John F. Kennedy International Airport to protest the circumstances surrounding the crash of Avianca Flight 52. The group, Colombianos Unidos de America, called Sunday for the release of all the facts about the flight, which apparently ran out of fuel before crashing on New York's Long Island, killing 73 people. Demonstrators charged that air traffic controllers had displayed bias against the flight because it was Colombian, making it circle the airport when it was low on fuel. ``There's obvious discrimination against all flights from Colombia,'' Fernando Oliver, who said he was a lawyer for survivors of two crash victims, told The New York Times. He added that the plane had not been allowed to land at another airport because drug-sniffing dogs were already in place at Kennedy. ``That's not the case at all,'' said Kathleen Bergen, a spokeswoman for the Federal Aviation Administration. ``The plane made an approach to Kennedy and missed. And it was coming around to make a second approach. I think that speaks for itself.'' Sgt. Pete Berry, a police spokesman, said the protest caravan started at Shea Stadium at about 11:30 a.m. and proceeded to the airport, which is about five miles away. Berry said the caravan was orderly and created no traffic problems. The first 73 cars displayed the names of the crash victims. Others carried placards and cards criticizing the air controllers. Flight 52 crashed Jan. 25 in Cove Neck, an affluent suburb on Long Island Sound. The crash is under investigation by the National Transportation Safety Board.

DOC.HEAD: Couple Killed 10 Years After Immigrating From Vietnam
DOC.TEXT: A month after celebrating the 10th anniversary of their arrival from Vietnam, a couple were killed along with a niece and nephew when a truck hit their car broadside at a busy intersection. Huy Huu Tran, 37, and his wife, Linh Tri-Cam Doan, 35, of Stillwater, held a lavish dinner last month to celebrate their success and thank friends and employers for helping make their American dream come true. Killed with them Sunday were a niece and nephew whose parents remain in Vietnam. The Rev. Merle Strohbehn of the First Presbyterian Church, which sponsored the couple, said that in 10 years the Trans had learned English, built careers and bought a home. Tran was a highly skilled machinist and his wife was a seamstress, he said. State Patrol Lt. Rod Lundgren said it appeared that the tractor-trailer rig, carrying potatoes, ran a red light. The driver was being held pending a decision by the county attorney on whether to file charges.

DOC.HEAD: Oily Water Seeps into Wetlands Area, Flood Control Channel
DOC.TEXT: A surging high tide pushed crude oil past a series of floating booms and through an earthen barrier into an environmentally sensitive marsh, coating at least three birds with oil. The oil flowed Sunday into an area of mud flats and pickle weed that is habitat for federally listed endangered birds. The birds covered with oil, not members of endangered species, were taken to be cleaned, said Gary Gorman, director of the Huntington Beach Wetlands Conservancy. ``There is a minor threat there,'' Gorman said. The conservancy is trying to restore the 25-acre marsh into a wetlands wildlife habitat. Workers from the Orange County Flood Control District rebuilt the 6-foot-high barrier while cleanup crews tried to contain the oil, Huntington Beach Fire Battalion Chief Dennis Groat said. ``We are back in cycles of higher than average tides,'' Groat said. ``We also have very strong surf swell out of the south.'' Tests were being performed to determine if the oil came from the damaged tanker American Trader, said officials of British Petroleum, operator of the ship. The American Trader, apparently punctured by its own anchor, spilled 400,000 gallons of crude off Huntington Beach on Feb. 7, closing 12 miles of Orange County beaches. ``There is some concern that this may have been from an upstream source,'' British Petroleum spokeswoman Marcia Meermans said. British Petroleum owned the crude oil. At least three endangered species _ the California least tern, the California brown pelican and the Beldings Savannah sparrow _ nest and forage in the marsh.

DOC.HEAD: Supreme Court allows CIA to withhold documents from Texas lawyer
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today refused to force the CIA to release its documents on the 1985 sinking by French government agents of the Greenpeace ship Rainbow Warrior. The justices, without comment, let stand rulings that the spy agency may withhold the documents from a Houston lawyer who is seeking them under the Freedom of Information Act (FOIA). Greenpeace, an international environmental group, had been preparing to monitor and protest a scheduled French nuclear weapons test when its vessel exploded and sank in the Auckland, New Zealand, harbor July 10, 1985. The French government two months later admitted that two of its intelligence agents, acting on orders from senior officials, had attached explosive devices to the ship's hull. Houston lawyer John R. Knight asked the Central Intelligence Agency in October 1985 for all documents in its possession dealing with the Rainbow Warrior sinking. His request was based on the FOIA, enacted in 1966 to curtail government secrecy. The CIA refused to disclose any documents, and Knight then filed an FOIA lawsuit. In resisting disclosure, CIA officials said the documents Knight sought are ``matters that are ... specifically exempt from disclosure by statute'' enpowering the CIA director to protect ``intelligence sources and methods from unauthorized disclosure.'' U.S. District Judge Gabrielle K. McDonald ruled for the CIA, and her ruling was upheld by the 5th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals last May. The appeals court relied heavily on a 1985 Supreme Court decision that gave the CIA unlimited power to conceal from the public not only the identities of secret agents but also all sources of intelligence information _ classified and unclassified. ``Given the Supreme Court's broad holding in (1985), we conclude that the CIA must prevail here,'' the appeals court said. ``The documents are exempt from FOIA disclosure. This is so because the director of Central Intelligence determined, with full authority to do so, that the release of the documents could compromise intelligence sources and methods.'' The 5th Circuit court added: ``In the absence of bad faith or some other compelling showing that he has abused his broad discretion, his determination may not be second-guessed by the courts.'' The case is Knight vs. U.S. Central Intelligence Agency, 89-878.

DOC.HEAD: Court Rules Against Businessman Who Sold Plans to Libya
DOC.TEXT: A California businessman sentenced to 15 years in prison and fined $6.6 million for selling two airplanes to Libya lost a Supreme Court appeal today. The court, without comment, let stand Edward Elkins' conviction and sentence for conspiracy and violating U.S. export restrictions. Elkins, who owned a Santa Maria, Calif., company that made armored products, was convicted in a 1987 federal trial in Georgia of selling the planes for $87 million to a West German company owned by Libyans. Elkins made a $7 million profit on the sales. Prosecutors said Elkins first tried unsuccessfully to get State Department approval to sell a Lockheed military transport plane to a Libyan dealer. After that failed, prosecutors said Elkins succeeded in getting an export license from the Commerce Department for two other Lockheed planes, both L-100-30s. The government said the Libyans were told the L-100-30 planes could be modfied to permit midair refueling so they would be suitable for military use. Elkins never informed Lockheed or Commerce Department officials that the planes were to be modified, prosecutors said. Prosecutors said he also told the federal agency the planes were destined for the tiny nation of Benin. Investigators said one plane eventually was found in Cairo, Egypt, with an operations manual indicating it had been used by the Libyan Air Force. The 11th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals last September upheld Elkins' conviction and sentence. The appeals court rejected arguments that Elkins was convicted improperly under a federal anti-fraud law. The appeals court also upheld instructions the trial judge gave the jury to break a deadlock, and it ruled that Elkins' sentence was not excessive. The case is Elkins vs. U.S., 89-1206.

DOC.HEAD: Nine Killed In New Unrest Despite Mandela Peace Plea
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS thruout to UPDATE with more killings, details on prison hunger strike, Mandela's meetings; EDITS to trim; No Pickup
DOC.TEXT: Clashes in southeastern Natal province left at least 13 people dead, authorities said today, despite a plea by Nelson Mandela for warring black factions to throw their weapons into the sea. Mandela, in a speech Sunday in Durban to about 100,000 people, said the black factional fighting in Natal hindered the battle against apartheid, South Africa's policy of racial segregation. ``My message to those of you involved in this battle of brother against brother is this: Take your guns, your knives and your pangas and throw them into the sea,'' Mandela said. Pangas are similar to machetes. Police say the violence has claimed about 3,000 lives over the past four years. Police with shotguns killed two protesters and wounded four more today when they fired on a crowd attacking a community center in a black township near the central town of Kroonstad, police said. Two policemen were fatally shot near Pietermaritzburg in Natal Province late Sunday and two other officers died in separate attacks nearby, police said. Three men died and two were injured in clashes Sunday in Natal between rival factions, police said. Warring groups burned houses and huts in two areas of Natal during the fighting, they said. The main combatants in Natal are the African National Congress-aligned United Democratic Front and Inkatha, a relatively conservative Zulu political group headed by Mangosuthu Buthelezi. The Zulu leader is a staunch oppenent of apartheid, but he differs with the ANC over the best way to fight it. The ANC favors sanctions, boycotts, strikes and guerrilla attacks to put pressure on the government. Buthelezi does not endorse any of these actions and is a proponent of capitalism in contrast to the socialist-oriented ANC. In the black homeland of Venda, two people where killed when police dispersed a rally Saturday in honor of Mandela, the independent South African Press Association said in a report that quoted a witness. Also, police said two men were burned to death in Soweto, outside Johannesburg. The men had car tires placed around their necks and set alight, a form of attack known as the ``necklace.'' Police said they did not know the motive for the killings. In Cape Town, police arrested 25 people demonstrating outside Parliament in support of relatives at the nearby Robben Island Prison jailed for politically motivated acts. Police declared the protest illegal and forced the demonstrators, mostly women, into vans. The anti-apartheid Mass Democratic Movement said 343 men were participating in a hunger strike at the prison. The Prisons Service said only that ``a number'' of inmates were not eating. The hunger strikers consider themselves political prisoners who should be freed under reforms initiated by President F.W. de Klerk, the Mass Democratic Movement said. De Klerk has said his government will release people convicted of belonging to previously outlawed groups that he legalized Feb. 2. However, the government has refused to free activists convicted of violent crimes. De Klerk legalized the African National Congress and other black opposition groups and released Mandela in a bid to start talks on ending white-minority rule and sharing power with blacks. Mandela today resumed his busy schedule of meetings at his Soweto home. He held talks with Helen Suzman, an anti-apartheid politician who retired last year after 36 years in Parliament, and Gavin Relly, chief executive of Anglo American, the world's largest gold mining firm. Mandela, who favors state control of the mines, said afterward: ``Nationalization (of the mines) is the policy of the ANC and it is a step which is perfectly logical.'' Relly told reporters he did not discuss nationalization with Mandela, but said such a policy was ``not practical to make modern economies work.'' He leaves Tuesday for the ANC's exile headquarters in Zamiba, his first stop on an 18-day, four-nation tour.

DOC.HEAD: Central America: A Headache for Washington No More?
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: For a decade, Nicaragua has been a troublesome hotpoint for a succession of three American presidents. Now _ with the stunning election outcome in Nicaragua _ the region is being framed as an overnight success for democracy. In fact, no matter who had won in Nicaragua, Sunday's balloting would have struck a key blow for democracy. That's what President Bush had in mind Sunday when he held out an olive branch to the winner _ so long as it was a fair and free election. And Bush was quick this morning to signal that the U.S. challenge to Nicaragua was about to end. Morning news of the election of Violetto Chamarro _ and the defeat of Daniel Ortega and his Sandinista regime _ spread through Washington like welcome wildfire. ``In this year of remarkable political change,'' said Secretary of State James Baker III. ``Freedom, I think it's fair to say, won another victory yesterday in Nicaragua.'' The White House said it was considering an end to economic sanctions that helped dampen the Nicaraguan economy. The sanctions, along with military and political efforts by the United States, bedeviled the Sandinista government in its effort to establish popular support. Central America looked far less promising for the administration just 10 weeks ago. Panama was still under the rule of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega and there were widespread predictions that the Sandinista government would either win an outright majority in Nicaragua _ or might steal Sunday's election rather than accept defeat. The U.S. military ouster of Noriega was achieved at a far lower cost to the administration than many had predicted. And, in Nicaragua, an outcome that few had anticipated _ a victory by Chamorro and a promise by President Ortega to honor it _ actually has come to pass. Ortega may have lost the election but he proved many in Washington wrong on several counts. During the 1980's, he was widely perceived here as an anti-democrat intent on touching off a region-wide revolution that could extend up to the Texas border. Instead, he oversaw a fair campaign and a free election, the first in Nicaragua's history, and has said he'll abide by the will of the voters. Secretary of State James Baker III commended Ortega in the same breath as his praise for Mrs. Chamarro, though he was quick to provide a pointed reminder that the international community ``will insist that the decision of the Nicaraguan people be respected and that full civil and military power be transferred to the newly elected government.'' Central America is still on the administration's agenda. The most serious unresolved problem is the continuing war in El Salvador. But the Sandinista defeat is bound to have a demoralizing effect on the leftist FMLN rebels, who are now more isolated than at any time since they were formed a decade ago. Beyond that, if administration allegations about Sandinista arms shipments to the FMLN are true, Mrs. Chamorro's victory would appear to add to the insurgency's problems since they will no longer have Nicaraguan support. All this has the eventual potential of returning Central America to the relative obscurity the region experienced for the first century and a half of its independence. It was an area to which the United States used to pay almost no attention; former Secretary of State George P. Shultz said one of his predecessors told him he doubted that he spent more than three minutes on that issue during his entire time in office. With the Sandinista triumph of 1979 followed in short order by the election of a U.S. president _ Ronald Reagan _ with a well known aversion for leftists, Central America suddenly was a big item on Washington's agenda. It proved to be one of the most divisive issues of the Reagan presidency but now it appears those titanic confrontations with the Congress over aid to the Contra rebels are now history. The one immediate concern of the administration is the disposition of the 70,000 member Sandinista Army, a force whose loyalty lies with the Sandinista Front and not to the Nicaraguan state. That could create a situation common elsewhere in Latin America _ a military establishment which acts as an independent force beyond the reach of the elected authorities. Globally, Sunday's election constitutes for leftist forces yet another in a series of setbacks that began last year in Eastern Europe. A decade ago in this hemisphere, the left was in power in Cuba, Nicaragua, Grenada and Suriname. Now only Cuba is left.
George Gedda has covered foreign affairs for the Associated Press since 1968.

DOC.HEAD: Court Agrees To Decide Whether Losers Should Pay Witness Fees
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today agreed to decide whether a federal law requiring some lawsuit losers to pay the winners' lawyer fees also covers expert-witness fees. The court will review a ruling that deprived West Virginia University's hospital of reimbursement for the $104,000 it spent on three expert witnesses in successfully suing Pennsylvania. The WVU hospital in Morgantown, just six miles from the Pennsylvania state line, serves numerous Medicaid recipients who live in Pennsylvania. The hospital sued Pennsylvania officials in 1986 in a dispute over the state's system of reimbursements for Medicaid services under the Social Security Act. U.S. District Judge Sylvia Rambo in 1988 ruled that the Pennsylvania reimbursement system violated federal law, and ordered the state to develop a new system. She also ordered the state to pay $500,000 in lawyer fees incurred by the hospital, including $104,000 for expert witnesses who testified about deficiencies in the payment system for out-of-state hospitals. The Philadelphia-based 3rd U.S. Court of Appeals last Sept. 5 set aside that portion of the award representing most of the reimbursement for expert-witness fees. The appeals court said Congress, in passing the law providing lawyer-fee awards, did not intend to allow reimbursements for expert-witness fees. Other federal appeals courts have ruled that Congress did intend to include reimbursement for such fees. The 3rd Circuit court noted that federal court rules provide for the losing side in some cases to pay up to $30 a day for expert witnesses employed by the winning side. The appeals court said the WVU hospital could not be awarded more than that daily $30. In the hospital's appeal acted on today, its lawyers relied heavily on a Supreme Court decision last year that said lawyer-fee awards could take the work of paralegals into account. ``Just as paralegals assist in the preparation of an attorney's work product, experts educate counsel and preclude the need for the attorney to educate himself, which would obviously require more time and run up an attorney's fees even more,'' the appeal said. The case is West Virginia University Hospitals Inc. vs. Casey, 89-994.

DOC.HEAD: Blazing U.S.-Flag Tanker Being Towed To Indian Ocean
DOC.TEXT: Twelve tugboats raced against time today to shepherd the burning U.S.-flagged tanker Surf City out of the Persian Gulf to the Indian Ocean, shipping executives said. The move was ordered because of fears the tanker could explode off the coast of the United Arab Emirates and set nearby offshore oil terminals ablaze, or could sink, clogging the vital Gulf shipping channel. Flames intensified over the weekend when more of the volatile cargo of naphta and diesel fuel began spilling into parts of the 81,823-ton tanker that were ablaze following an explosion Thursday. ``The tugboats are blanketing it with foam and water as it moves, and the south-to-north wind is also helping cool the tanker,'' a Gulf-based shipping executive said on condition of anonymity. He estimated the tanker would need at least 10 hours to go through the Strait of Hormuz and into the open sea, where any threat to installations on shore would be eliminated. An internal explosion Thursday aboard the Surf City, a Kuwaiti-owned tanker flying the U.S. flag, set the ship alight and killed two of its 25 American crewmen. The cause of the explosion has not been determined. The U.S. Navy missile frigate USS Simpson rescued 23 crewmen from lifeboats and 22 were flown from Dubai to the United States over the weekend. One, Earl Washington, 41, of Louisiana, remained in a Dubai hospital for treatment of first-degree burns. The American warships kept a ``watchful eye'' on the vessel under tow and radioing warnings to other shipping to steer four miles clear, the shipping executives said. It was unclear why the cargo tanks, 70 percent of which were reported late Saturday to be still intact, had begun leaking and feeding the fire later. ``Unfortunately ... the fire on board the Surf City has continued and somewhat intensified,'' said a statement issued by the Chesapeake Shipping Inc., the company that operates Surf City and other Kuwaiti tankers re-flagged in the United States. The Surf City is one of 11 tankers that Kuwait re-registered at the height of the Iraq-Iran war to entitle them to U.S. Navy protection.

DOC.HEAD: Bad Weather: Atlantis Launch Delayed For Fifth Time
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 10th graf, `The shuttle...', with three grafs to UPDATE with commander statement, three astronauts to return to Houston. SUBS 15th graf, `Creighton, a ...'. to DELETE now redundant first reference for some astronauts.
DOC.TEXT: Poor weather forced the launch of shuttle Atlantis' secret military mission to be scrubbed today for the fifth time, the most delays since the doomed Challenger. NASA set the next attempt for early Wednesday. Peekaboo clouds and erratic winds tantalized NASA with possible launch opportunities for almost two hours early today and officials kept Atlantis and its five-man crew poised and ready for any momentary break in the weather. But the break never came. At 2:32 a.m. launch director Robert Sieck abandoned the launch attempt and announced NASA would not try again until early Wednesday. Experts saw little chance that launch weather would improve later in the week. ``We're just in kind of a stalemate because of the weather,'' said Tom Strange, an Air Force weather forecaster. He said there was only a 20 percent chance of favorable weather on Wednesday and a 40 percent chance on Thursday. Winds and clouds early today were on the very edge of acceptable limits and NASA extended a pause in the launch countdown in hopes that the weather would improve. Eventually the winds calmed enough for launch, but a cloud cover hung on stubbornly and Sieck decided to give up. NASA spokesman Kyle Herring said exhaustion among the astronauts, launch-pad technicians and engineers played a role in the decision to delay the next launch attempt until early Wednesday. ``We just want to give the crews a rest,'' Herring said. Atlantis' commander, Navy Capt. John O. Creighton, said in a statement today that the crew was disappointed, ``but we are convinced that the launch team and the mission management team made the correct decision ... We are looking forward to the next opportunity.'' Creighton and two of his crew members, Air Force Col. John H. Casper, the pilot, and Marine Lt. Col. David C. Hilmers, planned to fly back to the astronaut training base in Houston later today to practice in a shuttle simulator. The shuttle mission originally was scheduled to begin last Thursday. Two launch attempts were abandoned after Creighton developed a sore throat and head congestion. An attempt early Saturday was blocked by unacceptable weather conditions. Early Sunday, with clear skies and ideal weather, NASA counted down to within 31 seconds of launch and then had to call it off when a computer broke down. This mission has been postponed more times than any shuttle flight since Challenger, which had seven delays and then blew up shortly after liftoff on its eighth try on Jan. 28, 1986. All seven crew members died. Atlantis' flight is a classified military mission. As a result, the precise launch time and length of the flight are secret. However, sources said the spacecraft is to be launched just before 1 a.m. EST on Wednesday, is to fly about 4{ days and will land at Edwards Air Force Base in California. The sources, who spoke on condition they not be named, said Atlantis' cargo is a $500 million spy satellite capable of taking high-resolution reconnaissance photos and listening in on electronics communications all over the world. Atlantis is to deploy the satellite in an orbit that will carry the craft over more of the Soviet Union than any satellite previously launched by a shuttle. The other crew members are mission specialists Air Force Col. Richard Mullane and Navy Lt. Cmdr. Pierre J. Thuot. The Atlantis flight is to be the 34th shuttle mission, the sixth classified military flight, and the fourth after-dark shuttle launch.

DOC.HEAD: Court Leaves Gay Soldier Ban Intact in Wisconsin, California Cases
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs pvs 3rd graf, The court, with one graf to elaborate on meaning of court's action
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today left intact the U.S. military's general ban on homosexuals serving in the Army and Navy. The court, without comment, rejected appeals by a woman denied re-enlistment in the Army Reserve in Wisconsin because she is a lesbian and a California man released from Navy active duty because he is gay. The action today was not a ruling on the legality of the military ban but simply a summary rejection of the appeals. The justices did not preclude the possibility that in some future case they will agree to review the policy toward homosexuals. In other actions, the Supreme Court: _Said it will decide whether a federal law that requires some losers of lawsuits to pay the winners' lawyer fees also covers fees for expert witnesses. _Refused to force the CIA to release its documents on the 1985 sinking of the Greenpeace ship Rainbow warrior by French government agents. The justices let stand rulings that the spy agency may withhold the documents from a Houston lawyer who is seeking them under the Freedom of Information Act. _Let stand the 15-year prison sentence and $6.6 million fine of a California businessman convicted of conspiracy and violating u.s. export restrictions by selling two airplanes to Libya. Army Reserve Sgt. Miriam Ben-Shalom, 41, is stationed in Milwaukee and has been allowed to remain in the military pending the outcome of her appeal on the homosexuality issue. Ms. Ben-Shalom joined the Army Reserve in 1974, and was discharged in 1976 because she is an acknowledged lesbian. The Army policy at the time barred anyone who ``evidenced homosexual tendencies, desire or interest,'' even though never having engaged in any ``overt homosexual acts.'' A federal judge ordered Ms. Ben-Shalom reinstated, and she served out an enlistment that ended in August 1988. She then was prohibited from re-enlisting under an amended Army regulation. The new policy says, ``Homosexuality is incompatible with military service,'' and bars ``persons who engage in homosexual conduct or who by their statements demonstrate a propensity to engage in homosexual conduct.'' The 7th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals last August upheld the revised policy. The appeals court, although acknowledging there never has been any complaint about Ms. Ben-Shalom's performance of her military duties, said the Army has acted to protect ``morale, discipline and the effectiveness of our fighting forces.'' Judges should not put the Army's interests at risk by imposing change ``with possible consequences we cannot safely evaluate,'' the appeals court said. James M. Woodward of Spring Valley, Calif., challenged the Navy's general ban on homosexuals. He enlisted in 1972 for a six-year hitch in the Naval Flight Officer Candidate Program. He was allowed to enter the Naval Reserve program even though he had answered ``yes'' to a questionnaire that asked whether he was sexually attracted to men or desired sex with men. Woodward answered ``no'' to a question whether he had ever engaged in homosexual conduct. He completed flight school training and was commissioned as an ensign in the Naval Reserve. Woodward was serving in an air squadron stationed in the Philippines when in 1974 he was seen in the Subic Bay Officers' Club sitting with a sailor who was to be discharged for homosexual conduct. The Navy generally bars homosexuals but has retained some. When questioned by his commanding officer, Woodward acknowledged his homosexual tendencies. After Woodward refused to resign, the commanding officer recommended to the chief of naval personnel that Woodward be discharged. In a letter to that official, Woodward said, ``For the good of both the Navy and myself, I respectfully request the chance to contribute to the defense of the United States as an honest, open, `gay' officer.'' The Navy did not discharge Woodward but released him from active duty and assigned him to the Naval Air Reserve staff in San Diego. He served there until 1978, when he was discharged after completing his six-year military obligation. Woodward sued in 1976, alleging that he had been unlawfully separated from active duty. The suit sought back pay and reinstatement. The U.S. Claims Court dismissed Woodward's suit, and the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit upheld the dismissal last March 29. ``Woodward was not discharged for homosexuality; rather he was considered for reassignment, but because of his mediocre record as an officer and his homosexuality he was ultimately released from active duty,'' the appeals court said. Bush administration lawyers urged the high court to reject the appeals by Woodward and Ms. Ben-Shalom. The cases are Woodward vs. U.S., 89-344, and Ben-Shalom vs. Marsh, 89-876.

DOC.HEAD: UN Report: Situation Improved But Fear, Distrust Linger On
DOC.TEXT: The human rights situation in Romania has improved markedly since the revolution that toppled Nicolae Ceausescu, but fear, suspicion, and distrust linger on, according to a U.N. report released today. The report mentioned death threats against politicians and wide concern that the Securitate, Ceausescu's repressive secret police, may be still active although the new leadership says it has been disbanded. It also said the problem of ethnic minorities in Romania will require ``close examination and adequate measures'' and that the launching and distribution of printed media is ``not yet fully assured.'' The report was compiled by Swiss jurist Joseph Voyame, under a 1988 mandate from the 43-nation U.N. Human Rights Commission. Voyame spent five days in Romania earlier this month on an invitation from the new leadership. He was barred from Romania while Ceausescu held power and a first report based on sources outside Romania was dated Dec. 18, shortly before the dictator was deposed and later executed. His French-language update, prepared for the U.N. commission's current session, said human rights in Romania have ``not yet been fully restored'' but that the situation has ``considerably improved.'' It stated, however, the ``climate of suspicion and fear'' that prevailed under Ceausescu was likely to vanish only gradually. ``In the meantime, the manipulation of public opinion remains to be feared,'' the report said. Voyame cited testimony that a member of the national Peasants Party was slain in the town of Bacau, and that there were ``several cases of violent death among members of the Hungarian minority.'' In the report, Voyame said he was also informed that a critic of the National Salvation Front, the new leadership, was killed in a ``car accident under circumstances that are still unclear.'' ``In addition to these signs of physical violence, certain measures of psychological intimidation are said to continue,'' he said. ``Numerous persons have informed the special investigator of death threats against themselves, against members of their families, or against people they know.'' Voyame said witnesses ``from non-official circles criticized the fact that there is no precise information on how the problem of the Securitate has been resolved.''

DOC.HEAD: Court to Rule on Damages for Slain Sailors
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Mercedel correct in 7th graf, Torregano's mother
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today agreed to hear an appeal by the mother of a seaman stabbed to death aboard a ship in what was described as a vicious attack by another crew member. The court said it will use the case from New Orleans to consider increasing the damages ship owners, and possibly unions, may be forced to pay to parents and other heirs of slain sailors. The issues are whether the heirs are entitled to damages for the dead seaman's lost future wages and compensation for parents' ``loss of society.'' The case stems from an incident aboard the Archon during its maiden voyage while the ship was docked in Washington state on July 18, 1984. The victim, Ludwick Torregano, 24, a steward's assistant, was stabbed or cut at least 62 times by fellow crew member Clifford Melrose. Melrose later was convicted of second-degree murder in Clark County, Wash. Torregano's mother, Mercedel Miles, sued the ship owners and operators in federal court in New Orleans. Ms. Miles, administrator of her son's estate, was awarded $140,000 for the pain and suffering Torregano endured before his death and $7,800 for the loss of her son's support. But the jury refused to order additional damages for the loss of Torregano's future income or for loss of society by either Ms. Miles or the seaman's father, Joseph O. Torregano. Loss of society is defined as a broad range of mutual benefits family members receive from each other, including love, affection, care, attention, companionship, comfort and protection. The 5th U.S. Supreme Court of Appeals last September upheld the damages awarded by the jury. The appeals court also ruled that under maritime law the Archon was unseaworthy because Melrose was among its crew. ``The savagery of (Melrose's) attack itself leads us to conclude that Melrose has an especially dangerous disposition,'' the appeals court said. ``Melrose failed to measure up to the standard of his calling and rendered the vessel unseaworthy.'' That opened the way for increased damages against the Archon's owners and operators. But the appeals court then said that Torregano's parents are not entitled to compensation for loss of his future wages or for their loss of their son's society. Only dependents are entitled to be compensated for loss of society when a seaman dies, the appeals court said. ``The number of plaintiffs who could allege a loss of love and affection as a result of the death of a dearly beloved seaman _ aunts and uncles, nieces and nephews, even friends and lovers _ necessitates that we draw a line between those who may recover for loss of society and those who may not,'' the appeals court said. The appeals court also ruled that the Seafarers International Union may be sued by the ship owners and operators for its role in permitting Melrose to be hired as a member of the Archon crew. That means the union eventually could be forced to help pay any compensation awarded Ms. Miles. The case is Miles vs. Apex Marine, 89-1158.

DOC.HEAD: 747 Returns For Emergency Landing After Catches Fire
DOC.TEXT: A Saudi Arabian Airlines Boeing 747 with 159 people aboard made an emergency landing today after a cargo compartment caught fire, authorities said. No injuries were reported. The jumbo jet was en route from Kuala Lumpur to Jakarta when the fire broke out, airport fire brigade sources said. Crew members aboard the aircraft extinguished the blaze. A Civil Aviation Department spokesman told the National News Agency Bernama that the aircraft was being examned by the department's security unit. He declined to give further details.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Troop Withdrawal from Czechoslovakia Begins
DOC.TEXT: Twenty-two Soviet tanks left this northern Moravian city today, beginning the Red Army's withdrawal from Czechoslovakia nearly 22 years after Moscow sent troops to crush ``Prague Spring'' reforms. Few people came to wave goodbye and those who did showed little emotion. A brass band struck up the ``Internationale,'' the Communist anthem, during a brief ceremony inside the Soviet base at Frenstat that kicked off the first complete withdrawal of Soviet troops from any of Moscow's allies. The Soviet troops entered Czechoslovakia with a Warsaw Pact invasion that smashed the 1968 reforms. But in November 1989, a peaceful revolution toppled the hard-line Communists and the new government immediately began talks on withdrawing all Red Army troops. To Czechoslovaks, the Soviet troops ``meant empty shelves in stores, polluted water, an occasional fight in the pub and a reminder that we are not a free country,'' said Karel Micek, a spokesman for the Civic Forum movement. Withdrawal of the 73,500 Soviet troops stationed on Czechoslovak territory is to be completed by the end of next year. The withdrawal from Frenstat pod Radhostem, 110 miles southeast of Prague, was accompanied by a parallel pullout from Krnov on the Czechoslovak-Polish border, 150 miles east of the Czechoslovak capital. They are to be completed by March 13 and March 25 respectively. ``This is our new peace policy in practice ... a retreat from the policy of confrontation,'' Gen. Vladimir Malyshkievich, deputy chief of the Soviet contingent in Czechoslovakia, said during the ceremony. ``It is only proper this process starts in the center of Europe and on the day of the official visit of President Vaclav Havel in the Soviet Union,'' he said. Havel flew to Moscow today for two days of talks with Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, just three days after returning from the United States, where he met with President Bush. Havel and Gorbachev are expected to sign the agreement on troop withdrawals concluded in Prague on Feb. 22. The accord provides for a Soviet pullout in three stages, with a ``decisive part of the contingent'' leaving the country by the end of May. The first free elections in Czechoslovakia since the Communists consolidated power in 1948 are due in June. Czechoslovakia originally demanded the withdrawal by the end of 199O, but the Soviets, citing administrative problems, requested the deadline be extended until the end of 1991. The first of the T-62 tanks left Frenstat by train in the afternoon, en route to the Soviet border. ``Most probably they will reach the border some time tomorrow,'' said Stanislav Pohoral, a Defense Ministry spokesman. No official figures have been released on the number of troops affected by today's pullbacks. But Vadim Pliska, a Soviet soldier posted in Frenstat said ``some 2,000 soldiers and approximately 9O tanks'' were stationed there. Moscow currently has 73,500 soldiers, 1,22O tanks, 2,5O5 armored vehicles, 77 combat aircraft and 146 helicopters stationed on Czechoslovak soil.

DOC.HEAD: Praise Greets Nicaraguan Election Results
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS 4 grafs after 12th pvs, `Hurd said...' with comment by U.N. leader.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Nicaragua, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Nicaragua's presidential election drew praise today as a model of democracy and a step toward peace after more than 10 years of rebel warfare. Opposition candidate Violeta Barrios de Chamorro defeated President Daniel Ortega in elections Sunday and said the results showed the Nicaraguan people ``want to live in democracy, in peace and in freedom.'' Former President Jimmy Carter, invited to monitor the balloting in the Central American nation, called the process free and fair and said Ortega had promised to abide by the result. He also praised Ortega and the leftist Sandinistas for promoting a free election. ``They had total control over the government, over the electoral process,'' Carter told ABC television. ``I think Ortega can go out of office in April ... with a great deal of satisfaction that he has indeed been instrumental in letting the people exhibit democracy and freedom in one of its finest ways in this hemisphere.'' U.S. officials welcomed the result and pledged help to Nicaragua. The United States supported a decade-long insurgency against Ortega's Sandinista government and imposed an economic embargo to undermine Managua's economy. ``The United States looks forward to working with Mrs. Chamorro's new government in support of her stated goals of national reconciliation and economic reconstruction, and with President (Daniel) Ortega in helping assure a peaceful transition of power,'' President Bush said in a statement read by his spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater. Fitzwater said Bush was sending messages to Mrs. Chamorro, congratulating her on her win, and to Ortega, ``congratulating him on the conduct of the election and his stated willingness to abide by the results.'' ``In this year of political change, democracy won another victory,'' Bush said in his statement. In Spain, Foreign Minister Francisco Fernandez Ordonez praised the Nicaraguan electoral process and result. ``They augur well for the future of the country,'' he told reporters meeting with British Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd. Hurd said, ``This is very good news for Nicaragua, for Latin America, for everyone.'' United Nations Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar welcomed the Nicaraguan elections as a ``victory for democracy.'' Perez de Cuellar said, ``I am very pleased about the elections (which) took place in a very democratic manner. ``I think this is a great success for democracy in Nicaragua and also Central America,'' he said. ``It is a great thing for Central America and all Latin America and the whole hemisphere, and European countries.'' Perez de Cuellar emphasized he was not expressing support for the outcome of the election and said he had remained neutral in Chamorro's contest with Ortega.

DOC.HEAD: Teachers Want States to Require Geography
DOC.TEXT: Teachers want geography _ a distant subject to many young Americans _ to be among the courses required for high school graduation, according to a survey released Monday. The nationwide survey of 852 elementary and secondary school social studies and geography teachers found 86 percent favored changing requirements to require that high school students pass a geography course in order to graduate. Eighty-seven percent want state governments to increase geography requirements. The Rand McNally Report on Geography Education in America, conducted by Ketchum Communications Research and Measurement, comes on the heels of the first study of geography education by the National Assessment of Educational Progress _ popularly known as the Nation's Report Card. That report said high school seniors have a gap in their knowledge of geography, with only 37 percent able to find Southeast Asia on a world map. The average student could answer just 57 percent of the questions and the best score among more than 3,000 students tested was 59 percent, the report showed. Nine out of 10 teachers polled by Rand McNally said the quality of geography education American children currently receive could be considered poor or only fair. Unless geography education improves, 85 percent of the teachers said that U.S. citizens will not be able to adequately understand the importance of present and future environmental issues. And 83 percent said that other countries with citizens educated in geography will have competitive business advantages over the United States. The survey findings indicate that geography is not receiving ample time in the classroom because it is taught as part of a broader subject, such as history or social studies, said Dennis DeCock of Rand McNally. He said 90 percent of those surveyed said more classroom time should be spent on geography. Requiring high school students to pass a geography course to graduate is one of the keys to restoring geography teaching to its proper role, the teachers said. Seventy-two percent of those surveyed said most teachers have not received adequate training themselves in geography and therefore do not teach it well or at all. Eighty-nine percent said teachers of geography should be provided supplemental geography education. The teachers surveyed included members of the National Council for the Social Studies and the National Council for Geographic Education. Rand McNally, a leading producer of maps and geography teaching materials, said it has established an awards program for teachers who display creative classroom approaches to teaching geography. The program is co-sponsored by the National Council for Geographic Education and will feature a $10,000 cash prize.

DOC.HEAD: Frenchman, American Named for Physics Prize
DOC.TEXT: A Frenchman and a Scottish-born American were named on Monday to share the 1990 Wolf Prize for physics. The $100,000 award, to be presented in the Israeli parliament May 20, will be given to Pierre-Gilles de Gennes of the College of France in Paris and David J. Thouless of the University of Washington in Seattle, the Wolf Foundation said. De Gennes and Thouless were selected for their ``pioneering contributions to our understanding of the organization of complex condensed-matter systems,'' the foundation said. De Gennes, 57, has held the chair in condensed-matter physics at the College of France since 1971. The foundation praised him for developing basic concepts in the physics of macromolecular matter and of liquid crystals. Thouless, 55, earned his doctorate in physics at Cornell University in 1958. He has been in Washington state since 1980. The foundation said he was cited for contributions to understanding disordered and twin-layered matter. Winners already have been named in mathematics, agriculture, medicine, chemistry and the arts. The Wolf Prizes were established in 1975 to honor the late Ricardo Wolf. The German-born inventor immigrated to Cuba before World War I and later served as its ambassador to Israel. He died in 1981.

DOC.HEAD: Belgrade Stock Exchange Resumes Trading After 50-YearBreak
DOC.TEXT: The Belgrade stock exchange, the first of its kind in Communist-ruled Yugoslavia, resumed trading today after a break of almost half a century. ``The Yugoslav Capital Market _ Belgrade,'' will be the first of three stock exchanges set up in Yugoslavia this year, said Branislav Cosic, deputy manager of the new exchange. The other two will open in the northern cities of Zagreb and Ljubljana, he said, without giving a date. The Belgrade exchange, founded by four of Yugoslavia's largest banks, initially will handle only government bonds, but soon will start trading stocks issued by private companies, Cosic said. In the first day, ``no bonds or stocks offered by the four founding banks were exchanged,'' Cosic said. He said today ``was just an experimental day for future activities,'' but did not elaborate on the start-up operation. The Belgrade exchange, first established in 1886, folded in 1941, when Yugoslavia was occupied by Nazi Germany. When the Communists seized power in 1945, th Americans are smoking fewer cigarettes, but an Agriculture Department economist says demand continues to grow in the rest of the world. Last year, the per capita use of cigarettes in the United States was estimated at 2,936 ``pieces'' or fewer than 149 packs of 20 cigarettes each, down about 5 percent from the 1988 rate. The per capita use has declined for 16 straight years, said Verner Grise of the department's Economic Research Service. At its peak in 1963, use averaged 4,345 cigarettes, or more than 217 packs. Per capita consumption is based on all persons 18 or older, smokers and non-smokers alike. It does not indicate actual smoking habits and is used by the agency for year-to-year comparisons. But world cigarette trade increased about 12 percent, Grise said in the March issue of Farmline magazine. ``Shipments from the United States, West Germany, the Netherlands, Hong Kong (which is also an importer) and the United Kingdom were up, while those from Bulgaria and Belgium-Luxembourg were down,'' he said. ``Together, these seven countries account for about 84 percent of total world exports.'' Among the cigarette importing countries, the most important markets are the Soviet Union, France, Japan, Italy, Hong Kong and Turkey. During the first nine months of 1989, U.S. cigarette exports were up 16 percent from a year earlier, with all the major markets buying more, Grise said. In the ``relatively small markets,'' sales also rose in South America but declined in Australia-Oceania and Canada.

Australia, one of the world's biggest meat producers, is consuming less of its beef and lamb, according to an Agriculture Department dispatch from Canberra. ``They are eating more breakfast cereals, desserts, fruits and vegetables, but less meat, bakery products and canned vegetables, according to a recent survey,'' the report said. As reported in Retail World, an Australian publication, the value of retail purchases of meat and deli items dropped 33 percent from 1988 to 1989, while bakery products and canned vegetables each declined 14 percent. But purchases of breakfast cereals rose 25 percent; desserts, 20 percent; and fruits and vegetables, 22 percent. The item was reported in AgExporter magazine by the department's Foreign Agricultural Service.
Here, at a glance, are highlights of Monday's actions by the Supreme Court:

The U.S. military's general ban on homosexuals was left intact when the court, without comment, rejected two appeals. The court did not rule on the legality of the ban and it did not preclude the possibility that in some future case they will agree to review the policy toward homosexuals. The appeals were from Sgt. Miriam Ben-Shalom, 41, of Milwaukee, denied re-enlistment in the Army Reserve, and James M. Woodward of Spring Valley, Calif., released from Navy active duty. The cases are Woodward vs. U.S., 89-344, and Ben-Shalom vs. Marsh, 89-876.

Without comment, the court refused to force the CIA to release its documents on the 1985 sinking by French government agents of the Greenpeace ship Rainbow Warrior. The justices let stand rulings that the spy agency may withhold the documents from a Houston lawyer, John R. Knight, who is seeking them under the Freedom of Information Act. Greenpeace, an international environmental group, had been preparing to monitor and protest a scheduled French nuclear weapons test when its vessel exploded and sank in the Auckland, New Zealand, harbor July 10, 1985. The case is Knight vs. U.S. Central Intelligence Agency, 89-878.

Edward Elkins, a California businessman, sentenced to 15 years in prison and fined $6.6 million for selling two airplanes to Libya lost his appeal. The court, without comment, let stand his conviction and sentence for conspiracy and violating U.S. export restrictions. Elkins, who owned a Santa Maria, Calif., company, was convicted in a 1987 federal trial in Georgia of selling the planes for $87 million to a West German company owned by Libyans. Elkins made a $7 million profit on the sales. The case is Elkins vs. U.S., 89-1206.

The court agreed to decide whether a federal law that requires some losers of lawsuits to pay the winners' lawyer fees also covers fees for expert witnesses. It will review a ruling that deprived West Virginia University's hospital of reimbursement for the $104,000 it spent on three expert witnesses in successfully suing the state of Pennsylvania. The WVU hospital in Morgantown, just six miles from the Pennsylvania line, serves numerous Medicaid recipients who live in Pennsylvania. In 1988, the hospital won its suit against Pennsylvania officials in a dispute over the state's system of reimbursements for Medicaid services under the Social Security Act. The case is West Virginia University Hospitals Inc. vs. Casey, 89-994.

The justices said they will hear an appeal by the mother of a seaman stabbed to death aboard a ship by another crew member. The court said it will use the case from New Orleans to consider increasing the damages that ship owners, and possibly unions, may be forced to pay parents and other heirs of slain sailors to compensate for the dead seaman's lost future wages and for parents' ``loss of society.'' The case is Miles vs. Apex Marine, 89-1158.

DOC.HEAD: Calcutta Killer Claims 11th Homeless Victim
DOC.TEXT: A killer who preys on homeless people sleeping on the sidewalks of India's largest city has struck again, police said Monday, beating to death an 11th victim: a teen-age railroad porter. The body of the youth, his head bashed in and a blood-stained rock lying nearby, was found by police shortly after midnight under an overpass near eastern Calcutta's Sealdah railroad station, officers said. The area houses shops which normally stay open past midnight, but an electrical failure _ common in Calcutta _ had blacked out street lights and shops. Police officers, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the victim was about 14 years old and had been working as an unlicensed baggage porter at the nearby train station. His name was not immediately known. The killer, dubbed the ``Stone Man'' by police, killed his first known victim June 4. The toll reached seven by September and climbed to 10 on Feb. 20. All of the victims were pavement dwellers, homeless people who sleep on the sidewalks of this city of 10 million. The railroad porter, like previous victims, was sleeping alone. Most of Calcutta's homeless people sleep in groups, especially since the killings began. Estimates of the number of pavement sleepers range from the 65,000 suggested by city officials to as many as 1 million reported by Calcutta newspapers. Police have arrested several people in sweeps through the city, but no one has been charged.

DOC.HEAD: A Look At The Sanctions Against Nicaragua
With PM-Nicaragua, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. trade embargo against Nicaragua was first imposed by former President Reagan on May 1, 1985, and was continued by President Bush last Oct. 25. Bush said at the time that Nicaragua posed ``an unusual and extraordinary threat to the national security and foreign policy of the United States.'' He added, however, that if Nicaraguan President Daniel Ortega held fair elections and implemented democratic reforms ``the emergency that prompted the imposition of the trade sanctions would largely be resolved.'' Ortega's leftist Sandinista government was defeated in Sunday's election. The embargo bars imports from Nicaragua and bans U.S. exports to that country except to support Contra rebels. It also prohibits Nicaraguan aircraft or boats from entering the United States.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Sees `New Era' in Education
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Top 9 grafs new to update with Bush speech; picks up at pvs 7th graf, Bush outlined
DOC.TEXT: President Bush told the nation's governors today that adoption of national education goals was ``a new era'' with high expectations and results for the country's schools. Bush met with the governors at the White House and hailed the the fact that ``for the first time in history we now have national education goals and objectives.'' The six goals set for the year 2000 were set forth by Bush in his State of the Union address and endorsed over the weekend by the governors at their annual midwinter meeting. ``We're launching a new era in education reform,'' the president said. ``Its focus, high expectations; its hallmark, results.'' Gov. Booth Gardner of Washington, vice chairman of the National Governors' Association, said the goals would changes the nation's schools from being ``a place where people have an opportunity to learn to a place where we ensure that all students will learn.'' The governors made only minor changes in Bush's six goals. Their proposal to give education a share of any savings in defense spending was relegated to a resolution one Democratic governor said was so bland that no one could object. At a White House dinner for the governors Sunday night, Bush toasted them and ``our commitment to work together toward ... an American education system that is second to none.'' ``We came together not as Republicans and Democrats, not as partisan competitors, but as fellow chief executives with our hearts and minds focused on a single goal: the future of our kids, the future of our country,'' said Bush. Gov. Terry Branstad of Iowa, chairman of the governors association, said, ``We all expect that there's a lot of work ahead of us.'' Bush outlined the six goals in his State of the Union address last month. The governors spent two days tinkering with the language before they approved the goals and added a list of objectives for attaining them. The goals call for giving poor youngsters preschool services that include nutrition and health screening and making sure American students are competent in math, science, English, history and geography. Attached to the goals is a document seeking a commitment ``to provide at least one year of preschool for all disadvantaged children.'' It also said, ``federal funds should target those students most in need of assistance due to economic disadvantage or risk of academic failure.'' The resolution on defense savings called on the president ``to dedicate the peace dividend in a balanced manner among the federal budget deficit, education'' and other domestic programs. New Jersey Gov. James Florio said the language ``is so generalized, I don't know how anybody can be unhappy with that.'' The governors rejected a proposal by Democratic Gov. Roy Romer of Colorado urging the president to ``direct substantial federal resources from defense to educational needs and other productivity investments.'' Richard G. Darman, the White House budget director, gave the governors no promises and said any defense savings would be less than many are predicting. Delaware Gov. Michael Castle won adoption of a resolution calling on the governors to publicize the goals within their states. ```I don't believe the mere announcement of these goals by the president or the governors in this country is going to change education as dramatically as we'd like it to,'' Castle said. ``It's only going to happen if we now carry the word out.'' Education leaders generally favored the goals, although some complained there was no clear resolution of funding or how students' achievement would be assessed. ``The goals are good ones. They give us something to work for,'' said Keith Geiger, president of the National Education Association. ``The difficult task now comes in (determining) who's responsible for implementing them, how we're going to put together a long-range plan on the federal role, the state role and the local role.'' Timothy Dyer, the new president of the National Association of Secondary School Principals, said, ``America's governors receive an A-plus for rhetoric, but fail economics. Their goals are lofty, patriotic, noble and certainly what we all would like. However, without resources they are merely wishes.''

Here are President Bush's remarks Monday to the National Governors' Association about Sunday's election in Nicaragua: Any friend of democracy can take heart in the fact that Violeta Chamorro won the election. And the election process, by all accounts free and fair, is a credit to the people of Nicaragua who chose to determine their nature's future _ nation's future at the ballot box. And that is a victory for democracy. Yesterday's election moves us one step closer to the day when every nation in this hemisphere is a democracy, and I'll soon send messages _ I think they may have already gone out to _ to Mrs. Chamorro, congratulating her on her victory; to President Ortega, congratulating him on the conduct of the election and on his pledge to stand by its results; to President Carter and his counterpart on that one, Dan Evans; to Mr. Soares of the OAS; to Perez de Cuellar and Elliot Richardson of the United Nations for their leading roles in observing the elections. In the next few days, I'll be speaking with Central and South American leaders. This morning I talked to President Carlos Andres Perez of Venezuela about appropriate trade and economic measures that we can take to support the new government of Nicaragua. We hope now for a peaceful transition, for the institutionalization of the democratic process in Nicaragua, and there is space in a democratic Nicaragua for all political points of view. Given a clear mandate for peace and democracy, there is no reason at all for further military activity from any quarter, and we hope the cease-fire will be reestablished without delay, and respected by all sides. For years the people of Nicaragua have suffered, and today the people of Nicaragua have spoken. And now is the time for Nicaragua to move forward to freedom.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Combines pvs; edits to tighten; moves up reference to ceasefire
DOC.TEXT: President Bush today hailed Violeta Chamorro's upset election in Nicaragua and called for ``peaceful transition'' to democratic rule. Administration officials said he would decide swiftly on lifting the economic sanctions that hindered the Sandinista government. Bush said there was ``no reason at all for further military activity from any quarter.'' For most of a decade, Contra rebels supported by the United States have waged war against President Daniel Ortega. Bush spoke as key members of Congress said the United States should anticipate providing substantial economic aid to the new government in Managua. Secretary of State James A. Baker III embraced Mrs. Chamarro's triumph and praised the defeated Nicaraguan president for carrying out a fair election. He said he hoped the election would lead to a national reconciliation. Said Bush: ``For years the people of Nicaragua have suffered. And today the people of Nicaragua have spoken.'' The president said he had talked with Venezuelan President Carlos Andres Perez about ``appropriate trade and economic measures that we can take to support the new government of Nicaragua.'' Bush didn't address the issue of sanctions directly. But White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said the president would decide ``fairly soon'' on whether to lift them, and there already were calls in Congress for the president to do just that. The United States employed a variety of military, economic and political challenges to Ortega's Sandinistas over the past nine years and the sanctions were likely a factor in the weak Nicaraguan economy. ``We must provide her new government with aid, and let's not kid ourselves _ it will take big bucks,'' said Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole, R-Kan. ``She needs our help and she deserves it,'' he said of Mrs. Chamorro. ``Nobody said democracy was cheap,'' added Foreign Affairs Committee Chairman Dante Fascell, D-Fla. He said he was confident ``the commitment was there'' among lawmakers to provide financial help. The trade embargo against the nation of 3 million was imposed by President Reagan on May 1, 1985. It bars imports from Nicaragua and bans U.S. exports to that country except to support the Contra rebels fighting the leftist Sandinista government. It also prohibits Nicaraguan aircraft or boats from entering the United States. The challenge to Ortega was a controversial hallmark of the Reagan years, but last year Bush abandoned his military support of the Contra rebels. In brief comments to the nation's governors gathered at the White House, Bush offered congratulations to Mrs. Chamorro on her victory and to Ortega for permitting the fair elections to be held. He said there is ``space in a democratic Nicaragua for all political points of view.'' Fitzwater addressed the question of lifting sanctions when he spoke with reporters two hours before the president made his comments. ``The president is beginning a series of meetings this morning to consider all these questions coming out the election,'' Fitzwater said. The sanctions, Fitzwater added, ``are a matter of first consideration.'' ``We certainly would like to'' lift the sanctions, Fitzwater said. ``It's a time of celebration,'' said Sen. Richard Lugar, R-Ind., the ranking Republican on the Senate Foreign Relations Committee. ``In this year of political change, democracy won another victory,'' Bush said in an earlier, written statement. ``I am most pleased that there has been a free and fair election in Nicaragua and that the results are being accepted by both sides.'' Fitzwater was asked if Bush had been surprised that Ortega, whom the president last October had ridiculed as an ``unwanted animal at a garden party,'' had accepted the outcome so graciously. ``No,'' the spokesman said. He said that Ortega beforehand said that, if he lost, he would help with a transition ``that's smooth and effective.'' Baker went out of his way to ``commend Daniel Ortega and the Sandinista government for carrying out his commitment to conduct elections under international supervision.'' Bush said that in addition to his talks with Venezuela's president, he would talk with other Latin leaders concerning economic and trade issues. Mrs. Chamorro is expected to take office April 25. Fitzwater said the president was ``confident the international community will strongly support the results of yesterday's elections and will join in the effort to help all Nicaraguans rebuild their country.'' The White House spokesman said that the administration hoped that the cease-fire, which Ortega had declared an end to last fall, ``will be re-established immediately and respected by all sides.'' He added, ``We need a little time to absorb all the election process. We intend to consider this in an orderly and methodical fashion. ``We hope that all sides in this hotly fought contest will extend the hand of reconciliaton and cooperate together in rebuilding their country for the good of all Nicaraguans,'' the president's statement said. Baker, appearing at a meeting of the National Governors' Association, pointedly said the international community ``will insist that the decision of the Nicaraguan people be respected and that full civil and military power be transferred to the newly elected government.'' ``In this year of remarkable political change,'' said Baker ``Freedom, I think it's fair to say, won another victory yesterday in Nicaragua. ``We must show President-elect Chamorro and Nicaragua and those elected with her that we are prepared to work with them to make certain the sanctions are lifted,'' said Lugar. ``I would hope that the Congress and the president will be generous with economic assistance to that torn country.'' Baker called for reinstating the cease-fire between the Sandinistas and Contra opponents which have continued their armed opposition. ``We hope all sides in this hotely fought contest will extend the hand of national reconciliation,'' Baker said. Baker spoke shortly after the Supreme Electoral Council announced in Managua that with about 60 percent of precincts counted, Mrs. Chamorro had 459,655 votes, or 54.8 percent, to Ortega's 347,778, or 41.5 percent. Eight other parties split what little remained. On Sunday, relishing the very existence of elections in Nicaragua, Bush told reporters, ``If these elections are certifiably free and fair, whoever wins the election will find a better climate in which to improve relations with Nicaragua.'' Former President Carter and thousands of international observers had closely scrutinized Sunday's peaceful balloting and Carter proclaimed it fair. The Sandinistas took power during Carter's presidency in a revolution that toppled dictator Anastasio Somoza.

DOC.HEAD: Quarter Horse Association Celebrates 50th Anniversary
DOC.TEXT: He's at home on the range and has starred in more westerns than John Wayne, Roy Rogers and Gene Autry combined. He's also comfortable at polo matches or racetracks. Lynn Anderson and Sissy Spacek love him, as do Robert Redford, Burt Reynolds, George Strait, Tommy Lee Jones and Romanian gymnastics coach Bela Karolyi. Country-western's Michael Martin Murphy wrote a song in his honor. He's made some investors instant millionaires, and admirers are expected to risk $300 million on his performance this year. At 5 feet tall, he sounds a bit short, and at 1,100 pounds, maybe more than a tad hefty. But what the heck. You'd be husky, too, if you ate like a horse. And that's what we're talking about here. Horses. Quarter horses, really. The American Quarter Horse Association, founded here 50 years ago, returns this week to celebrate its golden anniversary and honor what it calls ``America's Horse.'' Thoroughbred breeders may lift a skeptical eyebrow, but according to the association, the versatile American quarter horse is: _ Skilled in disciplines ranging from cattle cutting to polo. _ Unequaled as a racehorse in sprint distances. The horse got its name from its burst of speed in quarter-mile races down the dirt streets of early settlements. _ The quickest horse in the world. Quarter horses are renowned for their lightning getaways, bursting from a starting gate to 45 mph in three strides. _ The world's finest roping, reining and cutting horse. _ The nation's most popular breed and the only breed indigenous to this country. The quarter horse even helped win the Old West _ the real one, not Hollywood's version. ``I'd agree with all those things,'' said Benny Scott of Fort Worth, former owner and publisher of Quarter Horse Racing. ``But if one word best sums up the quarter horse, it's versatility. ``And there's no question about popularity because the breed has the most horses in its registry.'' The quarter horse association claims the largest equine registry in the world, nearly 3 million, and the largest membership, 250,000, including 17,750 members in 62 other countries. ``The growth of the American quarter horse in international markets is the most exciting development in the breed in the last decade,'' said Brad Tate, the association's president. ``It's as if investors and ranchers around the world have fallen in love with America's horse.'' He said exports were up more than 20 percent in 1989 and the total export value grew to $26,818,000. Quarter horse racing is also increasing dramatically.
