The Amarillo-based association estimates 16,000 such races will be staged this year with purses totaling $60 million and wagering exceeding $300 million. The Labor Day All-American Futurity, crown jewel of quarter horse racing, offers a $2 million purse _ $96,909 per second over the quarter mile. In 1988, the winner of the race at Ruidoso, N.M., covered the distance in 22 seconds, and its owner earned $1 million on a horse purchased for $9,000. Next year, the association will open the American Quarter Horse Heritage Center and Museum in Amarillo to showcase the horse's historical role and house the group's hall of fame. This week's anniversary celebration kicks off Thursday at Billy Bob's Texas with a reception honoring quarter horse owners from around the world. Billy Bob's modestly bills itself as the world's largest honky tonk, and spokeswoman Becky Tillson likens the international reception to a ``United Nations of horsemen in cowboy hats jabbering in German, Italian, Spanish and Japanese.'' Horses are coming in from as far as New York, Montana and England. A ``Versatility Challenge'' on Sunday will match five of the nation's top American quarter horses competing in a variety of categories for a somewhat token $5,000. ``Spectators will have the rare opportunity of seeing in one arena the paragons of the breed in performance,'' said Tate.

DOC.HEAD: Group Says Nursing Home Insurance Market Fraught With Abuses
DOC.TEXT: Vulnerable older Americans are being duped into buying expensive nursing home insurance policies that fail to deliver the promised protection against staggering long-term care costs, a private advocacy group said Monday. The Families USA Foundation called for a government probe into what it said are widespread abuses in the long-term care insurance market, including misrepresentations by insurance agents, company refusals to pay benefits and extensive payment delays. ``There is so much evidence of insurance industry abuse of frail elderly consumers that the Federal Trade Commission should investigate,'' said Ron Pollack, executive director of the foundation. The problems include top-rated companies as well as fly-by-night operations, the foundation said. In one case, it said, an insurance agent visited a 74-year-old widow in Minnesota in the hospital to collect her first premium, and later denied her nursing home benefits because she was hospitalized when she bought the policy. In another, an elderly Iowa man was promised he need never worry about paying for a nursing home if he bought a policy that turned out to be so restrictive it would not cover 97 percent of the nursing home beds in Iowa. The Health Insurance Association of America issued a statement in response that said it would welcome an FTC investigation ``because we are convinced it will reveal that abuses are the exception, not the rule.'' It said Families USA was calling for a government inquiry in hopes of promoting ``an outdated, big-government approach to long-term care.'' Families USA believes the best solution to the long-term care problem is a broad-based social insurance program akin to Social Security or Medicare, with private insurance playing only a supplementary role. An estimated 40 percent of all elderly will spend some time in a nursing home, with half of all stays lasting six months or less and the other half averaging 2{ years, according to the health insurance association. Long-term care insurance was virtually non-existent before 1980 but the market has grown rapidly in recent years because of rising concern about the high cost of nursing home care, which averages more than $2,000 a month. More than 100 insurance companies now offer nursing home insurance and more than 1.3 million policies have been purchased. Families USA said it was asking Congress to seek an FTC probe into alleged unfair business practices in the nursing home market. The move was welcomed by two members by the House Energy and Commerce subcommittee on oversight and investigations, which is conducting its own investigation into nursing home insurance. Rep. John Dingell, a Michigan Democrat who chairs both the full committee and its oversight subcommittee, said the foundation's report was in line with what his investigators are finding. ``When untamed avarice and constant prevarication become the trademarks of a product, it is time for reform,'' Dingell said in a statement. Rep. Ron Wyden, D-Ore., also on the subcommittee, said the report would provide added impetus for federal regulation of the nursing home insurance market. ``It may well be necessary to have national minimum standards for private long-term care insurance,'' Wyden said. Currently, roughly half of nursing home costs are paid by individuals and the other half by the government, mainly through Medicaid. Medicaid coverage of nursing home costs is available only after people become impoverished.

DOC.HEAD: And Now For Some Comic Relief, Courtesy of Your Legislature
DOC.TEXT: As fast as you can, repeat the following five times: A potty parity proposal is pending in Pennsylvania. OK, good. If you don't feel just a little silly right now, you may have what it takes to serve in your state legislature. You could have the ability to keep a straight face while proposing laws to ban toad licking, soothe nervous chickens, pay people to vote, keep cheerleaders off steroids, exempt ostrich steaks from sales tax, bring back the whipping post and castrate sex offenders. Or, perhaps, to give your state its own official State Insect, State Marmot or State Soil. Every one of the above has been introduced in at least one legislature around the country this year, and that's not all. West Virginia legislators are considering a proposal to give lottery tickets to motorists who use their seat belts. A Tennessee representative has proposed a measure to encourage people to beat up flag burners _ he wants to reduce the penalty for assault in such cases to $1. A state senator in New Mexico has proposed creating a new county _ named after himself. You might be tempted to believe that all is not sobriety and seriousness in America's legislatures. But that would be ignoring some of the issues facing elected officials. It turns out, for instance, that there are people who get their kicks licking toads. According to the U.S. Drug Enforcement Administration, South American cane toads secrete a hallucinogenic toxin that can get the licker as high as a tree frog. Legislators in Georgia and South Carolina have introduced bills to outlaw the practice. ``They say these frogs grow to the size of a dinner plate,'' said a horrified Rep. Pat Harris of South Carolina. ``I don't want to see somebody walk across the statehouse grounds with a frog on a leash and pick him up and lick him.'' And consider the plight of the common chicken. One of Harris' colleagues in South Carolina, Rep. Larry Koon, has introduced a bill making it illegal to fire a gun within 300 yards of a chicken coop. The sound of a gunshot, it seems, can cause chickens to lose their vaunted composure, jump into a pile and suffocate each other. ``Last year, one of Mr. Koon's constitutents had chickens in a house,'' explained Rep. Tom Rhoad. ``Someone had a dove shoot in the field right next to the chicken house. And the guns fired and caused the chickens to huddle up in a corner, and the farmer lost over 1,000 chickens.'' The potty parity bill in Pennsylvania, and a similar one in Maryland, are aimed at eliminating a serious, even agonizing social problem: the long lines that form outside women's restrooms in stadiums, convention halls and other public places. Simply put, the proposals require more toilets for women. The list of official State Stuff could be expanded this year to include the official State Marmot of Alaska (the squirrelly ``senior hoary marmot'' at the Anchorage Zoo), the State Insect of Colorado (the yucca moth), and the official Soils of Kentucky (the Crider soil series), South Dakota (the Houdek soil series) and Michigan (the Kalkaska soil series). It's getting to be all too much for some legislators, among them Rep. Bill Lear of Kentucky. ``Last week it was the official butterfly,'' he fumed. ``This week it's the official soil. And if we keep this up somebody will want a bill for frivolous conduct and that will be for the General Assembly.''

DOC.HEAD: Mayor Says Bush Should Assure Soviets, East Europe on Unified Germany
DOC.TEXT: President Bush should assure the Soviet Union and other East European countries that they face no risk of aggression from a reunited Germany, West Berlin Mayor Walter Momper said Monday. ``The main achievement of the Soviet Union in the second world war was the security of their Western flank,'' Momper told reporters. ``If they really feel that they have lost this main achievement of the second world war, I think (Soviet President Mikhail) Gorbachev would get a blow that he really can't bear in his own country.'' Momper was to meet with Bush on Tuesday, two days after the president met with West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl at Camp David to coordinate their approach to the reunification of Germany. ``There is some concern in the Soviet Union over what might happen to the Soviet troops and to the security on their Western flank, and mainly the United States can help to assure the Soviet Union that there is nothing happening that might hit their security interests,'' said Momper. He said Bush also should reassure Poland, Czechoslovakia and other Eastern European countries. Momper called for East Germany to dismantle its military and for Britain, France, the Soviet Union and United States to extend their military control to all of East Germany for a transition period before complete German unification. The four powers, which defeated Nazi Germany in World War II, have retained occupation rights in Berlin for the 45 years since the war. Soviet troops should remain at reduced levels in East Germany for an unspecified time to assure Poland and the Soviet Union, Momper said.

DOC.HEAD: Cambodia Negotiators Consider Plan for U.N. Role
DOC.TEXT: Negotiations resumed Monday on ending the decade-old civil war in Cambodia, with Australia's proposal for an interim U.N. administration the main topic of discussion. None of the parties directly involved in the talks registered an explicit rejection of the United Nations playing a major role until elections are held, said Ali Alatas, foreign minister of Indonesia. Attending the latest talks are representatives of the Vietnamese-sponsored government of Cambodia; the three guerrilla factions; Vietnam; Laos; France; Australia; and the Association of Southeast Asian Nations, consisting of Brunei, Indonesia, Malaysia, the Philippines, Singapore and Thailand. In an address opening the conference, Alatis said there was broad support for the Australian proposal. He said the five permanent members of the U.N. Security Council _ The United States, Soviet Union, China, Britain and France _ had endorsed greater U.N. participation. No quick agreement was expected on the proposal, especially after reports reached Jakarta that thousands of Vietnamese troops had secretly returned to Cambodia to support premier Hun Sen's army against the guerrillas. Vietman claimed all its force withdrew in late September after nearly 11 years of occupation, but guerrilla leaders denied it. Three guerrilla groups are in an alliance led by Prince Norodom Sihanouk: the prince's own followers and the People's National Liberation Front of former Premier Son Sann, both non-Communist, and the Khmer Rouge, whose brutal regime was ousted by the Vietnamese invasion of December 1978. In Jakarta, Son Sann said of the Vietnamese: ``Everybody knows they are still in Cambodia, and when Phnom Penh troops fight us in western Cambodia, there are many Vietnamese troops among them.'' Khieu Samphan, nominal leader of the Khmer Rouge, said 20,000 Vietnamese troops had slipped back into Cambodia. The Vietnamese refused to let the United Nations verify their withdrawal in September. ``We have returned (home) and never come back,'' Foreign Minister Nguyen Co Thach said Monday in Jakarta. The latest conference is to run through Wednesday. Foreign Minister Gareth Evans said the Australian plan for a key U.N. role was an elaboration of earlier suggestions by Prince Sihanouk, Cambodia's former ruler, and Rep. Stephen Solarz, D-N.Y., who heads the House subcommittee on Asian and Pacific affairs. ``Foreign troops must leave Cambodia and not come back; the U.N. can monitor and verify this,'' Evans said. ``Foreign arms supply and military assistance has to stop; the U.N. can monitor and verify this. There has to be a cease-fire and associated measures so that hostilities do not start again; the U.N. can supervise, monitor and verify this.'' China arms the guerrilla coalition and the Soviet Union provides weapons to Vietnam and the Hun Sen government. The United States has shipped non-lethal supplies to the guerrillas led by Sihanouk and Son Sann. Evans said the United Nations ``should be involved in the civil administration of Cambodia in the transitional period leading up to free and fair elections. ... This central idea has been agreed by virtually everyone to whom we have spoken. Even that one Cambodian party which has not accepted it has publicly stated that it has not rejected it.'' His reference appeared to be to the Khmer Rouge. In addition to U.N. administrators, Evans proposed a Supreme National Council to be ``the repository of Cambodian national sovereignty and national unity during the transitional period. .. . Membership of the Supreme National Council could be made up of individuals from all the Cambodian parties serving in their personal capacity as `prominent cambodians.''' Other provisions of the Australian proposal would dismantle the Hun Sen government and declare Cambodia's U.N. seat vacant. It is held by the guerrilla coalition. Rafeeuddin Ahmed, who is representing Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar in Jakarta, said the United Nations ``would be prepared, in the framework of a comprehensive settlement, to contribute to the implementation of the agreements reached ... if that were the wish of all parties directly concerned.'' ``The secretary-general has stressed, however, that the mandate which may ultimately be entrusted to the United Nations must be well defined, realistic and practicable,'' he said. Foreign Minister Roland Dumas is serving as co-host of the talks with Alatas. The former colonial power in Cambodia recognizes neither the Hun Sen government nor the guerrilla alliance.

DOC.HEAD: Gunman Kills Two at Birthday Party
DOC.TEXT: A man described as upset over his pending divorce shot and killed his estranged wife and a neighbor at a birthday party and wounded three other people, police said. Authorities on Monday were seeking Carlos Barreto, 68, for questioning in Sunday's shootings, said police Sgt. Steve Harrison. Barreto's estranged wife, Elaine Renee Barreto, 37, died at the house where she was giving a party for some friends with February birthdays, said Lt. Bill Manger. Witnesses told police the gunman entered the house quietly at 3 a.m., put a revolver to Ms. Barreto's head and shot her. He then began shooting at the 15 guests as they sought cover behind furniture and in other rooms in the house. The neighbor who was shot, Shawn Robertson, 30, died at Desert Hospital, police said. Among the three wounded, Robert Coon, 30, was most seriously injured. He was hospitalized in critical condition, Harrison said.

DOC.HEAD: Some Fear Publicity Jeopardizes Young Sex Offender's Treatment
DOC.TEXT: The confession was supposed to be secret, not even admissible in court. But now, people who follow the news know the name of a 13-year-old who admitted molesting 64 preschoolers. The leak of David Hawkey's confession and the resulting widespread publicity has seriously jeopardized his treatment, say counselors at the youth home where he is undergoing court-ordered therapy. The boy now trusts no one and, because of fear of harassment, has been removed from the public school he was attending under supervision. Social workers say they don't know where he can be helped without being followed by the stigma of what he admitted. ``The question becomes, where can this child go now to get treatment? Are we going to have to send him out of state?'' asked Glenn DeMots, associate executive director of Bethany Christian Services in Grand Rapids. The boy from Fruitport, a mostly rural community of 1,100 residents about 30 miles northwest of Grand Rapids, has been at Bethany since last summer after pleading guilty to second-degree criminal sexual conduct for molesting one child while baby-sitting during services at Fruitport Bethel Baptist Church. As part of his treatment, he was urged to disclose the names of any other victims. He admitted molesting 63 otherchildren between ages 1{ to 4 years old during 1985-88. He also implicated his 17-year-old brother, Paul, who was charged with one count of first-degree criminal sexual conduct. Paul denies the charge. David was told beforehand that any disclosures he made would be given to his case worker and police to ensure treatment for the alleged victims. But otherwise, the confession from patient to therapist is confidential. But during the notification of congregation members, the confession became public. The story was first published, identifying the Hawkey boys, in The Muskegon Chronicle on Feb. 4. It wasn't long before the story was picked up nationally. David has been labeled as potentially one of the worst child molesters in U.S. history. Since the story broke, Muskegon County Prosecutor Tony Tague has filed two additional charges of first-degree criminal sexual conduct against David and said he expects more charges. ``I wouldn't feel comfortable just taking his word for (the number of victims), so we're trying to verify as many cases as we can,'' Tague said, adding that detectives were still interviewing many of the children. Tague said he would like to see David incarcerated until his 19th birthday, the maximum penalty because of his age at the time of the alleged crimes. Media representatives have said the seriousness of the alleged abuse made identification of the boys inevitable. ``If we didn't name them, every person in Fruitport with a 13-year-old neighbor is going to be looking sideways at him,'' said Chronicle Editor Gunnar Carlson. ``On the other hand, there were dozens and dozens of people who already knew precisely who was involved, so it certainly didn't come as any surprise to the congregation or to the extended family.'' David's attorney, Gerald Gibbs, said he is worried the publicity has tainted the case. ``I don't know what his chances are with all the publicity,'' Gibbs said. ``It's too early to know how seriously it's disrupted his treatment, but he already has a serious distrust of the system from all of this.'' The pastor of the church said the publicity has drawn his congregation together. ``I don't think the names should have been used ... but in some cases, it's been helpful for the victims and their parents to see the reports so they know (the boy) is being held and doesn't have access to them,'' the Rev. Billie Anderson said. Bethany officials fear the publicity and the prosecutor's aggressiveness may deter other young offenders from disclosing their crimes. ``Disclosure is the key to treatment,'' clinical supervisor Cindy Lindstrom said. ``This has created a lot of questions for the kids about what they should and shouldn't say. ... I'm very concerned how it could affect the rest of the program.''

DOC.HEAD: Jackson Announces He's Not Running for Mayor
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Combines pvs files, minor editing to update
DOC.TEXT: Jesse L. Jackson said today he will not run for mayor of the nation's capital in this fall's election. ``I want to continue to serve, but not as mayor,'' the civil rights leader and two-time Democratic presidential candidate said in a statement prepared for a news conference. Jackson's political plans have been the subject of conjecture since he moved to Washington in April 1989. The speculation intensified with Mayor Marion Barry's arrest last month on a cocaine possession charge. In his statement, Jackson did not address whether he would again seek the White House in 1992. He said he plans to continue working to end the city's drug and crime crisis and to push for statehood for the District of Columbia. ``At present I believe that I may best serve by continuing my work on a national level to change the direction of this country. I want to serve, but not as mayor,'' Jackson said. ``Because this is an election year, the mayor's issue has grown with the crisis in the city and the tribulations of the mayor,'' Jackson said in his statement. In recent weeks, Jackson has stressed repeatedly that championing the city's quest to become the nation's 51st state would remain his priority through the election year. Barry is in a South Carolina hospital for treatment for what an aide has called an alcohol problem. City Administrator Carol Thompson is in charge of the city in Barry's absence. Jackson's decision comes amid growing signs that voters _ and politicians _ are wary of a Jackson mayoral bid. A Washington Post poll released Thursday said Jackson would trail Barry if both were candidates in the September Democratic primary. The poll of 800 registered Democrats in the district found Barry was preferred by 25 percent of those surveyed, while 19 percent said they would vote for Jackson. Four other possible candidates split 33 percent of those polled, while the remaining 9 percent were listed as undecided, wouldn't vote or other. If Barry were not in the race, Jackson would receive support from 26 percent of those questioned, compared with 19 percent for city Councilman John Ray. The poll had a margin of error of 4 percentage points. In the past, Jackson refused repeatedly to rule out a run for Barry's job, saying he only would seek the office if Barry, a longtime colleague, did not run for a fourth term. Since his arrest, Barry has been silent on his plans for re-election. Mayoral aides have said Barry acknowledged privately the weekend after his arrest that he would not run again. The prospects for a Jackson candidacy had encountered other turbulence. Last fall, the city council passed a bill sponsored by two announced mayoral candidates that limits outside income from honoraria and speeches for the mayor to $10,000 per year. Jackson has said he earns about $200,000 a year, mostly from speeches and honoraria. The mayor's job pays $89,500 a year. In addition to Ray, there are three announced Democratic candidates for mayor and one Republican.

DOC.HEAD: Sandinistas Defeated In Stunning Upset
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 18 grafs to UPDATE with details, reax, background on Sandinista government. Pick up 15th pvs, `The Supreme...' Minor editing to trim.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos MGA8,13,14,16;LaserColor MGA17
DOC.TEXT: Opposition leader Violeta Barrios de Chamorro defeated President Daniel Ortega in a stunning rebuke to 10 years of leftist Sandinista rule in this war-weary nation, election returns showed today. Sunday's peaceful balloting _ the freest elections in Nicaraguan history _ was closely watched by thousands of international observers and, with more than three-fourths of the vote in, Mrs. Chamorro was winning just over 55 percent. Earlier, with more than half the results in, Ortega stopped short of formally conceding but said in a television appearance: ``These numbers and these percentages form a tendency that cannot be ignored.'' He said the precincts that had not yet reported held 50 percent of the vote, but admitted a Sandinista victory would ``break mathematical rules.'' ``I want to tell all Nicaraguans and all the nations of the world, that the president of Nicaragua, and the government, will respect and accept the popular mandate,'' Ortega added. The Sandinistas remain by far the largest single party _ the United Nationalist Opposition Mrs. Chamorro heads is a fractious alliance of 14 parties ranging from far right to far left _ and it was unclear how power would be transferred. Defense Minister Humberto Ortega, the president's brother, has said that if Mrs. Chamorro won, ``she would still have to deal with me,'' and that the army might disobey orders it considered unsound. Whether he commands that kind of loyalty remains to be seen. UNO has said it will eliminate the draft and greatly reduce the size of the army, the largest in Central America. Another question is how UNO, whose members' only common interest was getting rid of the Sandinistas, could form a government strong enough to stand up to the Sandinista bureaucracy. Ortega, 44, had branded Mrs. Chamorro, the 60-year-old publisher of the opposition newspaper La Prensa, an instrument of U.S. policy and had hoped to capitalize on Nicaraguan pride at standing up to the colossus of the North. But the voters rejected Ortega's one-party rule, which led to economic decline that the Sandinistas blamed on the U.S.-supported Contra insurgency and a U.S. trade embargo. Under the Sandinistas, Nicaragua became a self-proclaimed revolutionary state and adopted portions of Marxist and Leninist ideology to remake its economic and social structures. It won strong support from the Soviet Union and Cuba, and was accused by the United States of trying to foment Communist revolution in neighboring El Salvador. The Sandinist loss to the UNO, which says it favors Western-style representative government, followed by just a few months the restoration of democracy in a series of Soviet-aligned nations in East Europe and moves toward democratization in the Soviet Union itself. ``The Nicaraguan people have shown that they want to live in democracy, in peace and in freedom,'' Mrs. Chamorro told more than 1,000 cheering supporters. If her victory is confirmed, she will take office on April 25. In Washington, President Bush hailed the upset victory in Nicaragua as ``another victory'' for democracy in a remarkable year. His spokesman said a lifting of economic sanctions would be a ``first consideration.'' He said he spoke with Venezuelan President Carlos Andres Perez about ``appropriate trade and economic measures that we can take to support the new government of Nicaragua.'' Secretary of State James A. Baker III said the international community would insist ``full civil and military power be transferred to the newly elected government.'' Honduras said Chamorro's victory would pave the way for improved relations with its neighbor. The countries have quarreled over U.S.-backed Contra rebel bases in Honduras. The Supreme Electoral Council said that with 77.7 percent of precincts counted, Mrs. Chamorro had 618,699 votes, or 55.2 percent, to Ortega's 457,870 or 40.9 percent. Eight other parties split what little remained. Ortega's speech was filled with sadness and seemed at times almost like a valedictory, tracing the course of the Sandinista party from the time it led the revolution that toppled President Anastasio Somoza in 1979. ``Just as we managed to defeat Somocismo, so we also managed to defeat the counterrevolution and to indict before the world those who launched a policy of death against the people of Nicaragua,'' he said, referring to the United States. ``We were sure that this electoral process would bring all Nicaraguans that peace and stability we need so much,'' Ortega said. At times Ortega looked pained and it seemed as if he simply could not bring himself to say flatly that the party had lost. Flanked by top aides and his common-law wife, who looked pale and shaken, Ortega told Nicaraguans he was proud, in any case, that the Sandinistas had brought a democratic election to Nicaragua. Aristides Sanchez, a Contra leader, called the election result ``a triumph of the people. ``All Nicaraguans must now back the new government and attempt to achieve a national reconciliation,'' he said in a telephone interview from Miami. The United States ended military aid to the Contras in February 1988, but, at Bush's urging, Congress has continued to supply the ontras with non-lethal aid to pressure the Sandinistas into holding free elections. Mrs. Chamorro was asked as she left her house for campaign headquarters if she thought a transfer of power after 10{ years of Sandinista rule would be smooth. ``That's the commitment. We want peace and reconciliation.'' As they battled the Contra rebels, the Sandinistas muzzled dissent for years. Most pre-election polls said Mrs. Chamorro was trailing Ortega, but many Nicaraguans were afraid to reveal their true feelings outside a truly secret ballot box. Under the Sandinistas, the centrally planned economy was wracked by inflation and mismanagement. Celebrations began breaking out in various neighborhoods of Managua before dawn, with people burning some of the thousands of Sandinista banners draped across city streets. However, the celebrations appeared to die down quickly. A midnight celebration at Sandinista headquarters had been canceled. Turnout was heavy in what was considered Nicaragua's freest vote ever, with people lining up for as much as four hours to cast ballots and more than 3,000 international observers monitoring the peaceful election. Voters also selected 90 National Assembly members and representatives to 146 regional, city and town councils. The electoral council was extremely late in reporting votes, and opposition officials initially said they believed the council hadn't expected a Sandinista loss and was withholding announcement because it didn't know what to do. After the polls closed, former President Jimmy Carter, head of one observer group, called the ballot ``very fair.'' About 1.75 million of Nicaragua's 3.5 million people were registered to vote. A festive mood prevailed at the headquarters of Mrs. Chamorro early today, while at the Sandinista party headquarters the mood was funereal, with long faces and few smiles. Mrs. Chamorro favors market-oriented reform, but the Sandinistas recently softened their socialist line, promising a mixed economy and saying they would no longer expropriate private property. They also released political prisoners. Inflation, which ran 1,700 percent last year, and the draft were on the minds of many voters. Barely a Nicaraguan family has escaped losing a member to the war with the Contras, which has claimed 30,000 lives.

DOC.HEAD: Perrier Says Its Recall Nearly Complete
DOC.TEXT: Perrier said Monday the recall of the 160 million bottles of sparkling water it had on the market around the world was more than 90 percent complete. Withdrawing of Perrier's familiar green bottles began Feb. 14 when the water was found to contain the chemical benzene. The company said a redistribution plan is being developed and details will be announced. The recall was estimated to put a $35 million dent in Perrier's profits. Perrier said the problem that prompted the recall had been isolated at the gas filtration level of production. ``New procedures have been put in place to assure quality control: double filtration of carbonic gas, tests for hydrocarbon content, as well as continuous surveillance by an external laboratory,'' Perrier said. It said that after tests by independent experts, no contamination or pollution of the company's spring in Vergeze has been found.

DOC.HEAD: Israeli Foreign Minister Begins Visit
DOC.TEXT: Israeli Foreign Minister Moshe Arens arrived Monday for a four-day visit during which full diplomatic relations with Poland are to be restored after a 23-year break. Arens meets Tuesday with his Polish counterpart, Foreign Minister Krzysztof Skubiszewski, to sign the protocol establishing the ties broken by Poland after the 1967 Middle East War. He also has appointments Tuesday with Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki and President Wojciech Jaruzelski. The foreign minister's first day was spent in emotional visits to memorials to Poland's once-vibrant Jewish community, reduced to a few thousand from 3.5 million before World War II. ``Every Jew who comes to Poland must remember the tragedy of the Holocaust that the Jewish nation went through on this land,'' Arens said, the official PAP news agency reported. He paid homage at the monument to the Warsaw Ghetto uprising of 1943, when Jews, held in a walled-in section of the city to face starvation or deportation, rose up against the Nazi occupiers. Arens stood in silence at the monument at Umschlagplatz, the depot where 300,000 Warsaw Jews were loaded on trains to the Nazi concentration camps. He went to the Jewish Cemetery, where acres of overgrown graves testify to the obliteration of later generations. He laid a wreath at the Polish Tomb of the Unknown Soldier, and visited the Majdanek concentration camp near Lublin in southeastern Poland. Arens on Wednesday will go to the Auschwitz death camp in southern Poland, where the presence of a Roman Catholic convent in a former Nazi warehouse strained Jewish-Polish relations and stirred international controversy. Construction of an interfaith prayer center to house the nuns farther from the camp began last week, a year after the passing of the deadline for moving the convent set in an accord reached by Jewish and Catholic leaders in Geneva. Polish press coverage of the Arens visit has focused on the Solidarity-led government's position acknowledging the error of the decision to sever ties and the act's consequences, including an anti-Semitic purge in 1968. ``Poland Apologizes to Israel'' and ``Return to Normalcy'' were among the newspaper headlines Monday. The daily Zycie Warszawy said the breaking of ties ``could have looked spectacular then, and could even seem justified, but in fact it brought about more losses than profits.'' Poland, with the rest of the Warsaw Pact except Romania, cut relations with Israel after the 1967 war. Hungary in September became the first nation to restore ties, and Czechoslovakia was the second on Feb. 9. From 350,000 to 500,000 Israelis were born in Poland, the newspaper noted, including the first Israeli prime minister, David Ben Ben Gurion, and the present one, Yitzhak Shamir. Polish-Israeli relations have steadily improved since 1986, when each country established an interest section in the other's capital. Poland's new government, however, also has sought to establish even-handed relations with Arab states and has not changed its position in support of the Palestinian nation's right to a homeland. Arens is accompanied by a delegation of business leaders and has talks scheduled with Polish Finance Minister Leszek Balcerowic, who drafted Poland's radical shift toward a market-driven economy. Poland is seeking Western investment and officials have said they hope the improved relations will increase Polish-Israeli trade, estimated at $60 million last year.

DOC.HEAD: Economists Are Optimistic; On the Other Hand ...
DOC.TEXT: The nation's top business economists believe the economy will avoid a recession for the next three years and break the record expansion set in the ``glory days'' of the 1960s, according to a survey released on Monday. But the poll by the National Association of Business Economists indicated the economy is in a ``danger zone'' and is likely to grow only a sluggish 1.7 percent this year before accelerating to a 2.5 percent rate next year. The 65 professional forecasters also saw little sign of significant progress over the next two years in achieving the zero inflation goal set by the Federal Reserve. In fact, they predicted prices would rise 4.2 percent both this year and next, down slightly from 1989's 4.6 percent rate. The rate was 4.4 percent in both 1987 and 1988. Nevertheless, the survey showed that 60.6 percent believe the economy will avoid a recession through 1993, statistically unchanged from a 62.1 percent finding late last year. James F. Smith, the association's president and finance professor at the University of North Carolina, said the biggest news in the survey is its confirmation of the ``sea-change'' of optimism found among participants in December. A survey last May found 63 percent of the economists expecting a recession this year. Still, nearly 46.2 percent in the latest survey said the risk of an economic downturn increased in the fourth quarter of 1989. Of the 39.4 percent who thought a recession would occur in the next three years, 18.1 percent believe it started in the last quarter or will begin sometime this year. A survey summary contended ``the economy is in a danger zone.'' It said ``the probability of recession is not trivial and almost 80 percent of respondents think it has risen or remained the same over the last quarter,'' Only 21.5 percent said they believe the recession risk has decreased. ``We all know we have not repealed the business cycle; there will be a recession some day,'' Smith said . ``But our members are confident ... that we will shatter all records for the U.S. economy with the current expansion (now in its eighth year). ``When we get to October 1991, we will tie the glory days of the 1960s and break the 1961-1969 expansion,'' he said. Smith credited Fed Chairman Alan Greenspan and other members of the Federal Open Market Committee for the ``relatively confident outlook.'' ``In our latest policy survey, an astounding 72 percent of the nearly 300 respondents said what the Fed was doing was about right,'' Smith said. ``Now anything that gets almost three out of four economists to agree with it must be either tremendously good or tremendously bad. In this case, we would assume tremendously good.'' The FOMC, comprised of the Fed governors and district presidents, sets monetary policy and for more than a year has been trying to drive down inflation by keeping a tight rein on credit. The Bush administration and many economists have urged the Fed to ease credit and thus permit lower interest rates in an attempt to stimulate the economy, which slowed from a 3 percent growth rate in the third quarter to 0.5 percent in the fourth. However, Greenspan indicated to Congress last week the central bank would keep interest rates high. And in their survey, the NABE economists expect little movement in interest rates over 1990-1991.

DOC.HEAD: Experts Testify In Finale of Hazelwood Prosecution Case
DOC.TEXT: The giant hull of the Exxon Valdez was gashed twice as the tanker lumbered over one set of jagged rocks and grounded on another on Bligh Reef, a witness testified today. George Greiner Jr., formerly of the Coast Guard, showed jurors elaborate sets of charts, graphs and photographs of the ship in dry dock in San Diego. Greiner said he tracked the ship's course from a number of logs kept by the crew and found that its damage was intensified by the dramatic shifting of tides in Prince William Sound as the 987-foot tanker sat grounded on the reef. He said the rising tide ``caused a crushing effect,'' adding to the damage. Greiner testified as the trial of Joseph Hazelwood entered its fourth week with prosecutors planning to rest their case against the skipper Tuesday. The prosecution claims that Hazelwood, skipper of the crippled ship, was reckless in trying to drive it off the reef after the March 24 accident. Hazelwood's lawyers contend he never attempted the risky maneuver of backing off the reef but was trying to stabilize the vessel by moving forward. Prosecutors say that if Hazelwood had succeeded in moving it off the reef, the Exxon Valdez would have capsized, spilling even more oil and possibly killing crew members. The tanker spilled almost 11 million gallons of oil, killing countless birds, fish and other wildlife and blackening hundreds of miles of rocky shore. In addition to Greiner, prosecutors plan to call experts to testify about the effects of alcohol on the body and the figures reflected on blood-alcohol tests administered to Hazelwood after the accident. Hazelwood, 43, of Huntington, N.Y. is charged with second degree criminal mischief, a felony, and three misdemeanors: reckless endangerment, operating a vessel while intoxicated and negligent discharge of oil. If convicted on all counts he could face a maximim of 7\ years in prison and $61,000 in fines. Hazelwood was not on the bridge when the tanker grounded during a tricky passage into scenic Prince William Sound. A third mate who was in charge has blamed the accident on the helmsman's failure to steer properly. A key issue in the case is whether Hazelwood was drunk when he boarded the ship. He had spent a day in the port city of Valdez and was seen by witnesses drinking at a bar called the Pipeline Club. But in his first post-accident interview with the Coast Guard, played for jurors on Friday, Hazelwood denied drinking anything stronger than beer and said he drank nothing at all at the Pipeline Club.

DOC.HEAD: Christian Forces Skirmish, Deadlocking Mediation Efforts
DOC.TEXT: Christian forces skirmished in east Beirut on Monday, deadlocking mediation efforts to end the power struggle between rival Christian leaders and sending hundreds of frightened civilians fleeing. Two people died and 10 were wounded in the daylong exchanges of sniper fire, police said. That raised the casualty toll to 693 killed and 1,925 wounded since fighting broke out on Jan 30 between the Lebanese Forces led by Samir Geagea and the army troops of Gen. Michel Aoun. It is the worst fighting between Christian factions in the nearly 15-year-old civil war. A three-man mediation committee of independent Christian leaders was unable to stop the shooting and faced ``major difficulties'' in arranging an overall settlement, a police spokesman said on condition of anonymity. ``The snipers didn't stop shooting although the committee members were repeatedly informed by the two headquarters that orders had been issued to halt the exchanges,'' the spokesman said. The committee's failure to stabilize a repeatedly violated Feb. 17 cease-fire heightened concern that a new round of fighting is likely between the factions vying for control of the Christian enclave north of Beirut. The spokesman said the committee ``couldn't proceed with its plan to reopen roads'' inside Christian east Beirut because of the clashes. The committee arranged for some main roads to reopen Sunday, but so far that has been all the mediators have achieved. The mediation deadlock drove hundreds of Christian civilians to cross Beirut's dividing Green Line into Moslem west Beirut and flee to eastern and northern Lebanon. The police spokesman said there was a sharp increase in the number of evacuees in the afternoon, after radio stations reported the committee was making no progress in ending the bloodshed. At least 110,000 civilians have fled the 310-square-mile Christian enclave since Jan. 30, 35,000 of them since the fragile cease-fire began. Lebanon's national carrier, Middle East Airlines, has scheduled eight extra flights a week to Cyprus for the fleeing Christians. It normally flies to Larnaca, on the east Mediterranean island's south coast, four times a week. Christian sources said on condition of anonymity the committee could not get Aoun and Geagea to agree on its plan to stabilize the cease-fire. One source close to the mediators said Geagea's command proposed a ``disengagement of forces as a necessary step to normalize the situation before continuing with the plan to reopen roads.'' Geagea, the source said, ``believes that reopening roads without separating the forces will only jeopardize civilians who might get caught in the cross fire of any renewed fighting.'' The source said Aoun ``rejected the disengagement proposal and wanted a political agreement reached with the Lebanese Forces before the committee continues with its plan for reopening roads.'' Stabilizing the cease-fire without a political agreement would undercut Aoun's declared objective that the Lebanese Forces should disband and become a political organization. Geagea refuses to break up his military force. Geagea's fighters control two-thirds of the Christian enclave, including its three main ports and two isolated pockets on the northwestern edge of Beirut. Aoun's army holds Beirut's southeastern districts, eastern suburbs and the Metn mountains to the northeast. Shaker Abu Suleiman, a member of the committee, said the mediators are ``the thin thread'' that is preventing a new conflagration. ``We'll maintain our mission regardless of the difficulties because we do not want the population partitioned,'' he said. The leftist As-Safir daily, based in west Beirut, said Geagea has signed a ``written pledge'' to accept the authority of Syrian-backed President Elias Hrawi in east Beirut if Hrawi's government intervenes to halt the Christian feuding. Hrawi, elected Nov. 24, is recognized by Geagea, but rejected by Aoun, who considers himself the sole legitimate authority in Lebanon. The Syrians have 40,000 troops in Lebanon under a 1976 Arab League peacekeeping mandate. Aoun considers them an occupation army. In September 1988, Aoun, the army commander, was appointed head of an interim military Cabinet by outgoing President Amin Gemayel after parliament failed to elect a successor. When he took office, Hrawi fired Aoun as army chief and caretaker premier, but the general refused to step down, alleging Hrawi's election was unconstitutional. Aoun, Geagea and Hrawi are Maronite Catholics, the main Christian sect that has dominated Lebanon since independence from France in 1943.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Troops Begin Leaving Czechoslovakia
DOC.TEXT: A brass band struck up the ``Internationale'' on Monday as the Red Army began leaving Czechoslovakia 22 years after it arrived to crush a reform movement. Karel Micek of the Civic Forum said the presence of Soviet troops had meant ``empty shelves in stores, polluted water, an occasional fight in the pub and a reminder that we are not a free country.'' ``Their main problem was that they were here,'' said Micek, whose group played a central role in the peaceful revolution that ousted the Communist Party from exclusive power in November. Twenty-two Soviet T-62 tanks loaded on flatcars left the northern town of Frenstat, beginning a negotiated, three-stage pullout of the 73,500 Soviet military personnel, scheduled for completion next year. A second train, laden with 33 armored vehicles, left a few hours later from the Domasov nad Bystrici station near a Red Army base at Libava in eastern Czechoslovakia. It is the first time the Kremlin has removed its soldiers from the territory of a Warsaw Pact ally. Hungary is near agreement with the Soviets on a similar accord, but no deals have been struck with Poland and East Germany, the other Soviet allies in Europe that are hosts to Red Army troops. Soviet soldiers remained in Czechoslovakia after a Warsaw Pact invasion crushed the reformist ``Prague Spring'' of 1968. They entered Hungary in 1956 to put down an anti-Stalinist uprising. Before the withdrawal began, the Soviet Union had 1,220 tanks, 2,5O5 armored vehicles, 77 combat aircraft and 146 helicopters in Czechoslovakia, in addition to the 73,500 soldiers. Soon after the first train rolled toward the border, the official news agency CTK reported that Soviet-Czechoslovak military maneuvers would be held next month. ``The Czechoslovak People's Army and the Central Group of Troops of the Soviet Army will be held'' March 1-4 in western and northern Bohemia March 1-4, it said, quoting the Defense Ministry. It was not clear whether the announcement's timing was a coincidence or meant as a signal that Czechoslovakia remains a dependable Soviet ally despite the withdrawal and a government dominated by non-Communists. Another CTK dispatch quoted Deputy Foreign Minister Evzen Vacek as telling a parliamentary committee the pullout would be completed by June 30, 1991. No specific date had been mentioned previously. Ceremonies at Frenstat were simple and brief. The departure from the base 110 miles southeast of Prague is to be completed March 13 and Red Army troops are to be gone from Libava, 180 miles east of the capital, by March 25. The withdrawal agreement was initialed Feb. 22 in Prague and is to be signed in Moscow this week by Presidents Vaclav Havel and Mikhail S. Gorbachev. Havel flew to the Soviet capital Monday, three days after returning from the United States and talks with President Bush. Under the withdrawal agreement, a ``decisive part'' of the Soviet force is to be out by the end of May, a month before the first free elections in Czechoslovakia since the Communists consolidated power in 1948. ``This is our new peace policy in practice ... a retreat from the policy of confrontation,'' Gen. Vladimir Malyshkievich, deputy chief of Soviet forces in Czechoslovakia, said during the Frenstat ceremonies. ``It is only proper this process starts in the center of Europe and on the day of the official visit of President Havel in the Soviet Union.'' No official figures have been released on how many soldiers left Monday. Vadim Pliska, a Soviet trooper at Frenstat, said 2,000 soldiers and about 90 tanks were stationed there.

DOC.HEAD: Despite Million-Dollar Homes, Island Market Not What it Used to Be
DOC.TEXT: The slumping New England economy is taking its toll even on this exclusive little island, where corporate officers, rock stars, politicians and stockbrokers retreat for the summer. The $4 million beachfront cottages are still being snapped up, but economic and oceanic tides have washed away prospects for fast bucks from quickie developments. This pleases Nantucket's year-round residents, who say all the new construction threatens the island's natural charm. ``Developers aren't welcome here,'' Nantucket real estate agent David Webster said flatly. Speculation builders came to the island from the mid-1970s to mid-1980s, when New England banks were making jumbo loans for developers, who then bought land and built and built. They turned miles of the island's moors and golden heathlands into subdivisions with asphalt streets and green lawns. The real estate market already was pricy. In Nantucket's historic downtown, colonial homes from the 17th century regularly sold for millions of dollars, and prices escalated for properties along the ocean. ``You take a house that runs $700,000 inland here,'' Webster said. ``If it's within sight of water the price can go to $1.5 million. If it's on the beach, it's up to $3 million.'' About 600 new housing units a year were built on Nantucket's 30,000 acres during the peak years of the mid-1980s, Webster says. Now, he adds, about half that number are built each year. ``When I was a kid it used to be beautiful out here,'' Webster said, driving through an area dotted with new two-bedroom developments. ``There even used to be sheep grazing out here.'' The sheep are gone, but now, so are the developers. When the stock market crashed in 1987, the bottom started to fall out of the New England real estate market. Some developers were stuck with high-priced mortgages on lots and buildings. Webster mentions one who is taking a bath after building a 100-room motel that has no renters. ``They're paying $100,000 a month on the mortgage,'' Webster said. ``They can't pay it back. And what does the bank do? They don't want it.'' What economics haven't accomplished, nature has. Erosion on the island's windy southern and eastern coasts is eating away at beachfront lots holding houses that once sold for millions. ``On the south side of the island, beachfront properties are going for $300,000 that would go for $1.2 million on the north side,'' Webster said. ``People simply aren't building on the south side of the island anymore.'' Such developments please islanders, who have established commissions to preserve the island's historic downtown and the countryside. A land bank levies a 2 percent fee against all real estate transactions. The money is used to buy and administer land to be preserved. ``There was a feeling that if the people didn't do something, the land wouldn't be saved,'' said Dawn Darbey, director of the land bank.

DOC.HEAD: Musicians Say Grammy's Show World's Waking up to New Orleans Sound
DOC.TEXT: New Grammy award winners with New Orleans roots met Monday for an extra awards ceremony at City Hall and said the world is finally waking up to the New Orleans sound. ``I don't think we're doing anything differently. I think the world is just catching up to us,'' said Mac Rebennack, better known as Dr. John, who won a Grammy last week with Rickie Lee Jones for a jazz duet version of ``Makin' Whoopee.'' Mayor Sidney Barthelemy recognized the prize-winning artists with certificates of merit. Three of the Neville Brothers, winners for best pop instrumental with the song ``Healing Chant,'' also were on hand. Art Neville said national and world recognition of New Orleans music, with its jazz, Caribbean and African influences, was long overdue. Charles Neville said last week's four Grammy awards for New Orleans recording acts are bound to help the city's musicians. ``I think the big thing it did though, was give more credibility to New Orleans music,'' he said. ``We'll probably get regular air play now. Before this, programmers said New Orleans music was too regional. Well, it's true it is regional. But the region is the world.'' Aaron Neville, who also won a separate Grammy for a duet with Linda Ronstadt, said he's still not over Grammy night. ``I was excited and nervous the night of the awards. I'm just excited now,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Anglo-Irish Parliamentary Body: A Coming Together of Old Foes
DOC.TEXT: It was hardly the fall of the Berlin Wall, but the ceremony Monday in the House of Commons also was historic: It brought Irish and British lawmakers together as a joint parliamentary body for the first time in nearly 70 years. In the Jubilee Room of the cavernous House of Commons, champagne glasses clinked in jovial harmony and Irish and British voices once again discussed the question that has vexed the two island nations for centuries: how to understand each other. ``Our two people have an infinite capacity for mutual misunderstanding,'' former Irish Prime Minister Garret FitzGerald said in an interview, ``and the opportunity to sit down and talk to each other, know each other, understand how each other's minds work and dissipate some of the prejudices by undermining them, I think is very important.'' The British-Irish Inter-Parliamentary Body has no legislative powers, and the job of its 25 Irish and 25 British members will be limited almost entirely to talk. But it is the first forum of its kind since Ireland became independent in 1922 with its own parliament, the Dail, and it comes at a time when cautious hopes are being voiced about settling the Northern Ireland conflict. Peter Brooke, Britain's top official in Northern Ireland, has been talking about new possibilities of bringing feuding Protestant and Catholic leaders together; Irish Prime Minister Charles Haughey is to pay a rare visit to Belfast in April; and increasingly, Northern Irelanders are asking what 20 years of bloodshed and nearly 3,000 deaths have accomplished. ``There is movement at the moment. It's slight, I don't want to raise expectations, but I do believe it's real,'' said Irish Deputy Prime Minister Brian Lenihan, who will co-chair the new body with his British counterpart, Sir Geoffrey Howe. The reason, Lenihan told BBC Radio, is that the unionists, Northern Ireland's Protestant majority, are discovering that their refusal to negotiate with the Catholic nationalist minority is getting them nowhere. ``The unionists now see that the world is passing them by. Recent events in Europe ... mean that Northern Ireland more and more is becoming a backwater,'' said Lenihan. The unionists were offered two seats on the Inter-Parliamentary Body, but turned them down. They see it as a byproduct of the 1985 Anglo-Irish Agreement, which they believe undermines their union with Britain by giving the Irish government a say in the running of British-ruled Northern Ireland. Their boycott represents a reversal of history, for once it was the Irish nationalists who refused to have any dealings with London. As far back as 1843, Daniel O'Connell, the great Irish nationalist, warned his people never ``to expect anything except injustice from an English Parliament.'' Those suspicions linger. ``On the British side there's an insensitivity and on the Irish side there's a certain prickliness,'' said Austin Currie, a Northern Ireland Catholic who is a member of the Irish Dail and belongs to the new body. ``And if we recognize the insensitivity and the prickliness, that's the way to make progress.'' ``It's historic. There is no way that 20 or 15 years ago any group of Irish parliamentarians could have come here in the way that they have today,'' said Merlyn Rees, a former Northern Ireland secretary and now an opposition Labor Party lawmaker. He pointed to the staircase leading to the room where the inaugural cocktail party was going on and said, ``Where we're standing now there was an IRA bomb in 1974.'' FitzGerald argued it was the Irish Republican Army, through its bombing and shooting campaign to rid Northern Ireland of British rule, which was chiefly responsible for creating the Inter-Parliamentary Body. The IRA was as hostile to the Irish government as to the British, he said in an interview, and this had forced Dublin into coordinating strategy more closely with London. ``The actions of the IRA have so polarized opinion that the center of gravity of the Irish approach has come closer to that of the British,'' he said. ``It's the one positive contribution the IRA have ever made.'' The IRA's political wing, Sinn Fein, issued a statement hoping that members of the new body would ``press for an end to partition and the right of the Irish people to self-determination.''

DOC.HEAD: Army Shows Dismantling of Secret Police Phone-Tapping Center
DOC.TEXT: Military officers showed Monday how they had begun dismantling the telephone-tapping centers of Nicolae Ceausescu's secret police and said their work was proof the widespread eavesdropping was ended. ``Observe please that all the power boxes have been removed,'' said Maj. Gen. Nicolae Cerbu, deputy of the army Signal Corps, gesturing at a bank of cassette players in a listening center in Bucharest. Ceausescu's dreaded secret police, the Securitate, tapped tens of thousands of telephones as part of its vast domestic spying apparatus. The Securitate was officially disbanded after the December revolution that ended the Communist dictator's 24-year reign and led to his execution. The military organized a tour of the listening centers for reporters in an apparent effort to counter widespread criticism that authorities had done too little to dismantle the Securitate structures. ``This is the proof that it (bugging) doesn't happen now,'' said Col. Mihai Alexuta, another Signal Corps officer. Military officers said that in Bucharest, the Securitate maintained interception equipment at all 30 telephone exchanges, as well as in factories, hotels and military offices. The signals were sent to two secret recording studios where the conversations were monitored and transcribed, they said. ``The first people to be targeted with these listening devices were (in) the army,'' said Cerbu, who added that people generally were repulsed by this kind of activity.'' The officers said they believed they had found all the bugging centers in Romania but they declined to say how many there were. All the eavesdropping had been stopped, they said. The equipment will be dismantled and the parts inventoried and then given to different ministries or military departments for their use, Cerbu said. ``It's a pity to destroy these things, because they are expensive,'' he said. ``An amplifier could be well used in a small village where a ministry wants to set up telephones for people who don't have them.'' In one of the interception centers, a room about the size of a large broom closet located in a central telephone exchange, the officers opened a few of 48 small gray drawers set into a metal frame. Inside were circuit boards covered with transistors. The equipment was capable of intercepting 36 telephone calls at one time, and could be used for 18,000 different phones, Cerbu said. In a nearby concrete building with bars on the windows, which the officers said was a former Securitate headquarters, reporters were led up a narrow staircase to rooms filled with a series of cabinets, each containing 12 small built-in cassette players. In front were desks with switchboards. In one room were desks topped with gray metal transcription machines attached to sets of headphones. The fuses had been cut and some of the equipment was dismantled. The officers said different departments of the Securitate ordered the centers to monitor individuals, then requested the tapes or manuscripts. None of the cassettes had been found, the officers said. They said they did not know why. Cerbu said authorities had begun cutting power to the devices from the start of the revolution, ``because we knew that with them, the orders of commanders of troops in the revolution could be overheard.'' The armed forces sided with popular demonstrators to oust Ceausescu. The military knew some of the listening rooms existed, and technical staff at some of the centers alerted them to others, he said. The fate of the Securitate is one of the most hotly discussed issues in Romania. Only a handful of the 15,000 full-time officers of the secret police have been put on trial, and officials provided few details on the dismantling of the security force in the first two months after the revolution. In recent days, however, the Defense Ministry has said more than 3,500 senior members of the force have been dismissed, and state-run TV has shown eavesdropping centers in various cities.

DOC.HEAD: Florida School Accused of Boosting Income From Student Loans
DOC.TEXT: A private Florida school whose two owners paid themselves $12 million over four years was accused Monday of doctoring documents in order to boost income from federal guaranteed student loans. The staff of the Senate Permanent Investigations Subcommittee found evidence suggesting ``intentional abuse of the guaranteed student loan system'' by American Career Training School, said Chief Investigator David B. Buckley. Joseph A. Calareso, president of ACTS, located in Pompano Beach, Fla., was subpoenaed to testify before the subcommittee but refused to answer all but preliminary questions on grounds of possible self-incrimination. Investigators said the school was targeted only because it had a substantial number of student loans. ``I'm afraid they are just scratching the surface'' of a mountain of problems in the aid programs, said Sen. Sam Nunn, D-Ga., chairman of the subcommittee. Buckley and investigator Grace T. McPhearson said their analysis of ACTS records showed that in 1986 through 1989, 90 percent of students at the school _ including some who did not meet federal requirements _ received federal aid but that only 16 percent completed their courses. During that time, $150 million in loans were guaranteed for 60,000 ACTS students. Calareso and his brother, James, who own the school, paid themselves $12 million in salary and stock dividends, investigators said. The eight-year-old school offers training for people aspiring to careers as travel agents, motel operators and other travel-related jobs. It uses a combination home-campus system, involving 20 mailed lessons and a three-week stint on campus. In 1985, the first year it was eligible to participate in federal student-loan programs, the school's revenues increased by 800 percent, to $5.5 million, investigators testified. Revenues reached $34.5 million in 1989. Brenda Ann Brandon completed the five-week ACTS program before going to work for the school. Once the school was certified for participation in federal student-loan programs, she was put in charge of student aid. ``We, the employees of the financial-aid office, were instructed by Joseph Calareso to contact every new student, even cash students, and try and get them to finance their education through a guaranteed student loan,'' Mrs. Brandon said. ``This way, the school was guaranteed to receive the full tuition up front,'' she continued. ``If a cash student is on a payment plan, there is a lower probability that the school will receive all of the tuition, because the majority of the students enrolled never complete the course. With a loan, the school gets the money early on.'' During her time as an employee of the school _ she quit in 1988 _ Mrs. Brandon said, there was never a review of records by state, federal or outside agencies that was based on accurate information. Mrs. Brandon and subcommittee investigators said the school also submitted loan applications on behalf of students who were not qualified by education to receive federal aid. Angela M. Jones of Swansea, S.C., said that in 1987 she applied for admission to ACTS and soon received a $2,415 student loan check. She said she was told to endorse the check and return it to the school and was assured that it would never be deposited. She later received a second check to cover her on-campus training. Ms. Jones said she was never able to complete the course because the school failed to mail books and half her correspondence lessons. But the school insisted she still was liable for the full cost.

Drive-ins Cancel Kickboxer Movie After Brawls
DOC.TEXT: Gang-related shootings at two drive-in theaters prompted the theaters' operators to stop showing a movie about a gang-fighting kickboxer. Police said as many as 100 people and at least three gangs were involved in a Friday night brawl during a showing of ``Angel Town'' at the Hi-Way 39 Drive-in in Westminster, about 30 miles southeast of downtown Los Angeles. One 18-year-old was briefly hospitalized for a gunshot wound to his chest. The same night, at the South Bay 6 drive-in complex in Los Angeles, two reputed gang members were wounded as they strolled to the snack bar during ``Angel Town,'' according to Los Angeles County Sheriff's Sgt. Kenneth Brazile. Pacific Drive-in district manager Bob Gibson said he canceled the film for the rest of the weekend, and local officials said they were worried about the possibility of retaliatory attacks. ``I'd hate to see a gang war happen at a drive-in theater,'' said Westminster City Councilman Frank Fry. ``There are a lot of innocent people there and bullets do a lot of traveling.''

DOC.HEAD: Army Scientist Invents Cheap Way To Produce Spider Silk
DOC.TEXT: Until recently, the Army has kept quiet about a scientist's success in engineering the gene for spider silk into a bacteria that produces a fiber stronger than a silkworm's silk _ indeed, far stronger than steel. Now the secret is out. The military hopes to use the new fabric for bulletproof vests, helmets, parachute cords and other strong, light equipment. And the folks on New York's Seventh Avenue may want to take notice _ silk stockings may come back, too. The silk industry has long relied on the costly and time-consuming farming of silkworms, a cultural and commercial tradition in China and Japan, where the creatures have been domesticated for centuries. But the mass production of spider silk may someday mean a decline in the cost of commercial silk, according to Stephen Lombardi, the 28-year-old civilian molecular biologist credited with the invention. ``Right now they're still using the old way of doing it, with a lot of man hours spent babysitting silkworms,'' Lombardi said. ``This process is very simple and cheap. Our intent was to mass produce large quantities of silk cheaply and there's no reason why the general public shouldn't have access to the technology.'' That technology refers to Lombardi's success in isolating the gene that produces silk in the Golden Orb weaver spider and engineering the gene into bacteria. The bacteria in turn produces a spider silk protein. Until now, spiders have never been an efficient source of silk production. Unlike silkworms, they have not been domesticated and rarely can be kept alive long enough to produce quantities of silk. But with Lombardi's process, no spiders are needed. Jack Shamash, president of the New York-based Shamash and Sons, the country's largest silk importers, says the idea that spider silk could replace silkworms is ``a lot of nonsense.'' The United States has virtually no silk production and therefore lacks the needed network of factories and weavers to transform available spider silk into fabrics, he said. ``You'll have to build a whole billion-dollar industry,'' said Shamash. ``I very much doubt it could displace silk on the open market.'' Lombardi countered that his method of producing spider silk involves sophisticated biotechnology, but wouldn't require new factories or weavers. Existing fiber-spinning technology could be used on the spider silk, he said. Lombardi, who works at the Army's sprawling research laboratory in Natick, south of Boston, devised his method of replicating spider silk last spring. He presented a brief report last week at the American Association for the Advancement of Science convention in New Orleans and will detail his discovery at an American Chemical Society meeting here in April. Lombardi said scientists have studied spider silk for years in an effort to produce it in greater quantities. Natives of New Guinea and Madagascar have used spider silk to make fishing drop lines for centuries. The covering of a hot air balloon on display at the World's Fair was made of spider silk. Spider silk has five to 10 times the tensile strength of steel and can be stretched about 18 percent without breaking. Because of its toughness, spider silk is likely to replace Kevlar as the military's choice for bulletproof vests, Lombardi said. Spider silk is also envisioned for parachute cording, light tents, uniforms and even some fiber optic material. And while silk bulletproof vests may not sound very macho to the average American soldier, Lombardi said they will be more lightweight and even more effective. ``Remember there are species of spider in Madagascar that have ensnared small birds,'' he said. ``It's a tough fabric.''

DOC.HEAD: Indiana House's Power-Sharing Agreement is Unraveling
DOC.TEXT: A power-sharing agreement forced upon the evenly divided Republicans and Democrats in the Indiana House is breaking down into bickering and rules fights and may be heading for a messy divorce. ``It isn't working because apparently there is a basic lack of trust,'' said state Rep. Stephen C. Moberly, a Republican who for years had warned his colleagues about the potential problems in a House without a clear majority. ``The Republicans don't trust the Democratic speaker, and the Democrats don't trust the Republican speaker because both can manipulate the rules to help their party and their agenda,'' said Moberly. Under the power-sharing agreement approved in November 1988, after an election produced the half-and-half split, the 100-seat House has Republican and Democratic speakers who preside on alternate days and each House committee has a chairman from each party. That agreement takes a two-thirds vote to change, and remains in effect despite the defection Monday of Rep. Frank Newkirk from the Democratic to Republican Party, which gave the GOP an edge in voting. Legislative leaders boasted at the end of the 1989 session that the arrangement worked far better than many had predicted. But this year, the same leaders concede the setup is showing signs of strain. ``Over the last couple of days, it's degenerated,'' Republican House Speaker Paul S. Mannweiler said last week. ``I think it's just sort of unraveled.'' Democratic Speaker Michael K. Phillips isn't as pessimistic but concedes the system has its problems. ``The arrangement's working smoothly. We just disagree on the process,'' said Phillips. ``Still, nobody's jumped over the front desk to try to take over the speaker's chair.'' Both ``speakers du jour'' agree there have been problems in recent days although neither is willing to share the blame. Mannweiler believes the problems began when the 13 Democrats on the 26-member House Ways and Means Committee refused to attend a week's worth of committee hearings recently because the Democrats didn't want to consider Republican-sponsored bills. That doomed most of the bills, except one that Republicans forced out of committee by using a rarely successful blast motion to remove a welfare caseworker bill from the committee's jurisdiction and send the measure directly to the floor. Mannweiler also faults Phillips for failing one day last week to hand down 21 committee reports on Republican bills. That delayed consideration of the bills so they couldn't be amended by the full House on a day when Mannweiler was presiding. At the same time, Democrats maintain a list of alleged misdeeds by Republicans. Last week, after Democrats blocked a Republican bill to cut the auto excise tax, the GOP retaliated with a rare maneuver in which they called back for consideration a Democratic bill that had already been amended on the House floor and removed their opponents' excise tax proposal from the measure. Phillips protested, charging Mannweiler with ``an unprecedented and clearly erroneous interpretation of the rules and precedents'' of the House. Democrats also accused Republicans of ``vultureous conduct,'' claiming the GOP was taking advantage of a temporary 50-49 numerical edge resulting from the death last week of Rep. G. Edward Cook, whose successor will be chosen March 4. That margin grew to 51-48 with Newkirk's defection. ``The Republicans continue to think they can rewrite the rules to satisfy their needs,'' said Phillips. ``I also think they would not even be attempting this if Ed Cook were alive and in his seat.'' Democrats also criticized Republicans' request last week for an attorney general's opinion to determine if 50 votes, instead of the normal constitutional majority of 51, would be enough to pass a bill while the House temporarily has 99 members. The maneuvering and rare uses of House rules have created an uneasy atmosphere. House members can regularly be seen flipping through the chamber's 88-page rule book to determine if one side is taking advantage of the other. That is likely to continue during the final six working days of the session, which must be completed by March 15. Phillips threatened retaliation last week. ``You live by the rules, you die by the rules,'' he warned Republicans.

DOC.HEAD: Havel, Gorbachev Sign Declaration on New Type of Bilateral Relations
With AM-Czechoslovakia, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Czechoslovak President Vaclav Havel said he and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev established a new basis for relations Monday and said all Soviet troops would be withdrawn from Czechoslovakia by July 1, 1991. Havel, the playwright and opposition leader who scripted his country's peaceful return to democracy late last year, met with Gorbachev after arriving on his first official visit to the Soviet Union since he was elected Dec. 29 as his country's first non-Communist president in 41 years. The visit coincided with the start of the withdrawal of 73,500 Soviet troops still in Czechoslovakia 22 years after Moscow sent its military forces to crush the ``Prague Spring'' reforms. Havel flew to Moscow for talks with Gorbachev just three days after returning from the United States where he met with President Bush. At a news conference following the Kremlin meeting, Havel called the joint declaration he had signed earlier with Gorbachev a ``very important'' document that would pave the way for a new kind of cooperation. The declaration calls for relations to be developed ``on the basis of equality and complete mutual respect for each other's state sovereignty,'' Tass reported. Gorbachev and Havel looked on Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze and Foreign Minister Jiri Dienstbier of Czechoslovakia signed the agreement concluded in Prague on Feb. 22 outlining the troop withdrawal. Havel said he hoped all of the troops would return to the Soviet Union within one year, but that the agreement stipulated they must be gone by July 1, 1991. Soviet troops spearheaded the 1968 Warsaw Pact invasion that crushed the reforms. Moscow has 73,500 soldiers, 1,220 tanks, 2,505 armored vehicles, 77 combat aircraft and 146 helicopters stationed on Czechoslovak soil. Havel said Czechoslovakia had offered to help the Soviet Union with the withdrawal by providing free rail and water transport of men and equipment and assistance in constructing housing for the soldiers in the Soviet Union where there is a chronic shortage of apartments. Economic issues were also raised at plenary talks between officials of the two countries, and Havel said that Czechoslovakia should not renew cooperation agreements that had been concluded by the previous Communist government. However, economic matters were not the focus of the trip. In addition to Havel and Dienstbier, the Czechoslovak delegation includes Defense Minister Miroslav Vacek and Interior Minister Richard Sacher who is interested in reducing the links between officials of his ministry and those of the Soviet KGB operative on Czechoslovak soil. Havel, who spent five years in prison for his political activities against the totalitarian state _ an experience that is the source and strength of many of his writings _ appeared to be adjusting well to the role of a world statesmen. He seemed at ease at the news conference and said that during his talks with Bush and Gorbachev that both leaders had recognized the special role that Czechoslovakia had to play in the center of Europe. The Czechoslovak model of a peaceful recovery of democracy has also won admirers among opposition movements from the Soviet republic of Moldavia to the three Baltic republics, which are pressing for independence from Moscow. During his meeting with Gorbachev, Havel touched on the rapidly changing political situation in Europe. Last week in Washington, he had called on the United States to support moves toward democratic reform in the Soviet Union as a contribution to stability in Europe. However, he said that he had no specific message from Bush for Gorbachev. The two leaders also discussed the rapid rapprochement of the two Germanys. Havel said he told Gorbachev the reunification of Germany should be ``conducted in a way that would not complicate the whole European unification process, but would rather service as a motor for that process.'' On Tuesday, the former dissident is scheduled to meet with Yelena Bonner, widow of Andrei Sakharov, the Nobel Peace prize winner, who was a source of inspiration for a generation of opposition activists in Eastern Europe.

DOC.HEAD: Jackson Rules Out Running For Mayor But Not Another Presidential Bid
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS new 3rd graf to update with White comment.
DOC.TEXT: Jesse L. Jackson announced Monday he will not run for mayor of the ``dispirited'' nation's capital but he refused to rule out a third bid for the Democratic presidential nomination in 1992. ``I want to continue to serve, but not as mayor,'' Jackson said. ``At present I believe that I may best serve by continuing work at a national level to change the direction of this country.'' ``You have to almost predict a rerun of '88,'' said John White, a former national party chairman who advised Jackson in the late stages of his 1988 presidential bid.
