Jackson's political plans have been the subject of much conjecture since he moved to the District of Columbia last April. Speculation about a Jackson mayoral candidacy increased after Mayor Marion Barry's arrest last month on a cocaine possession charge and subsequent enrollment in a substance abuse treatment program. Jackson said he would continue to support the district's efforts to become a state, but he also said his Rainbow Coalition would press for action on issues at the national level, including changes in federal tax law, increased voter registration and expanding the federal government's housing programs. Jackson did not rule out another bid for the White House in 1992. ``It's premature,'' said the civil rights leader. ``We won't rule it in, but it's not the season for it.'' A top Jackson aide, who spoke only on condition of anonymity, suggested Jackson's current plans could provide a springboard for another presidential effort. ``It's too early to tell, too early to tell,'' the aide said. ``But if we pull statehood, these other things together, it gives us a lot of ways to jump, and another national campaign is certainly one.'' Jackson said his decision not to run was made difficult by ``the respect we have ... for the many people who have encouraged us to run.'' ``The district is divided and dispirited,'' Jackson said. ``I want to be a part of the healing process. My desire is to serve and uplift.'' One local supporter said the two-time Democratic presidential hopeful became convinced that a Jackson mayoral campaign might not have widespread voter support. ``Jesse wasn't convinced that there was a unanimity of support for him, a groundswell,'' the supporter said. ``He became aware that more and more people were thinking of him as something of an interloper.'' A Washington Post poll released last week found Barry was preferred by 25 percent of those surveyed, while 19 percent said they would vote for Jackson. If Barry were not in the race, Jackson would receive support from 26 percent of those questioned, compared with 19 percent for city Councilman John Ray. The poll, based on interviews with 800 registered voters, had a margin of error of 4 percentage points. Ray, a leading contender for the job, said Jackson's announcement ``takes a major player out of the race.'' Barry's re-election plans remain on hold as the mayor battles an eight-count indictment on cocaine possession and perjury charges filed against him earlier this month. Walter Fauntroy, the district's Democratic non-voting delegate to Congress, has said he will announce Saturday whether to enter the mayoral race.

DOC.HEAD: Postal Service Offers $50,000 Reward in Church Mail Bombing
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. Postal Service on Monday announced a reward of up to $50,000 for information leading to a conviction in a mail bombing that injured a pastor's daughter at his church. Postal inspectors, agents with the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms and Houston police are still investigating the bomb that exploded Jan. 30 when Lisa Osteen opened her father's mail at the Lakewood Church. ``This is a top priority investigation for all three agencies,'' said postal inspector Allison T. Brown. The bomb is believed to have been mailed from North Carolina on or about Jan. 26, said Judith Groome, another postal inspector in Houston. Miss Osteen, 31, was hospitalized for 11 days for treatment of bruises and flash burns from the bomb that exploded in her lap. She is director of ministries at the 10,000-member non-denominational church where her father, John Osteen, is pastor. The explosion was not believed connected to mail bombs that killed a judge in Alabama and a city councilman in Savannah, Ga.

DOC.HEAD: Ex-Reagan Aides Exult, Credit Nicaraguans as Much as U.S. Policy
DOC.TEXT: Former U.S. officials who helped mount military and economic opposition to the Nicaraguan government celebrated the defeat of Daniel Ortega on Monday but credited the courage of the Nicaraguan people as much as any U.S. efforts. The election triumph by Violeta Chamorro ``vindicates the struggle of many brave men and women,'' said Oliver North, who had been a key figure in the Reagan administration's effort to drive Nicaragua's leftist government from power. However, former Assistant Secretary of State Elliott Abrams said that in a way ``we were totally responsible because we never gave up the struggle.'' North, the former National Security Council aide, said of the Nicaraguans, ``Without the bravery of those people, the victory of democracy today would not have occurred. ... This was an answer to the prayers of many people.'' North, who was convicted of three felonies for his role in the Iran-Contra affair, was a crucial figure in the Reagan policy of providing military support for the Contra rebels. He was found guilty last year of shredding Contra-related documents and of concealing his role in aiding the rebels at a time when U.S. involvement was barred. Veterans of the Reagan campaign to support the Contras were giddy on Monday as they compared notes in phone calls to each other about what to many once seemed like a lost cause. Former Assistant Secretary of State Elliott Abrams joined two one-time aides, Otto Reich and Jonathan Miller, for a champagne lunch at an upscale restaurant to celebrate the news from Managua. More than most of his colleagues, Abrams credited American policy with the outcome. Asked how crucial the U.S. role was, Abrams said, ``In a sense we were totally responsible because we never gave up the struggle. A lot of people wanted to give up but we never gave it up. As soon as the Nicaraguan people had a chance, they got rid of their oppressors.'' Abrams' predecessor at the State Department, Tony Motley, said pressure from the Contras as well as the U.S. trade embargo contributed to the election result. But through unwise policies, he said, the Sandinistas ``showed themselves to be fully capable of screwing up the situation they inherited.'' Miller, who served with North at the National Security Council, said, ``I'm just giddy.'' More decisive than anything the United States might have done, he said, was ``the bravery and sophistication of the Nicaraguan people.'' Said Reich, a former ambassador to Venezuela, ``We put some of our treasure and political prestige on the line, but they (the Nicaraguans) put their lives on the line. This is a great day for democracy.'' Taking a different tack from the former Reagan officials, Sen. Tom Harkin, D-Iowa, said the election results vindicated the peace plan drawn up in 1987 by Costa Rican President Oscar Arias. A key element of that plan called for an end to U.S. military aid to the Contras. Sunday's outcome, he said, offers ``dramatic proof of the success of the Arias peace plan and the failure of the Contra war.'' Six months after the peace plan was adopted, Congress agreed to cut off military aid to the Contras, ignoring Reagan administration objections. Constantine Menges, a former Latin America hand at the National Security Council, said the ``courage and good sense of the Nicaraguan people produced this result.'' But he said the Sandinistas should not be counted out yet. He predicted government hardliners in Managua will try to maintain dominance through use of the secret police, the military and the party bureaucracy.

DOC.HEAD: Riot Police Use Tear Gas, Grenades To Block Students
DOC.TEXT: Riot police used tear gas and stun grenades Monday to stop student protesters from reaching the presidential office, where the government discussed an economic crisis that is provoking increased dissent. President Felix Houphouet-Boigny chaired the meeting with workers and employers, who reportedly reacted negatively to his proposals for more austerity measures. A delegate at the meeting said Houphouet-Boigny told them he was postponing a National Council meeting to consider their response. The council of 2,000 delegates from organizations and interest groups including trade unions, businesses and legislators, originally was to meet Monday. The delegate, who requested anonymity, said the meeting was particularly disturbed by a proposal to increase a ``solidarity tax'' on income from 1 percent to 10 percent. A foreign journalist watched a carload of policemen strew tear gas grenades along the route to the presidential palace before Houphouet-Boigny drove up. While they met, about 200 students ran through downtown Abidjan, demanding the release of detained colleagues and freedom of expression. They also demanded a meeting with the president. Riot police fired tear gas and hurled a stun grenade in a noisy explosion heard throughout the city center, scattering the frightened protesters. At the National University of Ivory Coast campus, in Cocody suburb, students said police fired tear gas to disperse about 150 students who were ``shouting slogans and demanding their right to dissent.'' In the residential suburb of Adjame, police beat up students and children who set up a blockade outside the marketplace, witnesses said. Witnesses said police also fired tear gas and hurled stun grenades at students in Yopougon, a working class suburb where the urest began Feb. 19, when they refused to board three buses going from their dormitories to the main university campus three miles away. Students said they were observing a boycott, defying an appeal by the president Sunday night for the unrest to end and classes to resume. Houphouet-Boigny made the call after he ordered the release of 137 students who were beaten and detained Saturday after they ended a 10-hour occupation of St. Paul's Roman Catholic cathedral in the capital's center. Students say many more students remain in detention. The government says all protesters have been freed. The students said they are protesting social injustices best illustrated by the system of grants. ``Some (Cabinet) ministers sons and other high-ranking government officials' children who drive to the university in BMWs are given grants. We, whose parents are poor farmers whose incomes have been halved, do not get grants,'' a militant student leader charged. In October, Houphouet-Boigny was forced to halve prices for cocoa and coffee promised to Ivorian farmers after years of subsidizing them. In another telling sign of the cumulative effects of a 10-year-old recession, the government slashed salaries of employees of state-run companies by 30 percent this month. Other government employees have suffered an eight-year wage freeze. Students are demanding that the salaries of Cabinet ministers also be cut by 30 percent. Sources close to the government said Monday that the president is considering their demand. Houphouet-Boigny has not been receptive to demands that he introduce a multiparty state in this West African nation that he has ruled since it became independent from France in 1960. While other authoritarian governments close to the Ivory Coast have bowed to popular pressure and are introducing democratic reforms _ such as the military government of Guinea _ Houphouet-Boigny has insisted that a multiparty system encourages tribal divisions and endangers national unity.

DOC.HEAD: Cotton Inventories Down, Prices Up
DOC.TEXT: Brisk exports and heavy domestic use are draining off U.S. cotton inventories and boosting prices, the Agriculture Department said Monday. Domestic mills used 7.8 million bales in 1988-89, the department's Economic Research Service said in a preliminary report. ``This season, strong denim demand and apparel sales are expected to push consumption to 8.2 million bales, the highest in nearly two decades,'' the report said. ``Mill use for the first six months of the season average about 8.4 million bales on a seasonally adjusted annual rate.'' Cotton exports are forecast at 7.7 million bales this season, up 25 percent from 6.15 million bales in 1988-89. As of mid-February, outstanding sales and shipments totaled nearly 7 million bales, compared with 4.7 million at this time last season. The U.S. cotton inventory by Aug. 1 is expected to be about 3.5 million bales, about half the 7.09 million on hand last Aug. 1. ``During the 1989-90 marketing year, both U.S. and world prices for cotton have exceeded those of the past season by substantial margins,'' the report said. ``The adjusted world price for August to mid-November averaged 67 cents per pound this season, about 23 cents ahead of the comparable-period average last season.''

DOC.HEAD: Ban on Soliciting Not Free-Speech Issue, Court Told
With AM-Scotus Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Postal Service is not violating free-speech rights by banning everyone, from the Red Cross to political extremists, from soliciting donations outside most post offices, the Supreme Court was told Monday. Justice Department lawyer John Roberts Jr., representing the Postal Service, said the area outside suburban or rural post offices is not ``a traditional public forum'' as is the city sidewalk outside an urban post office. Most of the nation's 35,000 post offices have their own sidewalks surrounded by parking lots. ``This property is dedicated to the Postal Service's use,'' Roberts contended. ``It's not just like a city sidewalk'' where free-speech rights must be considered. But Washington lawyer Jay Sekulow disagreed. ``The right to solicit ... classic political speech is not subject to architectural design,'' he said. ``A moat cannot be created by this intervening parking lot.'' At issue in a case from Bowie, Md., is a federal regulation banning ``soliciting, electioneering, collecting debts, vending and advertising'' on Postal Service property. A federal appeals court ruled in the Bowie case that the regulation is unconstitutional, but other courts have upheld it in other cases. Sekulow's clients, Marsha Kokinda and Kevin Pearl, were arrested Aug. 6, 1986, after they refused to stop soliciting contributions and distributing literature from a table on the sidewalk just outside the Bowie post office. The two are volunteers for the National Democratic Policy Committee, the political arm of an organization headed by political extremist Lyndon LaRouche. They were convicted of violating the federal regulation although there was no evidence they had blocked or interfered with people entering and leaving the post office. About 30 patrons had complained about the couple's presence. ``Would there have been any complaints if it were the Red Cross?'' Justice Anthony M. Kennedy asked the Justice Department lawyer. ``Probably not,'' Roberts answered, although adding that the blanket ban on soliciting prevents postal officials from favoring some groups over others. Roberts said the regulation is not being enforced against people who hand out leaflets, seek petition signatures or picket but only against those who solicit immediate contributions. ``It's when you let them ask for money that the crowds come out,'' he said. But Roberts said the Postal Service would not violate free-speech rights if it chose to banish from its property all activities not linked directly to postal business. Sekulow argued that the Postal Service never has elected to make its property ``an enclave immune from the First Amendment.'' When Justice Sandra Day O'Connor asked if the Postal Service must allow panhandling on its sidewalks, Sekulow said beggars have the same free-speech rights as anyone else, subject to the same time, place and manner regulations. O'Connor also asked Roberts why such time, place and manner regulations _ and not a total ban _ would not be an effective way to prevent congestion or inconvenience. Several other justices also voiced concern over the sweep of a blanket ban. ``Why isn't it (the regulation) overbroad?'' Justice Byron R. White asked. And Justice John Paul Stevens asked, ``Is there a history of a problem outside'' the buildings. ``One might argue it (the regulation) is overbroad.'' The case is U.S. vs. Kokinda, 88-2031.

DOC.HEAD: U.N. Report on Human Rights in Iran Inconclusive
DOC.TEXT: The United Nations on Monday released a largely inconclusive report on the human rights situation in Iran, based on the first visit by a special U.N. investigator since it came under international scrutiny in 1984. The 76-page report, compiled by Salvadoran jurist Reynaldo Galindo Pohl under a mandate from the U.N. Human Rights Commission, cites evidence of torture and other gross violations, along with denials. But he concedes that in many cases it was not possible to conduct an in-depth examination during the week-long stay last month and suggests a renewal of his mandate and another visit. The report lists the names of about 700 people allegedly executed in Iran, most of them in the past two years, along with 39 people alleged to have been executed by the Iraq-based Mujahedeen resistance. Iranian media reports have said that more than 1,300 were executed in Iran in slightly less than one year and Western human rights groups have carried much higher estimates. Galindo Pohl said that barring specific proof he rules out allegations that political prisoners had been executed under false charges of drug trafficking. He said there had been no public executions for five months, although ``probably hundreds are still awaiting execution.'' He added that he requested clemency for them and that he ``gained the impression that this harsh policy (of executions) could become a good deal less severe.'' Quoting testimony from several unidentified Iranians, the report refers to one witness who said five of his seven children were executed as suspected Mujahedeen members in an alleged wave of executions of 20,000 prisoners since the end of the Iran-Iraq war. Two sons were still in prison, one of them sick and the other paralyzed as the result of torture, according to the witness. But the report also notes that several people told the investigator that they had been wrongly listed by the Mujahedeen as victims of executions. It also included a list of various alleged acts of terrorism by the Mujahedeen. It said some witnesses said they had been induced to show self-inflicted marks of torture to enhance the ``false propaganda'' spread by the resistance. The Mujahedeen, in a statement sent to news agencies, denounced the report as the result of an ``ominous pact between the U.N. Center for Human Rights and the most abominable regime of our times.'' Galindo Pohl, the statement said, ``takes the side of the executioner rather than the victim.'' Describing a visit to Tehran's notorious Evin prison, Galindo Pohl said he was welcomed by a choir and a small band made up of prisoners. In the presence of Evin officials, he talked to the former secretary general of the outlawed Tudeh party who told of being tortured and showed his partially paralyzed hands and crushed fingers. Prisoners in the women's section told Galindo Pohl they had not been tortured or subjected to ill treatment. In addition to the former Tudeh leader, the report lists six other witnesses as describing having undergone torture. One said that about 90 percent of all Evin prison inmates had been ``either severely tortured or submitted to treatment akin to torture.'' But the report also listed four other witnesses, in addition to the Evin women prisoners, who said they had never seen or heard of torture cases except occasional slapping.

DOC.HEAD: More Than 20,000 Call For Democracy in Second Straight Rally
DOC.TEXT: More than 20,000 people chanting ``Democracy!'' and ``Liberty!'' massed in the capital Monday in a rally against the ruling Communist Party. The peaceful demonstration was the second in two straight days. At least 150,000 people gathered Sunday in Sofia chanting ``Down with the Communist Party!'' in the largest rally since the toppling of hard-line leader Todor Zhivkov in November. During Monday's protest, the crowd, which carried lighted candles and jangled their keys, gathered again in the square in front of the Communist Party headquarters in response to an appeal of the Union of Democratic Forces grouping major opposition movements. Both rallies were staged despite decisions of the party's Supreme Council on Friday to ban Communist cells at the workplace, postpone general elections from May to June _ the opposition had sought a delay until November to give it time to prepare _ and call foreign observers to monitor the voting. While professing a commitment to democracy, the Communist Party is in sole control of government and appears less willing to compromise with opposition forces than sister parties in Soviet bloc countries further on the path to pluralism. Participants at the Monday rally said the opposition planned to continue to organize such demonstrations as a way to pressure the Communist Party into accepting its demands for full democracy at talks between the two sides that opened in early January. Also Monday, a congress of the Bulgarian Communist youth union decided to split into three groups with the majority of the delegates voting for the setting up of a new independent youth organization called Bulgarian Democratic Youth. A second splinter group announced plans to form another independent organization called the ``Youth Confederation,'' while a third smaller group said it wanted to form a ``Youth Forum for Socialism,'' which would maintain its links with the ruling Communist Party.

DOC.HEAD: Fugitive Surrenders After Seeing Himself on `America's Most Wanted'
DOC.TEXT: A homicide suspect surrendered Monday, hours after seeing himself profiled on the network television show ``America's Most Wanted,'' authorities said. James Edward Noel showed up unannounced at the police department's Central Station. ```I believe you might be looking for me. I want to give myself up,''' Officer Bill Frio, a police spokesman, said Noel told officers at the front desk. Noel, a 45-year-old day laborer who was profiled on the Fox Network's Sunday night show, was taken into custody on a no-bail murder warrant. He was wanted in connection with the Oct. 2 slaying of 18-year-old Wendy Tarr, an apartment leasing agent who was shot in the head during a robbery attempt as she showed an apartment. Frio said Noel was on parole for a series of robberies and rapes in Fresno, Los Angeles and San Diego in which apartment managers were targeted. Fox officials said that of the 228 fugitives the show has profiled, 148 are in custody, 97 as a direct result of the TV show. Viewers tipped authorities to the whereabouts of most of those arrested, but nine people have surrendered, said Phil Gonzales, the show's publicist.

DOC.HEAD: Congress Discusses Aid to Nicaragua After Chamorro Win
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts 2 new grafs after 6th graf pvs, ``It's not, with Solarz comment, foreign aid background
DOC.HEAD: With AM-US-Nicaragua, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Violeta Chamorro's presidential victory in Nicaragua brought elation on Capitol Hill on Monday but also heightened Congress' problem of finding foreign aid money for new democracies. ``We must provide her new government with aid, and let's not kid ourselves _ it will take big bucks,'' said Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole, R-Kan. ``She needs our help and she deserves it.'' ``Nobody said democracy was cheap,'' added Foreign Affairs Committee Chairman Dante Fascell, D-Fla. House Speaker Thomas Foley, D-Wash., while not mentioning a specific aid figures, said the United States might start by sending amounts similar to past aid to the anti-Sandinista Contra rebels. Estimates ranged from $100 million to $300 million as the U.S. share of a multilateral package that could provide $1 billion for Nicaragua. But others cautioned that with a growing line of potential new foreign aid recipients _ Poland, Hungary, Czechoslovakia, Panama and others _ it would be difficult to promise new money when the budget already is falling short. ``It's not realistic to expect the result of all this is going to be a tripling of foreign aid,'' said Rep. Mickey Edwards, R-Okla., the senior GOP member of the foreign aid subcommittee. ``The American people aren't going to support it.'' This year, the United States will send about $9.8 billion in military, economic and development aid to several dozen friendly countries around the globe. The lion's share, $5.1 billion, goes to Israel and Egypt as a reward for entering into the Camp David peace process. The Bush administration has asked for a slight increase in the total, to $10.1 billion, for 1991. Rep. Stephen Solarz, D-N.Y., said he hoped the United States could come up with $200 million to $300 million as a contribution to a billion-dollar international emergency aid program for Nicaragua, similar to those aiding the Philippines and emerging democracies in Eastern Europe. The money should be taken out of the U.S. defense budget, he said. Dole used the occasion of Chamorro's win over leftist Sandinista President Daniel Ortega on Sunday to renew his proposal to alter the nation's foreign aid priorities, beginning with the two largest recipients, Israel and Egypt. ``The only way we're going to pay for new aid to Nicaragua, Panama, Czechoslovakia _ is to look to the foreign aid budget that now exists, and make some tough calls,'' Dole said in a Senate floor speech. But that proposal has so far met with stiff opposition, and Foley cautioned that Nicaragua should not automatically be given priority over current recipients of U.S. aid. Lawmakers overwhelmingly supported President Bush's call for a speedy lifting of trade sanctions, and many called for the immediate sending of a U.S. ambassador to Managua. The sanctions were imposed in 1985, and the American ambassador was sent home in 1988. Many of the legislators observed that Chamorro's win had accelerated an already breathtaking downfall of communism around the world. Asked his reaction, Edwards said, ``It was astonishment... It's happening from one end of the world to the other, the tyrants are being swept out.'' ``It is yet another example of the desire for democratic government that is being courageously expressed by people throughout the world living under totalitarian regimes,'' said Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine. Several members of Congress also noted that the demise of the Sandinista government could have an added benefit in nearby El Salvador, where leftist FMLN guerrillas fighting the elected government have relied on Managua for weapons and support. At the same time, the lawmakers warned that Chamorro faces a difficult road in rebuilding her nation's economy, moving her country out of war and maintaining her political coalition. ``Much remains to be done before democracy can be said to have been established in Nicaragua,'' said House Minority Leader Robert Michel, R-Ill., ``but this victory is a splendid beginning.'' From the other side of the political spectrum, Rep. Sam Gejdenson, D-Conn., called the outcome ``an amazing step forward for the Western Hemisphere'' and long overdue. Gejdenson, a member of the House Foreign Affairs Committee, attributed Chamorro's victory to her call for an end to the military draft; the country's economy, devastated by a decade of civil war and U.S. economic sanctions, and a popular belief that she could best demobilize the anti-Sandinista Contra rebels.

DOC.HEAD: New York Mayor Declares Death Of Conservatism
DOC.TEXT: New York Mayor David N. Dinkins pronounced conservatism dead Monday, saying that as communist governments fail worldwide, the Far Right has no reason to exist. ``The crest of the conservative flood has passed,'' Dinkins, a Democrat, said in a speech to the National Press Club. ``The Republicans still occupy the White House, but the conservative coalition has lost its way.'' Dinkins acknowledged that reporters may not believe him and ``may not be ready to report what I've said as fact, but hopefully soon you will recognize that what I say is true.'' In a sometimes poetic speech that compared conservatives to holograms, ``images of bent light that vanish as we walk by,'' and their cause to a spent volcano, Dinkins argued that revolutions in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union herald the death of communism. That, in turn, mean the end of U.S. conservatives, he said. ``Without communism, they have no enemy, and without an enemy, they have no energy,'' he said. Dinkins pointed to his own, 2-month-old administration as evidence that government can be ``sensitive to the needs and aspirations of all our people.'' He also predicted that the political right will not be able to win office by running as anti-abortionists, citing as proof his election and alluding to the elections of New Jersey Gov. James Florio and Virginia Gov. Douglas Wilder. ``Who would have thought a year ago that even the chairman of the Republican National Committee would claim to be agnostic on abortion?'' he asked. ``The effort to make God a partisan political being has failed. She will judge our performance later.'' Dinkins was non-committal about the Rev. Jesse Jackson's announcement Monday that he will not run for District of Columbia mayor.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Stocks Shrugging Off Tokyo's February Slide
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Stands for story slugged AM-Japan Market on News Advisory; version moved on financial wires; Thom cq in next-to-last graf
DOC.TEXT: The drop that has rocked the Tokyo Stock Exchange during the past few days has so far caused little more than a ripple on Wall Street. Analysts see plenty of cause for caution about the U.S. financial outlook as a result of the Japanese market's slide, which intensified Monday with its second-largest point decline ever. But the worries of many U.S. observers have been tempered by a belief that the selling might prove to be primarily a ``correction'' of speculative enthusiasm that has been unique to Tokyo trading for years. With a 4.5 percent decline Monday, the Nikkei average of 225 Japanese stocks extended its fall since the start of 1990 to more than 14 percent. In New York, by contrast, the Dow Jones average of 30 industrials rose 38.29 points to 2,602.48 on Monday, narrowing its loss for the year to date to 5.5 percent. The comparatively better performance by American stocks during that period is something of a rarity. Two decades ago, the leading indexes of American and Japanese stocks stood at about the same absolute level. By the end of 1989, riding the crest of their country's long industrial and commercial boom, Japanese prices were about 12 times higher than their U.S. counterparts. Along the way, shares in Tokyo reached levels considered outlandish by traditional Wall Street standards, such as the ratio of stock prices to the earnings per share of the companies involved. Recently, price-earnings ratios in Japan have been as high as 60 to one, compared with about 12 to one in the United States. Despite numerous arguments that the figures aren't directly comparable, and that Japanese business has earned the extra recognition, many U.S. analysts have remained unconvinced. ``American investors have thought for at least five years that the Tokyo market was grossly overvalued,'' said Robert Stovall, president of the New York money management firm Stovall-Twenty-First Advisors. The drop in Tokyo has been accompanied by a fierce debate over the computer-driven strategies known as program trading, with expectations increasing that Japanese officials will soon move to curtail this type of activity. That's all too familiar to participants in the American markets, where similar trading _ which critics say makes stock prices more volatile _ has stirred similar controversy for several years. ``I think it's exactly the same thing,'' said Suresh Bhirud, an analyst at Oppenheimer & Co. in New York. Many American analysts acknowledge that U.S. views of the Japanese market are influenced by a streak of international competitiveness, if not jealousy. They also point out that as Japanese stocks have slumped, the dollar has risen in value against the yen in world currency markets. ``It's good for the dollar and it's good for the American psyche,'' Stovall said. ``The Japanese are proving to be human.'' Whatever emotional satisfaction it may offer in American financial circles, however, there is also widespread concern that the Tokyo decline may have a widening negative impact if it continues much longer. For starters, a pinch on Japanese investors could induce them to pull money out of markets around the world _ such as the U.S. Treasury bond market _ where they have been playing an active role. In addition, analysts say, the drop in the Tokyo market has been prompted by rising interest rates in many of the world's financial capitals that may be increasing the odds of a worldwide recession. Thom Brown, an analyst at Rutherford, Browth & Catherwood Inc. in Philadelphia, says it would be reckless to ignore trouble warnings about the Japanese market simply because they have proved incorrect so far. ``To reiterate this warning does sound like crying wolf,'' he said. ``But remember the fable _ the wolf finally arrived.''

DOC.HEAD: Vial Containing Krypton Gas Broken
DOC.TEXT: A vial containing krypton 79 gas that was to be injected into a nuclear reactor accidentally broke but no employees were contaminated, officials reported Monday. Nine people were in the confinement dome of the Creys-Malville reactor Sunday when the vial of radioactive gas broke. The Central Ionizing Radiation Protection Service, a government agency, said there were no injuries. ``Neither portable equipment nor later checks in the on-site infirmary showed the slightest contamination and these people resumed their work normally Monday morning,'' the agency's statement said. The room where the accident occurred was evacuated Sunday morning. It was aired out and reopened at 9 p.m. ``The ejection of the radioactive gas by the chimney after the handling accident represented a total of less than one-100,000th of the annual activity authorized,'' the agency said, adding the incident was ``without consequence to public health or the environment.'' The reactor has been shut down since October 1989 for maintenance. It is scheduled to be restarted March.

DOC.HEAD: FDA Claims It's Doing More to Protect Against Faulty Mecical Devices
DOC.TEXT: The head of the Food and Drug Administration said Monday the agency has taken steps to minimize the chances that faulty medical devices ever reach consumers. ``We believe that the agency's procedures have matured significantly over the last decade,'' since the FDA approved a mechanical heart valve made by Shiley Inc. that later was removed from the market after reports of fatal malfunctions, said Acting FDA Commissioner James Benson. ``This maturation minimizes the possibility that faulty devices can reach the market,'' he told members of the House Energy and Commerce investigations subcommittee. But Rep. John Dingell, D-Mich., chairman of the panel, said: ``We have no assurance that the conditions at the FDA which permitted this valve to enter the market and stay for far too long have been corrected.'' He charged that the FDA moved too slowly against the heart valve and exposed hundreds of patients to unnecessary risk. Among the steps the FDA said it has taken are stronger criteria for approving implantable devices, better scientific analysis in the approval process and an improved early-warning system for detecting problems with devices already on the market, he said. A report by the subcommittee's majority staff raised quesions about the FDA's ``willingness and ability to fulfill its regulatory mandate to protect public health'' and charged that Shiley, owned by Pfizer Inc., misled the agency and failed to keep the FDA informed of malfunction reports. Pfizer officials denied those charges. Robert Fauteux, a spokesman for the company, said, ``we met the obligations under the law.'' Republican members of the subcommittee, while concerned about the Shiley valve, said they were also concerned that report failed to recognize the inherent risks of medical devices and that the heart valve has saved the lives of tens of thousands of patients. The risks of the Shiley valve ``must be considered with a great deal of caution,'' said Rep. Thomas Bliley, R-Va. ``We must to everything possible to avoid alarming'' patients who are living with the device. Shiley's convexo-concave 60-degree heart valve, approved in April 1979, has been implanted in 85,000 people, including about 40,000 in the United States. After reports of malfunctions and product withdrawals, Shiley removed it from the market in November 1986. About 4,000 of Shiley's 70-degree valves have been implanted in patients overseas. That device was never marketed in the United States. Shiley has reported to the FDA a total of 295 fractures of the 60-degree valve, with 178 deaths resulting, and 94 fractures and 70 deaths involving the 70-degree valve, according to the subcommittee's report. The valve consists of a disc inside a metal ring covered by a teflon sewing ring that is sutured to the heart to hold the valve in place. The disc, pivoting on two thin metal struts, opens to either a 60-degree or 70-degree angle to allow blood to flow through, and then closes. The fractures have occurred in the struts. When a fracture occurs the disc escapes from the ring, allowing an uncontrollable blood flow through the heart. Benson said that when the FDA approved the mechanical valve, agency officials were aware of the strut fracture problems with the Shiley valve, but they believed it produced fewer life-threatening blood-clot complications than older-model valves on the market. After evaluating the clinical data submitted by Shiley, the agency concluded that ``this advantage outweighed, or at least balanced, the strut fracture problem,'' Benson said. But in June 1984, the FDA performed its own analysis and determined that the Shiley valve did not decrease blood-clotting complications. Responding to criticism that the FDA notified physicians rather than patients about the risk of strut fracture in the valves, Benson said the agency continues to believe the informing physicians is most appropriate, since they can judge the extent to which a warning causes anxiety in a patient. However, Frederick Barbee of Minong, Wis., whose wife died after her valve fractured, said that if he had known about the risks, he might have been able to get his wife appropriate medical care faster and save her life.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Unveils Drug Guide For Parents
DOC.TEXT: President Bush unveiled a booklet Monday with crayon drawings by kids and tips for parents on how to persuade their children to steer clear of drugs. ``Drug education must begin at home,'' the president said. The 52-page booklet, ``Growing Up Drug Free: A Parent's Guide to Prevention,'' is available free from the U.S. Department of Education by calling 1-800-624-0100 or, in the Washington area, 202-732-3627. Copies can also be obtained from the Consumer Information Center, Pueblo, Colo., 81009. ``This little book ... is going to do a lot of good,'' Bush predicted. Ten girls and boys who illustrated the pamphlet joined Bush on stage for the unveiling. He pressed Katie Bell, whose crayon drawing of a happy family made the cover, into service. ``You better come here,'' he said, drawing the girl in a red dress and blue bow to his side. Later he thrust a booklet into her hands as a prop, saying, ``Hold this for me, would you?'' If the other children felt left out, it wasn't for long. As soon as Bush finished speaking, he went through the book page by page until he had identified each piece of art _ children skipping rope and playing basketball, as well as a jester-like figure with eyes bulging out of its head _ with the artist. ``You did this? Beautiful,'' the president gushed. Apart from the cute pictures, the booklet features some hard facts for parents about drugs, a quiz and tips on how to impart values to youngsters. ``This guide book is being released because we all care about kids, about keeping their futures bright with promise and keeping them free of the enslavement of drugs,'' said Bush. ``You don't get a pep course before becoming a parent, and kids don't come with owner's manuals. They have minds and problems of their own. So the best thing parents can do is talk to them and, just as important, listen to them. Know the facts about drugs and the warning signs that a kid's in trouble,'' he said. ``Above all, we parents can make sure that our actions are as good as our words. Where illegal drugs and alcohol abuse are concerned, for too long we have condoned what we should have condemned,'' said Bush. ``That's what this book is about: knowing when and how to talk to your kids, when to listen, where to draw the line and when to get help.'' ``Schools, churches, synagogues, community groups, law enforcement _ all can help us turn the tide on drug and alcohol abuse. But none can take a parent's place. Drug education must begin at home and in the neighborhood long before the classroom.'' ``I want to urge parents everywhere to read ... `Growing Up Drug Free,''' said Bush, who was also joined at the publication ceremony by Secretary of Education Lauro F. Cavazos. Katie Bell and most of the other children were from Oakview Elementary School in Fairfax County, Va. Bush gave the first copy of the booklet to Ann Lynch, president of the National PTA. ``That one is for you, you lucky duck,'' he told her.

DOC.HEAD: First Unemployed East Germans Register for Benefits
DOC.NOTE: Eds: To UPDATE with demonstrations, INSERT 2 grafs after 8th pvs; pickup 9th pvs, `At the...'
DOC.TEXT: Several thousand East Germans applied Monday for the first benefits their government has ever given the unemployed, whose ranks may swell dramatically as the nation moves toward capitalism. Labor officials said the number of applicants was much smaller than anticipated, but noted that economic reforms expected to cost hundreds of thousands of jobs have yet to be made. At the moment, East Germany has a severe labor shortage because skilled workers continue leaving for West Germany. Industrial production has slowed and the nation is threatened with financial collapse. West Germany has offered to bail out the East Germans by making its strong Deutschmark the currency of both countries, but only on condition East Germany adopt a market economy. No final decision on monetary union and the economic reforms is planned until after East Germany's first free elections March 18, but a decisive shift toward Western economic practices is expected soon afterward. Economists say more competitive Western methods will force many East German factories to close or lay off employees, which could increase unemployment among the 9 million workers to 15 percent within months. Finance Ministry officials proposed Monday that laws be altered to create more incentive for private enterprise by reducing income tax rates that require entrepreneurs to pay up to 95 percent of profits to the government. Lower taxes also would encourage formation of small and medium-sized businesses, which could help reduce unemployment. Meanwhile, the East German news agency ADN reported only about 10,000 people took part in regular Monday demonstrations in Leipzig that started the motor of East German reform in October with more than 100,000 marchers weekly. The numbers of Monday demonstrators have dwindled in recent weeks, as campaigning for March 18 elections has gotten under way. At the weekly negotiations with opposition groups, Defense Minister Theodor Hoffmann said reducing the size of East Germany's army would only increase the number of unemployed. Neues Deutschland, the Communist Party newspaper, proposed Monday that compulsory military service be ended in both Germanys and that a reunited Germany be demilitarized. East Germany has experienced some unemployment throughout its 40-year history, but authorities would not acknowledge the problem because it contradicted Communist ideology. On Monday, Labor Agency offices began taking applications for financial aid to the unemployed under regulations adopted Feb. 9. They provide monthly payments of three-quarters of previous income, made up of 500 East German marks (about $100 at the official exchange rate) from the government and a contribution from the applicant's last employer. Labor Agency statistics indicate 7,500 East Germans are out of work, but unofficial estimates put the number at 10 times that. About 25,000 people lost their jobs when the government disbanded the secret police, under pressure from pro-democracy groups. Officials said they were not certain how many East Germans applied for jobless benefits Monday, since people must apply at local offices hroughout the country. Only a few dozen applicants were at the East Berlin office on Rosa Luxemburg Street, in contrast with the 4,000 the Labor Ministry had expected. ``We are completely surprised that so few have come,'' said Joachim Guenter, spokesman for the Labor and Wages Ministry. Brigitte Schneider, a 52-year-old teacher, said she had been denied work in her profession because she was considered a ``traitor'' for not returning from a visit to West Germany in 1988. She came back later that year, but was forced to take a job with a music publishing enterprise. She quit in January. ``I'm trying to get a little money, as I don't know how else I will get by,'' she said. Ms. Schneider said she was living off savings, and ``now I have to worry about surviving.'' Although the official unemployment rate remains below 1 percent, tens of thousands of people are in jobs that will be made obsolete by better technology and others probably will be victims of more efficient operating procures. The flight of 340,000 people to West Germany last year and more than 100,000 more since Jan. 1, 1990, has transferred the immediate unemployment problem to West Germany, where more than 2 million people are out of work. A report Monday by the West German Institute for Labor Market and Employment Research said the continuing influx of East Germans and ethnic German refugees would keep unemployment high despite an economic boom expected to bring 4 percent growth this year. East German immigrants have been accepting jobs spurned by unemployed West Germans, contributing to growing problem of long-term joblessness.

DOC.HEAD: Business Leaders Back Head Start
DOC.TEXT: Business executives told Congress on Monday that President Bush's proposed increase of $500 million in spending on Head Start is a good first step, but the administration should fully fund the pre-school program. The administration is calling for $1.9 billion for Head Start in the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1, an increase over the $1.4 billion appropriated last year. But a representative of the National Alliance of Business told a House panel that the 25-year-old program should have enough money to serve all eligible low-income children. ``To fully fund an enriched Head Start program that could serve 3-, 4- and 5-year-olds, funding by the end of the decade would be in the range of $6 billion to $7 billion,'' said William H. Kolberg, president of the independent, non-profit alliance. Frank P. Doyle, a senior vice president at General Electric and a member of the Committee for Economic Development, stressed the importance of early intervention programs that better prepare low-income children for the rigors of school. ``We should attack the causes now rather than pay for the consequences later,'' said Doyle, who called for not only increasing the number of slots in the program but improving the salaries of Head Start instructors and raising the program's overall quality. Rep. James H. Scheuer, D-N.Y., chairman of the House Joint Economic subcommittee on education and health, said Head Start was the ``pearl of the 1960s anti-poverty program,'' and Bush realizes that is the case. The president said in his budget submission for fiscal 1991, ``research shows that Head Start children experience substantial immediate gains in cognitive growth, school readiness and achievement.'' But Scheuer faulted the president, saying the ``proposed funding did not match the rhetoric.'' The Democratic congressman noted that Bush's defense budget includes more than $12 billion for the Strategic Defense Initiative, the B-2 stealth bomber and moving the multiple-warhead, MX nuclear missiles from fixed silos to railroad cars. ``National security doesn't seem to mean having an educational society,'' Scheuer said. The congressman suggested that businesses, which spend about $30 billion to $40 billion a year training employees, might join with state and local governments to fund Head Start programs. But that plan drew little support from the business executives. ``I'm courageous but not foolhardy,'' said Kolberg, who emphasized that the programs should continue under government control. Doyle said current training and health programs grab a major share of his company's spending, and he was unsure whether the funds would be available for Head Start.

DOC.HEAD: Angolan Opponent Says It's Time for Elections There Too
DOC.TEXT: A leader of the opposition to the Marxist government of Angola said Monday that Violeta Chamorro's victory over leftist Daniel Ortega in Nicaragua underscores the need for free and fair elections in his own country. ``At the present moment, when we see so much change all around us, there is no considerable reason why Angola should still be denied the right of free and fair elections,'' Jeremias Chitunda, vice president of UNITA, said in an interview. Chitunda, in Washington for meetings with Bush administration officials and members of Congress, said that the results of Sunday's election in Nicaragua ``underscores the fact there is no more reason why the Marxists in Angola should resist this process,'' he said. ``Their friends have submitted to free and fair elections in Nicaragua.'' UNITA _ the National Union for the Total Independence of Angola _ has been fighing to force the government in Luanda to share power since shortly after Angola gained its independence from Portugal in 1975. Bitter fighting has been reported around Mavinga, 700 miles southeast of Luanda, since the government launched an offensive late in December. UNITA receives a reported $50 million in U.S. aid a year, including ground-to-air missiles. Angolan government troops use Soviet weapons. Chitunda has met with Vice President Dan Quayle and State Department officials as well as members of Congress during his talks in Washington. ``The administration has been recommitted to help overcome the existing logistical problems which the Soviets and Cubans sought to exploit by launching the offensive,'' he said. ``We understand it is also being observed that the administration is stressing further on other African countries the need to resume talks on an Angolan cease fire and for a solution.''

DOC.HEAD: Baltic Legislators Condemn Draft Law on State of Emergency
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 12 grafs to include expected action on presidency bill; picks up 8th `A mechanism'
DOC.TEXT: Legislators from the Baltics and other independent-minded republics denounced a draft law Monday that would let the Kremlin take over their governments by declaring a state of emergency. Several deputies said the proposal is even more dangerous because another bill on strengthening the presidency would permit the nation's leader to declare a state of emergency on his own. President Mikhail S. Gorbachev wants the legal authority to push through his program and halt the riots and ethnic strife that threaten his reforms. Some legislators said such laws must be drawn carefully to prevent ``a repetition of totalitarianism,'' as legislator Yuri Afanasiev put it during Sunday's huge pro-democracy demonstration in Moscow. The emergency bill is among dozens proposed in the current two-month session. Legislators said they have no legal guarantee, only Gorbachev's word, that peaceful demands for reform will not be crushed. Under the proposed law, the Presidium, of which Gorbachev is chairman, could suspend republican parliaments and city councils, cancel decisions of local governments and take over an area in cases of mass disorder. Tass said legislators were expected to consider on Tuesday the bill to expand presidential powers. Interfax, a news service of Moscow radio, said a draft calling for election of a president by universal, direct and equal suffrage had been submitted to the legislature. Aides to Gorbachev had said earlier the first election would be held in the Congress of People's Deputies at a meeting scheuled to start on Tuesday. The session has been postponed indefinitely. Interfax said a candidate would need a majority of the popular vote to win and the term would be five years. The president would have broad powers, including the right to declare war. The contents of the bill reported by Interfax could not be confirmed independently. Legislators said the emergency legislation, presented by the Council of Ministers on Monday, was too broad. ``A mechanism for preventing any groundless declaration of a state of emergency and abuse of power'' must be added, said Estonian legislator Marju Lauristin, according to a Tass report on the session in the Council of the Union, one of two houses of the Supreme Soviet legislature. Vaidotas Antanaitis, a legislator from Lithuania, said such powers conflict with Kremlin promises to give more autonomy to the republics, and he demanded the draft be changed to say that their governments must agree with the imposition of a state of emergency. The Baltic states of Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia have been careful to avoid any violence that could be used as an excuse to crack down on their strong mass movements for independence. They have used their parliaments to pass constitutional amendments allowing them to suspend national laws on their territories, and Latvia and Lithuania led the union in legalizing multiple political parties. But the Balts' demand for autonomy is hampered by the fact that Azerbaijani authorities in January refused to agree to imposition of a state of emergency in their capital of Baku, even though rioters were killing dozens of Armenians and forcing thousands others to flee for their lives. Gorbachev eventually ordered troops into the city in the face of strong local resistance, and more than 200 people died in the unrest in the southern Caucasus. The draft allows authorities during a state of emergency to hold troublemakers without trial for up to 30 days, ban strikes and demonstrations, fire the directors of factories and institutions, limit the use of communications and movements of citizens, place people under house arrest, expel non-residents, and abolish unregistered organizations. Authorities could also protect key sites and order a curfew. The draft law includes a clause allowing the Presidium to give additional powers as needed to special administrative bodies of power set up during the state of emergency. The Kremlin took over the local government of Nagorno-Karabakh from the republic of Azerbaijan in January 1989 in hopes of halting months of ethnic violence in the disputed territory occupied largely by Armenians. But the Kremlin committee was unable to solve the problems, and the Supreme Soviet legislature last fall ordered the administration of the area returned to Azerbaijan. Since then, the entire republic of Azerbaijan, including Nagorno-Karabakh, exploded in ethnic and nationalist violence. It remains under a state of emergency with Soviet troops maintaining order. Legislators also discussed a proposed law that would transform the Interior Ministry troops, who have been called out to halt ethnic violence in several republics in the last year, into a volunteer force of professional troops. The Interior Ministry now receives the majority of its soldiers from the Red Army draft, and Tass said the higher salaries required would quintuple the cost of the Interior Ministry forces. Reformers say an experienced force could be better trained to halt civic strife. The draft also would allow Interior troops to shoot armed opponents who refuse to drop their weapons, and anyone using combat weapons to endanger the lives of citizens or the soldiers, Tass said. Interior troops are barred from shooting without warning, and officials have said this restriction is too dangerous as violence grows. Legislators in the other house, the Council of Nationalities, reviewed the latest version of a draft law delegating to the republics more control over the economy, including the right to set their own budgets, regulate investment and conduct foreign trade, Tass said. The draft already has been rejected twice for leaving too much power in the hands of Moscow bureaucrats. Tass quoted Valerian Advadze of Georgia as saying the republics should be deciding which powers to delegate to the national government, not the other way around.

DOC.HEAD: Britain, Spain Mired on Gibraltar Sovereignty
DOC.TEXT: Britain and Spain agreed Monday to extend two treaties on criminal extradition and drug-trafficking to include Gibraltar, but remained stuck on the problem of sovereignty over the British colony at the southern tip of Spain. Spain had claimed that Britain turns a blind eye to tobacco-smuggling, drug trafficking and money-laundering in its 2.25-square-mile colony. But British Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd said after meeting with Foreign Minister Francisco Fernandez Ordonez of Spain that Fernandez Ordonez offered ``no hard evidence'' of illegal activities. Hurd told reporters Spain also was worried about Gibraltar's emergence as an offshore financial center with 25 banks and $3 billion in deposits, according to figures provided by the local government. He said he explained that what Gibraltar was doing ``was perfectly legitimate ... provided this was done under strict regulation as the key component, and that regulation is being imposed by the Gibraltarian authorities.'' In a joint statement, Britain and Spain said they agreed to extend their 1985 extradition treaty and their 1989 treaty on the prevention and suppression of drug-trafficking to Gibraltar. It said both parties expressed their ``well-known positions on the question of sovereignty,'' an indication little headway was made in the fifth round of talks since Britain and Spain agreed in November 1984 to discuss sovereignty. Spain had to cede Gibraltar to Britain under a 1713 treaty after losing the War of Spanish Succession and wants the limestone landmark back. Hurd said Britain must respect the wishes of about 25,000 Gibraltarians who voted overwhelmingly to remain under British control. ``There will never be an adavance on Gibraltar until sovereignty is returned to Spain,'' Fernandez Ordonez said.

DOC.HEAD: Peres Makes Rare Reference to Israeli Nuclear Program
DOC.TEXT: In a rare public reference to the Israeli nuclear weapons program, Deputy Prime Minister Shimon Peres on Monday cited the Dimona nuclear reactor in the southern Negev Desert as one of Israel's strategic assets. Israeli leaders are usually tight-lipped about Israel's nuclear capabilities, saying only that Israel will not be the first country to introduce nuclear weapons in the Middle East. Referring to Israel's strategic position Monday, Peres said: ``We have everything that a small nation can have. Tell me, are there any other countries that produce a plane of our own, a missile of our own, a tank of our own, a missile boat of our own? ``And we have something in Dimona which is called textile industry,'' he said jokingly. Dimona is the site of Israel's nuclear reactor. There have been frequent reports in the past about Israel's nuclear capabilities, including the development of nuclear-armed intermediate range missiles. Peres, leader of the center-left Labor Party, made the remarks in a question and answer session with members of the Conference of Presidents of Major American Jewish Organizations. In 1986, former Dimona technician Mordechai Vanunu revealed details of Israel's nuclear program to the Sunday Times of London. Scientists questioned by the newspaper said Vanunu's information showed Israel possessed the world's sixth largest nuclear arsenal. Vanunu was seized in Italy by Israeli agents and brought to Israel for trial. He was sentenced to 18 years in prison after being convicted in 1988 of treason and espionage. A report issued in 1987 by a major Israeli research institute said that ``Israel ... is far ahead of the Arab countries in terms of the capacity to achieve a military nuclear capacity.'' The report by Tel Aviv University's Jaffee Center for Strategic Studies said that ``Israel indeed does not possess nuclear weapons.'' ``On the other hand, and in view of its ongoing nuclear effort, it has positioned itself to be capable of producing nuclear weapons in less time than it would take an Arab country to do so,'' the report concluded.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Invites Soviets, Others to Global Warming Conference
DOC.TEXT: President Bush on Monday invited representatives of the world's largest industrial nations, including the Soviet Union, to a mid-April conference in Washington on global warming and other environmental problems. The conference, scheduled for April 17-18, will be ``devoted to science and economics issues'' involved in the controversy, according to a White House statement. Bush, whose stance on global warming has been derided by environmentalists as too pro-industry, had promised such a session after his December meeting in Malta with Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. About 20 nations were invited to the conference, including the world's major industrial powers and several nations, such as Brazil, with large land masses, aides said. ``The administration considers the conference a vital next step in a joint international approach to address possible changes in the global environment,'' the White House statement said. During his 1988 presidential campaign, Bush cited ``increasing evidence'' that the earth's atmosphere was heating up because of the so-called ``greenhouse effect'' and promised to convene a global conference to find ways of dealing with the problem. More recently, however, Bush has softened his approach, saying that the problem needs further study. In a speech that provoked widespread criticism from his audience, Bush told an international conference on climatic change earlier this month that ``our policies must be consistent with economic growth.'' He suggested that in some areas of the debate ``politics and opinion have outpaced the science.'' White House spokesman Stephen Hart said that the April conference was an attempt to ``find some common ground'' among scientific, environmental and economic interests and not the envirnomental summit Bush had called for in his campaign. The White House statement said Bush had designated as co-chairmen of the conference William Reilly, administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency; Michael Boskin, the chairman of the White House Council of Economic Advisers; and Dr. D. Allan Bromley, the president's science adviser. Hart said that invited nations were asked to send their leaders' own top environmental, scientific and economic advisers to the conference. The global conference Bush had advocated during his campaign would have included both the Soviet Union and China. While the Soviet Union is on the list of those invited to the April gathering, China is not. ``We would have obvious problems in terms of inviting China because of the current political situation,'' said a White House aide who asked for anonymity. ``This conference is not all-inclusive. It's just a cross section.'' Officials from several European countries _ including Norway, Denmark and Sweden _ have argued that enough scientific knowledge has been accumulated about the causes of global warming to warrant a commitment from industrial nations to at least stabilize carbon dioxide pollution at current levels over the next decade. Like a greenhouse, such pollution traps heat and reflects it back to earth, causing a warming of the atmosphere. While there is little dispute that greenhouse gases are increasing, there remains disagreement within the scientific community as to how severe the warming will become and what effect it might have on the earth.

DOC.HEAD: Israel to Reopen Arab Community Colleges
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 8 grafs to UPDATE with wounded in West Bank and army raising number of confirmed wounded to 15; pickup 8th pvs, `The death...'
DOC.TEXT: Israel, under pressure from the United States and the European Community, said Monday it will reopen Arab community colleges that had been ordered shut during most of the Palestinian uprising. But the army kept a closure order on six Palestinian universities with an enrollment of more than 22,000 students. In the occupied West Bank, three Arabs were shot and wounded by Israeli troops during stone-throwing clashes in the town of Tulkarem, Arab reports and Israel radio said. The most violent confrontation in the occupied territories in three weeks occurred in the Gaza Strip, where Arab reports said soldiers shot and wounded 28 Palestinians with lead or plastic bullets, including 22 in Rafah. U.N. relief workers said 38 other Palestinians from Rafah were treated for lesser injuries from rubber-coated metal pellets and about 100 people sought help for tear-gas inhalation after army helicopters sprayed the crowd. Some wounded were taken to nearby Khan Yunis, to Nasser Hospital, where squads of soldiers searched for suspects, chasing some patients through the halls, a hospital official said on condition of anonymity. The Rafah clash broke out after youths defied an army curfew and gathered at the home of a Palestinian man who died late Sunday after being shot in the back in a confrontation with troops, Arab reports said. The army confirmed at least 15 Palestinians suffered gunshot wounds and said it was checking further. It declared the Rafah area a closed military zone, preventing 50,000 Palestinians from leaving the town. The death Sunday raised to 659 the number of Palestinians killed by Israeli soldiers or civilians in the 26-month-old uprising against Israel's occupation. Another 189 Palestinians have been slain by fellow Arabs, most on suspicion of collaborating with Israeli authorities, and 43 Israelis have died. In Israel, meanwhile, thousands of Israeli Arabs staged a one-day strike to protest inadequate government funding for their town and city councils. The Arabs, who comprise about 17 percent of Israel's population, are angered by the government's failure to implement an agreement to write off about $50 million of their municipal debt. About 4,000 Israeli Arabs, led by four Arab members of Parliament, marched through downtown Haifa to press their demands. The order allowing community colleges and vocational schools to reopen will affect 16 West Bank schools with an enrollment of about 5,000 students, according to Shmuel Goren, coordinator for the Israeli military government. But Goren, speaking in Ramllah at the military government's West Bank headquarters, said the army did not lift its order closing six Palestinian universities and one polytechnic center. All of the schools were order closed in January 1988 after the army declared they were hotbeds of violence. Goren said the community and vocational colleges were reopened ``to bring about some change in the climate and feelings'' in the territories. ``When we reach the conclusion that the universities will really be a place for study, we will reopen them,'' he said. The European Parliament voted last month to freeze scientific and technical cooperation with Israel until the universities are reopened, and at least two planned Israeli-European Community conferences have been postponed indefinitely. The United States criticized continued closure of the universities in its annual human rights report last week. As Goren spoke with reporters, a group of Palestinian professors and students held a separate news conference in Jerusalem to demand the universities be reopened immediately and to ask for Western support. Inam Labadi, an economics student at Bir Zeit University, said Western nations were doing nothing while Israeli authorities committed ``a crime against academic freedom and against the simplest human rights.'' Mrs. Labadi, whose husband, brother and brother-in-law have been deported during the uprising, said the university closure ``is only aimed at imposing ignorance on our people.'' Gahbi Baramkeh, a Bir Zeit University vice president, said European sanctions on scientific cooperation with Israel were ``a highly appropriate'' response to continued closure of the universities.

DOC.HEAD: Record Cold Monday In The Northeast
DOC.TEXT: A large section of the Northeast was colder Monday than much of Alaska, with record lows from southern Virginia into New York state, and snow blew around the Great Lakes. Monday's low for the Lower 48 states was 23 degrees below zero at Saranac Lake, N.Y., in the northern Adirondacks. Elsewhere in the Northeast, Smethport, Pa., tumbled to 22 below zero and Wilcox, Pa., reported 20 below. Record lows were 10 at downtown Atlantic City, N.J., and 9 at the airport; 13, a tie, at Baltimore, downtown and airport; 6 below zero at Binghamton, N.Y.; 5 at Bridgeport, Conn.; 4 below at Hartford, Conn.; 8 at Newark, N.J.; 7, a tie, at New York City; 9 at New York's Kennedy Airport; 19, a tie, at Norfolk, Va.; 10, a tie, at Philadelphia; and 10 below at Syracuse, N.Y. But at the airport at Anchorage, Alaska, the temperature was 37 near midnight and Palmer, Alaska, reached 41 during the morning. On Friday, Philadelphia, Boston and New York City had enjoyed temperatures in the 60s. In the South, crops from North Carolina to Georgia mostly survived Monday's below-freezing temperatures, which dipped into the mid-teens in some places, but farmers braced for another night of cold weather. ``We may have taken a minor hit,'' Dale Linvill, an agricultural meteorologist with Clemson University, said of South Carolina's crops. ``There may be some spotted damage, but not enough to really worry about.'' ``We had some damage to the peach blooms and buds, but we feel like we'll come through OK,'' said Bill Reece, agricultural extension director in North Carolina's Montgomery County. ``It's the upcoming weather we're concerned about.'' The cold and wind snapped power lines during the night in northwestern Pennsylvania's Warren County, where Warren hit 6 below zero, and 1,700 customers in and around North Warren were without electricity until 6:30 a.m., said Jerry Clayton, a line foreman for Pennsylvania Electric Co. Warren County schools couldn't be heated in time for morning classes, said Transportation Director Mark Eberl said. Twenty schools in the county were closed, affecting 7,300 students. Schools throughout western Pennsylvania were delayed. Monday's cold followed a stormy weekend in which at least 20 deaths were blamed on the weather, most of them in traffic accidents on slippery highways. In all, 13 people died in weather-related accidents in Ohio. Another three died in Illinois, two in Indiana and one each in Michigan and Kentucky. At midday Monday, snow showers, gusty wind and blowing snow extended over eastern Upper Michigan and northern Lower Michigan, and over north-central Wisconsin and north-central Minnesota. A heavy snow watch in effect through Tuesday was posted across western Upper Michigan and northwestern Lower Michigan. Elsewhere, there were snow showers over south-central Kentucky. Freezing rain was scattered over southeastern Missouri, southern Illinois and southwestern Indiana. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EST ranged from 2 above zero at Caribou and Limestone, Maine, to 84 in Arizona at both Gila Bend and Yuma.

DOC.HEAD: Congressional Delegation to Visit South Africa
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs throughout to drop name of Hoyer, who unable to make trip
DOC.TEXT: An eight-member House delegation will travel to South Africa this week for meetings with government officials and black political leader Nelson Mandela, House Speaker Thomas S. Foley announced Monday. In addition to sessions with South African President F.W. de Klerk and African National Congress leader Mandela, the group will meet with other political and labor figures and with Archbishop Desmond Tutu and the Rev. Alan Boesak. The delegation will be led by Majority Whip William Gray, D-Pa., and Rep. Dean Gallo, R-N.J. Others in the group are Reps. Ron Dellums, D-Calif., Howard Wolpe, D-Mich, Stephen Solarz, D-N.Y., Mike Andrews, D-Texas, Beverly Byron, D-Md., and Jim McCrery, R-La.

DOC.HEAD: Noriega's Aides Kept Him In Dark
DOC.TEXT: Manuel Antonio Noriega's top aides gave him ``false reports'' about the possibility of American military action, but U.S. forces were caught off guard, too, by the strength of the Panamanian resistance, the general who led the military operation said Monday. ``In the two weeks preceeding Operation Just Cause, they never gave him an accurate assessment'' of U.S. military activities, Army Lt. Gen. Carl Stiner said of Noreiga's intelligence staff. Stiner said U.S. forces were surprised by two developments _ what proved to be poor intelligence about the power of Noriega's so-called ``Dignity Batallions'' and stiffer-than-expected resistance from the Panamanian Defense Forces. ``We didn't have the intelligence we should have had on the Dignity Batallions,'' Stiner said. ``They were stronger and more formidable to deal with ... because they just faded back into the population,'' he said of the paramilitary Noriega supporters dressed in civilian clothes and armed with automatic weapons. Stiner, who offered his assessment of the military operation to reporters, said the strong resistance came because the PDF apparently was tipped off to the operation just hours before its start at 1 a.m. on Dec. 20. Stiner said he tried to move the H-hour forward in order to maintain the surprise nature of the massive operation and minimize the casualties. The general said he was able to advance it only by 15 minutes because of its complexity. More than 12,000 U.S. troops were airlifted into Panama in an attempt to smash the Panamanian Defense Forces and seize Noriega, who later surrendered to U.S. authorities and was brought back to the United States to face federal drug charges. Stiner reported that, overall, 23 U.S. servicemen were killed and 324 were injured. ``It was compromised,'' Stiner said of the operation. ``We know it was compromised.'' This allowed some Panamanian officers to prepare their soldiers for the possibility of a U.S. attack, and that meant heavier-than-expected resistance at some of the landing zones where the airborne forces encountered live fire, the general said. Stiner said that at 10:00 p.m., the PDF radio networks carried such reports as, ``They are coming, the ball game is at 1:00 in the morning. ... Report to your units immediately and draw your weapons and prepare to fight.'' The general said there were several possiblities for the leak of information, but that he had no independent confirmation what exactly tipped off the PDF. Yet, the general said, the operation an unqualified success, and so much so that the commanders ``didn't learn a single lesson'' from the endeavor. The three-star general said the misleading information handed Noriega was discovered in documents captured during the December operation, and that it was provided to Noriega by his ``key staff ... his key henchmen.'' Stiner identified two of them as Col. Nivaldo Madrinan, the chief of Noriega's investigations department, and Capt. Eliezer Gaytan, chief of security. ``They were giving him false reports ... They were submitting reports to him that everything was fine,'' Stiner said. Asked if the misleading information indicated Norieaga was being set up by his cohorts, the general said he did not know if that was the case. Stiner said he also couldn't say exactly what information Noriega was given in the hours just prior to the operation. The Panamanian general was able to elude U.S. forces for days, until he sought refuge at the Vatican Embassy. Stiner, who is the commanding general for the 18th Airborne Corps at Fort Bragg, N.C., said his troops had practiced jumping from 800 feet, but that they actually dropped into the landing zones from 500 feet. With the live fire coming at them from the ground, some of the men ``in the excitement of being shot at,'' forgot to drop their 100 pound packs ahead of them and broke their ankles because of the heavy load. Stiner said commanders usually have a 6 percent injury rate in a training mission, and the injury tally in Panama ``wasn't much more than that.''

DOC.HEAD: Britton Gets 25 Years for Shotgun Slayings of Family
DOC.TEXT: A teen-ager who pleaded guilty in the shotgun slayings of his father, mother and 8-year-old brother was sentenced Monday to a minimum 25 years in prison. Brian Britton, 17, who prosecutors claimed had a fascination with the ``Rambo'' movie character portrayed by actor Sylvester Stallone, showed no emotion when sentenced to 25-years-to-life imprisonment on each of the second-degree murder counts. Britton, who pleaded guilty Jan. 3, also was sentenced to serve between 8 1-3 to 25 years for the attempted murder of his sister during the March 1989 rampage at the family's home in Poughkeepsie. Judge Judith Hillery ordered the sentences to run concurrently. Under New York state law, Britton must serve all of his minimum sentence. Hillery rejected a plea for leniency from public defender John Garrity Jr., who argued that Britton had been abused at home by an alcoholic father and an overbearing mother. Garrity claimed that Britton had suffered cracked ribs and a broken nose as the result of confrontations with his father. Pamela Sackett of the Dutchess County Coalition Against Child Abuse said she was disappointed the sentence was not reduced, saying it was ``very clear child abuse played a significant role'' in the slayings. Assistant Dutchess County District Attorney Thomas Dolan said there was no reason for the slayings other than the ``outrageous rage of a young man.'' He called Britton a calculating killer. Britton gave ``Rambo'' as his nickname when booked by authorities after the shootings. Prosecutors claimed he was fascinated with the gun-toting Vietnam veteran in the ``Rambo'' movie series, and also kept a range of military paraphernalia in the house, including Army fatigues, canteens and ``Soldier of Fortune'' magazines. Garrity argued that Britton had been forced by his father to watch violent shows on television, especially about war.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Praises Governors' Work in Education
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS 2 grafs after 5th graf pvs bgng, Bush told ... with Dukakis quoting Bush on defense cuts; picks up with 6th graf pvs bgng, Bush thanked...
DOC.TEXT: President Bush offered high praise Monday to the nation's governors for their work on education and pledged to keep the subject ``in the forefront of America's agenda.'' But some governors emerged from the White House meeting complaining that the president didn't back his words with money. ``He seemed unaccountably reluctant to make any commitments,'' said Gov. Richard Celeste of Ohio, chairman of the Democratic Governors' Association. Bush met with the governors the day after the state officials adopted six education goals that followed closely those outlined by the president in his State of the Union speech last month. ``We are launching a new era in education reform,'' said Bush. ``Its focus, high expectations; its hallmark, results.''
