Bush told the governors gathered in the East Room that ``for the first time in America's history we now have national education goals and objectives _ goals that pave the way to a decade-long commitment to excellence in education for all Americans, goals that will guide us on the journey toward an American renaissance in education.'' In a private luncheon with the governors Bush hinted that there may be some resources available in coming years to address the education goals. According to Massachusetts Gov. Michael S. Dukakis, the vanquished Democrat in the 1988 presidential election, Bush said defense spending may be cut further. With communism seemingly in retreat around the world, several of the governors asked Bush who was the enemy, Dukakis said. ``He said, `The enemy is instability.' OK, fine. But then he said, `Look, we've already cut the defense budget substantially below projected levels,' and he said `It's probably going to be cut even futher.''' Bush thanked the governors for their ``superb cooperation'' in the effort that began last fall at an education summit in Charlottesville, Va. The president and the governors agreed that adoption of the goals for improving American education over the next decade was only the beginning of a difficult process. ``We all expect that there's a lot of work ahead of us,'' said Gov. Terry Branstad of Iowa, chairman of the National Governors' Association. Adoption of the goals was the top item on the agenda of the NGA's annual midwinter meeting. The four day conference ends Tuesday. The goals call for giving poor children pre-school services that include nutrition and health screening and making sure American students are competent in math, science, English, history and geography. They also call for increasing adult literacy and making schools drug-free. Attached to the goals was a document seeking a commitment ``to provide at least one year of pre-school for all disadvantaged children.'' It also said, ``federal funds should target those students most in need of assistance due to economic disadvantage or risk of academic failure.'' In the budget he sent Congress this year, Bush proposed a $500 million increase in federal funds for the pre-school Head Start program. But when governors asked at the White House about funds for other educational programs, the president offered no encouragement. ``To the extent that the federal government doesn't propose more funds, they (the goals) may not be reachable,'' said Gov. L. Douglas Wilder of Virginia. Republican Gov. James Thompson of Illinois backed the president's reluctance to offer a greater federal commitment. ``The money is going to come primarily from states and local governments and that's where it should come from,'' said Thompson. Gov. Carroll Campbell of South Carolina, who was co-chairman of the governors' education task force, noted that the federal government pays only about 7 percent of the cost of public schools. ``We're going to have to carry the bulk of this, we and the local communities,'' said the South Carolina Republican. ``We're not looking for change in that ratio,'' said Roger Porter, White House domestic affairs adviser, referring to the 7 percent federal share. The governors also adopted a resolution urging the president to consider education among the areas that might get additional funds from any ``peace dividend,'' or reduction in defense spending because of reduced international tensions. Gov. Mario Cuomo of New York said that resolution was ``an acknowledgement _ not as bold a commitment as a lot of us would want _ but at least an acknowledgement that there is a federal role of some kind when it comes to revenue.'' ``I don't think the White House is prepared to offer the governors any more in the way of funds than are in the budget,'' said Celeste. ``I am a little disappointed.'' Bush pledged to ``do everything I can to provide the national leadership and energy to keep education in the forefront of America's domestic agenda.''

DOC.HEAD: States Sign Compact to Cooperate on Air Pollution
With AM-Clean Air, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The governors of six mid-Atlantic states, saying pollution knows no boundaries, signed a regional compact Monday to develop consistent clean-air standards and cooperate in monitoring air pollution. ``The updating of the Clean Air Act is taking entirely too long,'' New Jersey Gov. Jim Florio said, ``and therefore what this represents is our recognition that to protect the health of our constituents we can't wait for somebody to get around to upgrading the Clean Air Act.'' The Mid-Atlantic Region Air Management Agreement was signed by the governors of Delaware, Maryland, Virginia, North Carolina, Pennsylvania and New Jersey, as well as the city of Philadelphia, Allegheny County, Pa., and the District of Columbia. ``This is a good initiative,'' said Maryland Gov. William Donald Schaefer. ``The regulations in one state should be as similar as possible to those in the next state.'' Representatives of each state will meet Tuesday to begin deciding how to develop consistent policies on acid rain as well as on emissions of ozone, toxic chemicals and volatile organic chemicals that send vapors into the air. Already, Delaware, Maryland and New Jersey have laws restricting the vapors emitted by gasoline. Similar legislation is pending in Pennsylvania and Philadelphia, according to Phillip Retallnick, director of Delaware's Division of Air and Waste Management. Schaefer suggested the idea of regional cooperation could be extended to other environmental issues. He said mid-Atlantic governors might join forces on plastics recycling, while Virginia Gov. Douglas Wilder said he could foresee them acting together to solve problems of solid-waste disposal.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Southern Command Identifies Chopper Crash Victims
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. Southern Command Monday identified eight of nine people killed when a military helicopter crashed last week in a thunderstorm in a jungle. The helicopter and a second one crashed Wednesday while on a training flight near Punta Diego, about 50 miles southwest of Colon, on the Atlantic entrance to the Panama Canal. The Southern Command disclosed the names of the two men on the second helicopter on Friday. It issued a news release Monday that identified three of the four crew members on the first helicopter, a UH-1H, as 1st Warrant Officers Vincent Gibson and Richard Block, and Spec. Joel L. Meints. It said the name of the fourth was being withheld until relatives were notified. All four belonged to Company B, 1st Battalion, of U.S. Army South's 228 Airborne Regiment in Panama. The five passengers aboard were identified as Sgts. Sidney T. Dew and Antonio B. Solis, Specs. Rodney L. Blodgett and Kirk M. Magill and Pvt. 2 Charles D. Allison. They were members of Company B, 3rd Battalion, 17th Infantry, 7th Light Infantry Division, with headquarters at Fort Ord, Calif, according to the news release. The Southern Command did not disclose the ages or hometowns of any of the men. Those killed on the second helicopter, an OH-58 observation aircraft, were Capt. Richard D. Tyndall and Warrant Officer James W. Carl, the pilot. Carl was assigned to the Panamanian company and Tyndall to the Fort Ord company. The helicopters, based in Fort Kobbe, belonged to the Panamanian company. The Southern Command said last week that the crashes are under investigation but that sabotage was not suspected.

DOC.HEAD: Five Rebels Killed in Peru; Slogans Painted on Incan Ruins
DOC.TEXT: Police killed five pro-Cuban guerrillas in the central highlands, and rebels belonging to the fanatical Shining Path movement painted red anti-government threats Monday on Inca ruins above Cuzco, authorities said. A police patrol clashed Sunday evening with a column of rebels belonging to the Tupac Amaru Revolutionary Movement near Jauja, 100 miles east of Lima, killing five guerrillas while suffering no police casualties, police said. In Cuzco, 355 miles southeast of Lima, fighters of the Maoist Shining Path daubed threats on the huge stone walls of Sacsayhuaman, an Inca fortress on a hill overlooking the city, which is a popular tourist site. Police said about 15 hooded rebels tied up the two guards at the ruins before dawn Monday and then used red paint to write warnings against voting in presidential and general elections set for April 8. The signs also said, ``Long live President Gonzalo,'' the name used by Shining Path leader Abimael Guzman. On Feb. 8, the body of an American tourist shot in the head was found near the ruins, and police have not determined whether he was killed by thieves or Shining Path guerrillas. Shining Path rebels murdered seven foreign tourists last year in different parts of the highlands. But Cuzco had been relatively free of terrorism. The government extended for 60 days on Monday a state of emergency in a third of the nation, giving the military broad powers to fight leftist guerrillas. The measure affects eight departments _ Apurimac, Ayacucho, Huancavelica, Junin, Pasco, Huanuco, San Martin and Ucayali _ and one province, Ucayali in Loreto department. Peru is divided into 24 departments, which are subdivided into provinces. The areas are in the central and southern highlands and northern jungle. The state of emergency puts the areas under military control and suspends individual rights such as unrestricted travel, protection against arrest without a judicial order and prohibition against violation of residences without search warrants. Lima, Peru's capital and home to a third of its 22 million people, also is under a state of emergency, but it is administered by the national police. Political violence unleashed by the Shining Path in 1980 has killed more than 17,500 people. The government imposed the state of emergency for the first time in December 1982 in Ayacucho, birthplace of the rebel movement. Since then the measure has been steadily extended to other areas as rebel violence has expanded.

DOC.HEAD: Researchers Narrow Search For Gene For Hereditary Blindness
DOC.TEXT: Researchers have approximately located the gene responsible for an inherited disorder that causes eye disease and hearing impairment, a discovery they hope will lead them to the ailment's cause and treatment. Defects in the gene cause a disease called Type II Usher syndrome, which is marked by retinitis pigmentosa and moderate hearing impairment, according to an announcement Monday by the National Retinitis Pigmentosa Foundation in Baltimore. The foundation said the disorder afflicts an estimated 10,000 Americans. ``This finding represents the first localization of a gene associated with congenital hearing loss and is a significant advance in the molecular genetics of RP,'' said Dr. Alan Laties, chairman of the retinitis pigmentosa foundation's scientific advisory board. The discovery follows by less than a month the announcement that researchers had identified a genetic defect associated with another form of retinitis pigmentosa, the so-called autosomal dominant form. That form is not accompanied by hearing loss. The team that made the discovery was led by William Kimberling, director of the Center for Hereditary Communication Disorders at Boys Town National Research Hospital in Omaha, Neb. The gene was found to be located on the long arm of chromosome 1, one of the 23 chromosomes that carry human hereditary characteristics. Retinitis pigmentosa is an inherited disease that afflicts about 100,000 Americans. It begins with night blindness and gradually progresses to tunnel vision and total blindness. These symptoms are caused by degeneration of the retina. The cause of this degeneration is unknown. But with the discovery of genes that trigger it, researchers can begin to unravel the biochemical process that leads to the degeneration. They can then use that knowledge to try to develop drugs or other treatments to counteract or prevent degeneration.

DOC.HEAD: Tugs Tow Burning Tanker Out of Persian Gulf
DOC.TEXT: Tugboats towed the burning Kuwaiti tanker Surf City, which exploded last week, out of the Persian Gulf toward the Indian Ocean on Monday. Several salvage tugs and at least one U.S. Navy warship accompanied the 81,283-ton vessel on a 10-hour transit of the Strait of Hormuz, gateway to the gulf, military and shipping industry sources reported. The tanker was imperiled by a resurgence of fires fed by leaks from its weakened cargo tanks. Officials said the Surf City was taken out of the gulf to avoid the possibility of another explosion sinking it in busy shipping lanes or causing damage to terminal facilities off the United Arab Emirates. The Surf City was one of 11 Kuwait-owned tankers reflagged by the United States in 1987 so the Navy could protect them from attack in the Iran-Iraq war. A Gulf-based shipping executive, speaking on condition of anonymity, said salvage tugs were spraying foam and water on the tanker as it was towed out. He said a southerly wind was helping cool the ship, but also would slow its progress. The explosion on Thursday killed the American captain and first mate and forced the other 23 crewmen _ all Americans but one _ to abandon ship. They were rescued by the missile frigate USS Simpson, patrolling nearby. All were flown home later except boatswain Earl Washington, 41, of Louisiana, who remains in a Dubai hospital with burns. His hometown was not immediately known. Until the towing began, the tanker had remained off the Emirates while up to a dozen salvage tugs tried to contain the fires.

DOC.HEAD: Father Arrives in New Zealand to Reclaim Daughter
DOC.TEXT: The father of 7-year-old Hilary Foretich, whose mother went to jail for 25 months rather than disclose her whereabouts, said Monday that he had come to rescue his daughter. ``My daughter deserves to come back and have a normal life,'' said Dr. Eric Foretich, 45, as he arrived in Auckland. The mother, Dr. Jean Elizabeth Morgan, who claims her ex-husband sexually abused the child, accused him of hunting down their daughter like ``an animal.'' Foretich denies he abused the child. Last week, the Falls Church, Va., dental surgeon traced his daughter to New Zealand, where she has been living with her maternal grandparents. Hilary reportedly hasn't seen either of her parents in two years. ``Certainly we're going to do what we need to do to rescue my daughter,'' Foretich said. He met with his New Zealand lawyers immediately upon his arrival. Morgan was released from jail in September after Congress passed a law tailored for her that limited civil contempt imprisonment in Washington, D.C., to a year. Aided by private investigators, Foretich found that Hilary was living in the South Island town of Christchurch, 190 miles southwest of Wellington. The Family Court in Christchurch granted an interim order Friday giving the grandparents custody of the girl, and on Monday William Morgan, the child's grandfather, vowed to call police if the father approached the girl. Hilary spoke to her mother for the first time in two years Sunday and cried, said Antonia Morgan, her maternal grandmother. Morgan, a 42-year-old plastic surgeon in Washington, was jailed in August 1987 for refusing to say where her daughter was despite a U.S. judge's ruling for the former husband's unsupervised access. The couple separated before Hilary was born. In an interview from the United States, Morgan accused her ex-husband of seeking publicity and said: ``He has hunted her down like an animal. She does not want to see him, and he knows that.'' Morgan's attorney, Stephen Sachs, filed papers in Washington, D.C., Monday asking Superior Court Judge Herbert Dixon to return her passport so she can travel to New Zealand. She was forced to hand over the passport during the custody battle. ``By continuing to withhold Dr. Morgan's passport, this court is effectively preventing Dr. Morgan from appearing in the New Zealand proceeding to defend her interests and from responding to the request of Hilary's court-appointed counsel that she participate in those proceedings,'' the motion said. Dixon, who jailed Morgan in 1987, has scheduled a hearing for Tuesday morning. However, the passport is in the custody of the D.C. Court of Appeals, due to another ruling in the protracted case. Officials indicated that Dixon could suggest to the appeals court that the passport be returned. New Zealand's prime minister, Geoffrey Palmer, noting intense U.S. media interest in the case, said it was for the family court in Christchurch, not his Labor government, to rule on the matter. ``The paramount consideration in those cases is one issue: the welfare of the child,'' Palmer said. Hilary has spent the past two years in Christchurch, a famous cathedral town that is the staging post for ``Operation Deepfreeze,'' as the U.S. activities in Antarctica are called. Opposition National Party member Philip Burdon, voicing sympathy for the girl's mother, said that she chose to hide her daughter in New Zealand because it had a respected legal system and was an English-speaking country that the grandfather had visited before. ``We are not dealing with crackpots here,'' Burdon said. ``I have little sympathy for the motivations of the father who had already separated from of the mother of his child before she was born.''

DOC.HEAD: Excerpts From Chamorro's Speech
With AM-Nicaragua, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Following are excerpts from a speech by Violeta Barrios de Chamorro of the United National Opposition early Monday, shortly after returns showed she had won the Nicaraguan presidency. The remarks were translated by The Associated Press. _ ``I want to communicate to the people of Nicaragua that they should have complete confidence that this election favoring UNO is irreversible.'' _ ``I want to congratulate all Nicaraguans, because today all Nicaraguans have won, and we have given the world a magnificent example of civics. (We have) shown that Nicaraguans are a people who want to live in democracy, peace and especially in freedom.'' _ ``I will honor my commitment to achieving national reconciliation. Because only in this manner can we have peace and economic well-being.'' _ ``Today I ratify my commitment to faithfully carry out UNO's government program, which is a program of national salvation.''

DOC.HEAD: Indians Say Government Food Unhealthy, Unappetizing
DOC.TEXT: Many government food products are unfit for needy Indians who rely on them to survive, a congressional committee was told Monday as it examined smelly, unappetizing cans of meat. ``I'm not sure that I'd give this to a dog,'' Rep. Tony Hall, D-Ohio, said after examining the cans of beef and pork stamped ``USDA approved'' from food packages the government distributes through Indian tribes. Charles ``Red'' Gates, the food distribution program director for the Standing Rock Sioux Tribe, told the U.S. House Select Committee on Hunger the meats not only contain lard and animal veins, but also are loaded with fat and sodium. That compounds the unusually high rates of diabetes, heart disease, hypertension and infant mortality rates on North Dakota Indian reservations, Gates, tribal officials and reservation residents said. It was the first time the USDA had heard such complaints about its meat commodities, said USDA spokeswoman Darlene Barnes. Beef and pork commodity products must meet certain specifications and are limited to 1 percent sodium and 1 percent fat, she said. Among the 100 people attending the congressional hearing at the tribal council headquarters on south-central North Dakota reservation was Diane Ponga, 38, a speech aide for the school district. She told the committee that she and her husband, who suffers from high blood pressure, depend on commodity foods to feed their six children and two nieces. She said the children range in age from 6 to 19. ``But I don't let the kids see it, or they won't eat it,'' Ponga said, referring to the canned meat. Tribal officials asked the committee to push for higher nutritional and quality standards for commodity foods to ease the persistent health problems on the reservation. ``It's imperative the food provided doesn't contribute to health problems,'' said Twila Martin-Kekahbah, chairwoman of the Turtle Mountain Band of Chippewa Indians. Terrence Sloan, director for the Aberdeen Area Indian Health Service that serves North Dakota, South Dakota, Nebraska and Iowa, said health and nutrition problems are disproportionately higher on the Standing Rock reservation than anywhere else in the nation. The tribe includes 2.3 million acres in Sioux County of North Dakota and Corson County in South Dakota. Its enrolled population was 10,300 in January 1989. Deaths from heart disease on the reservation from 1984 through 1986 totaled 243 per 100,000 people, compared with 181 for all races in the United States, Sloan said. An infant mortality rate of 19 per 1,000 live births was nearly double the nationwide average, he said. Indians also have one of the highest diabetes rates worldwide, Sloan said. ``These problems will accelerate unless changes are made in nutrition and fitness programs on the reservation,'' he said. He suggested making fresh fruit and vegetables available through the commodity distribution program, providing delivery of food to the elderly and handicapped, implementing information programs on nutrition and food preparation, and reducing fat, salt and sodium in food items. Sloan also urged that income guidelines for the food stamp program be revised. A recent General Accounting Office study of four reservations, including Fort Berthold in North Dakota and Pine Ridge in South Dakota, showed some Indians cannot qualify for food stamps because their cars are worth more than $4,500. The $4,500 limit was set in 1978. Grocers also raise their prices on the days they know food stamps are being issued, the GAO found. Hall and Rep. Byron Dorgan, D-N.D., said they would support legislation to improve government nutrition programs. ``It's disgusting,'' Dorgan said. ``We've got to do better than this.''

DOC.HEAD: Wolf Withdraws Name for OTS Post
DOC.TEXT: A former congressional official who had been the Bush administration's leading candidate for chief regulator of the nation's savings institutions said Monday he has withdrawn his name from consideration. Frederick D. Wolf, formerly the No. 2 official at the General Accounting Office, said he informed the Treasury Department last week he is no longer interested in being appointed director of the department's Office of Thrift Supervision. Wolf, a partner with the Price Waterhouse & Co. accounting firm, said Treasury officials in late December asked him to apply for the job. Subsequently, administration, congressional and industry sources said Wolf was the most likely candidate to succeed M. Danny Wall, who announced his resignation on Dec. 4 but continues to serve. Wolf said he was disturbed that two months after being asked to consider the job, Treasury officials had still not recommended his name to the White House. He said he could only conclude that either the administration did not believe it was important to fill the job soon or did not favor his appointment. In the meantime, Wolf said he was forced to suspend work for several of his firm's clients in order to avoid a potential conflict of interest. The inability of the administration to decide on Wall's replacement, nearly three months after he quit, was taken by analysts as another sign of disarray in the management of the savings and loan bailout. Last month, Daniel Kearney, alluding to differences with the Treasury Department, resigned as the chief staff officer of the Resolution Trust Corp. Oversight Board. The board sets the policy and controls the purse strings of the bailout. ``I think this withdrawal is another black eye coming on top of Kearney's resignation,'' said Bert Ely, a financial institutions analyst in Alexandria, Va. ``It is bumbling.'' The failure to fill the post also likely will bolster the arguments of members of Congress, including House Banking Committee members Reps. Charles Schumer, D-N.Y., and Jim Leach, R-Iowa, who want to abolish the thrift office and divide its duties among commercial bank regulatory agencies. Wall, who had been under fire from Congress for his handling of the collapse of Lincoln Savings and Loan Association, Irvine, Calif., said he would like to leave the post soon. ``I have indicated that is my wish, but there's no date been set at this point,'' he said. ``I haven't put any deadlines down.'' Wall said Treasury is exploring the appointment of Jonathan Fiechter, currently the office's senior deputy director, as acting director. However, in a letter to President Bush, the U.S. League of Savings Institutions said the appointment of an acting director could leave the institution rudderless. It said its reading of last summer's S&L legislation does not leave its lawyers confident that an acting director, without Senate confirmation, could legally close failed S&Ls, issue rules or exercise the other powers of the director's office. Art Siddon, a spokesman for the Treasury Department, had no comment on the trade group's contention.

DOC.HEAD: Weather Still a Problem for Atlantis' Sixth Launch Try
^Eds: SUBS grafs 7-8, bgn `The astronauts...,' to UPDATE with all five astronauts flying back to their training center in Houston. Picks up 9th graf pvs, `We are...'
DOC.TEXT: NASA will wait until Wednesday for the sixth attempt to launch shuttle Atlantis on an undercover military mission, but weather may again interfere. Forecasters said there was only a 40 percent chance the weather would be favorable at launch time, expected about 12:45 a.m. The problem, they said, would be high winds and clouds, the forces that combined early Monday to halt the latest effort to put what sources said was a $500 million spy satellite in orbit. The outlook remains the same on Thursday. After Monday's scrub, the fifth in five days, shuttle managers decided to wait two days so that the five military astronauts and launch team could rest. ``We've got a 48-hour turnaround, and it's going to give us all a chance to get some rest,'' said NASA spokesman Bruce Buckingham. The astronauts were making use of the break to fly back to Houston to use training facilities at the Johnson Space Center. They were due back by noontime Tuesday. The crew includes Navy Capt. John O. Creighton, the commander; Air Force John H. Casper, the pilot; Marine Lt. Col. David C. Hilmers, the flight engineer; and mission specialists Air Force Col. Richard Mullane and Navy Cmdr. Pierre J. Thuot. ``We are disappointed we didn't launch, but are convinced that the launch team and the mission management team made the correct decision,'' Creighton said in a statement. ``We are looking forward to our next opportunity.'' The astronauts boarded Atlantis about 2{ hours before Monday's scheduled 12:54 a.m. liftoff. The countdown was put on hold, but a break in the weather never came and at 2:32 a.m. the launch was abandoned. Sunday's liftoff was halted by a computer problem with 31 seconds to go. The two previous launches were delayed due to weather, while the first attempt, on Thursday, was scrubbed because Creighton had a cold. So far, the delays have cost the National Aeronautics and Space Administration $2.75 million in fuel, labor and materials. The mission is nearing a record for postponements due to weather and mechanical problems. Columbia was launched Jan. 12, 1986, after six such delays. Challenger, launched 16 days later on the ill-fated flight that killed its seven astronauts, also had been delayed six times, but only three of those came during countdown. The others were the result of Columbia's delays. Because Atlantis' flight is a classified military mission, NASA is withholding details surrounding the length and purpose of the flight. However, sources who spoke on condition of anonymity said Atlantis' cargo is a $500 million spy satellite capable of taking high-resolution reconnaissance photos and listening in on electronics communications all over the world. The mission is to be the sixth classified military flight of 34 shuttle missions.

DOC.HEAD: Illinois Governor Named to Intelligence Post
DOC.TEXT: President Bush on Friday named Illinois Gov. James R. Thompson Jr. to be chairman of the Intelligence Oversight Board, a watchdog panel that keeps tabs on the government's intelligence services. Thompson succeeds W. Glenn Campbell. Bush also named Amos A. Jordan Jr. to the panel. He is vice chairman of the board of trustees at the Center for Strategic and International Studies in Washington. Jordan replaces Charles Tyroler II. The three-member panel was set up in 1981 to review U.S. intelligence activities and agency guidelines, and to report to the president and the attorney general whenever any practices are detected which might violate law. The third member of the panel is Michael W. McConnell.

DOC.HEAD: War, Poverty Lead to Nicaragua's Opposition Victory
AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: Fed up with war and poverty and liberated by a secret ballot, Nicaraguans unceremoniously dumped the ruling Sandinista party as soon as they had the chance. The Sandinistas lost, and lost big, despite their tight organization and militant workers; despite plastering Managua and the country with ``Daniel Presidente'' T-shirts, baseball caps and posters; despite a campaign that spent $7 million in a media-poor country, despite polls that showed 15-point leads. ``I think when people went to the polls, they voted with their stomachs. And I think they thought about the empty stomachs of their children,'' said Paul Reichler, an American lawyer and close adviser to President Daniel Ortega. The Sandinistas blamed their economic problems largely on the United States, and the United States certainly did its worst: it sponsored a guerrilla war and imposed an economic embargo. But in the end, the excuses didn't matter: people wanted a change. ``They had 10 years and could not do it,'' was the slogan of the jury-rigged opposition coalition led by newspaper publisher Violeta Barrios de Chamorro. She hammered away at the Sandinistas for their dogmatic, Marxist-oriented policies and state-controlled economy. It was a shocking fall for the young revolutionaries who entered Managua as heroes on July 19, 1979, after toppling the 45-year Somoza dynasty. But then they began to antagonize the church, restrict civil liberties, muzzle news media and install a generally repressive regime that critics said was a copy of the Cuban system. Nicaraguans fled their country by the hundreds of thousands. Some compared Sandinista experiments to those of children who just got a set of toy trains for Christmas. The Sandinistas eventually tried to change, admitting errors, promising a new mixed-market economic system, freeing the press and making possible the freest election in Nicaraguan history. But with an economy in shambles, a costly war that killed more than 60,000 people and the prospect of more poverty as its Eastern European allied regimes crumbled, the Sandinistas were left vulnerable to an electorate that ``lost its fear,'' in the words of a Sandinista journalist. ``It is to their credit that they created the atmosphere for a clean election,'' said truck driver Ramon Mendoza as he came out of a polling booth where there were no soldiers or other symbols of intimidation. ``But I could not vote for the Frente (the Sandinistas). A vote for the Sandinistas would mean that I am voting for higher inflation, for things to be more expensive every day, for my children to be drafted into the army and sent to war.'' ``We did not vote for Violeta,'' he added, referring also to his wife's vote. ``We voted for a change.'' ``We did not have the best candidate and we did not run the best campaign,'' said a close adviser to Mrs. Chamorro, the newspaper publisher who was a symbol more than a leader of an opposition coalition that included parties from the extreme right to the extreme left. ``I think they overestimated themselves,'' said Luis Guzman, leader of a Social Christian faction in the opposition coalition. ``They thought they could go for a plebiscite and win; Pinochet made the same mistake. They decided to run the risk. Now their only option is to accept what happened.'' The reference was to lame-duck President Augusto Pinochet of Chile. The Sandinistas, in another example of growing maturity as a party, appear to have accepted their fate. Some of their own foes thought it was sad the Sandinistas got the boot from an irate populace ``with short memory'' of the contributions the Sandinistas made in getting rid of dictator Anastasio Somoza and in the areas of health and education. ``We thought it would have been better to try to change the Sandinistas from within,'' said Mauricio Diaz, vice president of the Social Christian Party. ``People identified the problems with the Sandinistas. They do not think that part of the problem was caused by the United States.'' The Sandinistas remain the largest single party in the National Assembly and still control many labor unions, making them an important political force. The army is known as the Sandinista Army and is closely identified with the party. ``The new government will have to deal with the army very carefully,'' said Social Christian presidential nominee Erick Ramirez, a clear loser in this election because he gambled on staying out of the United National Opposition coalition that he thought would fall apart. The army is commanded by Gen. Humberto Ortega, Daniel Ortega's brother. Many of the Sandinistas' achievements have left a deep imprint in Nicaraguan history. They confiscated land as part of agrarian reform and distributed it to landless peasants, formed farming cooperatives, organized a giant literacy campaign, and improved public medical services. But their economic policies and their confrontation with Washington forced them eventually into regional isolation. The United States financed the Contra rebels that at one time numbered 15,000 and the Sandinistas had to raise an army to fight them. ``If we had to make some changes, we would change some of the economic policies of the past 10 years,'' campaign manager and Sandinista Directorate member Bayardo Arce told journalsits three days before the election. The Sandinistas obviously thought they would win, buoyed by polls and a tremendous final rally that drew 300,000 people. But Nicaraguans were afraid to tell pollsters the truth and the rallies were packed by government employees and labor unionists who felt compelled to attend. In the secrecy of a voting booth that the Sandinistas themselves arranged, all that changed.
Eloy O. Aguilar has been Associated Press bureau chief for Mexico and Central America since 1980.

DOC.HEAD: Nicaraguan Election Hailed as Victory for Democracy
With AM-Nicaragua, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Nicaraguan elections were hailed worldwide Monday as a model of democracy and a step toward peace in a country that has been mired in civil war for a decade. Hundreds of international observers monitored the campaign and the Sunday balloting, in which opposition candidate Violeta Barrios de Chamorro defeated incumbent Sandinista President Daniel Ortega. U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar welcomed the Nicaraguan elections as a ``victory for democracy'' throughout Central America. He said he supported the process but remained neutral on the outcome. Honduras said Mrs. Chamorro's victory would pave the way for improved relations. Nicaragua and Honduras have quarreled over U.S.-backed Contra rebel bases in Honduras. The United States, the Contras and others called for national reconciliation and a peaceful transition of power. But Nicaraguans living in the United States doubted the leftist Sandinista leadership would give up power easily, and European socialists blamed external forces for Ortega's defeat. The official Soviet news agency Tass carried a brief news story out of Managua, the capital of Nicaragua, headlined: ``Opposition Leader Wins Elections in Nicaragua.'' There was no other Soviet reaction initially. U.S. officials welcomed the result and began meetings to review policy on Nicaragua. Besides aiding the rebels, the United States imposed an economic embargo to undermine Nicaragua's economy. President Bush said he spoke with President Carlos Andres Perez of Venezuela about ``appropriate trade and economic measures that we can take to support the new government of Nicaragua.'' Presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said Bush was sending messages to Mrs. Chamorro, congratulating her on her win, and to Ortega, ``congratulating him on the conduct of the election and his stated willingness to abide by the results.'' Aristides Sanchez, a Contra leader, said all Nicaraguans now must work for national reconciliation. ``Because of the international observers and attention, this triumph has to be recognized by the Sandinists and by all Nicaraguans,'' he said. ``It is the first step to achieving a true democracy.'' Former President Jimmy Carter, invited to monitor the balloting, praised Ortega for holding free and fair elections. ``They had total control over the government, over the electoral process,'' Carter told ABC television. ``I think Ortega can go out of office in April ... with a great deal of satisfaction that he has indeed been instrumental in letting the people exhibit democracy and freedom in one of its finest ways in this hemisphere.'' Carter said Ortega promised to abide by the results. But Nicaraguan U.S. residents said they feared the army would reject the vote. ``The results were good, but it's a lie,'' said Barbara Zapata, 26, who left Managua five months ago. ``Daniel (Ortega) will not turn in the weapons.'' Edgar Toruno Raudales, 27, said an opposition government was worthless if the army remains in control of the Sandinistas. ``There could be a coup at any time,'' he said. World leaders called for a peaceful transition of power. President Rafael Leonardo Callejas of Honduras told a news conference he would ``establish appropriate mechanisms to achieve a concrete rapprochement with Nicaragua.'' Argentine President Carlos Menem said the election strengthened democracy throughout Central America. Chile said it would recognize Mrs. Chamorro's victory by inviting her to attend the inauguration next month of its new president, Patricio Aylwin. Ortega had been invited as Nicaragua's head of state. Former President Ronald Reagan, who spearheaded anti-Sandinista policy and support for the Contra rebels, asked that the fighting end. ``Now is the time for all parties to put down their weapons and join in a common pursuit of what is in the best interests of the Nicaraguan people,'' Reagan said. Pierre Guidoni of France's Socialist Party blamed Reagan policies during the 1980s for the Sandinista defeat, saying: ``The Sandinistas had to concentrate their efforts on national defense against armed aggression supported by the United States. They paid today by the ruination of their social project that a war economy could not support.''

DOC.HEAD: Ortega's Acceptance Speech Draws Praise
DOC.TEXT: In the end President Daniel Ortega lost the votes and won the hearts as observers, opposition leaders and Nicaraguans praised his gallant acceptance of defeat. ``It was a noble attitude, honest and genuine,'' said Joao Baena Soares, secretary general of the Organization of American States. Baena Soares also praised the Sandinista president for making it possible for the country to hold a ``clean demcoratic election in a peaceful atmosphere.'' ``It was a responsible attitude,'' said Mauricio Diaz, leader of the Social Christian party. ``He accepted reality. The Sandinistas defeated the Contra militarily, but they could not defeat the economic crisis.'' Edgar Isaac Aguirre, a taxi driver who never liked the Sandinsitas, said of Ortega: ``It was an honorable attitude on his part, the best thing he has done in 10 years of government.'' Hundreds of reporters, international pro-Sandinista solidarity workers and Nicaraguan supporters gathered at the Olaf Palme convention center through the night awaiting definitive elections results. When Ortega arrived shortly after 6 a.m. to concede defeat, many wept. At the end, tears sparkled in his eyes and his wife, Rosario Murillo, hugged him from behind and kissed his cheek. But with a stoicism that marked a dignified and reflective speech resembling nothing more than a valedictory, Ortega held back the tears. The former guerrilla leader whose brother was killed during the insurrection against dictator Anastasio Somoza said quietly, but firmly: ``The president of Nicaragua, the government, will respect and submit itself to the popular mandate that arose from the vote in these elections.'' ``I believe that in this historic moment the principal contribution we Sandinistas, we Nicaraguan revolutionaries, can make to the Nicaragua people is the guarantee of a pure and clean electoral process, which warms our consciences,'' Ortega said. ``Would that this sun rising this 26th of February illuminate the path toward the consolidation of democracy, of a mixed economy, of a free Nicaragua independent and democratic, in peace, not interfered with by any foreign power, in which all Nicaraguans would be able to demonstrate to the world that we can make these dreams and hopes come true.'' It was a moment of grace deeply appreciated by listeners and followers in a country of guerrilla bravado and a region not used to graceful acceptance of electoral defeats. Only last year, in neighboring Panama the military regime of Manuel Antonio Noriega annulled a presidential election because its candidate had lost it. ``We must recognize Daniel's gesture,'' said Agustin Jarquin, a member of the executive committee of the political council of the United National Opposition, whose candidate, Violeta Barrios de Chamorro, won the election. ``The Sandinistas must orient their followers so we can achieve national reconciliation.'' While there were words of praise and thanks for his companions in the Sandinista government, he did not speak of his own political future or the party's future _ whether there would be an attempt at reconciliation or a clash. Nor did he mention the United States and its long record of hostility, except as a sidelight and object of Sandinista struggle. He and his colleagues, many with clenched fists raised, withdrew from the hall to the strains of the Sandinista hymn and the refrain ``Free fatherland, victory or death.''

DOC.HEAD: Fistfight Breaks Out In Taiwan's National Assembly
DOC.TEXT: A brawl broke out in the electoral college on Monday _the third in eight days _ when opposition members challenged the qualifications of some elderly colleagues from the governing Nationalist Party. The protests are over the domination of the electoral college, known as the National Assembly, and the Legislature by aging Nationalists. On Monday, Huang Chao-hui of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party pushed fellow Assemblyman Hsiung Chi-ho, 76, and threatened to throw him out of the meeting. Nationalist Assemblyman Lee Hua-yang grabbed Huang's necktie. Huang punched back and the two rolled on the floor as others joined the pushing and shouting. The 752-seat National Assembly includes 646 members who last ran for office on the Chinese mainland shortly before 1949, when they fled here with the rest of the Nationalist government after it lost a civil war to Communist forces. Most of the senior members were runners-up in the mainland elections but filled seats vacated by the death of the original winner. They have not faced re-election in Taiwan because the Nationalists claim to still be the legitimate government of all China. Opposition Assemblyman Tsai Shih-yuan challenged the qualifications of 15 assembly members he claimed did not participate in the mainland elections. At one point, opposition members tried to shove 80-year-old Assemblywoman Liu Hsiang-ku from the meeting room, but stopped when she showed a certificate proving she was elected on the mainland. Opposition members, who hold only 11 seats, staged a violent protest on Feb. 19 when the electoral college began its one-month session. Days later, a riot in which scores were injured broke out around the Legislature.

DOC.HEAD: Bright and Brief
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf of GENOA, Nev.-dated 1st item to CORRECT spelling of actor's name to Caan, sted Cann.
DOC.TEXT: Nevada's oldest town finally has a gas station, but not for long. And more than 80 outsiders have taken up residence, including actor James Caan, but they're just temporary too. Genoa, renamed Silver Creek, Colo., for the time being, will be the setting for director Rob Reiner's latest movie, ``Misery,'' based on horror writer Stephen King's novel about a writer imprisoned by an insane woman. Since Hollywood's arrival last week, this town of about 400 residents nestling at the foot of the Sierra Nevada 10 miles south of Carson City has been transformed. A new sign at Genoa's main intersection reads ``Welcome to Silver Creek. Established 1851,'' a year after the real town was founded. However, anyone who pulls up to the new ``gas station'' will find that the pumps don't work. The new pay telephone outside Stan and Bobby's Sporting Goods, Liquor, and Video Rental store doesn't work, either. Shirley Giovacchini, whose home serves as the store, said only one disgruntled visitor has tried to use it so far. But the four new buildings on Main Street built by the film crew aren't fake. Genoa now has a cafe, general store, radiator shop and sheriff's station. Reiner is shooting the film on a closed set off limits to the public and media, and has hired about 100 locals as extras. Genoa was picked for the movie because the town is a day's drive from Los Angeles and resembles the fictional Colorado town in King's book, Enochs said.

DOC.HEAD: Early Returns Show Runoffs Needed
DOC.TEXT: Runoffs will be necessary in at least three of the four Soviet republics that held their first free legislative elections this weekend, unofficial returns indicated Monday. Tass said runoffs would be held in the Baltic republic of Lithuania, where the Communist Party was voted out of power, and in the Central Asian republics of Tadzhikistan and Kirghizia. It said preliminary results were not available for Moldavia, where the Popular Front has said it hoped to win at least half the 380 seats in the republic's legislature. Sajudis, the Lithuanian popular front, apeared to have won Saturday's elections by a landslide, according to Tass, the official Soviet news agency. Unofficial returns Sunday indicated Sajudis candidates won 72 of the 90 seats decided and the remaining 51 legislators are to be chosen in runoffs March 10. Tass said official results were expected Tuesday. The goal of Sajudis is to make Lithuania independent, as it was for 22 years before 1940, and negotiate an orderly secession with Moscow. The Soviet Union annexed Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia in 1940, under a secret agreement with Nazi Germany. In the Central Asian republics of Tadzhikistan and Kirghizia, candidates fell short of majorities in more than half the districts. Tass said Kirghizia, a mountainous republic on the border with China, would conduct runoffs early in March, but did not give details. It indicated a similar schedule for Tadzhikistan, where at least 22 people were killed in recent ethnic unrest. Reports from Dushanbe, capital of Tadzhikistan, said the election turnout was 64 percent. Tass said official results in both Central Asian elections were expected Thursday. It said no early returns were available from Moldavia, which borders Romania and has ethnic and cultural roots to that country. The Moldavian Popular Front has said it would press for the right of direct trade with other countries, a multiparty system, private property and a market economy.

DOC.HEAD: At Least 35 Dead as High Winds Hit Europe
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 3 grafs after 10th pvs, `In Ireland...' to UPDATE with town in Wales evacuated, details. Pickup 11th pvs, `Police imposed...'
DOC.TEXT: Gale-force winds struck Europe on Monday, tearing down roofs and power lines, disrupting transportation on land, sea and air, and killing at least 35 people. Winds were clocked at 100 mph at Aberporth along the Scottish border, while Leeds in central England reported winds of up to 98 mph. It was the second major storm to hit Europe since Jan. 25, when 95 people were killed in winds that gusted up to 106 mph. Wind speeds in late January and February were the strongest in 18 years, averaging 15 mph the last two weeks at Heathrow Airport, the London Weather Center said. Flood warnings were posted on the north coast of West Germany and parts of Denmark. Fishing boats were kept in port on France's west coast. Twelve deaths were reported in Britain, seven in West Germany and two in East Germany, five in Belgium, seven in France, and one each in Ireland and the Netherlands. The dead included a driver whose double-decker bus hit a fallen tree, an elderly man killed by a falling chimney and an elderly woman struck by a chunk of slate blown from a roof, police and rescue workers said. A policeman on patrol in suburban Brussels was killed and a colleague was injured when a tree was blown onto their car. In northeastern Damme, Belgium, the roof of the tourism office collapsed, killing one worker and injuring another. Two people died when their home collapsed in Bekkevoort, Belgium. A motorist was also killed by a tree in Embourg near Liege. In Hamburg, West Germany, a 76-year-old woman was killed when winds pushed her in front of a moving car. The dead in France included a 3-year-old girl killed by a falling branch in Avesnes sur Helpes. In the suburbs of Paris, where winds peaked at 75 mph, a 22-year-old man was killed by a falling wall and a 17-year-old was fatally injured by a slamming door. In Ireland, a motorcyclist was killed when a gust blew him off the road; a woman died in Zundert, in the southern Netherlands, when she lost control of her car during the storm. In the North Wales seaside town of Towyn, police were evacuating 2,000 people threatened by a high tide. Huge waves smashed a 200-yard hole in the sea wall and sent a torrent cascading through the streets, flooding homes. Four Royal Air Force helicopters began evacuating people soon after midday, but with a midnight high tide threatening to engulf the town, lifeboats, fishing vessels and other craft were called in. A spokesman for Bodelwyddan Hospital, where many of the Towyn people were taken, said 30 people had been brought in suffering hypothermia and shock, and ``a further 70 or so have been brought here by the helicopters simply because they have lost their homes.'' Police imposed a 50 mph speed limit in some areas in Britain, and the Automobile Association advised motorists to stay home. Many other traffic accidents were reported in northern Belgium and in the western Netherlands. In the Netherlands, 15 people were injured, including seven hurt when a huge tent in which they were celebrating Carnival collapsed in the southern town of Beek, Dutch radio reported. The winds disrupted ferry service between Ireland and Wales, as well as between the British mainland and the Isle of Wight and Northern Ireland. One Belfast-Liverpool ferry was forced to return to port because of high seas. In Hull, on Britain's west coast, damaged inner lock gates at King George Dock prevented two ferries from Rotterdam, the Netherlands, and Zeebrugge, Belgium, with about 1,000 passengers on board, from docking. The ferries were waiting offshore until high tide Monday night. In the port of Antwerp, a river ship sank after a 15-ton crane fell onto the vessel, injuring several people. Cuts in the overhead power lines halted some train traffic in Belgium, the state-owned railroad company said. Two bridges linking the southern and northern parts of the Netherlands were closed because of high winds, police said. Thousands of homes in Northern Ireland, the Thames Valley, south Wales and southwestern England were without electricity. Thirty residents of a senior citizens home in Stockport, near Manchester, were evacuated after the roof was blown off during the night, according to Press Association, the domestic British news agency. Rail service on the main line from Euston Station in London to the northwest was disrupted by downed power lines. British Rail reported scattered cancellations, and some trains were restricted to speeds as low as 20 mph because of the winds. At Heathrow Airport, many airlines were unable to load catered meals onto airplanes, and passengers were instead offered meals in the departure lounges. Authorities feared winds could blow over the trucks that lift trays of prepared meals onto aircraft. Flights were operating normally, but were canceled at Birmingham Airport, 100 miles to the northwest. At Amsterdam's Schiphol airport, the Netherlands' flag carrier KLM suspended 15 international flights, the airline said.

DOC.HEAD: ABC Home Video Special Beats Rooney-Less 60 Minutes
DOC.TEXT: CBS's usually top-rated ``60 Minutes'' came in second Sunday to a rerun of the one-hour premiere of ABC's ``America's Funniest Home Videos, preliminary ratings from A.C. Nielsen Co. showed Monday. CBS, however, dismissed speculation that the ratings loss was a result of the network's suspension of humorist Andy Rooney. ``It's stretching things to blame it on the absence of Rooney,'' said Michael Eisenberg, CBS vice president for research. Acccording to overnight ratings from 23 cities, ABC's rerun got a 31 per cent share of the audience and ``60 Minutes'' a 27 per cent share. NBC was a distant third with an 11 per cent share with a shortened version of the 1951 Disney cartoon classic, ``Alice in Wonderland.'' National audience estimates are due on Tuesday. Eisenberg said ABC's show, first was shown on Nov. 26, was a strong one and the half-hour series that followed it has proved a ratings hit. Sunday's ABC show aired in the time period usually held by ``Life Goes On.' Rooney, a ``60 Minutes'' feature since 1978, was suspended without pay for three months on Feb. 8 after a national gay magazine attributed a racial slur to him. Rooney denied making the remark. CBS News president David Burke never has given a specific reason publicly for Rooney's suspension.

DOC.HEAD: Air Force Man Injured in Emergency Landing
DOC.TEXT: An Israeli Air Force serviceman was slightly injured Monday when his Cessna plane was forced to make an emergency landing in the occupied Gaza Strip, the military command said. The plane, with two Air Force servicemen aboard, took off from an airfield in Israel for a routine training flight but developed a technical problem and had to make the emergency landing on a Gaza airstrip, the army said. It said the wounded serviceman was taken to a hospital in the southern town of Ashkelon. His companion suffered no injuries. No further details about the accident were released.

DOC.HEAD: Rocky Statue Loses Art Museum Battle
DOC.TEXT: It took three guys using a diamond-edged power saw and a jackhammer to knock Rocky Balboa off his feet Monday. The crew worked for more than two hours to separate the 8{-foot bronze likeness of the city's fictitious boxer from the steps of the Philadelphia Museum of Art, which has repeatedly insisted it doesn't want the statue. A lawyer for ``Rocky'' creator Sylvester Stallone pledged to fight on to get the statue, a movie prop, a permanent home atop the museum steps. In the original ``Rocky,'' which won best picture and best director Academy Awards in 1976, Stallone's Balboa character ran up the museum's stone steps in triumph while training for a fight. The statue had been moved to the museum from the Spectrum sports arena for the filming of Stallone's latest ``Rocky'' movie, ``Rocky V.'' Since filming of ``Rocky V'' ended here Friday, that cleared the way for the movie producers to move Stallone's likeness, at the museum's insistence. Using the power saw, the crew from W. Cantano & Sons cut into the statue's concrete base about 12 inches below Rocky's 22-inch feet to get at four prongs anchoring the statue into the concrete. After separating the 800-pound statue from the base, workers used a crane to lift it onto a truck. The stub of the concrete base was to be removed within hours. ``I feel kind of bad,'' said Bret Carpin of Cantano, which has moved the statue four times in the continuing battle between art and fiction. ``I hope he doesn't hold it against us.'' The museum was closed Monday, as usual, but the statue moving drew a crowd of television crews, photographers, curious museum employees and a few tourists. Amy Crackel from Decatur, Ill., came with her aunt, Susan, of Wayne, to see Rocky. ``It was neat to come the day they're moving it,'' she said, adding she has seen all four Rocky movies and plans to see the fifth. The statue will be placed in storage at the Spectrum until a new base can be built there, said Spectrum spokeswoman Debbie Albert. Stallone's lawyer, former state boxing commissioner James Binns, said the statue's removal ``really has nothing to do with where the statue will end up permanently. We will argue to have it moved back to the art museum.'' Fans protested the move. Even Mayor W. Wilson Goode supported leaving the statue at the museum. But museum officials have noted the statue's disproportionately large feet and overall small size relative to the museum in saying it was not an appropriate home. The statue was first placed in front of the museum for the filming of ``Rocky III'' and left there after the movie opened in 1982. Museum officials then said Stallone failed to remove it from their front steps as agreed, and the museum had to pay $12,000 to get it moved to the sports arena. When museum officials were approached about returning the statue for the fourth sequel, they demanded an agreement that the production company remove the statue when filming was over.

DOC.HEAD: Sandinista Groupies Shout Down Carter, Richardson
With AM-Nicaragua, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: When President Daniel Ortega admitted his defeat at the polls early Monday, most of those applauding him, singing the Sandinista Front anthem and crying their eyes out were Sandalistas. Sandalistas are the battalions of idealistic foreigners, mainly Americans and Western Europeans, who came to Nicaragua after the Sandinista revolution of July 1979. Nicaraguans gave them their nickname because of their fondness for thick leather sandals, part of a sort of uniform by which Sandalistas can be recognized at a distance. It was these foreigners who shouted catcalls and obscenities a few hours later in the same convention hall, when former U.S. President Jimmy Carter, U.N. observer mission chief Elliot Richardson and others held a news conference on the elections. ``The U.S. put the pressure on and the people had no choice'' but to vote for opposition presidential candidate Violeta Barrios de Chamorro, said Monika von Flotow. Ms. von Flotow, 33, a physical therapist from Santa Rosa, Calif., has been working for the past year in Matiguas, a small town deep in central Matagalpa province. It is in the midst of Contra territory, where people often are maimed by land mines or in skirmishes between rebels and soldiers. ``I don't think people were proud of how they voted,'' said Ms. von Flotow, her eyes red from weeping after Ortega's moving speech. Margo Malone, 29, of Bellingham, Wash., climbed atop a desk to see Ortega as he spoke. She hugged a friend and sobbed as the last strains of the Sandinista National Liberation Front anthem, the one with a line calling ``the Yankee, the enemy of humanity,'' filled the hall. ``The United States has shown that it can destroy a really important process, a really important revolution,'' said Ms. Malone, who has been in Nicaragua four months on her first visit. Not all Sandalistas dress alike. Ms. von Flotow, for example, has a conservative, unadorned look. But by and large, Sandalista woman can be recognized by flowing Indian print skirts and cotton tank tops; the men by often frayed pants and ancient T-shirts. For both sexes, however, it is cotton everything; a knapsack on every back; a look of blissful wonder at the natives and, for many, a feeling that the United States is ``the enemy of humanity.'' They often have little money for themselves, but have organized a worldwide ``solidarity'' network that has raised millions of dollars for the Sandinista government and organized pressure campaigns to bear upon the U.S. Congress and other governments. Nicaraguans have a low opinion of Sandalistas because of their unquestioning idealization of the Sandinistas and because many of them apparently have no little time to bath in Nicaragua's tropical heat. At a news conference by Carter, Richardson and other invited election observers, ``internationalistas,'' as the Sandinistas are also called, created a spectacle. They hammered on desks and booed at Carter when he said, ``I don't try to justify the actions of our government,'' answering a question as to why Washington continues supporting the Contras. Richardson, a former U.S. attorney general, was interrupted with obscene catcalls when he said he thought the United States would have normalized relations with the Sandinistas had Ortega won the elections.

DOC.HEAD: Rebels Claim Troops Launched Major Offensive
DOC.TEXT: Mozambican rebels claimed Monday that government forces backed by Zimbabwean troops and planes have launched a major offensive against guerrilla positions in central Mozambique. A statement distributed in the Portuguese capital by the Mozambican National Resistance said 2,500 Mozambican and Zimbabwean troops attacked rebel strongholds in the Gorongoza highlands Monday in Sofala province. The statement said the offensive was spearheaded by troops carried by Zimbabwean transport planes and backed by Soviet-built combat planes and helicopters. The Mozambican news agency AIM reported Saturday that government forces had destroyed four rebel camps the past week, one in Sofala and three in the south. The AIM report said 57 rebels were killed in the actions, but gave no indication these were major operations. AIM made no mention of Zimbabwean troops. Rebel leader Afonso Dhlakama is thought to have his headquarters in Gorongoza, 560 miles north of the capital Maputo. The rebels, who are also known by the Portuguese acronym Renamo, said a column of infantry and artillery was supporting the airborne troops. There was no independent confirmation of the rebel claims. The Renamo statement said the attack showed the ``bad faith'' of Zimbabwean President Robert Mugabe, who together with his Kenyan counterpart Daniel arap Moi has been attempting to mediate tentative peace moves to end 13 years of fighting in Mozambique. Despite intermittent talks between Renamo officials and Mozambican church leaders in Nairobi, Kenya, since last July, reports of violent clashes have continued. Earlier this month, the government accused Renamo of killing over 50 civilians in an attack on a train bringing Mozambican miners from work in neighboring South Africa. The rebels have faced repeated accusations of civilian massacres since they launched their insurgency in 1977, two years after Mozambique gained independence from Portugal. South Africa formerly supported the rebels, but since a 1984 accord between Maputo and Pretoria no government openly backs the rebels.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Committee May Act Quickly on Alaska Forest
DOC.TEXT: The chairman of the Senate committee that oversees the Tongass National Forest in Alaska said Monday he plans fast action on legislation affecting timber deals and wilderness protection there. Sen. Bennett Johnston, D-La., said ``Individuals might propose dramatically different solutions to the Tongass issue,'' but ``they almost all agree that what is needed most in southeast Alaska is certainty.'' The size of West Virginia and Delaware combined, the forest is treasured by environmentalists as a habitat for grizzly bear and bald eagles, and the largest spawning ground for salmon. It is the last remaining temperate-zone rain forest in North America. To local residents, it is the keystone of their economy through the timber it yields. The jobs-environment conflict has made the forest one of the most vigorously fought environmental issues in Congress since 1980, when Alaska lands legislation established the current forest management regime. During a hearing on legislation the House passed last summer, Johnston said he would have a Senate bill ready for a committee vote next week and fast floor action ``in hopes of getting to conference with the House and resolving these issues once and for all.'' The House measure would cancel 50-year contracts with two timber companies who supportrs of the bill say stifled other competition while getting trees at bargain rates. Rep. George Miller, D-Calif., who led the House debate for the bill called the contracts ``a raid on the taxpayers.'' Critics have claimed that the government in recent years has wound up getting $2 in revenue for $100 in timber production costs. Miller and other supporters said the legislation would open the forest to other companies and make more money for the government. It also strengthens restrictions on timbering in order to protect the wildlife habitat. Sen. Frank Murkowski, R-Alaska, said he and the rest of the Alaska delegation, Sen. Ted Stevens and Rep. Don Young, all oppose the House bill, which he says would cripple the economy of southeastern Alaska. Murkowski said the government is not losing money on Tongass timber sales and expanded wilderness areas in the forest are not needed. ``The purpose of our fight now is to maintain the viablity of Alaska communities whose lifeblood is the resources produced on public lands,'' said Murkowski, who has introduced a bill that preserves the 50-year contracts with Louisiana Pacific-Ketchikan and Alaska Pulp Co., a Japanese firm. Murkowski said the committee should postpone action on Tongass until June when the Forest Service will release a revised plan for the forest. Patricia Kearney, acting assistant secretary of agriculture for forests, said the service spent $7 million and two years working on the plan and urged that it be considered before Congress takes final action on how to manage the forest.

DOC.HEAD: Extra MH-47E Boeing Helicopters Unneeded
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Corrects name of manufacturer in 3rd graf: ``The General,'' from Boeing Vertol to Boeing division; SUBS last graf to note Boeing involvement in V-22
DOC.TEXT: The Defense Department's plan to buy 34 additional helicopters for commando missions at an estimated cost of $532 million lacks a ``sound mission-based justification,'' a congressional report said Monday. The Defense Department disagreed, saying plans to cancel a new vertical takeoff airplane make the additional helicopters necessary. The General Accounting Office said the Army based its decision to buy 34 MH-47E helicopters from The Boeing Co.'s Philadelphia-based Helicopters Division, in addition to its own needs of 17, on a May 1984 agreement between the Army and the Air Force. The accord said the Air Force would transfer the responsibility for providing helicopter support for commando operations to the Army. But in June 1987, the Defense Department told Congress that it had revised its requirements and only needed 17 MH-47E helicopters, and 41 MH-53J helicopters, to fly these missions of about 265 to 520 miles. ``The Army's reason for procuring an additional 34 MH-47E aircraft is based on an earlier memorandum of agreement between the Air Force and the Army, which has been superseded by the 1987 report,'' the GAO said. ``Therefore, we believe that the procurement of an additional 34 MH-47E aircraft at a total cost of $532 million is not warranted'' and ``without sound mission-based justification.'' Sen. William Roth, R-Del., who requested the GAO report, said the helicopters are needed to transport troops in and out of hostile territory, but the GAO was ``quite blunt in its conclusion.'' The Defense Department, in comments on a draft of the GAO report, disagreed with the agency's conclusion, saying it needed the additional helicopters because of the Bush administration's proposal to cancel the V-22 Osprey tilt-rotor vertical takeoff airplane, a joint project of Boeing and Bell Helicopter Textron.

DOC.HEAD: Family Bids Private Farewell To Forbes
DOC.TEXT: A bagpiper played ``Scotland the Brave'' at a private funeral Monday for Malcolm Forbes, the multi-millionaire publisher known for selling the joy of capitalism. The service for Forbes, who has been mourned by business leaders and socialites worldwide, was attended only by immediate family at The Church of St. John on the Mountain in this rustic borough 50 miles west of New York, where Forbes Inc. is headquartered. Forbes, the son of a poor Scottish family who emigrated to the United States and worked his way to affluence on Wall Street, died of a heart attack in his sleep Saturday at his 40-acre estate in nearby Far Hills. He was 70. His son Malcolm Jr. or ``Steve,'' who will succeed him as head of the publishing empire, delivered the eulogy, the Rev. Alfred Niese, pastor of the episcopal church, told The Courier-News of Bridgewater. Niese, who presided over services, would not give details about the ceremony. Niese said family members have attended the church since the late 1950s. Present at the funeral were Forbes' former wife Roberta; daughter Moira Mumma; four sons, Steve, Robert, Christopher and Timothy; and eight grandchildren. Forbes, whose worth has been placed anywhere from $400 million to $1 billion, was known as much for his recreational derring-do as a motorcyclist and balloonist as he was for his business acumen. He also was a lavish party-thrower and made his last birthday his biggest. Following a 1\-hour ceremony Monday, Forbes' flag-draped pine coffin was carried by his sons and grandsons to a hearse. His body is to be cremated and interred on the Fiji island of Lucala, owned by the Forbes family. A public memorial service was scheduled for 11 a.m. Thursday at St. Bartholomew's Church in Manhattan.

DOC.HEAD: Armored Cars Move in As Students Strike
DOC.TEXT: Armored cars and troops were deployed in the center of the capital Monday as student demonstrators armed with sticks and broken bottles forced newly reopened schools to close. There were no immediate reports of serious incidents or injuries. Air traffic controllers went on strike during the day, halting domestic and international flights. Postal and telecommunications workers and electricity workers also stopped work, cutting telephone links in the capital and power supply to some quarters of Gabon. President Omar Bongo, assailed by a failed coup attempt in October and violent student protests last month, was meeting with a crisis committee formed last week to try to dissolve social tension that has mounted under a 17-month-old austerity program. The strikes and protests indicate dissatisfaction with major political reforms announced by Bongo on Friday, including the creation of a Social Democratic Assembly to replace his discredited Democratic Party. Bongo told the nation in a televised address Friday that the new assembly would be open to all political ideas. But it falls short of his earlier promises to consider transforming Gabon into a multiparty democracy. After a weekend respite from strikes and protests, students took to the streets Monday with broken bottles and sticks. They forced newly reopened schools in the capital to close. A panic ensued at one school and students scuffled, but no injuries were reported. Some students set up barricades on roads. They were forced to disperse by soldiers and police, according to witnesses who provided no details. The elite Presidential Guard set up temporary camps in the March 12 suburb on the outskirts of the city where the National Assembly is located as well as the homes of many diplomats and high-ranking government officials. Last week, teachers, doctors and nurses stopped strikes to protest poor salaries and working conditions after Bongo promised a general review of government salaries at the end of the year. Under an austerity program imposed as a condition of further credit from Western nations and institutions, Gabonese government employees were forced to take pay cuts averaging 3 percent in October 1988. Other government spending also was reduced sharply, including the budget for education and health.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Hails Ortega Defeat; Officials Talk of Lifting Sanctions
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 11th graf: ``In Riverside,'' with Quayle praising Contras
DOC.TEXT: President Bush hailed Violeta Chamorro's upset election in Nicaragua as a ``clear mandate for peace and democracy'' Monday, and his spokesman said Bush wanted to lift U.S. trade sanctions that have hobbled the country's economy. Bush said the vote to oust leftist President Daniel Ortega ``moves us one step closer to the day when every nation in this hemisphere is a democracy.'' He called for a peaceful transfer of power from the Sandinista government that has ruled for 10 years. In a message aimed both at the Sandinistas and the U.S.-supported army of Contra rebels who tried to overthrow the government, Bush said, ``Given the clear mandate for peace and democracy, there is no reason at all for further military activity from any quarter.'' Later Monday, the president phoned Mrs. Chamorro to congraulate her on her victory. ``The president said the election reinforces the Nicaraguan people's commitment to the peace process and towards building a free and open society,'' said White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater. Bush told Mrs. Chamorro the election was ``a great day for the Nicaraguan people,'' Fitzwater said. The spokesman said Bush also discussed the situation with a number of allied leaders. There were immediate calls in Congress for aid for Mrs. Chamorro's government, which is to be inaugurated April 25. ``We must provide her new government with aid, and let's not kid ourselves _ it will take big bucks,'' said Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole, R-Kan. ``Nobody said democracy was cheap,'' said House Foreign Affairs Committee Chairman Dante Fascell, D-Fla. However, others cautioned that with a growing line of potential new foreign aid recipients _ Poland, Hungary, Czechoslovakia, Panama and others _ it would be difficult to promise any quick, major grants. Mrs. Chamorro's election was a sweet victory for the U.S. government, which had spent hundreds of millions of dollars in military and other assistance to arm the Contras and keep them going, and had also clamped economic sanctions on Nicaragua. In Riverside, Calif., Vice President Dan Quayle praised the Contras, saying, ``The Contras were an important force throughout to bring democracy.'' Ortega was a major irritant to the White House, and a frequent target of derision from presidents Reagan and Bush. As recently as October, Bush ridiculed Ortega at a summit of Latin leaders in Costa Rica as ``this little man'' and as ``that unwanted animal at a garden party.'' Changing his tune, Bush publicly congratulated Ortega Monday for allowing a free and fair election and pledging to abide by its results. Moreover, Bush said there is ``space in a democratic Nicaragua for all political points of view.'' Reagan, whose administration played a major role in arming the Contras, said that ``the people of Nicaragua and the cause of democracy have won an impressive and important victory'' and that ``now is the time for all parties to put down their weapons and join in a common pursuit of what is in the best interests of the Nicaraguan people.'' American supporters of the Sandinista government expressed disappointment at the election outcome but also said that the election was fair. The Rev. William Sloane Coffin said, ``The vote was largely one to end the killing, a vote for peace that the United States had shattered for years by arming the Contras. ... It was also a vote for food which our unilateral embargo had helped deny Nicaraguan families.'' Secretary of State James A. Baker III pointedly said the international community ``will insist that the decision of the Nicaraguan people be respected and that full civil and military power be transferred to the newly elected government.'' Bush said, ``We hope that all sides in this hotly fought contest will extend the hand of reconciliation and cooperate together in rebuilding their country for the good of all Nicaraguans.'' He said he had talked with Venezuelan President Carlos Andres Perez about ``appropriate trade and economic measures that we can take to support the new government of Nicaragua.'' White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said Bush wanted the lift U.S. sanctions ``as soon as it is feasible.'' He said he expected there would be a decision fairly soon. The sanctions will expire May 1 unless Bush extends them. Some officials are recommending Bush lift them much sooner if the Sandinistas show a disposition to respect the election results. These officials contend that early action on the sanctions would enable Nicaragua to get a head start on economic recovery. ``We certainly feel a special responsibility for the people of Nicaragua and the courageous actions that they have taken to bring these elections about,'' Fitzwater said. He also suggested the White House will seek more humanitarian aid for the Contras, many of whom are camped just outside Nicaragua in Honduras, after their U.S. funds run out this week. The trade embargo against Nicaragua was imposed on May 1, 1985, by then-President Reagan. It barred imports from Nicaragua and banned U.S. exports to that country except to support the Contra rebels. It also prohibited Nicaraguan aircraft or boats from entering the United States. Mrs. Chamorro, 60, the publisher of the opposition newspaper La Prensa, had been criticized by Ortega as an instrument of U.S. policy. She headed the United Nationalist Opposition, a fractious alliance of 14 parties ranging from far right to far left. ``Any friend of democracy can take heart in the fact that Violeta Chamorro won the election, and the election process ... is a credit to the people of Nicaragua, who chose to determine their nation's future at the ballot box,'' Bush said. ``And that is a victory for democracy.'' Bush said, ``For years the people of Nicaragua have suffered. And today the people of Nicaragua have spoken.'' The president learned of Mrs. Chamorro's victory in a 4:30 a.m. telephone call from Baker. Baker, in turn, had been called 15 minutes earlier by former President Jimmy Carter in Managua, where he was leading a team of election observers. Fitzwater said Bush called British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, French President Francois Mitterrand and Mexican President Carlos Salinas ``to thank them for the support they had exhibited over the past months for the return to a democratic process in Nicaragua.'' And Canadian Prime Minister Brian Mulroney called Bush to discuss the election and to voice support for ``the transfer to democratic rule,'' Fitzwater said. Fitzwater said that Bush, in meetings through the day with top aides on the election outcome, ``was very calm and concerned that we give full credit to the people of Nicaragua.''

DOC.HEAD: Small Temblor in Eastern Sierra
DOC.NOTE: Eds: RETRANSMITTING to fix cycle designator.
