DOC.TEXT: A small earthquake shook the eastern slope of the Sierra Nevada on Monday morning. No damage was immediately reported. Seismologists at California Institute of Technology in Pasadena registered the 7:17 a.m. temblor at 3.5 on the Richter scale, while the United States Geological Service at Menlo Park had a 3.9 reading. The epicenter was 17 miles southeast of Mammoth Lakes and 20 miles west-northwest of Bishop. The Richter scale is a measure of ground motion as recorded on seismographs. Every increase of one number means a tenfold increase in magnitude. An earthquake of 3.5 on the Richter scale can cause slight damage in the local area, 4 moderate damage.

DOC.HEAD: New Federal Flag Burning Law Upheld in Minnesota Case
DOC.TEXT: A U.S. appeals court on Monday upheld the conviction of a demonstrator who burned an American flag, but the justices did not rule on the constitutionality of a new federal law outlawing flag burning. A federal judge in Seattle has ruled the law unconstitutional and the Justice Department said Friday it would appeal directly to the Supreme Court. The demonstrator in Monday's case, William Charles Cary Jr., was sentenced to three months in prison and fined $25 for his role in the flag burning during a March 18, 1988, protest against U.S. involvement in Honduras. The demonstration in Minneapolis was outside an armed services recruitment center and the blazing flag was thrown into the occupied center, the 8th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals noted. Cary appealed, challenging the constitutionality of the federal statute that prohibits flag burning, which was passed after the U.S. Supreme Court struck down a similar Texas flag desecration statute as unconstitutional because it suppressed free expression. In Monday's 2-1 decision, a panel of the 8th Circuit said Cary's conviction was justified by the federal government's interest in halting and preventing further breaches of peace in front of its Armed Services Recruitment Center. The court noted that it was not affirming the conviction on the same grounds that the lower court based its ruling on. It said the lower court appeared to have upheld the constitutionality of the flag statute based upon a government interest in protecting the flag as a national symbol. According to the 8th Circuit opinion, written by Judge Frank Magill, the demonstration in Minneapolis attracted several hundred people opposed to the government's decision to send 3,200 troops to Honduras. The court said the demonstration turned violent in front of the recruitment center, as protesters broke windows and shot Roman candles through them. After Cary lit the flag, he threw it into an alcove of the recruitment center, the court said. Several other people rushed to put it out because of fears that the flames might ignite the occupied building, the court's opinion said. ``Cary's conduct demonstrated an intent to convey his disagreement with American foreign policy in Central America,'' the court wrote. Therefore, the court said, Cary's conduct was in the realm of free expression protected by the First Amendment. ``However, unlike (the Texas case), the government's interest in preventing breaches of the peace is implicated by the facts in this case. ... Because of the ongoing violence, there was an immediate threat that the burning would encourage the violence to continue,'' the court wrote. In his dissenting opinion, Circuit Judge Theodore McMillian said he believed the case was controlled by the Supreme Court's decision in the Texas case. ``The First Amendment prohibits the government from criminally punishing appellant for burning the flag of the United States as a means of politcal protest. Accordingly, I would reverse the judgment of the District Court,'' he wrote.

DOC.HEAD: Airplane Designer Burt Rutan Shows Off New Low-Cost Combat Jet
LaserPhoto LA13, LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: Burt Rutan, who designed the revolutionary Voyager airplane that circled the globe without refueling, showed off his new high-tech, low-cost combat jet on Monday, and the Air Force was impressed. More than 400 people turned out at Mojave Airport to watch the Ares aircraft go through its paces after emerging from Rutan's Scaled Composites Inc. hangar in the high desert. The lightweight, easy-to-maintain plane proved its agility in a 10-minute demonstration flight that marked only the fifth time the sleek gray, white and blue aircraft has been flown. ``It handled real comfortably,'' pilot Doug Shane said afterwards. ``It's very maneuverable, extremely agile.'' ``I'm interested in it from an innovative technology point of view,'' said Air Force Maj. Gen. John Schoeppner Jr. ``It's quite fascinating. I'm very excited about his design.'' The twin-tailed aircraft is powered by a single turbofan engine, and is made of composites, non-metallic materials such as graphite, which are strong but are not as heavy as traditional aviation metals. The plane's most distinctive feature is a Rutan specialty: a canard, or small wing, emerging from the fuselage forward of the main wing. Possible uses for the plane, which was three years in the making, include stopping drug smugglers, close air support operations and anti-helicopter missions. The aircraft is designed to be fitted with a 25mm gun or air-to-air and air-to-ground missiles. In a news release, Scaled Composites said the jet can provide ``minimum complexity, maintenance and acquisition costs to armies and air forces worldwide.'' Rutan refused to give a price for the plane. ``I can't talk about potential customers,'' he said. The plane's name comes from the Greek god of war, but is used as an acronym for capabilities and qualities the builder believes will sell it: Agile, Responsive, Effective Support. Rutan gained fame for designing Voyager, the ungainly, slender airplane that his brother, Dick, and co-pilot Jeana Yeager flew around the world non-stop on a single tank of fuel. Rutan used lightweight composite carbon-fiber materials, a canard design and fuel-stingy engines to allow Voyager to stay aloft the nine days it took to complete the 25,000-mile flight in December 1986.

DOC.HEAD: Attorney: Top Noriega Co-Defendant Negotiating Guilty Plea
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS 6 grafs to UPDATE with further arguments, judge not ruling; no pickup.
DOC.TEXT: A key co-defendant of Manuel Noriega is negotiating a plea bargain that could put him on the stand against his former boss, a defense attorney said Monday. ``The discussions are making good progress,'' said Samuel Burstyn, attorney for former Panamanian army Lt. Col. Luis del Cid. ``At some point, the lieutenant colonel may be confronted with an option he can't refuse.'' Burstyn refused to reveal details, except to say the proposed sentence would be far less than the 40 years del Cid was offered when taken into custody on drug-trafficking charges. And he added that the deal had not yet been signed. Assistant U.S. Attorney Michael Sullivan refused to comment on the possibility of a plea bargain. Noriega attorney Steven Kollin said the plea bargaining caught his defense team by surprise, and refused immediate comment. ``When he gets the plea, then we'll worry about it,'' said another Noriega attorney, David Lewis. A source involved in the case who spoke on condition of anonymity said one proposal would have del Cid serving as little as two to four years in prison in return for cooperation against the ousted Panamanian dictator. If convicted of all charges in the February 1988 indictment, del Cid could be sentenced to 70 years in prison. After his surrender in the wake of the December invasion of Panama, del Cid was identified by the U.S. government as one of Noriega's right-hand men. Burstyn would not confirm that del Cid would take the stand against his former boss, but noted that once he pleaded guilty he could not refuse a prosecution subpoena. The indictment against Noriega accuses del Cid of accepting $200,000 in drug payoff money from the government's star witness, pilot Floyd Carlton Caceres. The payoff came shortly after Carlton and Noriega fixed the price of a cocaine shipment they were making on behalf of the Medellin cocaine cartel, authorities said. Del Cid also appeared in a photograph at the side of Fidel Castro and Noriega in Cuba _ a meeting prosecutors claim was to smooth relations between the Panamanian leader and the Colombian cartel after one of its laboratories was raided in Panama. Confirmation of del Cid's plea negotiations came outside a hearing on the Noriega case before U.S. District Judge William Hoeveler. The attorneys were trying to devise a way to handle classified documents expected to be at the heart of Noriega's defense. Lewis, a New York-based expert on the Classified Information Protection Act, said the government's tough rules would classify material even when already printed in a book, as in the case of the just-published ``Our Man in Panama'' by John Dinges. Michael Olmsted, a Washington-based Justice Department attorney, said it makes no difference if information is widely known or not. ``Just because there was publication of a fact we consider classified does not ... make it unclassified,'' Olmsted said. Fellow prosecutor James McAdams of the U.S. attorney's office in Miami said prosecutors also are battling secretiveness. ``We have intelligence agencies saying `we know you have to try your case, but you're not going to do it with our stuff,''' complained McAdams. On the other hand, he said, defense attorneys are trying to push the prosecution in an attempt to force the government to drop charges to avoid revealing secrets. Hoeveler, noting the classified-information complications, said he hoped the trial would begin in November, but said it would start no later than January 1991. The judge also heard arguments by attorneys for the four remaining Noriega co-defendants in custody or out on bond, requesting separate trials. But prosecutors insisted the five be tried together. Hoeveler said he would rule later on the outstanding secrecy issues and the requests for separate trials. A sixth defendant, Panamanian pilot Eduardo Pardo, has pleaded guilty to flying drug proceeds from Fort Lauderdale to Panama. He has not been sentenced. Ten more defendants, including Medellin cartel boss Pablo Escobar Gaviria, remain at large.

DOC.HEAD: UPI Sues Photo Partner in New York
DOC.TEXT: United Press International said Monday it had asked a federal court for an injunction to prevent Reuters from backing out of a photo exchange agreement between the two news services. Reuters and UPI agreed in 1984 that UPI would provide news pictures from the United States to Reuters, while Reuters would provide UPI with pictures from other countries. The agreement was to run for 10 years. On Feb. 16, Reuters said it was canceling the agreement, and interrupted the exchange for four hours. Reuters said it was suing UPI in U.S. District Court in New York for an unspecified sum representing money it lost on the agreement. UPI's suit, also filed in U.S. District Court in New York, denied Reuters' allegations that UPI's service had declined since the exchange started in 1985.

DOC.HEAD: Chamorro Triumph Opens The Way to Peace in El Salvador
With AM-Nicaragua, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The election of Violeta Barrios de Chamorro as president of Nicaragua spells hope for peace and democracy in Central America, Salvadoran leaders said Monday. Mrs. Chamorro, candidate for the United National Opposition party alliance, was the surprise winner of Sunday's race over incumbent Daniel Ortega, head of the leftist Sandinista party that has governed Nicaragua since 1979. Armando Calderon Sol, head of the ruling Nationalist Republican Alliance Party, known as Arena, used the occasion to call for reopening of peace negotiations between the Salvadoran government and rebels, locked in a 10-year-old civil war that has claimed 72,000 lives. ``With the upset of the Sandinistas, democracy in the region is taking hold. There's no call to go on killing in El Salvador, and we should facilitate dialogue,'' Calderon said. ``This is a historic moment of reflection for the Salvadorans. I believe that now is when the Salvadoran democratic process should open political spaces for the incorporation of the guerillas and seek social harmony,'' he said. The Salvadoran government congratulated Mrs. Chamorro in a statement issued by Foreign Vice Minister Ricardo Valdivieso. Chamorro's triumph ``opens broad hopes for Nicaragua's social and economic development process and that of the whole Central American region,'' Valdivieso said. Salvadoran opposition party spokesman Ruben Zamora also praised Ortega's government for a clean electoral process. The elections ``are an example of democracy,'' said Zamora, head of the Popular Social Christian Movement party and the Democratic Revolutionary Front. Zamora's party and the Democratic Revolutionary Front are politically aligned with the Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front guerrillas, known as FMLN. Calderon, referring to rumors that Nicaragua has sent weapons to the Salvadoran rebels, said the fall of Sandinista government means ``the FMLN is historically cut off.'' Col. Mauricio Ernesto Vargas, military commander in four eastern provinces of El Salvador, said, ``This means the FMLN will have to change. They're going to lose the suupport they had from Nicaragua for damaging the political economic and social system in El Salvador,'' he said. ``Peace is closer with the change in Nicaragua,'' said Vargas in a telephone interview with The Associated Press. Salvadoran rebel leaders could not be reached for comment at their diplomatic offices in Mexico City.

DOC.HEAD: Five Sets of Vietnam-Era Remains Identified
DOC.TEXT: Five sets of remains belonging to Vietnam-era servicemen have been identified by the Army's Central Identification Laboratory, the U.S. Pacific Command said Monday. The remains of Navy Cmdr. Frank C. Elkins of Bladenboro, N.C., who was lost in North Vietnam on Oct. 12, 1966, were among 28 repatriated by Vietnam on June 21, 1989. Nine of those remains have been identified. The other four Americans were among 25 repatriated on Jan. 23, 1989. Seven of those remains have been identified. Three of the remains, all Army soldiers lost in South Vietnam on Dec. 2, 1969, were identified as Chief Warrant Officer William C. Dunlap of Tucson, Ariz.; Chief Warrant Officer Martin D. Vanden Eykel II of Wheaton, Ill.; and Staff Sgt. William D. Sanderlin of Fort Worth, Texas. The name of the fifth serviceman was withheld at the request of his family, the army said. The remains were scheduled to leave Hickam Air Force Base here for Travis Air Force Base, Calif., on Tuesday to begin their final journey home.

DOC.HEAD: Pregnant Cancer Victim Declines Treatment to Save Baby
DOC.TEXT: A pregnant cancer patient who refused chemical and radiation therapy so the fetus wouldn't be harmed gave birth to a boy, and mother and child appeared to be doing well Monday. ``This baby is perfect,'' Linda Babcock said from her room at St. Joseph Medical Center in this central Illinois city. ``To think that I might have aborted him. I think I would have died, too.'' The Clinton woman, who has three other children ages 8 to 18 and said she was in her 30s, was diagnosed last August as having inoperable form of lung cancer known as oat cell carcinoma. Untreated, her chances appeared slim. ``Textbooks say untreated oat cell cancer patients will live two to four months,'' said Dr. James Wade III, director of medical oncology-hematology at Decatur Memorial Hospital. ``The chances of her being able to deliver the baby without treatment are slim,'' he said during the pregnancy. On Friday, Dr. Harold A. Nord of Bloomington delivered Jesse Warren Babcock, weighing 5 pounds and 6 ounces. ``It's pretty incredible that if she has oat cell carcinoma, as the tests have shown, that she went throughout pregnancy without her physical condition deteriorating,'' Nord said Monday. ``In fact, in the last few weeks, she seemed to be getting better. ``I was amazed. ... This is the first time I've had a patient who had this condition _ known to be fatal _ and survived,'' said Nord, who has been in obstetrics for seven years. Mrs. Babcock said an X-ray was taken after the delivery and she was told her condition was unchanged. ``It hasn't changed since the very first diagnosis,'' she said. But Mrs. Babcock said she believes she no longer has cancer and will continue to do without normal therapy. ``I feel so much better,'' she said. ``I can breathe. I could tell it was there before. It felt like something cutting off my air, taking my life.'' After the diagnosis last summer, Mrs. Babcock faced hard choices: Should she undergo conventional radiation and chemical cancer therapy, which could extend her life but harm the baby? Should she forgo treatment and hope for the best? Should she have an abortion? After agonizing about the choices with her husband, George, a control technician at a nuclear power plant, Mrs. Babcock decided: No chemotherapy. No radiation treatment. No abortion. She adopted a program based on nutrition: lots of carrot juice, organically grown vegetables and fruits, plenty of purified water, lots of vitamin pills _ and faith in God. ``Sometimes the art of medicine is not so certain,'' Nord said after the successful birth. ``Give God the credit,'' Mrs. Babcock said. ``He guided me, through people I met, books I read. So many people helped me, prayed for me. I'll never be able to thank them enough.'' Mrs. Babcock and her baby are to go home Tuesday. ``I'm confident of living, of beating the cancer,'' she said. ``The baby saved me from death as I saved him.''

DOC.HEAD: Kidnapped Mayor Found Dead; Army Kills Four Rebels
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with mayor killed; no pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Five men kidnapped a mayor in northern Colombia Monday, and she was found dead hours later in a parked car with eight bullet wounds, most to the head, police said. The army reported that soldiers surprised leftist guerrillas preparing to blow up a section of the nation's main oil pipeline on Sunday and killed four rebels. The mayor of Apartado, Diana Cardona, had said in an interview in November that she had received several death threats from paramilitary groups in the region, which borders Panama. Five men subdued the bodyguard police assigned to her, then forced the 31-year-old woman into a car Monday morning as she left her home in Medellin bound for nearby Apartado, a police communique said. It did not mention the fate of the bodyguard. Ms. Cardona, a lawyer and member of the leftist Patriotic Union party, was appointed mayor less than a year ago after another member of the party, Ramon Castillo, fled the country because of death threats. Police had said earlier they suspected leftist guerrillas in the kidnapping of the mayor. Rebels have never been to known to harm anyone from the Patriotic Union, and the party is known to have ties to the Revolutionary Armed Forces guerrilla group. Apartado is in the Uraba region, where authorities have blamed right-wing death squads for several massacres of peasants and union leaders. An army statement said soldiers took one prisoner and two soldiers were wounded in the pipeline fight with guerrillas of the National Liberation Army near Toledo, 250 miles northeast of Bogota. The attack would have been the ninth this year on the pipeline, which runs from the Cano Limon field on the Venezuela border to the Caribbean port of Covenas. Previous bombings this year cost $40 million in repairs and lost production, said Andres Restrepo Londono, president of the state oil company Ecopetrol. Guerrillas of the National Liberation Army began attacking oil facilities in 1986. Restrepo assessed total damage since then at $512 million.

DOC.HEAD: Nicaraguan Exiles Cautiously Jubilant About Elections
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 6 grafs to UPDATE with large street celebration. Picks up 6th graf pvs, `Many Nicaraguan ...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto MH7
With AM-Nicaragua, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The main street through South Florida's largest Nicaraguan neighborhood was closed to traffic Monday night as thousands of jubilant exiles celebrated the upset victory of Violeta Barrios de Chamorro over the Sandinista regime. An estimated 8,000 Nicaraguans and other Hispanics converged on Sweetwater to dance and sing patriotic anthems, said Charles Toledo, police chief of the community west of Miami. Many, however, said they want to see the new government in action before deciding whether to return. ``Democracy is on its way back,'' said a jubilant Inez de Gutierrez, who nonetheless conceded she would not return immediately. ``We'll just wait a while and see how things go in Nicaragua, politically and economically,'' said Mrs. de Gutierrez, a 31-year-old cashier who has been in the United States for a year with her husband and young daughter. ``The country is in ruins. It's in great poverty, now.'' Police closed a five-block stretch of busy Flagler Street, which was clogged earlier in the evening with cars blaring horns and filled with flag-waving Nicaraguans, many of whom did not sleep since voting began Sunday morning. Many Nicaraguan exiles elsewhere in the United States also expressed astonishment and joy at the election outcome but some were skeptical that the Sandinistas would relinquish power. In Sweetwater, a group of Nicaraguan businessmen passed around a facsimile sent from Managua showing a dart board superimposed over a drawing of Sandinista leader Daniel Ortega. Ricardo Teran, whose family operates a retail and telecommunications conglomerate in Nicaragua, said he will return to Nicaragua next week to assess prospects of relocating permanently. ``Up until five hours ago, our total investment in Nicaragua was zero. The government had control of everything. Now, we're going to see if it's worth starting to build up the business again,'' he said. Renato Salazar said he will not be ready to return to his homeland until the Sandinistas relinquish control of the military and police forces. ``Democracy means total democracy, not the government being in charge of one part and the opposition in control of the army,'' he said. More than 100,000 Nicaraguans have resettled in south Florida since the Sandinista revolution in 1979. Opposition leaders were also pleased, but wanted to see what would happen next. Aristides Sanchez, a member of the Contras' ruling Civilian-Military Commission, appealed to all Nicaraguans to ``back the new government and attempt to achieve a national reconciliation.'' Adolfo Calero, former director of the U.S.-backed rebels, predicted the return of exiles to Nicaragua would be slow. ``There are mass exoduses, but no mass returns to a country,'' said Calero, who now works with the Nicaraguan American National Foundation. ``Slowly, the Nicaraguan exiles will go back to the country. I'm going back as soon as I get a passport from the country. ``I think the armed struggle is over,'' Calero said. ``The armed struggle was never an end in itself, it was always a means to force the Sandinistas into a political contest which the people won, headed by Violeta Chamorro.'' Immigration attorney Robert Boyer, who has been a legal adviser to Nicaraguans seeking asylum, predicted a high percentage of Nicaraguans, if they know that things will be safe and secure and will be able to establish themselves economically, will go back to Nicaragua. In Los Angeles, Luciano Cuadra, 32, of the Organization of Nicaraguans in Exile and a onetime Sandinista intelligence officer, said he had predicted Sunday that the leftist government almost certainly would win. ``I have never been happier to have been mistaken,'' he said. He said it could be months, however, before the world knows if the Sandinistas truly have relinquished power. ``Up to this moment, I'm still a skeptic,'' he said. At Casa Oscar Romero, a Catholic-funded shelter for Central Americans near Brownsville, Texas, Nicaraguans largely welcomed the election results but worried that the Sandinista army will not respect the vote. ``The results were good, but it's a lie,'' said Barbara Zapata, 26, who left Managua five months ago. ``Daniel (Ortega) will not turn in the weapons.''

DOC.HEAD: Ortega Bows to Voters' Verdict Following Upset Loss
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 16 grafs to UPDATE with Chamorro quote, two nighttime incidents in Managua, Leon, details. Picks up 11th pvs, `It's going...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos MGA12,16,34; LaserColor MGA14,16,17,18,22,23
DOC.TEXT: President Daniel Ortega said Monday his Sandinistas will honor the voters' wishes and surrender power to a 6-month-old opposition alliance that won an upset victory after a decade of one-party rule. ``We leave victorious because the Sandinistas have sacrificed, spilled blood and sweat, not to cling to government posts, but to bring Nicaragua something denied since 1821,'' when it declared independence from Spain, he said in a dramatic dawn speech. Ortega spoke hours after it was clear the electoral tide was against him and Violeta Barrios de Chamorro, publisher of the opposition newspaper La Prensa, would be the next president of this battle-scarred nation, which has in the past decade become one of the poorest in the Western Hemisphere. Later Monday, Ortega went to Mrs. Chamorro's home for a brief congratulatory visit. Ortega, accompanied by several foreign observers, including former President Jimmy Carter, hugged Mrs. Chamorro, who called him ``my darling.'' Ortega replied, ``You know that I respect you, and that I love you and congratulate you on your victory.'' ``In this election there weren't any victors or losers. What I want is that we all work for the reconciliation of Nicaragua,'' she said. ``I am ready to contribute to the national reconciliation,'' Ortega said. Earlier, as she headed for a victory celebration at her campaign headquarters, Mrs. Chamorro said simply, ``People wanted a change.'' With 82 percent of the precincts counted, Mrs. Chamorro had 633,357 votes, or 55.2 percent, to 468,040, or 40.8 percent for Ortega, with the other 4 percent going to minor candidates, the Supreme Electoral Council said. The coalition also won a majority in the National Assembly. Mrs. Chamorro is to take office April 25 and the transition could be difficult, given the bad blood between winners and losers. On leaving office, Ortega is to become a member of the National Assembly. After a day of calm following the election, there were at least two violent incidents after nightfall Monday, including rock- and bottle-throwing between inebriated Sandinista and UNO supporters. Crowds of about 50 on each side were screaming insults at each other across a street in western Managua; only five or six actually tossed objects. About 150 riot police called to the scene dispersed the crowd with tear gas and night sticks. One person suffered a head injury. In the provincial capital of Leon, Sandinista militants attacked and occupied the local UNO headquarters, according to a Sandinista party official. The Sandinista supporters left the UNO house when Sandinista officials went to the scene and asked the militants to accept their defeat with maturity. There were no reports of injuries. ``It's going to be a bit harder than the normal transition,'' said Alfredo Cesar, one of Mrs. Chamorro's closest advisers and a former leader of the Contra rebels. ``That means the two sides .. . will sit down and make sure the transition is accomplished in a peaceful manner.'' There was elation at the White House. ``In this year of political change, democracy won another victory,'' President Bush said in a statement, and officials said lifting the U.S. economic embargo was under discussion. Ronald Reagan, in whose administration the Contras were organized and went to war, issued a statement saying: ``The people of Nicaragua and the cause of democracy have won an impressive and important victory.'' In Riverside, Calif., Vice President Dan Quayle praised the U.S.-supported forces that tried to overthrow the Sandinistas, saying, ``The Contras were an important force throughout to bring democracy.'' Under the Sandinistas, Nicaragua became a self-proclaimed revolutionary state and adopted portions of Marxist and Leninist ideology to remake its economic and social structures. It won strong support from the Soviet Union and Cuba, and was accused by the United States of trying to foment a Communist revolution in neighboring El Salvador. The Sandinista loss to the United National Opposition, which is known as UNO and favors Western-style representative government, followed by months the movement toward democracy in a several Soviet-aligned nations of East Europe and democratization in the Soviet Union itself. ``We have a whole new political landscape in Central America today. We have democracy on the march and dictators on the decline,'' Quayle said, adding that the region's anti-democratic axis of Cuba, Nicaragua and Panama has been reduced to just Cuba. ``Today we have democracy in Panama, yesterday people voted for democracy in Nicaragua, and now only one remains.'' Both Ortega and Mrs. Chamorro presented themselves as candidates of national reconciliation and economic recovery, Ortega because he believed the United States would recognize his victory and Mrs. Chamorro because she had Washington's support. She promised economic recovery to a nation that suffered from a decade of war, a debilitating U.S. economic embargo and poor management. Ortega and the Sandinistas mounted a carefully orchestrated campaign that ended with a rally attended by an estimated 300,000 people. The man who marched into Managua as a victorious young revolutionary in July 1979 had not expected to lose, and the first hours of the stunning upset were tense. Former President Jimmy Carter was among thousands of international election observers who monitored the voting. Defense Minister Humberto Ortega, the president's brother, and Interior Minister Tomas Borge, who controls the police, had suggested they might not give an opposition government control of those forces. Daniel Ortega said he spoke for his party and government, however, in promising to honor the results. ``I want to tell all Nicaraguans and all the nations of the world that the president of Nicaragua and the government will respect and submit itself to the popular mandate,'' he said. Most polls had shown Ortega ahead, but the results always were in question because many people refused to express their opinions to strangers. Paul Reichler, an American lawyer and one of Ortega's close advisers, said: ``I think that, when people went to vote, they voted with their stomachs, and I think they thought about the empty stomachs of their children.'' ``I think when it came right down to it, Nicaraguans has just suffered enough. They had suffered too much.'' In opposition, the Sandinistas will be the largest and best-organized party in Nicaragua. ``It's a hell of an opposition force in any democracy,'' said Cesar. ``They are going to have their own rights, their own space. Ortega will be treated as a former president, with all the dignity that entails.'' Ortega said the Sandinistas had created ``an independent, dignified and sovereign Nicaragua with economic and social development and with complete democracy.'' Throughout the campaign, Ortega equated the opposition alliance with the Somoza dictatorship the Sandinistas overthrew. He and Mrs. Chamorro served on the first junta after the late President Anastasio Somoza was ousted, but she resigned after nine months and later accused the Sandinistas of betraying promises of pluralism. Her coalition consists of 14 political parties and one native Indian organization that span the poltical spectrum. Ortega called the election and invited the international observers that made it the freest in Nicaraguan history and perhaps the most closely monitored anywhere. The election was part of a Central American peace agreement that also involves disbanding the Contras.

DOC.HEAD: New McMartin Judge Picked to Preside Over Ray Buckey Retrial
DOC.TEXT: A new judge was picked Monday to hear the retrial of McMartin preschool defendant Raymond Buckey, who faces 13 child molestation counts left over from the nation's longest criminal trial. Superior Court Judge Stanley Weisberg, known for his efficiency in moving cases along, will hear the retrial scheduled to start March 9, court officials said. Buckey, 31, and his mother, Peggy McMartin Buckey, 63, were acquitted on 53 charges of child molestation in January, but the Superior Court jury deadlocked on 13 other counts against Raymond Buckey. Superior Court Judge William Pounders presided over that trial, which lasted nearly three years. Reports of child molestation at the McMartin Pre-School triggered a wave of hysteria in Southern California. The case lingered in the courts in various stages for nearly seven years, and cost more than $15 million. Weisberg is to meet with prosecutors and defense attorneys in a pretrial hearing Wednesday.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Retransmitting to fix file number.
DOC.TEXT: Poor weather forced the launch of shuttle Atlantis' secret military mission to be scrubbed today for the fifth time, the most delays since the doomed Challenger. NASA set the next attempt for early Wednesday. Peekaboo clouds and erratic winds tantalized NASA with possible launch opportunities for almost two hours early today and officials kept Atlantis and its five-man crew poised and ready for any momentary break in the weather. But the break never came. At 2:32 a.m. launch director Robert Sieck abandoned the launch attempt and announced NASA would not try again until early Wednesday.

Despite ominous government warnings and a high police profile, pro-democracy activists marched by the hundreds of thousands in more than 30 Soviet cities to demand an end to one-party Communist rule. The rallies Sunday, unprecedented in scope in the Communists' 72-year rule, came a day after voters in the independence-minded republic of Lithuania apparently stripped the Communists of their parliamentary majority. The day also saw republic-wide elections in another restive republic _ Moldavia. A series of official warnings last week that extremists would provoke violence kept the turnout low in some cities Sunday and prevented some protests altogether. Riot police dragged away people who tried to hold an unsanctioned demonstration in Leningrad, but there were no reports of major unrest. ``We heard about tanks, about police waiting with gas and shovels,'' said a middle-aged woman who was not deterred from demonstrating Sunday in Moscow along with more than 100,000 people.

President Bush and West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl, following ``extraordinarily frank'' talks at Camp David, say the world has nothing to fear from a united Germany and promise it will stay tethered to the Western military alliance. Emerging Sunday from two days of talks at the presidential retreat, Bush and Kohl sought to allay fears from Moscow to Warsaw to London that the two Germanys are marching to the altar too rapidly. Bush said they shared ``a common belief that a unified Germany should remain a full member of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, including participation in its military structure,'' but with ``a special military status'' for the territory of what is now East Germany. Kohl, without mentioning NATO by name, said, ``The alliance of free democracies in Europe and North America ... are of fundamental importance for peace and security. This is true now. This will be true in the future.''

Are the sidewalks outside many post offices free-speech havens or speech-free zones? The Supreme Court tackles that question today, and Bush administration lawyers want all Postal Service property declared off-limits to those who pass out literature or solicit contributions. At issue in a case from Bowie, Md., is a federal regulation banning ``soliciting, electioneering, collecting debts, vending and advertising'' on Postal Service property. A federal appeals court ruled in the Bowie case that the regulation impermissibly interferes with free-speech rights, but other courts have upheld the ban.

President Bush is meeting with the nation's governors to promote ``the future of our kids'' by discussing the state leaders' revisions to his goals for U.S. schools to meet by the year 2000. Leaders of the National Governors Association predicted an amicable meeting today since they made only minor changes in Bush's six goals. Their proposal to give education a share of any savings in defense spending was relegated to a resolution one governor said was so bland no one could object. ``I expect full well for the president to endorse what the governors have approved,'' NGA Chairman Terry Branstad of Iowa said after the group approved the changes on Sunday. Later, at a dinner for the governors at the White House, Bush toasted them and ``our commitment to work together toward ... an American education system that is second to none.''

DOC.HEAD: CALIFORNIA
Lotto
DOC.TEXT: Tickets containing all six winning numbers in the California Lottery's weekend ``Lotto 6-49'' game were sold in the cities of Eureka and Carlsbad, lottery officials said Sunday, and each is worth $3,186,409. There were six tickets containing five winning numbers and the bonus number, and each was worth $282,498. The tickets were purchased in South Gate, Newhall, Los Angeles, Baker, Covina and Modesto. The winning numbers were: 44, 30, 33, 18, 36, 49 and the bonus number, 43. The numbers are listed in the order they were announced, but any combination would win. There were 277 tickets sold with five of six winning numbers, and each ticket was worth $3,152. Some 14,012 tickets with four of six winning numbers paid off at $56 each, and the 260,149 tickets with three of six winning numbers were worth an automatic $5 each. Saturday night's televised drawing was delayed for 50 minutes by what officials first thought was a breakdown of the machine that spits out the balls containing the winning numbers. ``It was human error,'' California Lottery spokeswoman Carolyn Walker said later. She said a person who was supposed to press three buttons on the machine that randomly selects the numbers forgot to press the third button in the sequence. The buttons cause the numbered balls to drop out of the machine. Citizens are chosen randomly to press the buttons that release the numbered balls for the twice-weekly drawing, Ms. Walker said, because lottery employees are prohibited from starting the drawing. Lottery officials already had stopped the 7:55 p.m. statewide broadcast of the drawing before they realized what went wrong, Ms. Walker said. When the final button was finally pressed, the balls dropped normally. Security cameras in the Sacramento TV studio made the required videotape of the drawing, so it is valid even though it wasn't broadcast live, she said. Sales from Wednesday night to Saturday's drawing were $15,878,153. Wednesday's lottery jackpot is expected to be worth about $5 million.

DOC.HEAD: Today In History
DOC.TEXT: Today is Friday, March 9, the 68th day of 1990. There are 297 days left in the year.

Today's highlight in history: On March 9, 1989, the Senate rejected President Bush's nomination of John Tower to be defense secretary. The 53-47 vote was the first time in 30 years that a president was denied his choice of a Cabinet member. Also one year ago: Eastern Airlines filed for bankruptcy protection in a bid to conserve cash and gain time to persuade striking employees to return to work. On this date: In 1661, Cardinal Jules Mazarin, the chief minister of France, died, leaving King Louis XIV in full control. In 1796, Napoleon Bonaparte married Josephine de Beauharnais. In 1822, Charles M. Graham of New York was granted a patent for artificial teeth. In 1860, the first Japanese ambassador to the United States, Niimi Buzennokami, and his staff arrived in San Francisco. In 1862, during the Civil War, the ironclads Monitor and Virginia, formerly the Merrimac, clashed for five hours to a draw at Hampton Roads, Va. In 1916, Mexican raiders led by Pancho Villa attacked Columbus, N.M., killing more than a dozen people. In 1933, Congress, called into special session by President Franklin D. Roosevelt, began its ``100 days'' of enacting New Deal legislation. In 1945, U.S. bombers launched incendiary bomb attacks on Japan, causing widespread devastation. In Tokyo, at least 120,000 people died. In 1954, CBS newsman Edward R. Murrow critically reviewed Wisconsin Sen. Joseph R. McCarthy's anti-communism campaign on the television program See It Now. In 1964, the U.S. Supreme Court issued its landmark New York Times vs. Sullivan decision, which effectively narrowed the definition of libel by requiring proof of malice. In 1975, work began on the Alaskan oil pipeline. In 1977, about a dozen armed Hanafi Moslems invaded three buildings in Washington, D.C., killing one person and taking more than 130 hostages. The siege ended two days later. In 1983, Anne M. Burford resigned as chief of the embattled Environmental Protection Agency. In 1983, Margaret Heckler was sworn in as secretary of Health and Human Services. Ten years ago: Former Texas Gov. John Connally dropped out of the race for the Republican presidential nomination, one day after losing the South Carolina primary to Ronald Reagan. Five years ago: An American negotiating team arrived in Geneva for new U.S.-Soviet arms talks. Today's birthdays: Author Mickey Spillane is 72. Actress Joyce Van Patten is 56. Actor-comedian Marty Ingels is 54. Actor Raul Julia is 50. Actress Trish Van Devere is 47. Chess player Bobby Fischer is 47. Actor Emmanuel Lewis is 19. Thought for today: ``Those who speak most of progress measure it by quantity and not by quality.'' _ George Santayana, American philosopher (1863-1952). End Adv Fri March 9

DOC.HEAD: Today In History
DOC.TEXT: Today is Saturday, March 10, the 69th day of 1990. There are 296 days left in the year.

Today's highlight in history: On March 10, 1876, Alexander Graham Bell made what was, in effect, the first telephone call. His assistant, located in an adjoining room in Boston, heard Bell's voice over the experimental device say to him, ``Mr. Watson, come here. I want you.'' On this date: In 1496, Christopher Columbus concluded his second visit to the New World as he left Hispaniola for Spain. In 1629, England's King Charles I dissolved parliament. He would not call it back for eleven years. In 1785, Thomas Jefferson was appointed minister to France, succeeding Benjamin Franklin. In 1848, the Senate ratified the Treaty of Guadalupe Hidalgo, ending the war with Mexico. In 1864, Ulysses S. Grant became commander of the Union armies in the Civil War. In 1880, the Salvation Army arrived in the United States from England. In 1948, the anti-communist foreign minister of Czechoslovakia, Jan Masaryk, plunged to his death in Prague. In 1949, Mildred E. Gillars, who had made wartime broadcasts for the Nazis under the name ``Axis Sally,'' was convicted of treason in Washington. (She ended up serving 12 years in prison.) In 1969, James Earl Ray pleaded guilty in Memphis, Tenn., to the assassination of civil rights leader Martin Luther King Jr. (Ray later repudiated that plea.) In 1987, the Vatican issued a 40-page document on scientific techniques involving procreation, condemning such practices as surrogate motherhood, test-tube births and cloning. Ten years ago: The author of the Scarsdale Diet, Dr. Herman Tarnower, was shot to death at his home in Purchase, N.Y. Jean Harris was arrested and later convicted of the crime. Five years ago: Soviet leader Konstantin U. Chernenko died at age 73. One year ago: One day after the Senate rejected the defense secretary nomination of John Tower, President Bush announced he would nominate Republican Congressman Dick Cheney of Wyoming for the post. Also one year ago: In South Africa, the main Afrikaner church _ the predominantly white Dutch Reformed Church _ for the first time unequivocally condemned apartheid. Today's birthdays: Playwright David Rabe is 50. Newspaper columnist Bob Greene is 43. Britain's Prince Edward is 26. Thought for today: ``Art is a lie that makes us realize truth.'' _ Pablo Picasso, Spanish painter (1881-1973). End Adv Sat March 10
