Last week, the Tokyo market suffered two of its five worst daily declines ever and experienced volatility in several sessions.

Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. said it paid 1989 bonuses of $196 million in cash and $64 million in company stock, less than reports that pointed to large payments prior to the firm's collapse. On Friday, Drexel released details about the payments after harsh reaction from bankruptcy court creditors, who criticized the firm for reportedly paying up to $350 million in bonuses shortly before its parent filed for Chapter 11 protection. Drexel said 44 percent, or $113 million, of the total bonuses was guaranteed to executives and top professionals early in 1989 in an effort to keep them at the firm after it agreed to plead guilty to securities crimes and pay $650 million in penalties.

Sweden's car maker Volvo and Renault, the French state-owned automotive company, said they intend to make sizeable investments in each other in hopes of making both companies more competitive. The announcement Friday capped a year of negotiations between the two companies, whose worldwide sales have been under pressure.

General Motors Corp. will shut down parts of three assembly plants Monday, laying off 4,200 people in a reflection of the wave of cutbacks by major automakers attempting to weather the industry's hard times. GM will eliminate one of two shifts at each of its car assembly plants in Doraville, Ga., and Linden, N.J., resulting in 1,900 and 1,600 layoffs, respectively. The nation's largest automaker also is trimming production effective Monday at its assembly plant in Fairfax, Kan., causing about 700 layoffs.

Vehicle sales by the major automakers fell 12.1 percent in mid-February compared with last year as January's minivan buying frenzy appeared to take some steam out of this month's sales. The eight companies with North American plants reported Friday they sold cars and trucks at an average daily rate of 32,258 during the Feb. 11-20 period this year, compared with a rate of 36,687 during the same time last year. Car sales were down 1.5 percent, and truck sales, which include minivans, slumped 13 percent.

Federal regulators seized the savings and loan industry's second-largest holder of junk bonds, a California institution that worked closely with indicted financier Michael Milken. The Treasury Department's Office of Thrift Supervision on Friday turned Imperial Savings Association, San Diego, over to the Resolution Trust Corp., a federal agency created in August to dispose of insolvent S&Ls. Also seized was Mercury Savings and Loan Association, Huntington Beach, Calif.

The Justice Department said any settlement with Exxon Corp. over possible criminal charges from the Alaskan oil spill won't compromise civil claims by the state or its citizens. Spokesman David Runkel delivered a statement Friday in response to criticism from environmentalists and Alaskan officials that the department was trying to force the state to go along with what it considered an inadequate settlement of the federal case.

Talks between the United States and Japan on reducing the $49 billion trade imbalance between the two countries ended with few signs of progress and ample evidence of mutual frustration. ``We must say we find ourselves frustrated and concerned at this point,'' Deputy U.S. Trade Representative Linn Williams told reporters Friday after the talks. Japan's Foreign Minister Taro Nakayama, meanwhile, called for urgent Cabinet-level meetings, saying U.S. demands were ``much severer'' than Japan had expected.

Stock prices stumbled on Wall Street Friday but the decline appeared mild compared with a plunge earlier in the day in Tokyo, where stocks took their fifth-biggest drop ever. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials finished 10.58 points lower at 2,564.19. The dollar rose against most other currencies in foreign exchange trading. Bond prices rose slightly. Corn futures prices added to the steady gains of the three previous sessions; wheat futures also rose while soybeans slumped; precious metals retreated; oil futures were mixed; and livestock and meat were mixed.

DOC.HEAD: Forbes's Death Costs Forbes Magazine it Best Salesman
With PM-Obit-Forbes
DOC.TEXT: Forbes magazine is the cornerstone of a Forbes family empire that ranges from publishing to collections of Faberge eggs, a Moroccan palace, a South Pacific island and acres of Colorado ranchland. Malcolm S. Forbes made it all work in tandem through force of personality. Publishing executives and analysts said Forbes magazine lost its its best salesman this past weekend with the death of its chairman and editor in chief. Forbes' sojourns by motorcycle and hot air balloon through exotic locales and his lavish parties attended by heads of state, celebrities and corporate bosses undoubtedly helped create excitement about his flagship magazine. ``I'm sure that trickled down to advertising orders,'' said magazine publishing consultant Martin Walker. Media analyst John Reidy agreed that Forbes' style ``helped in a major way to bring in advertisers _ there was probably nobody quite like that before.'' But the analysts said Forbes also left behind a strong organization in which he gave increasing responsibility to his designated successor, his oldest son Malcolm Forbes Jr., known as Steve, and that the company should thrive. Malcolm Jr., who has won four awards for economic forecasting from USX Corp., announced Sunday he would take over as chairman and chief executive of the magazine and the family-owned company and as editor in chief of Forbes. Three other Forbes' sons also have roles with the company. ``While the death of Malcolm Forbes is a loss to journalism and certainly to the company he did so much to build, one can fully anticipate that that his company will continue to do very well,'' said Marshall Loeb, managing editor of Fortune, a key competitor to Forbes magazine. Forbes magazine was started two years before Malcolm Forbes was born. His father, Scottish immigrant Bertie Charles Forbes, was a syndicated financial journalist for a New York newspaper and launched Forbes in 1917. Malcolm Forbes, born Aug. 19, 1919, became associate publisher of the magazine in 1947. When B.C. Forbes died, he was succeeded by his oldest son, Bruce, and Malcolm moved up to the posts of editor and publisher. Bruce died in 1964, and Malcolm took the top jobs. The magazine had about 800 ad pages a year and a circulation of 100,000. At his death, ad pages were over 3,900 and circulation exceeded 735,000. Forbes made his father's magazine unique among the business magazines by providing ``a more personalized view of business'' than Fortune and Business Week did, according to the magazine analyst Walker. The magazine focused more on the strategies of individual entrepreneurs and corporate leaders rather than day-to-day business news. Its big annual list was not of the top companies, like the Fortune 500, but the wealthiest 400 American individuals and families. ``He forced the others to address business in a more human and personal way,'' Walker said. Fortune's Loeb said, ``He shook us all up.'' Last year, the biweekly Forbes' ad pages were slightly ahead of the biweekly Fortune at 3,775 pages but behind the weekly Business Week at 4,914 pages, according to Publishers Information Bureau figures for 1989. Walker said Forbes' circulation trails both Fortune and Business Week, which he said were at 783,000 and 901,000, respectively. A few years after taking over the business, Forbes decided to diversify into other areas. He purchased ranch land in Colorado and land by lakes in Missouri, parts of which have been made available for sale. The company acquired Laucala, one of the Fiji Islands in the South Pacific, where executives can go on retreats. In keeping with his wishes, Forbes' body will be cremated and the ashes buried on the island. Forbes invited dozens of bigwigs to his palace in Tangier, Morocco, last year for his 70th birthday party. Visitors to the Forbes building in New York can see a collection of jeweled Farberge eggs that were made in czarist Russia. Forbes owns the Old Battersea House on the River Thames in London, which he used only last week for an international bridge tournament featuring some top corporate chiefs. He was stricken only hours after his return from London early Saturday. His fortune has been estimated at between $400 million and $1.2 billion. All of these holdings helped Forbes cultivate contacts with corporate executives, which he hoped made them more disposed to buy advertising with his magazine. Indeed, he initially suggested he might be able to write off the $2 million cost of his Moroccan birthday bash as a business expense. Forbes also expanded his publishing holdings. The Forbes company owns American Heritage magazine, a monthly that specializes in stories about important historical events. Only a week ago, Forbes launched Egg, a magazine exploring the latest in fashion and food in New York and Los Angeles. Forbes also owns 12 weekly newspapers and two shopping guides in central New Jersey, where the Forbes estate is located. It owns an investment advisory institute that publishes a newsletter and offers educational programs.

DOC.HEAD: Reflections on an Annual Meeting: A Wierd, Weird World at Disney Gathering
DOC.TEXT: Why is Mickey Mouse so short? Why doesn't Disney hire kids to help develop projects? Isn't Chairman Michael Eisner offended by Bette Midler's foul mouth? Of every five Disney stockholders, four own fewer than 100 shares. About half have 10 or fewer. Many own a single share, and proudly possess certificates bearing the likeness of the world's most famous rodent to prove it. And as they did this past week, thousand upon thousands throng to the Disney shareholders' meeting each year with attitudes so protective, they might be worrying over a favorite restaurant changing its menu rather than an entertainment colossus that turned a $703 million profit last year. A young boy timidly addressed the question about Mickey's stature to Disney Chairman Michael Eisner and President Frank Wells at Tuesday's annual meeting, held in the cavernous Anaheim Convention across from Disneyland. Eisner cupped his ear, then glanced at Wells as the boy repeated his question into a microphone. ``He says, `Why is Mickey Mouse so short?''' Wells said, peering across the huge podium at Eisner as 9,000 shareholders looked on. Eisner shrugged and smiled. ``Well, he's a mouse!'' Why don't kids help develop projects? Wells doesn't miss studio attraction in California like the one Disney has opened to crushing crowds in Florida (forget it _ but check out Hollywoodland, coming to you at Disneyland in 1996). The vast majority of Disney shares, of course, are held by bigtime private and institutional investors, most notably Texas' Bass brothers, concerned with the bottom line that Wells and Eisner have nurtured so well since they were brought in to run the company in 1984. (The share price is about eight times higher than then, after adjusting for stock splits). But meeting-goers are more likely to worry whether the company, in its quest to conquer the worlds of entertainment and leisure, has betrayed the G-rated, young-at-heart, Magic Kingdom legacy left by affable old Uncle Walt. Particularly worrisome to many shareholders were four-letter words in movies from Disney's Touchstone studio, with Miss Midler, who has a multipicture deal with the studio, singled out by name repeatedly. There were many other concerns: if the upcoming ``Dick Tracy'' with Warren Beatty and Madonna would be a bloodfest (it's less violent than you'd believe from the trailer, Eisner said); if painting crews visible during day hours at theme parks might cost Disney its ``razor's edge'' at the parks; if Disney is ruining morale by underpaying workers. Eisner and Wells dodged the bombs with aplomb, for the most part, and with a lot of help from mega-screen video appearances by Kermit the Frog, Miss Piggy (Disney bought Muppets rights last year), and naturally Mickey himself. Free passes to Disneyland didn't hurt, of course. And, thank Mary Poppins, no one brought up that nasty PR mess about the officer on the Queen Mary refusing to shave his mustache to conform to Disney's tight-ship dictums (Disney bought the Queen Mary along with the Spruce Goose and the Disneyland Hotel from the Wrather Corp.). But Eisner and Wells will need all the pixie dust they can get in the future. Just wait till word filters down that the head of Disney's start-up record label, Hollywood Records, is the attorney for _ hide your ears, Minnie _ Guns 'N Roses, the current foul-mouthed champions of bad-boy rock.

DOC.HEAD: Malcolm Forbes Mourned by Friends, Admirers
DOC.TEXT: Malcolm Forbes, the self-proclaimed ``capitalist tool'' of business publishing who used the world as a stage for his lavish parties and ballooning exploits, was mourned as one who reveled in life and free enterprise. ``Death happens to everyone but we never believed it would happen to him; he always defied the odds,'' son Malcolm ``Steve'' Jr., who will succeed his father as head of the publishing empire, said Sunday. ``What he wanted inscribed on his tombstone says it all: `While alive, he lived.''' Forbes died of a heart attack while sleeping Saturday at his 40-acre estate in Far Hills, N.J. He was 70. ``I feel like a great light has been turned off,'' said Elizabeth Taylor, a frequent companion of Forbes. ``He was one of the best friends I ever had.'' ``I don't know anyone who enjoyed life so much or gave so much back,'' said Barbara Walters, who partied with billionaire developer Donald Trump, Chrysler Chairman Lee Iacocca, former Secretary of State Henry Kissinger and some 1,000 other guests at Forbes' $2 million, 70th birthday bash last fall in Tangier, Morocco. Various estimates placed the worth of Forbes, chairman and chief shareholder of Forbes Inc., at anywhere from $400 million to $1 billion. Whatever the amount, Forbes gleefully relished his riches. He made the first free flight over Beijing in a hot-air balloon and set six world ballooning records. He owned 68 motorcycles and made the first motorcycle tour of China. He globe-trotted with movie stars and heads of state aboard his gold-fixtured, helicopter-equipped yacht, the Highlander. But he also was gracious to everyday folks like Libby Rook, a management consultant from Vienna, Va., who marked her 44th birthday aboard the Highlander in 1987 after writing to Forbes on a dare from co-workers. ``It's not how much money you have but what you do with it,'' Forbes once told the Star-Ledger in Newark. ``The joy of living is incredible. We work hard at the things we have to do, so why not take time to enjoy the things we want to do?'' Forbes was a tireless collector, accumulating toy soldiers by the battalion and buying up a dozen Faberge eggs, the hand-crafted artworks of Imperial Russia. He was an enthusiastic champion of free enterprise and emblazoned his corporate slogan, ``Capitalist Tool,'' on his helicopters, balloons, even his clothing and luggage. ``He was a real free spirit,'' said opera star Beverly Sills, who sang ``Happy Birthday'' at the Moroccan party. ``He had such a joy of life. I think he would have had it if he had been a poor man.'' ``Malcolm Forbes was someone who lived life to its fullest and in doing so made all of our lives a little more colorful,'' said Iacocca. ``He was the quintessential American _ optimistic, buoyant and lots of fun,'' said Kissinger. Forbes was born in Englewood, N.J., on Aug. 19, 1919, two years after his father, Scottish emigrant Bertie Charles Forbes, founded Forbes magazine. He graduated from Princeton in 1941, then published two weekly newspapers in Ohio for a year. He enlisted in the Army in 1942, was wounded in combat and received the Bronze Star and Purple Heart. Forbes won a seat on the Borough Council in Bernardsville, N.J. in 1949. He served in the state Senate from 1951 to 1957 and ran for governor of New Jersey in 1957, losing to Robert B. Meyner. After his father's death in 1954, he became publisher and editor in chief of Forbes. The biweekly magazine, which offered a more personalized account of business news than its competitors, rode the 1980s bull market and the pro-business Reagan era to the greatest success since its founding. Experts valued the company's flagship magazine as high as $600 million, while its American Heritage magazine, suburban newspaper, real estate and art holdings almost add $100 million or more. ``He was a hell of a competitor and a promotional genius,'' said Stephen Shepard, editor in chief of Business Week magazine. ``He was a worthy competitor, certainly _ tough, charming, very, very effective,'' said Marshall Loeb, managing editor of Fortune. ``He was unique and larger than life as a journalist, entrepreneur and human being,'' said Warren H. Phillips, chairman and chief executive of Dow Jones & Co., which publishes The Wall Street Journal. Malcolm Forbes Jr. will succeed his father as chairman and chief executive of Forbes, Inc., and editor in chief of Forbes magazine. He formerly was president and chief operating officer of Forbes, Inc., and deputy editor in chief. ``Father _ Pop _ always looked to the future,'' said Malcolm Jr. ``He wanted this to remain a family business and it shall. As he wished, and as the family wishes, I will succeed him as chief executive. We will continue to move ahead as he was doing.'' The younger Forbes said his father's body would be cremated and the ashes buried at the Forbes-owned Pacific island of Lucala in Fiji, in line with his wishes. The immediate family will hold a private service today at an undisclosed location in New Jersey. A public memorial service was scheduled for 11 a.m. Thursday at St. Bartholomew's Church in Manhattan. In addition to his former wife, Roberta Laidlaw, and Malcolm Jr., survivors include sons Robert, Christopher and Timothy, a daughter, Moira Mumma, a brother, Wallace and eight grandchildren.

DOC.HEAD: Publisher Had Opinions, and the Vehicle to Flaunt Them
With PM-Obit-Forbes
DOC.TEXT: Malcolm Forbes had strong opinions on most matters of policy and style, and the perfect vehicle to flaunt them. His wit and breezy writing style were displayed in the Fact and Comment section that led each issue of his magazine. There, Forbes gave a highly personal account of everything from the key business and political issues of the day to pop culture, favorite books and restaurants. In the latest issue dated March 5, Forbes opined that fiber optics and satellite technology were likely to overcome cable television, urged the establishment of national standards on education to help the United States compete with Japan and Europe, and applauded President Bush for his personal diplomacy with major world leaders. ``He may sound more cautious than those impressed by dramatic hip-shooting would like. But we are mighty fortunate that in situations of international inflammability he knows to whom to talk. And knows what he's talking about.'' Forbes also put in a plug for his own personal diplomacy: the lending of nine of his 12 Faberge eggs to a Kremlin exhibition, carried to the heart of Communist power aboard his own Boeing 727 emblazoned ``Capitalist Tool.'' ``It is the first time in my life that I have really been wholeheartedly rooting for the stability and survival of the Russian government as presently constituted _ at the least, for the duration of the exhibit!'' he wrote. Forbes spiced up his column with a sprinkling of witticisms, which were collected in two volumes, the most recent being ``The Further Sayings of Chairman Malcolm'' in 1986. He had plenty of advice for his magazine's target audience, the nation's corporate managers: ``He who has the wheel determines the direction.'' ``In management, the staid seldom stay long.'' ``If you have no critics you likely have no successes.'' ``Attention is to people what fertilizer is to flowers.'' He also wrote frequently on wealth, suggesting that anyone who strived hard could achieve it but that wealth alone didn't give a person's true measure: ``Money seldom changes people. It just makes them more visible.'' ``Subtract a person's material worth and what's left is his real worth.'' ``To be free, one must have `bread.''' ``Alchemy isn't a myth _ Attitude and action can turn anyone and anything golden.'' But some of his more memorable quips dealt simply with living, something Forbes sought to do in great style: ``For enhancing any meal, the only thing that beats good wine is a better one. Come to think of it, even a poor one is better than none at all.'' ``Style is one thing, fashion usually quite another.'' ``If you don't enjoy the climb, giving what it takes to get to the top isn't worth it.'' ``Criticizing doers is far less fun than doing.'' ``As you get older _ Don't slow down. Speed up. There's less time left.'' Ironically, his most recent book, ``They Went That-a-way,'' described the ``extraordinary exits,'' as he put it, of 175 famous historical figures. Forbes said he wanted to satisfy ``an oft-expressed curiosity on the part of Us, the Living. When some well-known name pops up in conversation, how many times have we said, `Whatever became of him-her?''' He denied having any morbid fascination with death itself, though. ``Since it's life's only certainty, and since being against it isn't apt to affect the result, dwelling on death strikes me as a woeful, wanton waste of time,'' he wrote. ``It seems to me life is for the living.''

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Down 4.5 Percent In Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: The Nikkei Stock Average closed at 33,321.87, down 1,569.10 points, or 4.5 percent on the Tokyo Stock Exchange Monday.

DOC.HEAD: With Japan-Markets
DOC.TEXT: Monday's drop in the key index on the Tokyo Stock Exchange was the second biggest ever in terms of points, though not in terms of percentage. Here is a list of the 10 biggest plunges in the 225-share Nikkei Stock Average:

DOC.HEAD: Nordstrom Fourth-Quarter Earnings Fall 34 Percent
DOC.TEXT: Nordstrom Inc. said today its earnings fell 34 percent in the fourth quarter due largely to higher merchandise markdowns and a $15 million charge for estimated back wage claims by employees. For the three-month period ended Jan. 31, Nordstrom's profits fell to $31.4 million or 39 cents a share, from $47.5 million or 58 cents a share a year earlier. Revenues rose 12 percent to $857.5 million from $765.1 million. The upscale department store, which recently came under fire for allegedly exploiting employees, said it has responded to a Washington state Department of Labor and Industry ruling by implementing additional record-keeping procedures to ensure all employee work is properly recorded and compensated. The state labor agency ruled recently that Nordstrom had a pattern of making sales clerks work during off-hours and not paying them for it, following a complaint by Locals 367 and 1001 of the United Food and Commercial Workers union. It ordered the company to calculate and pay them uncompensated hours retroactive two years. Nordstrom spokesman John Goesling said the company has established a $15 million reserve for back wage claims. ``That's our estimate at the present time'' of what the back pay claims in Washington state will be, Goesling said. The union had estimated claims in Washington could reach between $30 million and $40 million. The company also attributed the drop in fourth-quarter net income to ``higher merchandise markdowns and shrinkage,'' a euphemism for in-house theft. For the year, Nordstrom earned $114.9 million or $1.41 a share, down 7 percent from $123.3 million or $1.51 a share in the previous year. Sales totaled $2.7 billion, up nearly 15 percent from $2.3 billion. The company also said it has instituted a claims procedure for reimbursing back pay. The claims forms have been sent to Nordstrom sales employees in other states, but not in Washington, where the forms must be reviewed by the state's labor office and the two union locals. The company is attempting to arrange meetings so that those forms may be mailed out in Washington by the end of the week, Goesling said. Nordstrom also said that it also expects a class action lawsuit to be filed on behalf of certain shareholders. Such a suit, if filed, would allege that the company knew or should have known that unpaid work and overtime claims by employees would adversely affect the price of Nordstrom stock and that the company should have made a disclosure to this effect, the company said in a statement. In a meeting last Tuesday, the board of directors voted to increase the quarterly dividend to 7.5 cents per share, payable March 15 to shareholders of record March 5.

DOC.HEAD: Rig Count Declined by 21
DOC.TEXT: The number of working U.S. oil and gas rigs continued its first quarter trend and declined by 21 this week to 897, Baker Hughes Inc. reported. The year-to-date count, however, remains 19 percent above last year's pace, according to Ike Kerridge Jr., an economist with Baker Hughes. This year, the count has averaged 960 rigs, while last year at this time, the count averaged 806, he said Monday. Kerridge said the rig count generally declines during the first quarter and is expected to bottom out in March or April although last year it bottomed out in May. Last week the rig count increased for the first time in 1990 when it jumped by 19 rigs to total 918. A year ago, the count was 757. Baker Hughes' rig count _ the widely watched industry index of drilling activity _ reflects the number of rotary rigs actively exploring for oil and gas as of last Friday, not the number of producing wells. Houston-based Hughes Tool Co., an oil toolmaker company that merged with Baker International Corp. of Orange, Calif., has kept track of the rig count since 1940. In December 1981, at the height of the oil boom, the rig count reached a peak of 4,500. But oil prices plunged to less than $10 per 42-gallon barrel in the summer of 1986, prompting a collapse in the rig count that bottomed out at 663 _ the lowest since Hughes began compiling figures. Among major oil producing states, Texas saw drastic activity for the third straight week posting a loss of eight rigs. Last week it gained 16 and slipped by seven the previous week. Oklahoma this week had the biggest decline with 13 after no activity last week. Other states posting losses were California and North Dakota with one each. States posting gains for the week included Kansas, seven; Pennsylvania, two; and Louisiana and Wyoming, one each. There were no changes in the number of rigs operating in Colorado, Michigan, New Mexico and Ohio.

DOC.HEAD: Industry Reports Weekly Production
DOC.TEXT: Domestic coal production totaled 20.3 million tons during the week ending Feb. 17, down 2.4 percent from the 20.8 million tons produced in the previous week, the U.S. Department of Energy reported Monday. The U.S. coal industry produced 19.4 million tons in the same week last year, according to the department's Energy Information Administration. Kentucky ranked first among the 27 coal-producing states with 3.48 million tons produced. Wyoming was second at 3.2 million tons and West Virginia was third at 3.1 million tons, the agency said. Domestic coal production so far this year is 140.1 million tons, 7.6 percent ahead of last year's production at this time. The week's production accounts for bituminous and lignite coal.

DOC.HEAD: EC Criticizes U.S. On Telecom Trade
DOC.TEXT: The governing body of the European Community Monday criticized the United States for keeping it on a list of trade partners considered trade offenders in the telecommunications sector. According to a statement by the EC Commission, the 12-nation group ``made substantial progress'' in tearing down telecom trade barriers in 1989, and ``regretted'' that it had not been struck off the U.S. list of telecommunications trade offenders. The United States first put the European Community on its so-called priority list in 1986 after U.S. companies said European Community governments had unfair procurement policies and complained they were locked out of the Community's telecom equipment and services markets. According to EC officials, U.S. telecom exports to the European Community rose to $788 million in 1988 from $569 million in 1987 as a result of the market-opening measures. During the same period, the European Community exported $370 million worth of equipment to the United States, up from $243 million. Under its trade laws, the United States last week had to either impose countermeasures against the European Community for its telecommunications policy, drop its name from the list, or extend its place on the list for another year. The commission said the measures taken so far to open its telecom market justified being removed from the U.S. list. Officials said the EC market for telecom equipment has been open since 1988, and argue that European Community governments have agreed in principle to open telecom markets for services and in public procurement. A U.S. official, who asked not to be identified, said he was not surprised by the commission's reaction. But he said that while progress has been made in opening up the market for telecommunications equipment, advances so far in services and public procurement amount to ``preliminary political steps'' that could not justify removing the European Community from the priority list of trade offenders.

The stock market was mixed in moderate trading today with buyers turning to blue chips in the wake of a severe setback in Tokyo. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials rose 19.59 to 2,583.78 by noon on Wall Street. But the broader market had a tougher time. Declining issues maintained a narrowing lead over advancing ones of about a 9-to-8 margin on the New York Stock Exchange, with 600 up, 672 down and 506 unchanged. The composite index of all NYSE-listed issues added 0.73 to 180.08. Volume on the floor of the Big Board amounted to 61.52 million shares at midday, down from 81.50 million at the same point on Friday. Wall Street analysts said although there was uneasiness about the severe selloff in Tokyo traders took comfort from the limited impact the slump had on markets elsewhere around the world. Stocks in London, Frankfurt, West Germany and other financial centers posted only marginal declines. Strength in the dollar and in the bond market also deflected the shock waves in the aftermatch of the tumble on the Tokyo Stock Exchange, the world's biggest equities market. The main index of the Tokyo market plunged by 1,569.10 points, second only to its ``Black Monday'' decline in October 1987. Gene Seagle, vice president and director of technical research at Gruntal Financial Inc., said the U.S. market's ability to weather the Tokyo plunge without losing its composure relieved anxieties that world markets had become intimately linked. He said Japanese money managers apparently were buying U.S. securities today. Pfizer topped the Big Board's list of actively trading stocks and was up ] to 56|. Western Union followed, rising 3-16 to 1[. Among the active blue chips, IBM gained { to 103[, Merck was unchanged at 68, Philip Morris was unchanged at 37{, General Electric added { to 61, General Motors advanced ] to 43} and Sears rose | to 40|. One point-plus loser among the actively trading issues was Homestake, off 1] at 20.

DOC.HEAD: Economy in `Danger Zone,' But Most Economists Don't Predict Recession
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts 5 new grafs with news conference remarks after 2nd graf, The survey
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. economy is in ``a danger zone'' but will avoid a recession in the next three years, according to a survey of the nation's top business economists released today that found little hope of ending inflation. The survey by the National Association of Business Economists found 60.6 percent of the professional forecasters believing the economy will skirt a recession through 1992, nearly the same as the 62.1 percent making the same prediction in the last survey released in December. NABE President James F. Smith said the biggest news in the survey is its confirmation of the ``sea change'' of optimism among the participants in December. A NABE survey last May found 63 percent of the economists expecting a recession this year. ``There was some trepidation that was a fluke,'' Smith said at a news conference called to release the new survey. ``Fortunately, it wasn't.'' Smith, a finance professor at the University of North Carolina, cautioned that ``we have not repealed the business cycle and we will have a recession some day.'' But, he added, ``our members are confident ... that we will shatter all recordso good-faith bargaining with Greyhound management,'' president Edward M. Strait said in a statement. ``It is our sincere hope that these discussions produce positive results.''

DOC.HEAD: Lockheed and Machinists Union Reach Tentative Accord
DOC.TEXT: Lockheed Corp., the nation's eighth largest defense contractor, reached a tentative labor agreement with the union representing about 20,000 workers for the aerospace firm. The tentative contract reached early Sunday still must be ratified by rank and file members of the International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers. A nationwide vote was scheduled for March 4. ``We feel it's the best contract that we can negotiate at this time, especially with government audits,'' union negotiator Bob Gregory said Sunday, referring to government monitoring of Lockheed's hourly compensation costs. Tom Goff, spokesman for the Calabasas-based Lockheed, confirmed that the two sides had reached a tentative agreement. A week earlier, union members rejected management's latest offer by a 98 percent margin. The union said Lockheed's earlier offer was inadequate and set up a two-tier wage structure. As part of the tentative agreement, both sides declined to disclose terms of the contract until the rank-and-file votes. The union workers have been operating under an extension of the previous three-year contract that expired last October. The present contract offer will be retroactive to October and runs through March 1, 1993, Gregory said. The union's Local District 727 represents 6,000 workers in Burbank and Palmdale. The contract also covers workers at Lockheed plants in Sunnyvale and Marietta, Ga. Contract talks had resumed Thursday in Florida and concluded early Sunday. Asked about changes in the contract offer's pension plan, Gregory said that it establishes an employee stock ownership plan for union members. Lockheed set up an employee stock-ownership plan for salaried employees last April. The plan, designed to strengthen the company against take-over attempts, gave salaried workers control of 17 percent of the company.

DOC.HEAD: Perrier Says Its Recall Nearly Complete
DOC.TEXT: Source Perrier SA today said it was planning to restock its sparkling water on supermarket shelves in six to eight weeks, following a worldwide recall due to benzene contamination. The company, from its headquarters in Paris, said it was implementing a series of ``stringent new inspection measures'' before production resumes, including new monitoring and testing procedures and double filtering of the carbon dioxide gas that goes into its sparkling water from Vergeze in France. It said a timetable for reintroduction would be established when all tests are completed and the new procedures are in effect, but estimated the familiar green bottles would be back on the shelf within two months. Perrier recalled 160 million bottles worldwide after benzene was found in some bottles overseas. The company first recalled 72 million bottles in North America, attributing the problem to an employee who inadvertently contaminated a bottling machine by cleaning it with benzene. The company later expanded the recall worldwide and acknowledged that benzene is found naturally in the carbon dioxide gas. The gas is extracted separately from the spring water before the two are combined in the Perrier plant for bottling. Perrier said the contamination occurred because workers failed to replace filters designed to remove the benzene from the carbon dioxide. In a statement from Paris, where Source Perrier is located, the company cited experts as saying the water source was pure and no one's health was ever at risk because of the benzene. It said a small amount of minor elements is found in all naturally occurring gases, and said all companies that use carbon dioxide in carbonated beverages filter the gas to remove small levels of such compounds. ``All international medical experts and regulatory officials consulted on the matter confirm that the health of Perrier consumers was never in danger,'' the company said. However, Source Perrier said it was instituting new measures to assure the purity of its product. It said the gas system would be checked twice a day, both before and after the filtering stage. The gas will be filtered twice, and the company will conduct specific tests for hydrocarbonate compounds. It also said backup verification would be conducted by an outside laboratory and a team of international experts. Perrier said its recall is 90 percent complete. The 72 million bottles in North America will be destroyed and recycled in facilities approved by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency. Several suits have been filed against Perrier and its U.S. affiliate, Perrier Group of America Inc. of Greenwich, Conn., charging that customers have been damaged by the benzene contamination. The suits, filed in Connecticut and Pennsylvania, seek class actions against the companies.

DOC.HEAD: Piper Shuts Down Plant For Two Weeks; Works Laid Off Temporarily
DOC.TEXT: VERO BEACH, Fla (CP) _ Financially troubled Piper Aircraft Corp. shut down its plant here for two weeks today and laid off more than three-fourths of its workers, a company spokesman said. Joe Ponte, director of marketing, said the layoffs are the result of a severe cash crunch and that the company did not plan to seek protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of the federal bankruptcy law. ``It's not Chapter 11, just layoffs and a shutdown,'' said Ponte. About 580 workers will be on an extended layoff, he said. The rest of the nearly 1,100 employees will return to work March 12, after the shutdown, he said. ``We have a tremendous backlog in aircraft on order,'' Ponte said in an interview. About 300 people remain on the job to help deal with backlogs in aircraft deliveries, he said. Piper, which manufactures aircraft for general aviation, was purchased by California investor M. Stuart Millar from Forstmann Little and Co. in 1987. No purchase price was disclosed. Ponte said the company will go to a four-day work week after the shutdown to help the company get back on its feet. He said the problems resulted from a rapid expansion of the company after Stuart Millar bought the company in 1987. ``We tried to minimize debt and tried to fund rapid growth with cash flow and we really underestimated how much it would require,'' Ponte said. Ponte said Piper had to take drastic action to deal with the problem. He said people ordering aircraft and parts might experience delays but they will receive their products. Piper has had trouble competing with the giant Cessna Aircraft Co. , which is controlled by General Dynamics Corp., a U.S. defense contractor. Cessna surpassed Piper in 1967 to become the world's leading aircraft manufacturer in total units sold.

DOC.HEAD: Second-Worst One-Day Fall In History; Dollar Higher
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 1 graf for grafs 7-8 pvs, `Meanwhile, stock... to UPDATE with later New York, London figures; PICKS UP 9th graf pvs, `In an...
DOC.TEXT: The Tokyo Stock Exchange's main index suffered its second largest one-day fall today, and exchange officials reportedly sought to restrict a form of computer-guided trading seen as a major factor in recent declines. The dollar closed sharply higher. The 225-share Nikkei Stock Average plunged 1,569.10 points, or 4.5 percent, closing at 33,321.87, its lowest level since 33,309.71 last July 5. Today's plunge was second only to the 3,836.48 on Oct. 20, 1987. That fall of 14.9 percent, however, still was well below the previous day's 22.6 percent on Wall Street, on the ``Black Monday'' that triggered a global crash. Volume was a light 400 million shares on the first section. Analysts said stock, bond and yen prices were driving each other down in a vicious cycle. Meanwhile, stock prices rose New York with the Dow Jones average of 30 industrials up 24.55 points to 2,588.74 at 1:30 p.m. EST. Share prices finished higher in London. The Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index gained 12.6 points to close at 2,249.3. In an effort to stop the fall in stock prices, the Tokyo Stock Exchange asked that securities firms limit their index arbitrage selling to the beginning of the morning and afternoon sessions until March 8, Kyodo News Service reported without elaborating. In arbitrage trading, which also was cited as a cause for Wall Street's ``Black Monday'' crash, investors profit from differences in prices for the same security in different markets, for instance, the spot and future markets. Computers spot the price gaps and guide the trading. But arbitrageurs, seen by many analysts as the key factor in the Nikkei's 2,570-point loss for all of last week, were not very active today as futures prices fell the maximum amount allowed during the morning session. On the foreign exchange market, the dollar rose 2.18 yen, closing at 148.65 yen. It opened at 147.50 yen and ranged between 147.42 yen and 149.05 yen. The dollar now has gained 4.13 yen in the last five trading days. The bond market held firm in today's trading. The yield on the benchmark 10-year government bonds closed at 6.875 percent, down slightly from its 6.98 percent opening. At one point today, the Nikkei average fell to 32,477.46 points, 2,413.51 beneath its Friday close. Masahiro Umemori, an analyst for Nomura Securities, said that about an hour before the market's close, some investors began to feel stock prices were reasonable again. The index climbed 844.41 points in the last hour. Because of overall light trading, the few buy orders had a large impact on the index, Umemori added. Robert Alan Feldman, an economist for Salomon Brothers Asia Ltd., said such last-minute turnarounds were common on the Tokyo market and did not signify that the market's fall had been stopped. Johsen Takahashi, director of Mitsubishi Research Institute Inc., said the Tokyo market's problem was ``cheap yen, cheap stocks and cheap bonds _ the decline of each one has accelerated the decline of the other two.'' In a vicious cycle, analysts said, the weakening of the bond market had reduced demand for the yen, whose cheap value reduced the attractiveness of buying stocks. Takahashi said Japan might be able to stem the stock market's decline by lowering interest rates, but such action was unlikely because it might accelerate the country's already overheating economy. A rapidly expanding money supply as well as a tightening labor market have led to growing inflation in the country in the last few months. ``Japan's domestic boom has been too good,'' he said, and this has led to an overevaluation of the yen as well as stock prices. The Bank of Japan sold an estimated $1.6 billion in efforts to support the yen. Bank of Japan Governor Yasushi Mieno said today he was concerned about recent changes in the stock, bond and foreign exchange markets but saw no immediate need for changes in monetary policy. ``We don't change monetary policy only because stock prices moved rapidly or the yen moved rapidly. We base a change in monetary policy on an overall consideration of economic conditions, prices, currency rates, money supply and others,'' he said. In Hong Kong, meanwhile, share prices closed lower in thinner trading in response to the Tokyo market's plunge. The Hang Seng Index, the market's key indicator of blue chips, lost 21.68 points, or 0.75 percent, closing at 2,872.63. In Sydney, shares closed sharply lower in response to the fall in Tokyo. The all-ordinary share price index fell 35.3 points to 1,545.7, down 2.2 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Waldenbooks Stepping Up Effort to Woo Customers
DOC.TEXT: Waldenbooks is launching a new program that combines incentives to attract customers with a high-tech purchase tracking system for use in individualized marketing to readers, Waldenbooks' chief executive said Monday. The ``Preferred Reader'' program being rolled out Friday is the latest step in Waldenbooks' campaign to promote itself as a service-oriented retailer and distinguish itself from such competitors as B. Dalton or Brentano's. Harry Hoffman, president and chief executive officer of the nation's largest bookstore chain, said Waldenbooks will be the first in its field to use such a technologically sophisticated approach to monitor what customers buy. ``We think this kind of program will build a loyal customer base, increase our share of the market and provide people who like books ... with outstanding information and keep them more aware of what's happening in the book business on a monthly basis,'' he said in an interview. ``I think the ability to reach people who we know are interested in what we have is going to be a tremendous opportunity to get a better return from advertising than we had in the past,'' he said. A customer can sign up for the program in a store or by calling a toll-free number. For a $10 annual membership fee, preferred readers receive 10 percent off every purchase and get back $5 for every $100 spent. The membership fee will be cut in half, to $5, during the March kick-off. Checks will automatically be accepted when shoppers show their preferred reader cards to cashiers. Each card will carry an individualized bar code allowing Waldenbooks to record via computer what a customer buys. The information will be used by Waldenbooks, which is based in Stamford, Conn. and owned by K mart Corp., to target specific tastes when sending news or special discounts by mail. Hoffman said every program member will receive a monthly brochure containing general information about books, authors, and similar topics. Inserts occasionally will be included. Science fiction fans will get advance notice of a pending title while mystery readers will receive coupons for discounts off future purchases of books in that genre, for example. The program, being implemented at all 1,250 Waldenbooks stores, eventually will replace the genre specific clubs the company has had for years, said Ron Jaffe, senior director of marketing. New members no longer will be enrolled in the current clubs, which cater to people with particular reading interests. Jaffe said in an interview that the existing clubs, members of which will be offered free one-year memberships in the preferred reader program, have about 3{ million people as active participants. Jaffe said the program is part of a $15 million campaign in Waldenbooks' repositioning. ``We really hope that by doing this we become the bookstore of choice when someone is out buying books,'' he said. Besides upgrading its use of database marketing, Jaffe said the chain over the past year or so has undertaken other changes. Store displays and category presentations have been redesigned to be more ``reader friendly'' and individual stores have greater flexibility to stock books that satisfy local market preferences. Among other benefits of the new preferred reader program, members will be able to order books by telephone, selecting from 100,000 titles available at the company's Nashville, Tenn. distribution warehouse. Operators will be able to search by computer for hard-to-find books. Non-members also will be allowed to call the 800-number but they won't be eligible for the discounted prices. Hoffman said Waldenbooks will redirect a significant portion of its $10 million to $12 million annual advertising budget to support the program, cutting back outlays on some conventional methods, such as catalogs in magazines. Target marketing has advantages over the ``shotgun approach'' of running ads in newspapers, said Hoffman, noting: ``I think most retailers in the '90s are going to have to look at this type of program.''

DOC.HEAD: Prices Rise
DOC.TEXT: Stock prices finished higher on London's Stock Exchange Monday, as late afternoon buying reversed early declines following another market plunge in Tokyo. London stocks initially were battered by the Nikkei index's second worst showing in Tokyo since the October 1987 crash. But later in the session, London stocks rose after a bullish start on Wall Street, dealers said. By the close of the European day, the Dow Jones industrial Average was up 20.94 points at 2,585.13. ``The blood bath some were suggesting on Wall Street just didn't appear,'' said one head of dealing at a London investment firm. The Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index rose 12.6 points, or 0.6 percent, to close at 2,249.3, bounding back from a low of 2,208.4 minutes after official trading began. Volume was 337 million shares, compared with 472.6 million shares Friday. Earlier in Tokyo, the Nikkei index plummeted 1,569.10 to 33,321.87 in its third sharp drop in less than a week. Dealers cited the belief that the Japanese market was overvalued and fears of higher interest rates. Following Tokyo's gyrations last week, the London market reacted bearishly but without the signs of hysteria associated with the unexpected plunges in New York share prices in October 1989 and October 1987.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Up, Gold Lower
DOC.NOTE: Eds: An AMer expected by 5:30 p.m. EST
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. dollar rose Monday against other major foreign currencies in Europe, fueled by the Tokyo stock market's steepest one-day decline since the October 1987 global crash. Gold prices were lower. The dollar benefited from nervousness over the declines in Tokyo stock prices last week and expectations that further weakness is likely, said Reijer Groenveld, a dealer with Bank of America in London. Dealers said the drop on the Tokyo stock market fortified perceptions that the Bank of Japan won't move quickly to raise interest rates, even though officials say they are increasingly worried about the yen's weakness. The Bank of Japan repeatedly sold dollars for yen to boost the Japanese currency, dealers said. But the large-scale intervention was viewed as reinforcing speculation that the underlying trend in the yen is downward, Groenveld and other dealers said. In Tokyo, the dollar rose to a closing 148.65 Japanese yen from 146.47 yen at Friday's close. Later, in London, it rose to 148.80 yen. In London, the British pound fell to $1.6927 from $1.7090 late Friday. Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late rates Friday, included: 1.6903 West German marks, up from 1.6779; 1.4865 Swiss francs, up from 1.4770; 5.7205 French francs, up from 5.6715; 1.9023 Dutch guilders, up from 1.8890; 1,250.25 Italian lire, up from 1,240.75, and 1.1975 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1965. Gold fell in London to a late bid of $411.75 a troy ounce from $416.50 late Friday. In Zurich, gold fell to a closing bid of $411.25 an ounce from $415.50 late Friday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold fell $2.47 an ounce to close at $412.15. Silver bullion fell in London to a late bid of $5.23 a troy ounce, down from $5.27 late Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Grains, Soybeans Lower in Sluggish Trading
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices closed mostly lower Monday on the Chicago Board of Trade as old crop wheat prices posted gains while new crop futures fell. March wheat futures prices rose on scattered commission house buying in anticipation that deliveries will be small because of low stocks, analysts said. The offer to the Soviet Union on Friday by the U.S. Agriculture Department of 1 million metric tons of wheat under the export bonus program had little influence on the market because it had been widely rumored last week, analysts said. The market now is waiting for an actual tender by the Soviet Union for direction. Pat O'Connell, an analyst for Refco Inc., said the corn deliveries also are expected to small but the expectation of rain in western crop areas weighed on the market. Soybean prices were lower Monday, kept on the defensive by a rash of commission house and professional selling. Rain in South American crop areas also weighed on the soybean market. At the close, wheat was 1\ cents lower to 2{ cents higher with the contract for delivery in March at $3.96{ a bushel; corn was 2 cents lower to a { cent higher with March at $2.46\ a bushel; oats were } cent to 1\ cents lower with March at $1.36\ a bushel; soybeans were 1} cents to 3} cents lower with March at $5.61{ a bushel.

The stock market moved ahead in late trading today, led by a strong advance in blue-chip issues. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials was up 34.23 at 2,598.42 with five minutes left to go in the session.

The stock market kept its composure in the wake of a nasty tumble on Tokyo's exchange and managed a moderate advance today. Buyers focused their attention on blue-chip stocks. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials finished on a strong note, boosted by a late rally, after sporting more modest gains for most of the session. The rally in the blue chips helped pull the broader market into the plus column. Although uneasiness about the selloff in Tokyo permeated the market, traders took comfort from the limited impact the slump had on stocks elsewhere around the world. The market in London, for instance, finished its session in positive territory after some initial bearishness subsided. Strength in the dollar also helped deflect the shock waves from the Tokyo Stock Exchange, the world's biggest equities market. The main index of the Tokyo market plunged by 1,569.10 points, a decline that was second in size only to the drop in October 1987. Gene Seagle, vice president and director of technical research at Gruntal Financial Inc., said the U.S. market's ability to cope with the Tokyo drop without losing its composure relieved anxieties that world markets had become too intimately linked. He said Japanese money managers apparently were buying U.S. securities today after bailing out of their domestic market.

DOC.HEAD: Earnings Fall 34 Percent in 4th Quarter; $15 Million Charge For Back Pay
DOC.TEXT: Fashion retailer Nordstrom Inc. said Monday its fourth quarter earnings dropped 34 percent from a year earlier because of higher merchandise markdowns and a $15 million provision for estimated back pay claims. Separately, the Nordstrom workers union leader called the back wage provision inadequate and said the union planned to file a class-action lawsuit against the clothing store chain. Nordstrom acknowledged the threat of that suit and said it believed it also may face a class-action shareholder suit. For the three-month period ended Jan. 31, Nordstrom's profits fell to $31.4 million or 39 cents a share, from $47.5 million or 58 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenue rose 12 percent to $857.5 million in the quarter from $765.1 million. In addition to the charge for back wage payments, Nordstrom attributed the drop in fourth-quarter net income to higher merchandise markdowns. Industry analysts have said the company had to respond to aggressive price-cutting by its competitors during the Christmas season. For the year, Nordstrom's profit fell 7 percent to $114.9 million, or $1.41 a share, from $123.3 million, or $1.51 a share, in the previous year. Sales totaled $2.7 billion, up nearly 15 percent from $2.3 billion in the previous year. Nordstrom, which has built a reputation for good customer service, has been accused of allegedly pressuring employees to sometimes perform work without compensation. Following a labor union complaint, the Washington state Department of Labor and Industry ruled earlier this month that Nordstrom had a pattern of making sales clerks work during off-hours without compensation and ordered the company to pay them for two years' worth of uncompensated hours. Nordstrom said Monday it had responded to the ruling by adopting additional record-keeping procedures to ensure employee work properly was recorded and paid. It also said it had instituted a claims procedure for reimbursing back pay. The $15 million reserve for back wage claims represented the company's present estimate of claims for Washington state, said spokesman John Goesling. Joe Peterson, president of United Food & Commercial Workers Union Local 1001, said the back wage fund is ``wholly inadequate. It won't even cover claims of employees in Washington state, let alone claims in Alaska, Utah, Oregon, California and Virginia.'' Nordstrom has 60 stores in Washington, Oregon, California, Alaska, Virginia and Utah. It plans 16 more, including moving into Illinois, New Jersey, Maryland, Minnesota, Indiana, Connecticut, Massachusetts and New York. Peterson said the union estimates Nordstrom could be liable for up to $40 million in claims in Washington and for more than $200 million in back pay and penalties in California. The union has not yet studied possible claims in the other states, he said. Peterson also said the claims procedure was an attempt by the company to bargain directly with workers instead of the union over claims. Last week, the National Labor Relations Board complained that Nordstrom had been improperly bargaining directly with employees over back wages, rather than going through the union. Peterson said the UFCW could file its lawsuit this week, unless the company showed a willingness to negotiate a settlement with the union. Nordstrom said it expects a class-action lawsuit to be filed on behalf of certain shareholders. Such a suit, if filed, would allege the company should have disclosed that unpaid work and overtime claims by employees adversely would affect the price of Nordstrom stock, the company said. Nordstrom stock has fallen from a Sept. 1 high of $41.75 a share to $29.25 a share at Monday's close.

DOC.HEAD: Shareholders Sue Heart Valve Maker
With AM-Heart Valve
DOC.TEXT: Pfizer Inc. shareholders filed a lawsuit Monday accusing company executives of withholding information about the financial impact of defects in a mechanical heart valve made by its Shiley Inc. unit. Pfizer stock has been battered in recent days because of potential liabilities from defects in a heart valve product that was removed from the market after reports of malfunctions that killed patients. The class-action lawsuit, filed in U.S. District Court in Manhattan, was brought on behalf of shareholders who purchased Pfizer stock between March 27, 1988, and last Thursday, when a House subcommittee announced it would hold hearings on the heart valve. The shareholders said the price of Pfizer stock tumbled after the announcement of the hearing by the House Energy and Commerce investigations subcommittee, which began Monday. They also claimed that Pfizer, without telling shareholders, had settled numerous cases involving Shiley heart valves out of court, many for $1 million or more. ``None of the information publicly disseminated by Pfizer during the class period gave any indication of the true nature or extent of the problems experienced by the company with its Shiley heart valve,'' said the lawsuit. The lawsuit names Pfizer Chief Executive Edmund T. Pratt Jr. and six other executives. The shareholders are seeking unspecified damages for alleged losses. ``There is no merit to the suit and we will vigorously defend it,'' Pfizer spokesman Rick Honey said. Pfizer, is headquartered in Manhattan and incorporated in Delaware. Pfizer stock, which has dropped about $14 in recent weeks in apparent anticipation of the congressional hearings, lost another 25 cents Monday, closing at $56 on the New York Stock Exchange. The so-called 60-degree Shiley valve has been implanted in 85,000 people, including about 40,000 in the United States. The FDA approved the valve for U.S. marketing in April 1979, but after reports of malfunctions and product withdrawals, Shiley removed it from the market in November 1986. The valve consists of a disc inside a metal ring covered by a teflon sewing ring that is sutured to the heart to hold the valve in place. The disc, pivoting on two thin metal struts, opens to either a 60-degree or 70-degree angle to allow blood to flow through, and then closes. About 4,000 of Shiley's 70-degree valves have been implanted in patients overseas. That device was never marketed in the United States. Shiley has reported to the Food and Drug Administration a total of 295 fractures of the 60-degree valve, with 178 deaths resulting, and 94 fractures and 70 deaths involving the 70-degree valve, according to a report by the House subcommittee. At the hearing Monday, Rep. John Dingell, D-Mich., chairman of the investigations subcommittee, said there has been ``no assurance that the (FDA) procedures that allowed the heart valve to stay on the market so long have been corrected.'' The Democratci majority on the panel issued a report stating that Shiley exploited the FDA's honor system by failing to notify the agency of product changes and reports of malfunctions.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Up, Gold Lower
Precede LONDON BC
DOC.TEXT: The dollar climbed broadly Monday in foreign exchange trading, reaching its highest levels in eight months against the Japanese yen despite reported efforts by monetary authorities in Japan and the United States to curb its advance. Gold prices fell. Republic National Bank in New York quoted a bid for gold at $408.50 a troy ounce as of 4 p.m. EST, down $7 from Friday's late bid. Another sharp decline in the Tokyo stock market overnight helped the dollar because the decline reduced chances that Japanese authorities would raise interest rates there, analysts said. ``They can't raise interest rates because that would send their stock and real estate markets into a tailspin,'' said Jerry Rothman, a currency broker for Elders Futures Inc. He said the Bank of Japan and the Federal Reserve Board each intervened in the currency markets during the trading day in an effort to curb the dollar's rise and stop the yen's fall. But Rothman and other dealers said the dollar sales by the central banks failed to drive the dollar lower. ``This is the highest dollar level against the yen since last June,'' Rothman said. ``But there is little they can do about it short of raising interest rates.'' Karen Gibbs, a senior vice president in financial futures at Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. in Chicago, said the dollar also benefited from its traditional role as a safe haven because of the financial uncertainty in Japan. In Tokyo, the dollar rose to a closing 148.65 Japanese yen from 146.47 yen at Friday's close. Later, in London, it rose to 148.80 yen. In New York, the dollar rose to 148.63 yen from 147.07 yen. The dollar gained ground against the British pound. In London, the pound fell to $1.6927 from $1.7090 late Friday. In New York, the pound fell to $1.6903 from $1.7092. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late rates Friday, included: 1.6882 West German marks, up from 1.6785; 1.4860 Swiss francs, up from 1.4740; 5.7140 French francs, up from 5.6825; 1,248.50 Italian lire, up from 1,241.50, and 1.19405 Canadian dollars, down from 1.19825. Late rates in Europe, compared with late rates Friday, included: 1.6903 West German marks, up from 1.6779; 1.4865 Swiss francs, up from 1.4770; 5.7205 French francs, up from 5.6715; 1.9023 Dutch guilders, up from 1.8890; 1,250.25 Italian lire, up from 1,240.75, and 1.1975 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1965. On New York's Commodity Exchange, gold for curent delivery dropped $6.30 an ounce to $408.70. Earlier, gold fell to $411.75 a troy ounce in London from $416.50 late Friday. In Zurich, gold fell to a closing bid of $411.25 an ounce from $415.50 late Friday. In Hong Kong, gold lost $2.47 an ounce to close at $412.15. Silver bullion fell in London to a late bid of $5.23 a troy ounce, down from $5.27 late Friday. In New York, silver for current delivery fell 9.1 cents an ounce to $5.147 on the Commodity Exchange.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with closing prices throughout.
DOC.HEAD: Wall Street Takes Tokyo Tumble in Stride
With AM-Markets Rdp Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The stock market kept its composure in the wake of a nasty tumble on Tokyo's exchange and managed a convincing advance Monday. Buyers focused their attention on blue-chip stocks and a late rally propelled the Dow Jones average of 30 industrials sharply higher. The key indicator finished with a gain of 38.29 at 2,602.48, snapping a string of five straight declines. Advancing issues outnumbered declining ones by about 9 to 7 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 822 up, 639 down and 492 unchanged. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to a moderate 148.91 million shares, only slightly above the 148.49 million traded in Friday's session. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 179.43 million shares. Despite uneasiness about the selloff in Tokyo, investors refrained from dumping stocks in the United States. Traders took comfort from the limited impact the Tokyo slump had on stocks elsewhere around the world. The market in London, for instance, finished its session in positive territory after initial bearishness subsided. Strength in the dollar also helped deflect the shock waves from the Tokyo Stock Exchange, the world's biggest equities market. The exchange's main index, the 225-share Nikkei Stock Average, plunged 1,569.10 points, or 4.5 percent, closing at 33,321.87, its lowest level since 33,309.71 last July 5. It was the largest point drop since the loss of 3,836.48 on Oct. 20, 1987. Gene Seagle, vice president and director of technical research at Gruntal Financial Inc., said the U.S. market's ability to cope with the Tokyo drop without losing its composure relieved anxieties that world markets had become too intimately linked. There also was a perception that Tokyo's troubles were unique and unrelated to the U.S. market. In another positive influence on the U.S. market, Japanese money managers apparently bought U.S. securities after bailing out of their domestic market. Florida Progress topped the Big Board's list of actively traded issues and closed down [ at 37}. Texas Utilities, the second most heavily traded stock, gained { to 35[. Pfizer fell \ to 56 and ranked third on the actives' list. It also slid Friday amid worries about product-liability problems related to defective heart valves formerly made by one of its units. A Congressional subcommittee began hearings on the valves and criticized the company and the Food and Drug Administration for their handling of the situation. Among the active blue chips, IBM jumped 1] to 104, AT&T added 1 to 39[, Philip Morris rose \ to 37}, General Electric went up } to 61\, General Motors advanced 1[ to 44{ and Sears rose { to 40{. One point-plus loser among the actively trading issues was Homestake, off 1} at 19|. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market rose $28.65 billion, or 0.91 percent, in value. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks went up 1.91 to 181.26. Standard & Poor's industrial index rose 5.36 to 378.51, and S&P's 500-stock composite index gained 4.52 at 328.67. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market rose 1.43 to 420.95. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index closed at 350.36, off 0.74.

DOC.HEAD: Wall Street Avoids Tokyo Market's Plunge; Strong Bonds, Dollar Credited
DOC.TEXT: Wall Street shrugged off the latest bad news from Japan, and the U.S. stock market closed higher Monday despite the Tokyo market's second-worst drop ever. Markets in London and Frankfurt also showed strength following the latest plunge in Tokyo, where stock prices have been on a sustained decline from record highs reached in late 1989. On Monday, the Dow Jones average of 30 industrial stocks rose 38.29 points to 2,602.48. Broader market indicators also rose, with advancing issues outnumbered decliners by about 9 to 7 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks. Earlier, the key index on the Tokyo Stock Exchange, the 225-share Nikkei Stock Average, finished down 1,569.10 points, at 33,321.87. That loss was second only to the 3,836.48-point drop on Oct. 20, 1987, after Wall Street's Black Monday, and gave the index a total loss of more than 14 percent since the year began. But analysts said higher bond prices and the strength of the dollar in foreign exchange contributed to the resiliency of the U.S. market. They also said Monday's rise shows the link between Wall Street and Tokyo isn't as strong as once thought. ``I think this is a continuation of what we saw last week,'' said Gordon L. Smith, a managing director at Alex. Brown & Sons Inc., a Baltimore brokerage. ``It looks like we've decoupled the markets at least temporarily.'' Two sharp drops in the Tokyo market last week caused nervousness on Wall Street but no severe selloffs. Prices on other overseas markets generally closed lower Monday in the wake of Tokyo's selloff. However, European markets recovered some of the losses suffered in early trading and Britain's market ended higher. In London, the Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index rose 12.6 points to close at 2,249.3. Dealers said the market was boosted by the strong showing on Wall Street. Share prices on the Frankfurt Stock Exchange closed lower but well above their lows for the day when the market rebounded after an opening plunge. Earlier, in Hong Kong, share prices closed lower in thin trading. A.C. Moore, research director for Argus Research in New York, said the U.S. markets were boosted by increased buying in stock-index futures related to the strong bond market. The benchmark 30-year Treasury bond rose about $5.94 per $1,000 in face amount, while its yield fell to 8.48 percent from 8.55 percent late Friday. Rising bond prices ``tend to induce buying in stock index futures, and when stock index futures go up that makes underlying quality stock go up,'' said Moore. Moore said Wall Street's rally was surprising, but said it may not last. He said the U.S. markets remain troubled by low corporate profits and high interest rates. Jack Conlon Jr., a managing director at Rothschild Inc., said Wall Street's performance Monday demonstrates that ``the factors that are weighing the Japanese market are applicable to the Japanese market in itself.'' Among those, he said, are fear of higher Japanese interest rates due to rising inflation and concern over domestic political uncertainties. He also said Japanese investors have been less of a factor in the U.S. stock markets in recent years. Some observers had feared that with the Tokyo market falling, Japanese investors would pull out of the U.S. markets due to a cash crunch. In Japan, top financial officials said Monday there was nothing wrong with the nation's economic fundamentals despite the market plunge. Bank of Japan Governor Yasushi Mieno said he was watching the market developments with a sense of apprehension, ``but, at the same time, with composure'' because Japan's strong corporate sales and earnings have not softened. Finance Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto told reporters that the plunge in stock prices and the depreciation of the yen against the dollar was due to speculation, not worsening economic conditions. The dollar finished up 2.18 yen at 148.65 yen Monday in Tokyo _ its highest level in eight months. Low trading volume on the Tokyo Stock Exchange and computerized index arbitrage trading, which can involve rapid trading of huge amounts of shares, have been blamed in part for the market's recent volatility. Kyodo News Service said the exchange asked securities firms to limit their index arbitrage selling to the start of the morning and afternoon trading sessions until March 8. Traders involved in index arbitrage attempt to profit from brief discrepancies between the prices of stock-index futures and the prices of the stocks they actually represent.

DOC.HEAD: Precious Metals Plunge as Dollar Rises
DOC.TEXT: Precious metals futures prices plunged Monday on New York's Commodity Exchange on heavy selling in Japan and the dollar's renewed strength. On other markets, energy futures were sharply higher; grains and soybeans were lower; livestock and pork futures declined; and cocoa was sharply lower. Gold prices were pushed lower following heavy selling overnight in Tokyo as after the Tokyo Stock Exchange dropped sharply. The sell-off in Tokyo was the exchange's steepest one-day decline since the October 1987 global crash. ``A lot of gold assets were being liquidated to meet margin calls,'' said Richard Levine, an analyst with Elders Futures Inc in New York. ``The sell-off was particularly pronounced in platinum because that is a traditional precious metal for the Japanese.'' Silver prices did not fall as sharply but approached low levels, Levine said. The dollar's strength made the precious metals less attractive to investors. Analysts said the dollar benefited from nervousness over the declines in Tokyo stock prices last week and expectations that further weakness was likely. Gold settled $6.30 to $7.10 lower with the contract for delivery in April at $411.80 a troy ounce; silver was 9.1 cents to 10.4 cents lower with March at $5.148 a troy ounce. Platinum was $15 to $15.40 lower with April at $511.10 a troy ounce. Energy futures climbed on the New York Mercantile Exchange, with outer months contracts showing the best gains. West Texas Intermediate crude oil was 37 cents to 71 cents higher with April at $21.79 a barrel; heating oil was .75 cent to 1.32 cents higher with March at 59.05 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was .02 cent lower to 1.35 cents higher with March at 59.83 cents a gallon. Grain and soybean futures prices closed mostly lower on the Chicago Board of Trade. March wheat futures prices rose on scattered commission house buying in anticipation deliveries will be small because of low stocks, analysts said. The offer to the Soviet Union on Friday by the U.S. Department of Agriculture of 1 million metric tons of wheat under the export bonus program had little influence on the market because it had been widely rumored, analysts said. The market now is waiting for an actual tender by the Soviet Union for direction. Soybean prices were lower Monday, kept on the defensive by a rash of commission house and professional selling. Rain in South American crop areas also weighed on the soybean market. Wheat was 1\ cents lower to 2\ cents higher with March at $3.96\ a bushel; corn was 2 cents lower to a \ cent higher with March at $2.46 a bushel; oats were a \ cent to 1 cents lower with March at $1.36{ a bushel; soybeans were 1{ cents to 3{ cents lower with March at $5.61} a bushel. Cocoa futures settled sharply lower on New York's Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange, which analysts attributed to a record world supply. Cocoa was $14 to $25 lower with May at $1,019 a ton. Livestock and pork futures were mostly lower on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Live cattle were .28 cent lower to .05 cent higher with April at 75.27 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .37 cent lower to .05 cent higher with March at 79.85 cents a pound; hogs were .30 cent lower to .57 cent higher with April at 49.72 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .05 cent to .98 cent lower with March at 53.27 cents a pound.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Futures Higher
DOC.TEXT: Energy futures prices finished mostly higher in light trading Monday in a market that appeared to be influenced by technical factors, traders said. The April contract for West Texas Intermediate, the key grade of U.S. crude oil, rose 37 cents to $21.79 a 42-gallon barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange. May crude finished 41 cents higher at $21.88 a barrel while June jumped 44 cents to $21.86. Later contracts were even higher. Refined products traded on the New York Merc ended mixed. Unleaded regular gasoline for delivery in March, which fell 0.40 cent to 59.85 cents a gallon Friday, fell an additional 0.02 cent to 59.83 cents. But April rose 0.68 cent to 61.65 cents and May rose 0.78 cent to 66.18 cents a gallon. Later contract months jumped more. No. 2 heating oil for March delivery gained 0.75 cent to 59.05 cents a gallon, after rising 0.15 cent to 58.30 cents a gallon Friday. April heating oil advanced 0.73 cent to 58.00 cents and May settled at 57.18 cents, up 0.88 cent. Jerry Samuels, a vice president in the energy division of Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc., said there was ``very little fundamental news in the market.'' ``Nothing came out concerning supply and demand ... that seemingly would warrant a move in the upside,'' he said. Samuels attributed the rising prices to a variety of technical factors and said the severe cold in the Northeast helped give heating oil a boost. But Robert Baker, a senior energy analyst with Prudential-Bache Securities Inc., said the cold snap was forecast and already had been figured into prices.

DOC.HEAD: Analysts Call for Examination of Government Failure in S&L Crisis
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration should examine why government officials stood by as nation's savings and loans lost billions of dollars, a group of free-market analysts said Monday. S&L legislation passed last August requires the Treasury Department to study the deposit insurance system to determine whether it encouraged S&L executives to take unwise risks. The report, due a year from now, is expected to form the basis of the next attempt by Congress to reform the financial system. But an outline of the study fails to recognize the critical role in the S&L collapse played by elected and appointed officials, said the Shadow Financial Regulatory Committee, a panel of 12 experts from universities, banks and law firms. Officials allowed S&Ls to paper over their weaknesses with accounting gimmicks and postponed closing S&Ls when they failed, worsening the problem and defering it to someone else's watch, the group said in an informal position paper. ``The current system confronts authorities with a painful trade-off between protecting general taxpayers' economic interests and incurring the displeasure of politically strong regulatory clients and their various political allies,'' the committee said. To counter the problem, committee members recommended that members of Congress be required to report all efforts to win favors for constituent firms, that estimated S&L and bank losses be put into regulatory agencies' budgets in the year they occur and that most most of the agencies' discretion in enforcing regulations be removed. On another matter, they criticized the Federal Reserve Board for lending more than $1 billion at below market rates to ailing commercial banks in New England. Such lending, from the Fed's discount window, can serve to keep institutions afloat that should otherwise be closed, allowing uninsured depositors to withdraw their money, the committee said.

DOC.HEAD: Piper Shuts Down Plant for Two Weeks
DOC.TEXT: Financially troubled Piper Aircraft Corp. said Monday it laid off 675 workers indefinitely, or close to 10 percent of its foce, and shut down its plant for two weeks. In addition, 550 employees at the facility will be placed on a four-day, 32-hour work week when the plant reopens March 12. No return date is known for the other 125 workers affected by the shutdown.
