Joe Ponte, director of marketing, said the layoffs are the result of a severe cash crunch and rapid expansion the past several years. But he said the company does not plan to seek protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of the federal bankruptcy law. Piper, which laid off 450 workers last month, will keep about 425 employees on the job during the shutdown to help deal with backlogs in aircraft deliveries, he said. Piper, which manufactures aircraft for general aviation, was purchased by California investor M. Stuart Millar in 1987. Piper President and Chief Executive Officer Ray Johnson said there have been discusions by Piper parent Romeo Charlie Inc. to open an assembly plant at vacant Piper facilities in Lock Haven, Pa. Piper has had trouble competing with the giant Cessna Aircraft Co., controlled by General Dynamics Corp., a defense contractor.

DOC.HEAD: Oklahoma Mortgage Case To Be Vehicle To Settle Old Procedural Issue
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court agreed Monday to use an Oklahoma dispute over mortgage insurance to settle the question of when a court judgment is final, a recurring procedural issue in the federal courts. The justices said they will consider reinstating a suit by FirsTier Mortgage Co. against Investors Mortgage Insurance Co. involving eight mortgage loans on buildings in Elk City, Okla. FirsTier accused Investors of bad faith in failing to pay off insurance claims. U.S. District Judge Luther Bohanon, sitting in Oklahoma City, threw out the suit, announcing from the bench on Jan. 26, 1989 that the insurance policies were void because of fraud. FirsTier then asked the 10th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals to overrule the judge and revive the suit. The appeals court said last September that the judge's oral announcement was not a final decision and therefore the appeals court did not have authority over the case. In appealing to the Supreme Court, FirsTier said the judge's ruling from the bench disposed of all claims in the case and should be considered a final decision. All that remained was for the judge to put the details in writing, and the lack of a written opinion should not make the appeal premature, FirsTier argued. The company said the 10th Circuit court ruling is in conflict with rulings by other federal appeals courts. The case is FirsTier Mortgage vs. Investors Mortgage Insurance, 89-1063.

DOC.HEAD: Leading Candidate to Oversee Thrifts Withdraws from Consideration
DOC.TEXT: A former congressional official who had been the Bush administration's leading candidate to be chief regulator of the nation's savings and loans said Monday he has withdrawn his name from consideration. Frederick D. Wolf, formerly the No. 2 official at the General Accounting Office, said he informed the Treasury Department last week he is no longer interested in being appointed director of the department's Office of Thrift Supervision. Wolf, a partner with the Price Waterhouse & Co. accounting firm, said in a telephone interview that Treasury officials in late December asked him to apply for the job. Subsequently, administration, congressional and industry sources said Wolf was the most likely candidate to succeed M. Danny Wall, who announced his resignation on Dec. 4 but continues to serve. Wolf said he was disturbed that two months after being asked to consider the job, Treasury officials still had not recommended his name to the White House. He said he could only conclude that either the administration did not believe it was important to fill the job soon or did not favor his appointment. In the meantime, Wolf said he was forced to suspend work for several of his firm's clients in order to avoid a potential conflict of interest. The inability of the administration to decide on Wall's replacement, nearly three months after he quit, was taken by analysts as another sign of disarray in the management of the savings and loan bailout. Last month, Daniel Kearney, alluding to differences with the Treasury, resigned as the chief staff officer of the Resolution Trust Corp. Oversight Board. The board sets the policy and controls the pursestrings of the bailout. ``I think this withdrawal is another black eye coming on top of Kearney's resignation,'' said Bert Ely, a financial institutions analyst in Alexandria, Va. ``It is bumbling.'' The failure to fill the post also could bolster the arguments of members of Congress, including House Banking Committee members Reps. Charles Schumer, D-N.Y., and Jim Leach, R-Iowa, who want to abolish the thrift office and divide its duties among commercial bank regulatory agencies. Wall, who had been under fire from Congress for his handling of the collapse of Lincoln Savings and Loan Association, Irvine, Calif., said he would like to leave the post soon. ``I have indicated that is my wish, but there's no date been set at this point,'' he said in a telephone interview. ``I haven't put any deadlines down.'' Wall said Treasury is exploring the appointment of Jonathan Fiechter, currently the office's senior deputy director, as acting director. However, in a letter to President Bush, the U.S. League of Savings Institutions warns that the appointment could leave the institution rudderless. It said its reading of last summer's S&L legislation does not leave its lawyers confident that an acting director, without Senate confirmation, could legally close failed S&Ls, issue rules or exercise the other powers of the director's office. Art Siddon, a spokesman for the Treasury Department, had no comment on the trade group's contention.

DOC.HEAD: Local Investors Agree To Buy MBank
DOC.TEXT: MCorp, the remains of what was once Texas's second-largest bank holding company, said it had agreed to sell its largest bank, 109-year-old MBank-El Paso, to investors headed by the bank's local officers. ``If this sale is successful, the investor group fully intends to pursue local communitywide investment and to insure ownership and operations based at the local level,'' said Henry Ellis, president of MBank-El Paso. Ellis would not name the sale price or the investors, but H.M. Daugherty, Jr., chairman and chief executive officer, said he and Ellis are principal investors. MBank-El Paso was one of five banks MCorp kept after the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. stripped the bank holding company of 20 Texas banking subsidiaries last year after MCorp filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection. Those 20 banks were bought by Banc One Corp., an Ohio banking company, and now operate as Bank One-Texas. The agreement calls for MCorp to receive an undisclosed amount of cash and turn over all the issued and outstanding stock of MBank-El Paso to the investor group. Dallas-based MCorp said specifics of the deal would be set forth in filings with the federal bankruptcy court, which must approve the sale along with bank regulators. The sale is expected to be completed before Sept. 30. MBank-El Paso has assets of $1.1 billion and deposits totaling about $946 million. MBank has been in Chapter 11 bankruptcy proceedings since March 31, 1989. MCorp's federally assisted bailout in 1989 was the third largest in history after Continental Illinois of Chicago in 1984 and FirstRepublic Bank Corp. of Dallas in 1988. MBank-El Paso has 600 employees, including those in its eight branches in the city. Tom Hudgins, MCorp group chairman, said the holding company also is trying to sell its four remaining banks in Waco, New Braunfels, Corpus Christi and Brownsville. MCorp already has agreed to sell MVestment Corp., a trust and investment subsidiary, to Ameritrust Corp. in a deal awaiting federal regulatory approval.

DOC.HEAD: Consumers Less Confident About Future, Survey Shows
DOC.TEXT: U.S. consumers are more positive about current economic conditions but are less confident about the future than they were in January, according to a survey released Monday. The Conference Board's monthly survey on consumer confidence also showed consumers' buying plans mixed. The business research group said its consumer confidence index for February is 105.4, down 1 point from January. Nearly 25 percent of the respondents said current business conditions are good, up from 23 percent in January. In looking ahead to the next six months, however, more consumers than previously said they fear the general business climate will worsen. Respondents also are increasingly apprehensive about job prospects, the Conference Board said. The number of people who expect their incomes to rise in the near future was down three percentage points at 25.6 percent, the survey of 5,000 U.S. households showed. ``Although the overall measure of consumer confidence did not change much in February, the consumer's increasing ambivalence about the immediate future is of some concern,'' said Fabian Linden, executive director of the board's Consumer Research Center. ``It is still difficult to account for the consumer's growing uneasiness, but apprehension about jobs appears to be a major factor.'' Consumers' plans to buy a car, which had improved in the surveys for December and January, were largely unchanged in February at 7.6 percent, the poll showed. Homebuying intentions increased to 3.9 percent from 3.6 percent. Plans to purchase a major appliance declined slightly, however.

DOC.HEAD: K mart to Charge $640 M Against 1989 Earnings
DOC.TEXT: K mart Corp. said Monday it would take a charge of $640 million against 1989 earnings to cover the costs of a $2.3-billion program to modernize the nation's second-largest retail chain. The discount retailer said it plans to close 30 of its 2,194 stores, modernize or expand other stores and open new about 250 new K marts during the five-year program, spokesman Orren Knauer said. The company in November reported a 17.5-percent drop in third quarter profits to $104.1 million. It blamed the decline from the year-earlier quarter on price cuts made to improve the company's market share. Knauer declined to estimate K mart's 1989 earnings. But analysts with Seidler-Amdec Securities Inc. of Los Angeles, Calif., predicted K mart profits would be about $730 million before the charge. In 1988, K mart earned $803 million. ``K mart is taking a far more aggressive approach to modernize their stores than they were planning before,'' said Tom Tashjian, associate director of Seidler-Amdec. ``The Wal-mart and Target chains are clearly better at merchandise presentation than K mart at this time.'' ``K mart is going to get it done quickly to keep a solid market share and keep themselves in a competitive position,'' Tashjian said. But Knauer said K mart's decision, which affects all but three of its U.S. stores, wasn't a reaction to competition. ``We made the decision because of internal factors,'' Knauer said, citing an 18-month pilot project during which several stores were renovated or moved. ``It was based on Christmas sales and the success of stores where we've already made changes. ``In the enlarged, relocated and prototyped stores, customer acceptance of the layouts, fixturing and new merchandise assortments has been very good, and sales results have exceeded expectations,'' he said. The program also includes moving about 280 stores, Knauer said. ``The population base may have shifted. If so, we'll find property closer to the existing population base,'' he said. K mart Chairman Joseph Antonini said in a statement that the store enlargements and relocations should be completed by 1993, and other refurbishments will be done by 1994. Tashjian said K mart's profitability began lagging behind Wal-mart and Target because the latter companies expanded more recently. ``All the companies are about 25 years old, but K mart's expansion was early on in that period,'' Tashjian said. ``The others have expanded during the latter part of the 25 years so they have younger, better-looking stores. Target is much more fun to shop in.'' K mart has 4,171 outlets in the U.S., Puerto Rico and Canada, including 2,288 K mart stores, 1,258 Waldenbooks, 141 Builders Square and 282 Pay Less Drug stores. The Troy-based company also purchased PACE Membership Warehouse Inc. for $322 million late last year. The three stores that won't be affected by the program are newly built outlets in Oak Park, Mich., and Virginia Beach, Va., and a refurbished store in Rochester, Mich.

DOC.HEAD: Conrail Buys Back $1 Billion In Shares
DOC.TEXT: Conrail said it had bought back 22.32 million of its shares _ about one third of its outstanding common stock _ at $49 a share or a total of over $1 billion. Under a previously announced ``dutch auction,'' Conrail invited shareholders to tender their shares at a price between $43 and $53. The cash tender offer expired at midnight Feb. 14. The next day, Conrail announced it would repurchase shares delivered at or below $49. The Philadelphia-based freight railroad said Monday the exact number of shares it was buying was 22.32 million. Conrail said it began paying for the shares Monday. The repurchase is part of a financial restructuring announced last month intended in part to increase Conrail's stock price to help ward off any unwanted takeover attempts. On April 3, a 10 percent limitation on ownership of Conrail's stock will be lifted under the terms of the Conrail Privatization Act of 1986, the law under which the government privatized the company. Conrail stock closed at $1.25 higher Monday at $45.50 on the New York Stock Exchange. The stock closed at $46.125 on Jan.17, the day the restructuring plan was announced.

DOC.HEAD: New President Named for Cox Broadcasting Division
DOC.TEXT: Nicholas D. Trigony has been named president of the broadcasting division of Atlanta-based Cox Enterprises Inc. The 49-year-old Trigony will succeed Stanley G. Mouse, 68, when he retires on Wednesday, Cox Enterprises said in a statement Monday. Trigony is executive vice president for the division, which is responsible for Cox' seven television stations, five AM and seven FM radio stations, as well as TeleRep, a national television sales representation firm. Mouse joined the company in 1945 as an announcement and promotion director at WHIO-AM in Dayton, the first broadcasting property of the company's founder, the late Gov. James M. Cox of Ohio. In 1969, Mouse was elected a corporate vice president of Cox Communications Inc., a public company that later merged with the private Cox Enterprises. He became president of the broadcasting division in 1987. Cox Enterprises also owns newspapers, including The Atlanta Journal and Constitution, and cable television stations.

DOC.HEAD: New Money Delayed for International Monetary Fund
DOC.TEXT: The United States and other leading countries have failed to agree on providing billions of dollars to the International Monetary Fund for lending to the Third World and eastern Europe. The fund said Monday it has put off a decision on new funding until the end of June in yet another setback for the agency. The deadline had been set for March 31 after repeated postponements. That date would have represented a two-year delay over the normal timetable for reviewing fund resources. Decisions normally are taken every five years. Poland has recently won a $730 million loan from the fund and approval is reported to be near on a $213 million loan for Hungary. Though small in comparison with the borrowing needs of eastern Europe, these loans are important in opening the way to lending by others. Governments and commercial banks take confidence from the strict economic measures that the fund requires countries to put in place before it lends money. Resources of the fund amount to the equivalent of $117 billion, but much of that is in currencies of Third World countries and is not in demand by borrowers. Managing Director Michel Camdessus has asked that the total be doubled. Although he had widespread support among the 152 member governments, the United States, Britain and Saudi Arabia demurred. The United States has been reported ready for a 50 percent increase. That would require it to put up nearly $12 billion as the largest source of the fund's money. The outlays would not count in the U.S. budget because the money is considered still the property of the United States, which receives interest on dollars that the fund lends out. The United States itself could borrow other countries' currency, as it has in the past. Japan raised a problem when it asked to be the number two contributor instead of number five. Officials said this issue had been virtually settled, with West Germany as number three, though the relative positions of Britain and France are not yet clear. The officials, who spoke on condition they not be named, said the U.S. Treasury is concerned about overdue payments to the fund from 11 Third World countries, which have reached nearly $4.8 billion. The fund has set up special arrangements for loans to the poorest countries on easier terms, but those which have not brought their accounts up to date are not eligible to not take advantage of the offer. Treasury Undersecretary David C. Mulford has been asked to testify Thursday on the fund before a panel of Congressmen, the subcommittee on international development, finance, trade and monetary policy of the Banking Committee in the House of Representatives.
